BOOK EIGHTH.--CEMETERIES TAKE THAT WHICH IS COMMITTED THEM
CHAPTER I 
모모WHICH TREATS OF THE MANNER OF ENTERING A CONVENT
모모It was into this house that Jean Valjean had, as Fauchelevent expressed it, "fallen from the sky."
모모He had scaled the wall of the garden which formed the angle of the Rue Polonceau.
모모That hymn of the angels which he had heard in the middle of the night, was the nuns chanting matins; that hall, of which he had caught a glimpse in the gloom, was the chapel. That phantom which he had seen stretched on the ground was the sister who was making reparation; that bell, the sound of which had so strangely surprised him, was the gardener's bell attached to the knee of Father Fauchelevent.
모모Cosette once put to bed, Jean Valjean and Fauchelevent had, as we have already seen, supped on a glass of wine and a bit of cheese before a good, crackling fire; then, the only bed in the hut being occupied by Cosette, each threw himself on a truss of straw.
모모Before he shut his eyes, Jean Valjean said:
모모"I must remain here henceforth."
모모This remark trotted through Fauchelevent's head all night long.
모모To tell the truth, neither of them slept.
모모Jean Valjean, feeling that he was discovered and that Javert was on his scent, understood that he and Cosette were lost if they returned to Paris.
모모Then the new storm which had just burst upon him had stranded him in this cloister.
모모Jean Valjean had, henceforth, but one thought,-- to remain there.
모모Now, for an unfortunate man in his position, this convent was both the safest and the most dangerous of places; the most dangerous, because, as no men might enter there, if he were discovered, it was a flagrant offence, and Jean Valjean would find but one step intervening between the convent and prison; the safest, because, if he could manage to get himself accepted there and remain there, who would ever seek him in such a place? To dwell in an impossible place was safety.
모모On his side, Fauchelevent was cudgelling his brains.
모모He began by declaring to himself that he understood nothing of the matter. How had M. Madeleine got there, when the walls were what they were? Cloister walls are not to be stepped over.
모모How did he get there with a child?
모모One cannot scale a perpendicular wall with a child in one's arms.
모모Who was that child?
모모Where did they both come from? Since Fauchelevent had lived in the convent, he had heard nothing of M. sur M., and he knew nothing of what had taken place there. Father Madeleine had an air which discouraged questions; and besides, Fauchelevent said to himself:
모모"One does not question a saint." M. Madeleine had preserved all his prestige in Fauchelevent's eyes. Only, from some words which Jean Valjean had let fall, the gardener thought he could draw the inference that M. Madeleine had probably become bankrupt through the hard times, and that he was pursued by his creditors; or that he had compromised himself in some political affair, and was in hiding; which last did not displease Fauchelevent, who, like many of our peasants of the North, had an old fund of Bonapartism about him. While in hiding, M. Madeleine had selected the convent as a refuge, and it was quite simple that he should wish to remain there. But the inexplicable point, to which Fauchelevent returned constantly and over which he wearied his brain, was that M. Madeleine should be there, and that he should have that little girl with him. Fauchelevent saw them, touched them, spoke to them, and still did not believe it possible.
모모The incomprehensible had just made its entrance into Fauchelevent's hut.
모모Fauchelevent groped about amid conjectures, and could see nothing clearly but this: "M. Madeleine saved my life."
모모This certainty alone was sufficient and decided his course.
모모He said to himself:
모모"It is my turn now." He added in his conscience:
모모"M. Madeleine did not stop to deliberate when it was a question of thrusting himself under the cart for the purpose of dragging me out."
모모He made up his mind to save M. Madeleine.
모모Nevertheless, he put many questions to himself and made himself divers replies:
모모"After what he did for me, would I save him if he were a thief?
모모Just the same.
모모If he were an assassin, would I save him?
모모Just the same.
모모Since he is a saint, shall I save him? Just the same."
모모But what a problem it was to manage to have him remain in the convent! Fauchelevent did not recoil in the face of this almost chimerical undertaking; this poor peasant of Picardy without any other ladder than his self-devotion, his good will, and a little of that old rustic cunning, on this occasion enlisted in the service of a generous enterprise, undertook to scale the difficulties of the cloister, and the steep escarpments of the rule of Saint-Benoit. Father Fauchelevent was an old man who had been an egoist all his life, and who, towards the end of his days, halt, infirm, with no interest left to him in the world, found it sweet to be grateful, and perceiving a generous action to be performed, flung himself upon it like a man, who at the moment when he is dying, should find close to his hand a glass of good wine which he had never tasted, and should swallow it with avidity. We may add, that the air which he had breathed for many years in this convent had destroyed all personality in him, and had ended by rendering a good action of some kind absolutely necessary to him.
모모So he took his resolve:
모모to devote himself to M. Madeleine.
모모We have just called him a poor peasant of Picardy.
모모That description is just, but incomplete.
모모At the point of this story which we have now reached, a little of Father Fauchelevent's physiology becomes useful.
모모He was a peasant, but he had been a notary, which added trickery to his cunning, and penetration to his ingenuousness. Having, through various causes, failed in his business, he had descended to the calling of a carter and a laborer.
모모But, in spite of oaths and lashings, which horses seem to require, something of the notary had lingered in him.
모모He had some natural wit; he talked good grammar; he conversed, which is a rare thing in a village; and the other peasants said of him:
모모"He talks almost like a gentleman with a hat."
모모Fauchelevent belonged, in fact, to that species, which the impertinent and flippant vocabulary of the last century qualified as demi-bourgeois, demi-lout, and which the metaphors showered by the chateau upon the thatched cottage ticketed in the pigeon-hole of the plebeian:
모모rather rustic, rather citified; pepper and salt. Fauchelevent, though sorely tried and harshly used by fate, worn out, a sort of poor, threadbare old soul, was, nevertheless, an impulsive man, and extremely spontaneous in his actions; a precious quality which prevents one from ever being wicked. His defects and his vices, for he had some, were all superficial; in short, his physiognomy was of the kind which succeeds with an observer.
모모His aged face had none of those disagreeable wrinkles at the top of the forehead, which signify malice or stupidity.
모모At daybreak, Father Fauchelevent opened his eyes, after having done an enormous deal of thinking, and beheld M. Madeleine seated on his truss of straw, and watching Cosette's slumbers. Fauchelevent sat up and said:--
모모"Now that you are here, how are you going to contrive to enter?"
모모This remark summed up the situation and aroused Jean Valjean from his revery.
모모The two men took counsel together.
모모"In the first place,"' said Fauchelevent, "you will begin by not setting foot outside of this chamber, either you or the child. One step in the garden and we are done for."
모모"That is true."
모모"Monsieur Madeleine," resumed Fauchelevent, "you have arrived at a very auspicious moment, I mean to say a very inauspicious moment; one of the ladies is very ill.
모모This will prevent them from looking much in our direction.
모모It seems that she is dying.
모모The prayers of the forty hours are being said.
모모The whole community is in confusion. That occupies them.
모모The one who is on the point of departure is a saint.
모모In fact, we are all saints here; all the difference between them and me is that they say `our cell,' and that I say `my cabin.'
모모The prayers for the dying are to be said, and then the prayers for the dead.
모모We shall be at peace here for to-day; but I will not answer for to-morrow."
모모"Still," observed Jean Valjean, "this cottage is in the niche of the wall, it is hidden by a sort of ruin, there are trees, it is not visible from the convent."
모모"And I add that the nuns never come near it."
모모"Well?" said Jean Valjean.
모모The interrogation mark which accentuated this "well" signified: "it seems to me that one may remain concealed here?"
모모It was to this interrogation point that Fauchelevent responded:--
모모"There are the little girls."
모모"What little girls?" asked Jean Valjean.
모모Just as Fauchelevent opened his mouth to explain the words which he had uttered, a bell emitted one stroke.
모모"The nun is dead," said he.
모모"There is the knell."
모모And he made a sign to Jean Valjean to listen.
모모The bell struck a second time.
모모"It is the knell, Monsieur Madeleine.
모모The bell will continue to strike once a minute for twenty-four hours, until the body is taken from the church.--You see, they play.
모모At recreation hours it suffices to have a ball roll aside, to send them all hither, in spite of prohibitions, to hunt and rummage for it all about here. Those cherubs are devils."
모모"Who?" asked Jean Valjean.
모모"The little girls.
모모You would be very quickly discovered. They would shriek:
모모`Oh! a man!'
모모There is no danger to-day. There will be no recreation hour.
모모The day will be entirely devoted to prayers.
모모You hear the bell.
모모As I told you, a stroke each minute. It is the death knell."
모모"I understand, Father Fauchelevent.
모모There are pupils."
모모And Jean Valjean thought to himself:--
모모"Here is Cosette's education already provided."
모모Fauchelevent exclaimed:--
모모"Pardine!
모모There are little girls indeed!
모모And they would bawl around you!
모모And they would rush off!
모모To be a man here is to have the plague.
모모You see how they fasten a bell to my paw as though I were a wild beast."
모모Jean Valjean fell into more and more profound thought.--"This convent would be our salvation," he murmured.
모모Then he raised his voice:--
모모"Yes, the difficulty is to remain here."
모모"No," said Fauchelevent, "the difficulty is to get out."
모모Jean Valjean felt the blood rush back to his heart.
모모"To get out!"
모모"Yes, Monsieur Madeleine.
모모In order to return here it is first necessary to get out."
모모And after waiting until another stroke of the knell had sounded, Fauchelevent went on:--
모모"You must not be found here in this fashion.
모모Whence come you? For me, you fall from heaven, because I know you; but the nuns require one to enter by the door."
모모All at once they heard a rather complicated pealing from another bell.
모모"Ah!" said Fauchelevent, "they are ringing up the vocal mothers. They are going to the chapter.
모모They always hold a chapter when any one dies.
모모She died at daybreak.
모모People generally do die at daybreak. But cannot you get out by the way in which you entered?
모모Come, I do not ask for the sake of questioning you, but how did you get in?"
모모Jean Valjean turned pale; the very thought of descending again into that terrible street made him shudder.
모모You make your way out of a forest filled with tigers, and once out of it, imagine a friendly counsel that shall advise you to return thither! Jean Valjean pictured to himself the whole police force still engaged in swarming in that quarter, agents on the watch, sentinels everywhere, frightful fists extended towards his collar, Javert at the corner of the intersection of the streets perhaps.
모모"Impossible!" said he.
모모"Father Fauchelevent, say that I fell from the sky."
모모"But I believe it, I believe it," retorted Fauchelevent. "You have no need to tell me that.
모모The good God must have taken you in his hand for the purpose of getting a good look at you close to, and then dropped you.
모모Only, he meant to place you in a man's convent; he made a mistake.
모모Come, there goes another peal, that is to order the porter to go and inform the municipality that the dead-doctor is to come here and view a corpse.
모모All that is the ceremony of dying. These good ladies are not at all fond of that visit.
모모A doctor is a man who does not believe in anything.
모모He lifts the veil. Sometimes he lifts something else too.
모모How quickly they have had the doctor summoned this time!
모모What is the matter?
모모Your little one is still asleep.
모모What is her name?"
모모"Cosette."
모모"She is your daughter?
모모You are her grandfather, that is?"
모모"Yes."
모모"It will be easy enough for her to get out of here.
모모I have my service door which opens on the courtyard.
모모I knock.
모모The porter opens; I have my vintage basket on my back, the child is in it, I go out. Father Fauchelevent goes out with his basket--that is perfectly natural. You will tell the child to keep very quiet.
모모She will be under the cover. I will leave her for whatever time is required with a good old friend, a fruit-seller whom I know in the Rue Chemin-Vert, who is deaf, and who has a little bed.
모모I will shout in the fruit-seller's ear, that she is a niece of mine, and that she is to keep her for me until to-morrow. Then the little one will re-enter with you; for I will contrive to have you re-enter. It must be done. But how will you manage to get out?"
모모Jean Valjean shook his head.
모모"No one must see me, the whole point lies there, Father Fauchelevent. Find some means of getting me out in a basket, under cover, like Cosette."
모모Fauchelevent scratched the lobe of his ear with the middle finger of his left hand, a sign of serious embarrassment.
모모A third peal created a diversion.
모모"That is the dead-doctor taking his departure," said Fauchelevent. "He has taken a look and said:
모모`She is dead, that is well.' When the doctor has signed the passport for paradise, the undertaker's company sends a coffin.
모모If it is a mother, the mothers lay her out; if she is a sister, the sisters lay her out.
모모After which, I nail her up.
모모That forms a part of my gardener's duty.
모모A gardener is a bit of a grave-digger. She is placed in a lower hall of the church which communicates with the street, and into which no man may enter save the doctor of the dead.
모모I don't count the undertaker's men and myself as men.
모모It is in that hall that I nail up the coffin. The undertaker's men come and get it, and whip up, coachman! that's the way one goes to heaven.
모모They fetch a box with nothing in it, they take it away again with something in it.
모모That's what a burial is like.
모모De profundis."
모모A horizontal ray of sunshine lightly touched the face of the sleeping Cosette, who lay with her mouth vaguely open, and had the air of an angel drinking in the light.
모모Jean Valjean had fallen to gazing at her.
모모He was no longer listening to Fauchelevent.
모모That one is not listened to is no reason for preserving silence. The good old gardener went on tranquilly with his babble:--
모모"The grave is dug in the Vaugirard cemetery.
모모They declare that they are going to suppress that Vaugirard cemetery.
모모It is an ancient cemetery which is outside the regulations, which has no uniform, and which is going to retire.
모모It is a shame, for it is convenient. I have a friend there, Father Mestienne, the grave-digger. The nuns here possess one privilege, it is to be taken to that cemetery at nightfall.
모모There is a special permission from the Prefecture on their behalf.
모모But how many events have happened since yesterday! Mother Crucifixion is dead, and Father Madeleine--"
모모"Is buried," said Jean Valjean, smiling sadly.
모모Fauchelevent caught the word.
모모"Goodness! if you were here for good, it would be a real burial."
모모A fourth peal burst out.
모모Fauchelevent hastily detached the belled knee-cap from its nail and buckled it on his knee again.
모모"This time it is for me.
모모The Mother Prioress wants me.
모모Good, now I am pricking myself on the tongue of my buckle.
모모Monsieur Madeleine, don't stir from here, and wait for me.
모모Something new has come up. If you are hungry, there is wine, bread and cheese."
모모And he hastened out of the hut, crying:
모모"Coming! coming!"
모모Jean Valjean watched him hurrying across the garden as fast as his crooked leg would permit, casting a sidelong glance by the way on his melon patch.
모모Less than ten minutes later, Father Fauchelevent, whose bell put the nuns in his road to flight, tapped gently at a door, and a gentle voice replied:
모모"Forever!
모모Forever!" that is to say:
모모"Enter."
모모The door was the one leading to the parlor reserved for seeing the gardener on business.
모모This parlor adjoined the chapter hall. The prioress, seated on the only chair in the parlor, was waiting for Fauchelevent.


BOOK EIGHTH.--CEMETERIES TAKE THAT WHICH IS COMMITTED THEM
CHAPTER II 
모모FAUCHELEVENT IN THE PRESENCE OF A DIFFICULTY
모모
It is the peculiarity of certain persons and certain professions, notably priests and nuns, to wear a grave and agitated air on critical occasions.
모모At the moment when Fauchelevent entered, this double form of preoccupation was imprinted on the countenance of the prioress, who was that wise and charming Mademoiselle de Blemeur, Mother Innocente, who was ordinarily cheerful.
모모The gardener made a timid bow, and remained at the door of the cell. The prioress, who was telling her beads, raised her eyes and said:--
모모"Ah! it is you, Father Fauvent."
모모This abbreviation had been adopted in the convent.
모모Fauchelevent bowed again.
모모"Father Fauvent, I have sent for you."
모모"Here I am, reverend Mother."
모모"I have something to say to you."
모모"And so have I," said Fauchelevent with a boldness which caused him inward terror, "I have something to say to the very reverend Mother."
모모The prioress stared at him.
모모"Ah! you have a communication to make to me."
모모"A request."
모모"Very well, speak."
모모Goodman Fauchelevent, the ex-notary, belonged to the category of peasants who have assurance.
모모A certain clever ignorance constitutes a force; you do not distrust it, and you are caught by it. Fauchelevent had been a success during the something more than two years which he had passed in the convent.
모모Always solitary and busied about his gardening, he had nothing else to do than to indulge his curiosity.
모모As he was at a distance from all those veiled women passing to and fro, he saw before him only an agitation of shadows. By dint of attention and sharpness he had succeeded in clothing all those phantoms with flesh, and those corpses were alive for him. He was like a deaf man whose sight grows keener, and like a blind man whose hearing becomes more acute.
모모He had applied himself to riddling out the significance of the different peals, and he had succeeded, so that this taciturn and enigmatical cloister possessed no secrets for him; the sphinx babbled all her secrets in his ear. Fauchelevent knew all and concealed all; that constituted his art. The whole convent thought him stupid.
모모A great merit in religion. The vocal mothers made much of Fauchelevent.
모모He was a curious mute. He inspired confidence.
모모Moreover, he was regular, and never went out except for well-demonstrated requirements of the orchard and vegetable garden.
모모This discretion of conduct had inured to his credit. None the less, he had set two men to chattering:
모모the porter, in the convent, and he knew the singularities of their parlor, and the grave-digger, at the cemetery, and he was acquainted with the peculiarities of their sepulture; in this way, he possessed a double light on the subject of these nuns, one as to their life, the other as to their death.
모모But he did not abuse his knowledge. The congregation thought a great deal of him.
모모Old, lame, blind to everything, probably a little deaf into the bargain,--what qualities! They would have found it difficult to replace him.
모모The goodman, with the assurance of a person who feels that he is appreciated, entered into a rather diffuse and very deep rustic harangue to the reverend prioress.
모모He talked a long time about his age, his infirmities, the surcharge of years counting double for him henceforth, of the increasing demands of his work, of the great size of the garden, of nights which must be passed, like the last, for instance, when he had been obliged to put straw mats over the melon beds, because of the moon, and he wound up as follows: "That he had a brother"--(the prioress made a movement),--"a brother no longer young"--(a second movement on the part of the prioress, but one expressive of reassurance),--"that, if he might be permitted, this brother would come and live with him and help him, that he was an excellent gardener, that the community would receive from him good service, better than his own; that, otherwise, if his brother were not admitted, as he, the elder, felt that his health was broken and that he was insufficient for the work, he should be obliged, greatly to his regret, to go away; and that his brother had a little daughter whom he would bring with him, who might be reared for God in the house, and who might, who knows, become a nun some day."
모모When he had finished speaking, the prioress stayed the slipping of her rosary between her fingers, and said to him:--
모모"Could you procure a stout iron bar between now and this evening?"
모모"For what purpose?"
모모"To serve as a lever."
모모"Yes, reverend Mother," replied Fauchelevent.
모모The prioress, without adding a word, rose and entered the adjoining room, which was the hall of the chapter, and where the vocal mothers were probably assembled.
모모Fauchelevent was left alone.


BOOK EIGHTH.--CEMETERIES TAKE THAT WHICH IS COMMITTED THEM
CHAPTER III 
모모MOTHER INNOCENTE
모모
About a quarter of an hour elapsed.
모모The prioress returned and seated herself once more on her chair.
모모The two interlocutors seemed preoccupied.
모모We will present a stenographic report of the dialogue which then ensued, to the best of our ability.
모모"Father Fauvent!"
모모"Reverend Mother!"
모모"Do you know the chapel?"
모모"I have a little cage there, where I hear the mass and the offices."
모모"And you have been in the choir in pursuance of your duties?"
모모"Two or three times."
모모"There is a stone to be raised."
모모"Heavy?"
모모"The slab of the pavement which is at the side of the altar."
모모"The slab which closes the vault?"
모모"Yes."
모모"It would be a good thing to have two men for it."
모모"Mother Ascension, who is as strong as a man, will help you."
모모"A woman is never a man."
모모"We have only a woman here to help you.
모모Each one does what he can. Because Dom Mabillon gives four hundred and seventeen epistles of Saint Bernard, while Merlonus Horstius only gives three hundred and sixty-seven, I do not despise Merlonus Horstius."
모모"Neither do I."
모모"Merit consists in working according to one's strength.
모모A cloister is not a dock-yard."
모모"And a woman is not a man.
모모But my brother is the strong one, though!"
모모"And can you get a lever?"
모모"That is the only sort of key that fits that sort of door."
모모"There is a ring in the stone."
모모"I will put the lever through it."
모모"And the stone is so arranged that it swings on a pivot."
모모"That is good, reverend Mother.
모모I will open the vault."
모모"And the four Mother Precentors will help you."
모모"And when the vault is open?"
모모"It must be closed again."
모모"Will that be all?"
모모"No."
모모"Give me your orders, very reverend Mother."
모모"Fauvent, we have confidence in you."
모모"I am here to do anything you wish."
모모"And to hold your peace about everything!"
모모"Yes, reverend Mother."
모모"When the vault is open--"
모모"I will close it again."
모모"But before that--"
모모"What, reverend Mother?"
모모"Something must be lowered into it."
모모A silence ensued.
모모The prioress, after a pout of the under lip which resembled hesitation, broke it.
모모"Father Fauvent!"
모모"Reverend Mother!"
모모"You know that a mother died this morning?"
모모"No."
모모"Did you not hear the bell?"
모모"Nothing can be heard at the bottom of the garden."
모모"Really?"
모모"I can hardly distinguish my own signal."
모모"She died at daybreak."
모모"And then, the wind is not blowing in my direction this morning."
모모"It was Mother Crucifixion.
모모A blessed woman."
모모The prioress paused, moved her lips, as though in mental prayer, and resumed:--
모모"Three years ago, Madame de Bethune, a Jansenist, turned orthodox, merely from having seen Mother Crucifixion at prayer."
모모"Ah! yes, now I hear the knell, reverend Mother."
모모"The mothers have taken her to the dead-room, which opens on the church."
모모"I know."
모모"No other man than you can or must enter that chamber.
모모See to that. A fine sight it would be, to see a man enter the dead-room!"
모모"More often!"
모모"Hey?"
모모"More often!"
모모"What do you say?"
모모"I say more often."
모모"More often than what?"
모모"Reverend Mother, I did not say more often than what, I said more often."
모모"I don't understand you.
모모Why do you say more often?"
모모"In order to speak like you, reverend Mother."
모모"But I did not say `more often.'"
모모At that moment, nine o'clock struck.
모모"At nine o'clock in the morning and at all hours, praised and adored be the most Holy Sacrament of the altar," said the prioress.
모모"Amen," said Fauchelevent.
모모The clock struck opportunely.
모모It cut "more often" short. It is probable, that had it not been for this, the prioress and Fauchelevent would never have unravelled that skein.
모모Fauchelevent mopped his forehead.
모모The prioress indulged in another little inward murmur, probably sacred, then raised her voice:--
모모"In her lifetime, Mother Crucifixion made converts; after her death, she will perform miracles."
모모"She will!" replied Father Fauchelevent, falling into step, and striving not to flinch again.
모모"Father Fauvent, the community has been blessed in Mother Crucifixion. No doubt, it is not granted to every one to die, like Cardinal de Berulle, while saying the holy mass, and to breathe forth their souls to God, while pronouncing these words:
모모Hanc igitur oblationem. But without attaining to such happiness, Mother Crucifixion's death was very precious.
모모She retained her consciousness to the very last moment.
모모She spoke to us, then she spoke to the angels. She gave us her last commands.
모모If you had a little more faith, and if you could have been in her cell, she would have cured your leg merely by touching it.
모모She smiled.
모모We felt that she was regaining her life in God.
모모There was something of paradise in that death."
모모Fauchelevent thought that it was an orison which she was finishing.
모모"Amen," said he.
모모"Father Fauvent, what the dead wish must be done."
모모The prioress took off several beads of her chaplet.
모모Fauchelevent held his peace.
모모She went on:--
모모"I have consulted upon this point many ecclesiastics laboring in Our Lord, who occupy themselves in the exercises of the clerical life, and who bear wonderful fruit."
모모"Reverend Mother, you can hear the knell much better here than in the garden."
모모"Besides, she is more than a dead woman, she is a saint."
모모"Like yourself, reverend Mother."
모모"She slept in her coffin for twenty years, by express permission of our Holy Father, Pius VII.--"
모모"The one who crowned the Emp--Buonaparte."
모모For a clever man like Fauchelevent, this allusion was an awkward one. Fortunately, the prioress, completely absorbed in her own thoughts, did not hear it.
모모She continued:--
모모"Father Fauvent?"
모모"Reverend Mother?"
모모"Saint Didorus, Archbishop of Cappadocia, desired that this single word might be inscribed on his tomb:
모모Acarus, which signifies, a worm of the earth; this was done.
모모Is this true?"
모모"Yes, reverend Mother."
모모"The blessed Mezzocane, Abbot of Aquila, wished to be buried beneath the gallows; this was done."
모모"That is true."
모모"Saint Terentius, Bishop of Port, where the mouth of the Tiber empties into the sea, requested that on his tomb might be engraved the sign which was placed on the graves of parricides, in the hope that passers-by would spit on his tomb.
모모This was done. The dead must be obeyed."
모모"So be it."
모모"The body of Bernard Guidonis, born in France near Roche-Abeille, was, as he had ordered, and in spite of the king of Castile, borne to the church of the Dominicans in Limoges, although Bernard Guidonis was Bishop of Tuy in Spain.
모모Can the contrary be affirmed?"
모모"For that matter, no, reverend Mother."
모모"The fact is attested by Plantavit de la Fosse."
모모Several beads of the chaplet were told off, still in silence. The prioress resumed:--
모모"Father Fauvent, Mother Crucifixion will be interred in the coffin in which she has slept for the last twenty years."
모모"That is just."
모모"It is a continuation of her slumber."
모모"So I shall have to nail up that coffin?"
모모"Yes."
모모"And we are to reject the undertaker's coffin?"
모모"Precisely."
모모"I am at the orders of the very reverend community."
모모"The four Mother Precentors will assist you."
모모"In nailing up the coffin?
모모I do not need them."
모모"No. In lowering the coffin."
모모"Where?"
모모"Into the vault."
모모"What vault?"
모모"Under the altar."
모모Fauchelevent started.
모모"The vault under the altar?"
모모"Under the altar."
모모"But--"
모모"You will have an iron bar."
모모"Yes, but--"
모모"You will raise the stone with the bar by means of the ring."
모모"But--"
모모"The dead must be obeyed.
모모To be buried in the vault under the altar of the chapel, not to go to profane earth; to remain there in death where she prayed while living; such was the last wish of Mother Crucifixion.
모모She asked it of us; that is to say, commanded us."
모모"But it is forbidden."
모모"Forbidden by men, enjoined by God."
모모"What if it became known?"
모모"We have confidence in you."
모모"Oh!
모모I am a stone in your walls."
모모"The chapter assembled.
모모The vocal mothers, whom I have just consulted again, and who are now deliberating, have decided that Mother Crucifixion shall be buried, according to her wish, in her own coffin, under our altar.
모모Think, Father Fauvent, if she were to work miracles here!
모모What a glory of God for the community! And miracles issue from tombs."
모모"But, reverend Mother, if the agent of the sanitary commission--"
모모"Saint Benoit II., in the matter of sepulture, resisted Constantine Pogonatus."
모모"But the commissary of police--"
모모"Chonodemaire, one of the seven German kings who entered among the Gauls under the Empire of Constantius, expressly recognized the right of nuns to be buried in religion, that is to say, beneath the altar."
모모"But the inspector from the Prefecture--"
모모"The world is nothing in the presence of the cross.
모모Martin, the eleventh general of the Carthusians, gave to his order this device: Stat crux dum volvitur orbis."
모모"Amen," said Fauchelevent, who imperturbably extricated himself in this manner from the dilemma, whenever he heard Latin.
모모Any audience suffices for a person who has held his peace too long. On the day when the rhetorician Gymnastoras left his prison, bearing in his body many dilemmas and numerous syllogisms which had struck in, he halted in front of the first tree which he came to, harangued it and made very great efforts to convince it.
모모The prioress, who was usually subjected to the barrier of silence, and whose reservoir was overfull, rose and exclaimed with the loquacity of a dam which has broken away:--
모모"I have on my right Benoit and on my left Bernard.
모모Who was Bernard? The first abbot of Clairvaux.
모모Fontaines in Burgundy is a country that is blest because it gave him birth.
모모His father was named Tecelin, and his mother Alethe.
모모He began at Citeaux, to end in Clairvaux; he was ordained abbot by the bishop of Chalon-sur-Saone, Guillaume de Champeaux; he had seven hundred novices, and founded a hundred and sixty monasteries; he overthrew Abeilard at the council of Sens in 1140, and Pierre de Bruys and Henry his disciple, and another sort of erring spirits who were called the Apostolics; he confounded Arnauld de Brescia, darted lightning at the monk Raoul, the murderer of the Jews, dominated the council of Reims in 1148, caused the condemnation of Gilbert de Porea, Bishop of Poitiers, caused the condemnation of Eon de l'Etoile, arranged the disputes of princes, enlightened King Louis the Young, advised Pope Eugene III., regulated the Temple, preached the crusade, performed two hundred and fifty miracles during his lifetime, and as many as thirty-nine in one day.
모모Who was Benoit?
모모He was the patriarch of Mont-Cassin; he was the second founder of the Saintete Claustrale, he was the Basil of the West.
모모His order has produced forty popes, two hundred cardinals, fifty patriarchs, sixteen hundred archbishops, four thousand six hundred bishops, four emperors, twelve empresses, forty-six kings, forty-one queens, three thousand six hundred canonized saints, and has been in existence for fourteen hundred years.
모모On one side Saint Bernard, on the other the agent of the sanitary department! On one side Saint Benoit, on the other the inspector of public ways! The state, the road commissioners, the public undertaker, regulations, the administration, what do we know of all that? There is not a chance passer-by who would not be indignant to see how we are treated.
모모We have not even the right to give our dust to Jesus Christ!
모모Your sanitary department is a revolutionary invention. God subordinated to the commissary of police; such is the age. Silence, Fauvent!"
모모Fauchelevent was but ill at ease under this shower bath. The prioress continued:--
모모"No one doubts the right of the monastery to sepulture.
모모Only fanatics and those in error deny it.
모모We live in times of terrible confusion. We do not know that which it is necessary to know, and we know that which we should ignore.
모모We are ignorant and impious.
모모In this age there exist people who do not distinguish between the very great Saint Bernard and the Saint Bernard denominated of the poor Catholics, a certain good ecclesiastic who lived in the thirteenth century. Others are so blasphemous as to compare the scaffold of Louis XVI. to the cross of Jesus Christ.
모모Louis XVI.
모모was merely a king. Let us beware of God!
모모There is no longer just nor unjust. The name of Voltaire is known, but not the name of Cesar de Bus. Nevertheless, Cesar de Bus is a man of blessed memory, and Voltaire one of unblessed memory.
모모The last arch-bishop, the Cardinal de Perigord, did not even know that Charles de Gondren succeeded to Berulle, and Francois Bourgoin to Gondren, and Jean-Francois Senault to Bourgoin, and Father Sainte-Marthe to Jean-Francois Senault. The name of Father Coton is known, not because he was one of the three who urged the foundation of the Oratorie, but because he furnished Henri IV., the Huguenot king, with the material for an oath. That which pleases people of the world in Saint Francois de Sales, is that he cheated at play.
모모And then, religion is attacked. Why?
모모Because there have been bad priests, because Sagittaire, Bishop of Gap, was the brother of Salone, Bishop of Embrun, and because both of them followed Mommol.
모모What has that to do with the question?
모모Does that prevent Martin de Tours from being a saint, and giving half of his cloak to a beggar?
모모They persecute the saints.
모모They shut their eyes to the truth.
모모Darkness is the rule.
모모The most ferocious beasts are beasts which are blind. No one thinks of hell as a reality.
모모Oh! how wicked people are! By order of the king signifies to-day, by order of the revolution. One no longer knows what is due to the living or to the dead.
모모A holy death is prohibited.
모모Burial is a civil matter.
모모This is horrible. Saint Leo II.
모모wrote two special letters, one to Pierre Notaire, the other to the king of the Visigoths, for the purpose of combating and rejecting, in questions touching the dead, the authority of the exarch and the supremacy of the Emperor.
모모Gauthier, Bishop of Chalons, held his own in this matter against Otho, Duke of Burgundy. The ancient magistracy agreed with him.
모모In former times we had voices in the chapter, even on matters of the day.
모모The Abbot of Citeaux, the general of the order, was councillor by right of birth to the parliament of Burgundy.
모모We do what we please with our dead. Is not the body of Saint Benoit himself in France, in the abbey of Fleury, called Saint Benoit-sur-Loire, although he died in Italy at Mont-Cassin, on Saturday, the 21st of the month of March, of the year 543?
모모All this is incontestable.
모모I abhor psalm-singers, I hate priors, I execrate heretics, but I should detest yet more any one who should maintain the contrary.
모모One has only to read Arnoul Wion, Gabriel Bucelin, Trithemus, Maurolics, and Dom Luc d'Achery."
모모The prioress took breath, then turned to Fauchelevent.
모모"Is it settled, Father Fauvent?"
모모"It is settled, reverend Mother."
모모"We may depend on you?"
모모"I will obey."
모모"That is well."
모모"I am entirely devoted to the convent."
모모"That is understood.
모모You will close the coffin.
모모The sisters will carry it to the chapel.
모모The office for the dead will then be said. Then we shall return to the cloister.
모모Between eleven o'clock and midnight, you will come with your iron bar.
모모All will be done in the most profound secrecy.
모모There will be in the chapel only the four Mother Precentors, Mother Ascension and yourself."
모모"And the sister at the post?"
모모"She will not turn round."
모모"But she will hear."
모모"She will not listen.
모모Besides, what the cloister knows the world learns not."
모모A pause ensued.
모모The prioress went on:--
모모"You will remove your bell.
모모It is not necessary that the sister at the post should perceive your presence."
모모"Reverend Mother?"
모모"What, Father Fauvent?"
모모"Has the doctor for the dead paid his visit?"
모모"He will pay it at four o'clock to-day. The peal which orders the doctor for the dead to be summoned has already been rung. But you do not understand any of the peals?"
모모"I pay no attention to any but my own."
모모"That is well, Father Fauvent."
모모"Reverend Mother, a lever at least six feet long will be required."
모모"Where will you obtain it?"
모모"Where gratings are not lacking, iron bars are not lacking. I have my heap of old iron at the bottom of the garden."
모모"About three-quarters of an hour before midnight; do not forget."
모모"Reverend Mother?"
모모"What?"
모모"If you were ever to have any other jobs of this sort, my brother is the strong man for you.
모모A perfect Turk!"
모모"You will do it as speedily as possible."
모모"I cannot work very fast.
모모I am infirm; that is why I require an assistant.
모모I limp."
모모"To limp is no sin, and perhaps it is a blessing.
모모The Emperor Henry II., who combated Antipope Gregory and re-established Benoit VIII., has two surnames, the Saint and the Lame."
모모"Two surtouts are a good thing," murmured Fauchelevent, who really was a little hard of hearing.
모모"Now that I think of it, Father Fauvent, let us give a whole hour to it.
모모That is not too much.
모모Be near the principal altar, with your iron bar, at eleven o'clock. The office begins at midnight. Everything must have been completed a good quarter of an hour before that."
모모"I will do anything to prove my zeal towards the community. These are my orders.
모모I am to nail up the coffin.
모모At eleven o'clock exactly, I am to be in the chapel.
모모The Mother Precentors will be there.
모모Mother Ascension will be there.
모모Two men would be better.
모모However, never mind!
모모I shall have my lever. We will open the vault, we will lower the coffin, and we will close the vault again.
모모After which, there will be no trace of anything. The government will have no suspicion.
모모Thus all has been arranged, reverend Mother?"
모모"No!"
모모"What else remains?"
모모"The empty coffin remains."
모모This produced a pause.
모모Fauchelevent meditated.
모모The prioress meditated.
모모"What is to be done with that coffin, Father Fauvent?"
모모"It will be given to the earth."
모모"Empty?"
모모Another silence.
모모Fauchelevent made, with his left hand, that sort of a gesture which dismisses a troublesome subject.
모모"Reverend Mother, I am the one who is to nail up the coffin in the basement of the church, and no one can enter there but myself, and I will cover the coffin with the pall."
모모"Yes, but the bearers, when they place it in the hearse and lower it into the grave, will be sure to feel that there is nothing in it."
모모"Ah! the de--!" exclaimed Fauchelevent.
모모The prioress began to make the sign of the cross, and looked fixedly at the gardener.
모모The vil stuck fast in his throat.
모모He made haste to improvise an expedient to make her forget the oath.
모모"I will put earth in the coffin, reverend Mother.
모모That will produce the effect of a corpse."
모모"You are right.
모모Earth, that is the same thing as man.
모모So you will manage the empty coffin?"
모모"I will make that my special business."
모모The prioress's face, up to that moment troubled and clouded, grew serene once more.
모모She made the sign of a superior dismissing an inferior to him.
모모Fauchelevent went towards the door.
모모As he was on the point of passing out, the prioress raised her voice gently:--
모모"I am pleased with you, Father Fauvent; bring your brother to me to-morrow, after the burial, and tell him to fetch his daughter."


BOOK EIGHTH.--CEMETERIES TAKE THAT WHICH IS COMMITTED THEM
CHAPTER IV 
모모IN WHICH JEAN VALJEAN HAS QUITE THE AIR OF HAVING READ AUSTIN CASTILLEJO
모모
The strides of a lame man are like the ogling glances of a one-eyed man; they do not reach their goal very promptly.
모모Moreover, Fauchelevent was in a dilemma.
모모He took nearly a quarter of an hour to return to his cottage in the garden.
모모Cosette had waked up.
모모Jean Valjean had placed her near the fire.
모모At the moment when Fauchelevent entered, Jean Valjean was pointing out to her the vintner's basket on the wall, and saying to her, "Listen attentively to me, my little Cosette. We must go away from this house, but we shall return to it, and we shall be very happy here.
모모The good man who lives here is going to carry you off on his back in that.
모모You will wait for me at a lady's house. I shall come to fetch you.
모모Obey, and say nothing, above all things, unless you want Madame Thenardier to get you again!"
모모Cosette nodded gravely.
모모Jean Valjean turned round at the noise made by Fauchelevent opening the door.
모모"Well?"
모모"Everything is arranged, and nothing is," said Fauchelevent. "I have permission to bring you in; but before bringing you in you must be got out.
모모That's where the difficulty lies.
모모It is easy enough with the child."
모모"You will carry her out?"
모모"And she will hold her tongue?"
모모"I answer for that."
모모"But you, Father Madeleine?"
모모And, after a silence, fraught with anxiety, Fauchelevent exclaimed:--
모모"Why, get out as you came in!"
모모Jean Valjean, as in the first instance, contented himself with saying, "Impossible."
모모Fauchelevent grumbled, more to himself than to Jean Valjean:--
모모"There is another thing which bothers me.
모모I have said that I would put earth in it.
모모When I come to think it over, the earth instead of the corpse will not seem like the real thing, it won't do, it will get displaced, it will move about.
모모The men will bear it. You understand, Father Madeleine, the government will notice it."
모모Jean Valjean stared him straight in the eye and thought that he was raving.
모모Fauchelevent went on:--
모모"How the de--uce are you going to get out?
모모It must all be done by to-morrow morning.
모모It is to-morrow that I am to bring you in. The prioress expects you."
모모Then he explained to Jean Valjean that this was his recompense for a service which he, Fauchelevent, was to render to the community. That it fell among his duties to take part in their burials, that he nailed up the coffins and helped the grave-digger at the cemetery. That the nun who had died that morning had requested to be buried in the coffin which had served her for a bed, and interred in the vault under the altar of the chapel.
모모That the police regulations forbade this, but that she was one of those dead to whom nothing is refused. That the prioress and the vocal mothers intended to fulfil the wish of the deceased.
모모That it was so much the worse for the government. That he, Fauchelevent, was to nail up the coffin in the cell, raise the stone in the chapel, and lower the corpse into the vault. And that, by way of thanks, the prioress was to admit his brother to the house as a gardener, and his niece as a pupil.
모모That his brother was M. Madeleine, and that his niece was Cosette.
모모That the prioress had told him to bring his brother on the following evening, after the counterfeit interment in the cemetery.
모모But that he could not bring M. Madeleine in from the outside if M. Madeleine was not outside. That that was the first problem.
모모And then, that there was another: the empty coffin."
모모"What is that empty coffin?" asked Jean Valjean.
모모Fauchelevent replied:--
모모"The coffin of the administration."
모모"What coffin?
모모What administration?"
모모"A nun dies.
모모The municipal doctor comes and says, `A nun has died.' The government sends a coffin.
모모The next day it sends a hearse and undertaker's men to get the coffin and carry it to the cemetery. The undertaker's men will come and lift the coffin; there will be nothing in it."
모모"Put something in it."
모모"A corpse?
모모I have none."
모모"No."
모모"What then?"
모모"A living person."
모모"What person?"
모모"Me!" said Jean Valjean.
모모Fauchelevent, who was seated, sprang up as though a bomb had burst under his chair.
모모"You!"
모모"Why not?"
모모Jean Valjean gave way to one of those rare smiles which lighted up his face like a flash from heaven in the winter.
모모"You know, Fauchelevent, what you have said:
모모`Mother Crucifixion is dead.'
모모and I add:
모모`and Father Madeleine is buried.'
모모"Ah! good, you can laugh, you are not speaking seriously."
모모"Very seriously, I must get out of this place."
모모"Certainly."
모모"l have told you to find a basket, and a cover for me also,"
모모"Well?"
모모"The basket will be of pine, and the cover a black cloth."
모모"In the first place, it will be a white cloth.
모모Nuns are buried in white."
모모"Let it be a white cloth, then."
모모"You are not like other men, Father Madeleine."
모모To behold such devices, which are nothing else than the savage and daring inventions of the galleys, spring forth from the peaceable things which surrounded him, and mingle with what he called the "petty course of life in the convent," caused Fauchelevent as much amazement as a gull fishing in the gutter of the Rue Saint-Denis would inspire in a passer-by.
모모Jean Valjean went on:--
모모"The problem is to get out of here without being seen.
모모This offers the means.
모모But give me some information, in the first place. How is it managed?
모모Where is this coffin?"
모모"The empty one?"
모모"Yes."
모모"Down stairs, in what is called the dead-room. It stands on two trestles, under the pall."
모모"How long is the coffin?"
모모"Six feet."
모모"What is this dead-room?"
모모"It is a chamber on the ground floor which has a grated window opening on the garden, which is closed on the outside by a shutter, and two doors; one leads into the convent, the other into the church."
모모"What church?"
모모"The church in the street, the church which any one can enter."
모모"Have you the keys to those two doors?"
모모"No; I have the key to the door which communicates with the convent; the porter has the key to the door which communicates with the church."
모모"When does the porter open that door?"
모모"Only to allow the undertaker's men to enter, when they come to get the coffin.
모모When the coffin has been taken out, the door is closed again."
모모"Who nails up the coffin?"
모모"I do."
모모"Who spreads the pall over it?"
모모"I do."
모모"Are you alone?"
모모"Not another man, except the police doctor, can enter the dead-room. That is even written on the wall."
모모"Could you hide me in that room to-night when every one is asleep?"
모모"No. But I could hide you in a small, dark nook which opens on the dead-room, where I keep my tools to use for burials, and of which I have the key."
모모"At what time will the hearse come for the coffin to-morrow?"
모모"About three o'clock in the afternoon.
모모The burial will take place at the Vaugirard cemetery a little before nightfall. It is not very near."
모모"I will remain concealed in your tool-closet all night and all the morning.
모모And how about food?
모모I shall be hungry."
모모"I will bring you something."
모모"You can come and nail me up in the coffin at two o'clock."
모모Fauchelevent recoiled and cracked his finger-joints.
모모"But that is impossible!"
모모"Bah!
모모Impossible to take a hammer and drive some nails in a plank?"
모모What seemed unprecedented to Fauchelevent was, we repeat, a simple matter to Jean Valjean.
모모Jean Valjean had been in worse straits than this.
모모Any man who has been a prisoner understands how to contract himself to fit the diameter of the escape. The prisoner is subject to flight as the sick man is subject to a crisis which saves or kills him.
모모An escape is a cure. What does not a man undergo for the sake of a cure?
모모To have himself nailed up in a case and carried off like a bale of goods, to live for a long time in a box, to find air where there is none, to economize his breath for hours, to know how to stifle without dying-- this was one of Jean Valjean's gloomy talents.
모모Moreover, a coffin containing a living being,--that convict's expedient,-- is also an imperial expedient.
모모If we are to credit the monk Austin Castillejo, this was the means employed by Charles the Fifth, desirous of seeing the Plombes for the last time after his abdication.
모모He had her brought into and carried out of the monastery of Saint-Yuste in this manner.
모모Fauchelevent, who had recovered himself a little, exclaimed:--
모모"But how will you manage to breathe?"
모모"I will breathe."
모모"In that box!
모모The mere thought of it suffocates me."
모모"You surely must have a gimlet, you will make a few holes here and there, around my mouth, and you will nail the top plank on loosely."
모모"Good!
모모And what if you should happen to cough or to sneeze?"
모모"A man who is making his escape does not cough or sneeze."
모모And Jean Valjean added:--
모모"Father Fauchelevent, we must come to a decision:
모모I must either be caught here, or accept this escape through the hearse."
모모Every one has noticed the taste which cats have for pausing and lounging between the two leaves of a half-shut door.
모모Who is there who has not said to a cat, "Do come in!"
모모There are men who, when an incident stands half-open before them, have the same tendency to halt in indecision between two resolutions, at the risk of getting crushed through the abrupt closing of the adventure by fate. The over-prudent, cats as they are, and because they are cats, sometimes incur more danger than the audacious.
모모Fauchelevent was of this hesitating nature.
모모But Jean Valjean's coolness prevailed over him in spite of himself.
모모He grumbled:--
모모"Well, since there is no other means."
모모Jean Valjean resumed:--
모모"The only thing which troubles me is what will take place at the cemetery."
모모"That is the very point that is not troublesome," exclaimed Fauchelevent. "If you are sure of coming out of the coffin all right, I am sure of getting you out of the grave.
모모The grave-digger is a drunkard, and a friend of mine.
모모He is Father Mestienne.
모모An old fellow of the old school.
모모The grave-digger puts the corpses in the grave, and I put the grave-digger in my pocket.
모모I will tell you what will take place.
모모They will arrive a little before dusk, three-quarters of an hour before the gates of the cemetery are closed. The hearse will drive directly up to the grave.
모모I shall follow; that is my business.
모모I shall have a hammer, a chisel, and some pincers in my pocket.
모모The hearse halts, the undertaker's men knot a rope around your coffin and lower you down.
모모The priest says the prayers, makes the sign of the cross, sprinkles the holy water, and takes his departure.
모모I am left alone with Father Mestienne. He is my friend, I tell you.
모모One of two things will happen, he will either be sober, or he will not be sober.
모모If he is not drunk, I shall say to him:
모모`Come and drink a bout while the Bon Coing [the Good Quince] is open.'
모모I carry him off, I get him drunk,-- it does not take long to make Father Mestienne drunk, he always has the beginning of it about him,--I lay him under the table, I take his card, so that I can get into the cemetery again, and I return without him.
모모Then you have no longer any one but me to deal with.
모모If he is drunk, I shall say to him:
모모`Be off; I will do your work for you.'
모모Off he goes, and I drag you out of the hole."
모모Jean Valjean held out his hand, and Fauchelevent precipitated himself upon it with the touching effusion of a peasant.
모모"That is settled, Father Fauchelevent.
모모All will go well."
모모"Provided nothing goes wrong," thought Fauchelevent.
모모"In that case, it would be terrible."


BOOK EIGHTH.--CEMETERIES TAKE THAT WHICH IS COMMITTED THEM
CHAPTER V 
모모IT IS NOT NECESSARY TO BE DRUNK IN ORDER TO BE IMMORTAL
모모
모모On the following day, as the sun was declining, the very rare passers-by on the Boulevard du Maine pulled off their hats to an old-fashioned hearse, ornamented with skulls, cross-bones, and tears. This hearse contained a coffin covered with a white cloth over which spread a large black cross, like a huge corpse with drooping arms. A mourning-coach, in which could be seen a priest in his surplice, and a choir boy in his red cap, followed.
모모Two undertaker's men in gray uniforms trimmed with black walked on the right and the left of the hearse.
모모Behind it came an old man in the garments of a laborer, who limped along.
모모The procession was going in the direction of the Vaugirard cemetery.
모모The handle of a hammer, the blade of a cold chisel, and the antennae of a pair of pincers were visible, protruding from the man's pocket.
모모The Vaugirard cemetery formed an exception among the cemeteries of Paris.
모모It had its peculiar usages, just as it had its carriage entrance and its house door, which old people in the quarter, who clung tenaciously to ancient words, still called the porte cavaliere and the porte pietonne.[16] The Bernardines-Benedictines of the Rue Petit-Picpus had obtained permission, as we have already stated, to be buried there in a corner apart, and at night, the plot of land having formerly belonged to their community.
모모The grave-diggers being thus bound to service in the evening in summer and at night in winter, in this cemetery, they were subjected to a special discipline. The gates of the Paris cemeteries closed, at that epoch, at sundown, and this being a municipal regulation, the Vaugirard cemetery was bound by it like the rest.
모모The carriage gate and the house door were two contiguous grated gates, adjoining a pavilion built by the architect Perronet, and inhabited by the door-keeper of the cemetery.
모모These gates, therefore, swung inexorably on their hinges at the instant when the sun disappeared behind the dome of the Invalides.
모모If any grave-digger were delayed after that moment in the cemetery, there was but one way for him to get out-- his grave-digger's card furnished by the department of public funerals. A sort of letter-box was constructed in the porter's window. The grave-digger dropped his card into this box, the porter heard it fall, pulled the rope, and the small door opened.
모모If the man had not his card, he mentioned his name, the porter, who was sometimes in bed and asleep, rose, came out and identified the man, and opened the gate with his key; the grave-digger stepped out, but had to pay a fine of fifteen francs.
모모
모모[16] Instead of porte cochere and porte batarde.
모모
This cemetery, with its peculiarities outside the regulations, embarrassed the symmetry of the administration.
모모It was suppressed a little later than 1830.
모모The cemetery of Mont-Parnasse, called the Eastern cemetery, succeeded to it, and inherited that famous dram-shop next to the Vaugirard cemetery, which was surmounted by a quince painted on a board, and which formed an angle, one side on the drinkers' tables, and the other on the tombs, with this sign: Au Bon Coing.
모모The Vaugirard cemetery was what may be called a faded cemetery. It was falling into disuse.
모모Dampness was invading it, the flowers were deserting it.
모모The bourgeois did not care much about being buried in the Vaugirard; it hinted at poverty.
모모Pere-Lachaise if you please! to be buried in Pere-Lachaise is equivalent to having furniture of mahogany.
모모It is recognized as elegant.
모모The Vaugirard cemetery was a venerable enclosure, planted like an old-fashioned French garden.
모모Straight alleys, box, thuya-trees, holly, ancient tombs beneath aged cypress-trees, and very tall grass. In the evening it was tragic there.
모모There were very lugubrious lines about it.
모모The sun had not yet set when the hearse with the white pall and the black cross entered the avenue of the Vaugirard cemetery. The lame man who followed it was no other than Fauchelevent.
모모The interment of Mother Crucifixion in the vault under the altar, the exit of Cosette, the introduction of Jean Valjean to the dead-room,-- all had been executed without difficulty, and there had been no hitch.
모모Let us remark in passing, that the burial of Mother Crucifixion under the altar of the convent is a perfectly venial offence in our sight.
모모It is one of the faults which resemble a duty. The nuns had committed it, not only without difficulty, but even with the applause of their own consciences.
모모In the cloister, what is called the "government" is only an intermeddling with authority, an interference which is always questionable.
모모In the first place, the rule; as for the code, we shall see.
모모Make as many laws as you please, men; but keep them for yourselves.
모모The tribute to Caesar is never anything but the remnants of the tribute to God. A prince is nothing in the presence of a principle.
모모Fauchelevent limped along behind the hearse in a very contented frame of mind.
모모His twin plots, the one with the nuns, the one for the convent, the other against it, the other with M. Madeleine, had succeeded, to all appearance.
모모Jean Valjean's composure was one of those powerful tranquillities which are contagious. Fauchelevent no longer felt doubtful as to his success.
모모What remained to be done was a mere nothing.
모모Within the last two years, he had made good Father Mestienne, a chubby-cheeked person, drunk at least ten times.
모모He played with Father Mestienne.
모모He did what he liked with him.
모모He made him dance according to his whim. Mestienne's head adjusted itself to the cap of Fauchelevent's will. Fauchelevent's confidence was perfect.
모모At the moment when the convoy entered the avenue leading to the cemetery, Fauchelevent glanced cheerfully at the hearse, and said half aloud, as he rubbed his big hands:--
모모"Here's a fine farce!"
모모All at once the hearse halted; it had reached the gate.
모모The permission for interment must be exhibited.
모모The undertaker's man addressed himself to the porter of the cemetery.
모모During this colloquy, which always is productive of a delay of from one to two minutes, some one, a stranger, came and placed himself behind the hearse, beside Fauchelevent.
모모He was a sort of laboring man, who wore a waistcoat with large pockets and carried a mattock under his arm.
모모Fauchelevent surveyed this stranger.
모모"Who are you?" he demanded.
모모"The man replied:--
모모"The grave-digger."
모모If a man could survive the blow of a cannon-ball full in the breast, he would make the same face that Fauchelevent made.
모모"The grave-digger?"
모모"Yes."
모모"You?"
모모"I."
모모"Father Mestienne is the grave-digger."
모모"He was."
모모"What!
모모He was?"
모모"He is dead."
모모Fauchelevent had expected anything but this, that a grave-digger could die.
모모It is true, nevertheless, that grave-diggers do die themselves.
모모By dint of excavating graves for other people, one hollows out one's own.
모모Fauchelevent stood there with his mouth wide open.
모모He had hardly the strength to stammer:--
모모"But it is not possible!"
모모"It is so."
모모"But," he persisted feebly, "Father Mestienne is the grave-digger."
모모"After Napoleon, Louis XVIII.
모모After Mestienne, Gribier. Peasant, my name is Gribier."
모모Fauchelevent, who was deadly pale, stared at this Gribier.
모모He was a tall, thin, livid, utterly funereal man.
모모He had the air of an unsuccessful doctor who had turned grave-digger.
모모Fauchelevent burst out laughing.
모모"Ah!" said he, "what queer things do happen!
모모Father Mestienne is dead, but long live little Father Lenoir!
모모Do you know who little Father Lenoir is?
모모He is a jug of red wine.
모모It is a jug of Surene, morbigou! of real Paris Surene?
모모Ah!
모모So old Mestienne is dead! I am sorry for it; he was a jolly fellow.
모모But you are a jolly fellow, too.
모모Are you not, comrade?
모모We'll go and have a drink together presently."
모모The man replied:--
모모"I have been a student.
모모I passed my fourth examination. I never drink."
모모The hearse had set out again, and was rolling up the grand alley of the cemetery.
모모Fauchelevent had slackened his pace.
모모He limped more out of anxiety than from infirmity.
모모The grave-digger walked on in front of him.
모모Fauchelevent passed the unexpected Gribier once more in review.
모모He was one of those men who, though very young, have the air of age, and who, though slender, are extremely strong.
모모"Comrade!" cried Fauchelevent.
모모The man turned round.
모모"I am the convent grave-digger."
모모"My colleague," said the man.
모모Fauchelevent, who was illiterate but very sharp, understood that he had to deal with a formidable species of man, with a fine talker. He muttered:
모모"So Father Mestienne is dead."
모모The man replied:--
모모"Completely.
모모The good God consulted his note-book which shows when the time is up.
모모It was Father Mestienne's turn.
모모Father Mestienne died."
모모Fauchelevent repeated mechanically:
모모"The good God--"
모모"The good God," said the man authoritatively.
모모"According to the philosophers, the Eternal Father; according to the Jacobins, the Supreme Being."
모모"Shall we not make each other's acquaintance?" stammered Fauchelevent.
모모"It is made.
모모You are a peasant, I am a Parisian."
모모"People do not know each other until they have drunk together. He who empties his glass empties his heart.
모모You must come and have a drink with me.
모모Such a thing cannot be refused."
모모"Business first."
모모Fauchelevent thought:
모모"I am lost."
모모They were only a few turns of the wheel distant from the small alley leading to the nuns' corner.
모모The grave-digger resumed:--
모모"Peasant, I have seven small children who must be fed.
모모As they must eat, I cannot drink."
모모And he added, with the satisfaction of a serious man who is turning a phrase well:--
모모"Their hunger is the enemy of my thirst."
모모The hearse skirted a clump of cypress-trees, quitted the grand alley, turned into a narrow one, entered the waste land, and plunged into a thicket.
모모This indicated the immediate proximity of the place of sepulture.
모모Fauchelevent slackened his pace, but he could not detain the hearse.
모모Fortunately, the soil, which was light and wet with the winter rains, clogged the wheels and retarded its speed.
모모He approached the grave-digger.
모모"They have such a nice little Argenteuil wine," murmured Fauchelevent.
모모"Villager," retorted the man, "I ought not be a grave-digger. My father was a porter at the Prytaneum [Town-Hall]. He destined me for literature.
모모But he had reverses.
모모He had losses on 'change. I was obliged to renounce the profession of author.
모모But I am still a public writer."
모모"So you are not a grave-digger, then?" returned Fauchelevent, clutching at this branch, feeble as it was.
모모"The one does not hinder the other.
모모I cumulate."
모모Fauchelevent did not understand this last word.
모모"Come have a drink," said he.
모모Here a remark becomes necessary.
모모Fauchelevent, whatever his anguish, offered a drink, but he did not explain himself on one point; who was to pay?
모모Generally, Fauchelevent offered and Father Mestienne paid. An offer of a drink was the evident result of the novel situation created by the new grave-digger, and it was necessary to make this offer, but the old gardener left the proverbial quarter of an hour named after Rabelais in the dark, and that not unintentionally. As for himself, Fauchelevent did not wish to pay, troubled as he was.
모모The grave-digger went on with a superior smile:--
모모"One must eat.
모모I have accepted Father Mestienne's reversion. One gets to be a philosopher when one has nearly completed his classes.
모모To the labor of the hand I join the labor of the arm. I have my scrivener's stall in the market of the Rue de Sevres. You know? the Umbrella Market.
모모All the cooks of the Red Cross apply to me.
모모I scribble their declarations of love to the raw soldiers. In the morning I write love letters; in the evening I dig graves. Such is life, rustic."
모모The hearse was still advancing.
모모Fauchelevent, uneasy to the last degree, was gazing about him on all sides.
모모Great drops of perspiration trickled down from his brow.
모모"But," continued the grave-digger, "a man cannot serve two mistresses. I must choose between the pen and the mattock.
모모The mattock is ruining my hand."
모모The hearse halted.
모모The choir boy alighted from the mourning-coach, then the priest.
모모One of the small front wheels of the hearse had run up a little on a pile of earth, beyond which an open grave was visible.
모모"What a farce this is!" repeated Fauchelevent in consternation.


BOOK EIGHTH.--CEMETERIES TAKE THAT WHICH IS COMMITTED THEM
CHAPTER VI 
모모BETWEEN FOUR PLANKS
모모Who was in the coffin?
모모The reader knows.
모모Jean Valjean.
모모Jean Valjean had arranged things so that he could exist there, and he could almost breathe.
모모It is a strange thing to what a degree security of conscience confers security of the rest.
모모Every combination thought out by Jean Valjean had been progressing, and progressing favorably, since the preceding day.
모모He, like Fauchelevent, counted on Father Mestienne.
모모He had no doubt as to the end.
모모Never was there a more critical situation, never more complete composure.
모모The four planks of the coffin breathe out a kind of terrible peace. It seemed as though something of the repose of the dead entered into Jean Valjean's tranquillity.
모모From the depths of that coffin he had been able to follow, and he had followed, all the phases of the terrible drama which he was playing with death.
모모Shortly after Fauchelevent had finished nailing on the upper plank, Jean Valjean had felt himself carried out, then driven off.
모모He knew, from the diminution in the jolting, when they left the pavements and reached the earth road.
모모He had divined, from a dull noise, that they were crossing the bridge of Austerlitz.
모모At the first halt, he had understood that they were entering the cemetery; at the second halt, he said to himself:--
모모"Here is the grave."
모모Suddenly, he felt hands seize the coffin, then a harsh grating against the planks; he explained it to himself as the rope which was being fastened round the casket in order to lower it into the cavity.
모모Then he experienced a giddiness.
모모The undertaker's man and the grave-digger had probably allowed the coffin to lose its balance, and had lowered the head before the foot.
모모He recovered himself fully when he felt himself horizontal and motionless.
모모He had just touched the bottom.
모모He had a certain sensation of cold.
모모A voice rose above him, glacial and solemn.
모모He heard Latin words, which he did not understand, pass over him, so slowly that he was able to catch them one by one:--
모모"Qui dormiunt in terrae pulvere, evigilabunt; alii in vitam aeternam, et alii in approbrium, ut videant semper."
모모A child's voice said:--
모모"De profundis."
모모The grave voice began again:--
모모"Requiem aeternam dona ei, Domine."
모모The child's voice responded:--
모모"Et lux perpetua luceat ei."
모모He heard something like the gentle patter of several drops of rain on the plank which covered him.
모모It was probably the holy water.
모모He thought:
모모"This will be over soon now.
모모Patience for a little while longer.
모모The priest will take his departure. Fauchelevent will take Mestienne off to drink.
모모I shall be left. Then Fauchelevent will return alone, and I shall get out. That will be the work of a good hour."
모모The grave voice resumed
모모"Requiescat in pace."
모모And the child's voice said:--
모모"Amen."
모모Jean Valjean strained his ears, and heard something like retreating footsteps.
모모"There, they are going now," thought he.
모모"I am alone."
모모All at once, he heard over his head a sound which seemed to him to be a clap of thunder.
모모It was a shovelful of earth falling on the coffin.
모모A second shovelful fell.
모모One of the holes through which he breathed had just been stopped up.
모모A third shovelful of earth fell.
모모Then a fourth.
모모There are things which are too strong for the strongest man. Jean Valjean lost consciousness.


BOOK EIGHTH.--CEMETERIES TAKE THAT WHICH IS COMMITTED THEM
CHAPTER VII 
모모IN WHICH WILL BE FOUND THE ORIGIN OF THE SAYING:
모모DON'T LOSE THE CARD
모모This is what had taken place above the coffin in which lay Jean Valjean.
모모When the hearse had driven off, when the priest and the choir boy had entered the carriage again and taken their departure, Fauchelevent, who had not taken his eyes from the grave-digger, saw the latter bend over and grasp his shovel, which was sticking upright in the heap of dirt.
모모Then Fauchelevent took a supreme resolve.
모모He placed himself between the grave and the grave-digger, crossed his arms and said:--
모모"I am the one to pay!"
모모The grave-digger stared at him in amazement, and replied:--
모모"What's that, peasant?"
모모Fauchelevent repeated:--
모모"I am the one who pays!"
모모"What?"
모모"For the wine."
모모"What wine?"
모모"That Argenteuil wine."
모모"Where is the Argenteuil?"
모모"At the Bon Coing."
모모"Go to the devil!" said the grave-digger.
모모And he flung a shovelful of earth on the coffin.
모모The coffin gave back a hollow sound.
모모Fauchelevent felt himself stagger and on the point of falling headlong into the grave himself. He shouted in a voice in which the strangling sound of the death rattle began to mingle:--
모모"Comrade!
모모Before the Bon Coing is shut!"
모모The grave-digger took some more earth on his shovel. Fauchelevent continued.
모모"I will pay."
모모And he seized the man's arm.
모모"Listen to me, comrade.
모모I am the convent grave-digger, I have come to help you.
모모It is a business which can be performed at night. Let us begin, then, by going for a drink."
모모And as he spoke, and clung to this desperate insistence, this melancholy reflection occurred to him:
모모"And if he drinks, will he get drunk?"
모모"Provincial," said the man, "if you positively insist upon it, I consent.
모모We will drink.
모모After work, never before."
모모And he flourished his shovel briskly.
모모Fauchelevent held him back.
모모"It is Argenteuil wine, at six."
모모"Oh, come," said the grave-digger, "you are a bell-ringer. Ding dong, ding dong, that's all you know how to say.
모모Go hang yourself."
모모And he threw in a second shovelful.
모모Fauchelevent had reached a point where he no longer knew what he was saying.
모모"Come along and drink," he cried, "since it is I who pays the bill."
모모"When we have put the child to bed," said the grave-digger.
모모He flung in a third shovelful.
모모Then he thrust his shovel into the earth and added:--
모모"It's cold to-night, you see, and the corpse would shriek out after us if we were to plant her there without a coverlet."
모모At that moment, as he loaded his shovel, the grave-digger bent over, and the pocket of his waistcoat gaped.
모모Fauchelevent's wild gaze fell mechanically into that pocket, and there it stopped.
모모The sun was not yet hidden behind the horizon; there was still light enough to enable him to distinguish something white at the bottom of that yawning pocket.
모모The sum total of lightning that the eye of a Picard peasant can contain, traversed Fauchelevent's pupils.
모모An idea had just occurred to him.
모모He thrust his hand into the pocket from behind, without the grave-digger, who was wholly absorbed in his shovelful of earth, observing it, and pulled out the white object which lay at the bottom of it.
모모The man sent a fourth shovelful tumbling into the grave.
모모Just as he turned round to get the fifth, Fauchelevent looked calmly at him and said:--
모모"By the way, you new man, have you your card?"
모모The grave-digger paused.
모모"What card?"
모모"The sun is on the point of setting."
모모"That's good, it is going to put on its nightcap."
모모"The gate of the cemetery will close immediately."
모모"Well, what then?"
모모"Have you your card?"
모모"Ah! my card?" said the grave-digger.
모모And he fumbled in his pocket.
모모Having searched one pocket, he proceeded to search the other. He passed on to his fobs, explored the first, returned to the second.
모모"Why, no," said he, "I have not my card.
모모I must have forgotten it."
모모"Fifteen francs fine," said Fauchelevent.
모모The grave-digger turned green.
모모Green is the pallor of livid people.
모모"Ah!
모모Jesus-mon-Dieu-bancroche-a-bas-la-lune!"[17] he exclaimed. "Fifteen francs fine!"
모모
[17] Jesus-my-God-bandy-leg--down with the moon!
모모
"Three pieces of a hundred sous," said Fauchelevent.
모모The grave-digger dropped his shovel.
모모Fauchelevent's turn had come.
모모"Ah, come now, conscript," said Fauchelevent, "none of this despair. There is no question of committing suicide and benefiting the grave. Fifteen francs is fifteen francs, and besides, you may not be able to pay it.
모모I am an old hand, you are a new one.
모모I know all the ropes and the devices.
모모I will give you some friendly advice. One thing is clear, the sun is on the point of setting, it is touching the dome now, the cemetery will be closed in five minutes more."
모모"That is true," replied the man.
모모"Five minutes more and you will not have time to fill the grave, it is as hollow as the devil, this grave, and to reach the gate in season to pass it before it is shut."
모모"That is true."
모모"In that case, a fine of fifteen francs."
모모"Fifteen francs."
모모"But you have time.
모모Where do you live?"
모모"A couple of steps from the barrier, a quarter of an hour from here. No. 87 Rue de Vaugirard."
모모"You have just time to get out by taking to your heels at your best speed."
모모"That is exactly so."
모모"Once outside the gate, you gallop home, you get your card, you return, the cemetery porter admits you.
모모As you have your card, there will be nothing to pay.
모모And you will bury your corpse. I'll watch it for you in the meantime, so that it shall not run away."
모모"I am indebted to you for my life, peasant."
모모"Decamp!" said Fauchelevent.
모모The grave-digger, overwhelmed with gratitude, shook his hand and set off on a run.
모모When the man had disappeared in the thicket, Fauchelevent listened until he heard his footsteps die away in the distance, then he leaned over the grave, and said in a low tone:--
모모"Father Madeleine!"
모모There was no reply.
모모Fauchelevent was seized with a shudder.
모모He tumbled rather than climbed into the grave, flung himself on the head of the coffin and cried:--
모모"Are you there?"
모모Silence in the coffin.
모모Fauchelevent, hardly able to draw his breath for trembling, seized his cold chisel and his hammer, and pried up the coffin lid.
모모Jean Valjean's face appeared in the twilight; it was pale and his eyes were closed.
모모Fauchelevent's hair rose upright on his head, he sprang to his feet, then fell back against the side of the grave, ready to swoon on the coffin.
모모He stared at Jean Valjean.
모모Jean Valjean lay there pallid and motionless.
모모Fauchelevent murmured in a voice as faint as a sigh:--
모모"He is dead!"
모모And, drawing himself up, and folding his arms with such violence that his clenched fists came in contact with his shoulders, he cried:--
모모"And this is the way I save his life!"
모모Then the poor man fell to sobbing.
모모He soliloquized the while, for it is an error to suppose that the soliloquy is unnatural. Powerful emotion often talks aloud.
모모"It is Father Mestienne's fault.
모모Why did that fool die?
모모What need was there for him to give up the ghost at the very moment when no one was expecting it?
모모It is he who has killed M. Madeleine. Father Madeleine!
모모He is in the coffin.
모모It is quite handy. All is over.
모모Now, is there any sense in these things? Ah! my God! he is dead!
모모Well! and his little girl, what am I to do with her?
모모What will the fruit-seller say?
모모The idea of its being possible for a man like that to die like this! When I think how he put himself under that cart!
모모Father Madeleine! Father Madeleine!
모모Pardine!
모모He was suffocated, I said so. He wouldn't believe me.
모모Well!
모모Here's a pretty trick to play! He is dead, that good man, the very best man out of all the good God's good folks!
모모And his little girl!
모모Ah!
모모In the first place, I won't go back there myself.
모모I shall stay here.
모모After having done such a thing as that!
모모What's the use of being two old men, if we are two old fools!
모모But, in the first place, how did he manage to enter the convent?
모모That was the beginning of it all. One should not do such things.
모모Father Madeleine!
모모Father Madeleine! Father Madeleine!
모모Madeleine!
모모Monsieur Madeleine!
모모Monsieur le Maire! He does not hear me.
모모Now get out of this scrape if you can!"
모모And he tore his hair.
모모A grating sound became audible through the trees in the distance. It was the cemetery gate closing.
모모Fauchelevent bent over Jean Valjean, and all at once he bounded back and recoiled so far as the limits of a grave permit.
모모Jean Valjean's eyes were open and gazing at him.
모모To see a corpse is alarming, to behold a resurrection is almost as much so.
모모Fauchelevent became like stone, pale, haggard, overwhelmed by all these excesses of emotion, not knowing whether he had to do with a living man or a dead one, and staring at Jean Valjean, who was gazing at him.
모모"I fell asleep," said Jean Valjean.
모모And he raised himself to a sitting posture.
모모Fauchelevent fell on his knees.
모모"Just, good Virgin!
모모How you frightened me!"
모모Then he sprang to his feet and cried:--
모모"Thanks, Father Madeleine!"
모모Jean Valjean had merely fainted.
모모The fresh air had revived him.
모모Joy is the ebb of terror.
모모Fauchelevent found almost as much difficulty in recovering himself as Jean Valjean had.
모모"So you are not dead!
모모Oh!
모모How wise you are!
모모I called you so much that you came back.
모모When I saw your eyes shut, I said: `Good! there he is, stifled,' I should have gone raving mad, mad enough for a strait jacket.
모모They would have put me in Bicetre. What do you suppose I should have done if you had been dead? And your little girl?
모모There's that fruit-seller,--she would never have understood it!
모모The child is thrust into your arms, and then-- the grandfather is dead!
모모What a story! good saints of paradise, what a tale!
모모Ah! you are alive, that's the best of it!"
모모"I am cold," said Jean Valjean.
모모This remark recalled Fauchelevent thoroughly to reality, and there was pressing need of it.
모모The souls of these two men were troubled even when they had recovered themselves, although they did not realize it, and there was about them something uncanny, which was the sinister bewilderment inspired by the place.
모모"Let us get out of here quickly," exclaimed Fauchelevent.
모모He fumbled in his pocket, and pulled out a gourd with which he had provided himself.
모모"But first, take a drop," said he.
모모The flask finished what the fresh air had begun, Jean Valjean swallowed a mouthful of brandy, and regained full possession of his faculties.
모모He got out of the coffin, and helped Fauchelevent to nail on the lid again.
모모Three minutes later they were out of the grave.
모모Moreover, Fauchelevent was perfectly composed.
모모He took his time. The cemetery was closed.
모모The arrival of the grave-digger Gribier was not to be apprehended.
