모모How quickly they cover all that it is their mission to destroy and to bury, and how promptly they create frightful gulfs!
모모Such was the physiognomy of the salons of those distant and candid times when M. Martainville had more wit than Voltaire.
모모These salons had a literature and politics of their own. They believed in Fievee.
모모M. Agier laid down the law in them. They commentated M. Colnet, the old bookseller and publicist of the Quay Malaquais.
모모Napoleon was to them thoroughly the Corsican Ogre. Later on the introduction into history of M. le Marquis de Bonaparte, Lieutenant-General of the King's armies, was a concession to the spirit of the age.
모모These salons did not long preserve their purity.
모모Beginning with 1818, doctrinarians began to spring up in them, a disturbing shade. Their way was to be Royalists and to excuse themselves for being so. Where the ultras were very proud, the doctrinarians were rather ashamed. They had wit; they had silence; their political dogma was suitably impregnated with arrogance; they should have succeeded. They indulged, and usefully too, in excesses in the matter of white neckties and tightly buttoned coats.
모모The mistake or the misfortune of the doctrinarian party was to create aged youth.
모모They assumed the poses of wise men.
모모They dreamed of engrafting a temperate power on the absolute and excessive principle.
모모They opposed, and sometimes with rare intelligence, conservative liberalism to the liberalism which demolishes.
모모They were heard to say: "Thanks for Royalism!
모모It has rendered more than one service.
모모It has brought back tradition, worship, religion, respect.
모모It is faithful, brave, chivalric, loving, devoted.
모모It has mingled, though with regret, the secular grandeurs of the monarchy with the new grandeurs of the nation.
모모Its mistake is not to understand the Revolution, the Empire, glory, liberty, young ideas, young generations, the age.
모모But this mistake which it makes with regard to us,-- have we not sometimes been guilty of it towards them?
모모The Revolution, whose heirs we are, ought to be intelligent on all points. To attack Royalism is a misconstruction of liberalism.
모모What an error! And what blindness!
모모Revolutionary France is wanting in respect towards historic France, that is to say, towards its mother, that is to say, towards itself.
모모After the 5th of September, the nobility of the monarchy is treated as the nobility of the Empire was treated after the 5th of July.
모모They were unjust to the eagle, we are unjust to the fleur-de-lys. It seems that we must always have something to proscribe!
모모Does it serve any purpose to ungild the crown of Louis XIV., to scrape the coat of arms of Henry IV.? We scoff at M. de Vaublanc for erasing the N's from the bridge of Jena! What was it that he did?
모모What are we doing?
모모Bouvines belongs to us as well as Marengo.
모모The fleurs-de-lys are ours as well as the N's. That is our patrimony.
모모To what purpose shall we diminish it? We must not deny our country in the past any more than in the present. Why not accept the whole of history?
모모Why not love the whole of France?
모모It is thus that doctrinarians criticised and protected Royalism, which was displeased at criticism and furious at protection.
모모The ultras marked the first epoch of Royalism, congregation characterized the second. Skill follows ardor.
모모Let us confine ourselves here to this sketch.
모모In the course of this narrative, the author of this book has encountered in his path this curious moment of contemporary history; he has been forced to cast a passing glance upon it, and to trace once more some of the singular features of this society which is unknown to-day. But he does it rapidly and without any bitter or derisive idea.
모모Souvenirs both respectful and affectionate, for they touch his mother, attach him to this past.
모모Moreover, let us remark, this same petty world had a grandeur of its own. One may smile at it, but one can neither despise nor hate it. It was the France of former days.
모모Marius Pontmercy pursued some studies, as all children do.
모모When he emerged from the hands of Aunt Gillenormand, his grandfather confided him to a worthy professor of the most purely classic innocence. This young soul which was expanding passed from a prude to a vulgar pedant.
모모Marius went through his years of college, then he entered the law school.
모모He was a Royalist, fanatical and severe.
모모He did not love his grandfather much, as the latter's gayety and cynicism repelled him, and his feelings towards his father were gloomy.
모모He was, on the whole, a cold and ardent, noble, generous, proud, religious, enthusiastic lad; dignified to harshness, pure to shyness.


BOOK THIRD.--THE GRANDFATHER AND THE GRANDSON
CHAPTER IV 
모모END OF THE BRIGAND
모모 The conclusion of Marius' classical studies coincided with M. Gillenormand's departure from society.
모모The old man bade farewell to the Faubourg Saint-Germain and to Madame de T.'s salon, and established himself in the Mardis, in his house of the Rue des Filles-du-Calvaire. There he had for servants, in addition to the porter, that chambermaid, Nicolette, who had succeeded to Magnon, and that short-breathed and pursy Basque, who have been mentioned above.
모모In 1827, Marius had just attained his seventeenth year.
모모One evening, on his return home, he saw his grandfather holding a letter in his hand.
모모"Marius," said M. Gillenormand, "you will set out for Vernon to-morrow."
모모"Why?" said Marius.
모모"To see your father."
모모Marius was seized with a trembling fit.
모모He had thought of everything except this--that he should one day be called upon to see his father. Nothing could be more unexpected, more surprising, and, let us admit it, more disagreeable to him.
모모It was forcing estrangement into reconciliation.
모모It was not an affliction, but it was an unpleasant duty.
모모Marius, in addition to his motives of political antipathy, was convinced that his father, the slasher, as M. Gillenormand called him on his amiable days, did not love him; this was evident, since he had abandoned him to others.
모모Feeling that he was not beloved, he did not love.
모모"Nothing is more simple," he said to himself.
모모He was so astounded that he did not question M. Gillenormand. The grandfather resumed:--
모모"It appears that he is ill.
모모He demands your presence."
모모And after a pause, he added:--
모모"Set out to-morrow morning.
모모I think there is a coach which leaves the Cour des Fontaines at six o'clock, and which arrives in the evening. Take it.
모모He says that here is haste."
모모Then he crushed the letter in his hand and thrust it into his pocket. Marius might have set out that very evening and have been with his father on the following morning.
모모A diligence from the Rue du Bouloi took the trip to Rouen by night at that date, and passed through Vernon.
모모Neither Marius nor M.Gillenormand thought of making inquiries about it.
모모The next day, at twilight, Marius reached Vernon.
모모People were just beginning to light their candles.
모모He asked the first person whom be met for "M. Pontmercy's house."
모모For in his own mind, he agreed with the Restoration, and like it, did not recognize his father's claim to the title of either colonel or baron.
모모The house was pointed out to him.
모모He rang; a woman with a little lamp in her hand opened the door.
모모"M. Pontmercy?" said Marius.
모모The woman remained motionless.
모모"Is this his house?" demanded Marius.
모모The woman nodded affirmatively.
모모"Can I speak with him?"
모모The woman shook her head.
모모"But I am his son!" persisted Marius.
모모"He is expecting me."
모모"He no longer expects you," said the woman.
모모Then he perceived that she was weeping.
모모She pointed to the door of a room on the ground-floor; he entered.
모모In that room, which was lighted by a tallow candle standing on the chimney-piece, there were three men, one standing erect, another kneeling, and one lying at full length, on the floor in his shirt.
모모The one on the floor was the colonel.
모모The other two were the doctor, and the priest, who was engaged in prayer.
모모The colonel had been attacked by brain fever three days previously. As he had a foreboding of evil at the very beginning of his illness, he had written to M. Gillenormand to demand his son.
모모The malady had grown worse.
모모On the very evening of Marius' arrival at Vernon, the colonel had had an attack of delirium; he had risen from his bed, in spite of the servant's efforts to prevent him, crying:
모모"My son is not coming!
모모I shall go to meet him!"
모모Then he ran out of his room and fell prostrate on the floor of the antechamber.
모모He had just expired.
모모The doctor had been summoned, and the cure.
모모The doctor had arrived too late.
모모The son had also arrived too late.
모모By the dim light of the candle, a large tear could be distinguished on the pale and prostrate colonel's cheek, where it had trickled from his dead eye.
모모The eye was extinguished, but the tear was not yet dry.
모모That tear was his son's delay.
모모Marius gazed upon that man whom he beheld for the first time, on that venerable and manly face, on those open eyes which saw not, on those white locks, those robust limbs, on which, here and there, brown lines, marking sword-thrusts, and a sort of red stars, which indicated bullet-holes, were visible.
모모He contemplated that gigantic sear which stamped heroism on that countenance upon which God had imprinted goodness.
모모He reflected that this man was his father, and that this man was dead, and a chill ran over him.
모모The sorrow which he felt was the sorrow which he would have felt in the presence of any other man whom he had chanced to behold stretched out in death.
모모Anguish, poignant anguish, was in that chamber.
모모The servant-woman was lamenting in a corner, the cure was praying, and his sobs were audible, the doctor was wiping his eyes; the corpse itself was weeping.
모모The doctor, the priest, and the woman gazed at Marius in the midst of their affliction without uttering a word; he was the stranger there.
모모Marius, who was far too little affected, felt ashamed and embarrassed at his own attitude; he held his hat in his hand; and he dropped it on the floor, in order to produce the impression that grief had deprived him of the strength to hold it.
모모At the same time, he experienced remorse, and he despised himself for behaving in this manner.
모모But was it his fault?
모모He did not love his father?
모모Why should he!
모모The colonel had left nothing.
모모The sale of big furniture barely paid the expenses of his burial.
모모The servant found a scrap of paper, which she handed to Marius. It contained the following, in the colonel's handwriting:--
모모"For my son.--The Emperor made me a Baron on the battle-field of Waterloo.
모모Since the Restoration disputes my right to this title which I purchased with my blood, my son shall take it and bear it. That he will be worthy of it is a matter of course."
모모Below, the colonel had added:
모모"At that same battle of Waterloo, a sergeant saved my life. The man's name was Thenardier.
모모I think that he has recently been keeping a little inn, in a village in the neighborhood of Paris, at Chelles or Montfermeil.
모모If my son meets him, he will do all the good he can to Thenardier."
모모Marius took this paper and preserved it, not out of duty to his father, but because of that vague respect for death which is always imperious in the heart of man.
모모Nothing remained of the colonel.
모모M. Gillenormand had his sword and uniform sold to an old-clothes dealer.
모모The neighbors devastated the garden and pillaged the rare flowers.
모모The other plants turned to nettles and weeds, and died.
모모Marius remained only forty-eight hours at Vernon.
모모After the interment he returned to Paris, and applied himself again to his law studies, with no more thought of his father than if the latter had never lived. In two days the colonel was buried, and in three forgotten.
모모Marius wore crape on his hat.
모모That was all.


BOOK THIRD.--THE GRANDFATHER AND THE GRANDSON
CHAPTER V 
모모 THE UTILITY OF GOING TO MASS, IN ORDER TO BECOME A REVOLUTIONIST
모모 Marius had preserved the religious habits of his childhood. One Sunday, when he went to hear mass at Saint-Sulpice, at that same chapel of the Virgin whither his aunt had led him when a small lad, he placed himself behind a pillar, being more absent-minded and thoughtful than usual on that occasion, and knelt down, without paying any special heed, upon a chair of Utrecht velvet, on the back of which was inscribed this name:
모모Monsieur Mabeuf, warden.
모모Mass had hardly begun when an old man presented himself and said to Marius:--
모모"This is my place, sir."
모모Marius stepped aside promptly, and the old man took possession of his chair.
모모The mass concluded, Marius still stood thoughtfully a few paces distant; the old man approached him again and said:--
모모"I beg your pardon, sir, for having disturbed you a while ago, and for again disturbing you at this moment; you must have thought me intrusive, and I will explain myself."
모모"There is no need of that, Sir," said Marius.
모모"Yes!" went on the old man, "I do not wish you to have a bad opinion of me.
모모You see, I am attached to this place.
모모It seems to me that the mass is better from here.
모모Why?
모모I will tell you. It is from this place, that I have watched a poor, brave father come regularly, every two or three months, for the last ten years, since he had no other opportunity and no other way of seeing his child, because he was prevented by family arrangements. He came at the hour when he knew that his son would be brought to mass.
모모The little one never suspected that his father was there. Perhaps he did not even know that he had a father, poor innocent! The father kept behind a pillar, so that he might not be seen. He gazed at his child and he wept.
모모He adored that little fellow, poor man!
모모I could see that.
모모This spot has become sanctified in my sight, and I have contracted a habit of coming hither to listen to the mass.
모모I prefer it to the stall to which I have a right, in my capacity of warden.
모모I knew that unhappy gentleman a little, too. He had a father-in-law, a wealthy aunt, relatives, I don't know exactly what all, who threatened to disinherit the child if he, the father, saw him.
모모He sacrificed himself in order that his son might be rich and happy some day.
모모He was separated from him because of political opinions.
모모Certainly, I approve of political opinions, but there are people who do not know where to stop. Mon Dieu! a man is not a monster because he was at Waterloo; a father is not separated from his child for such a reason as that. He was one of Bonaparte's colonels.
모모He is dead, I believe.
모모He lived at Vernon, where I have a brother who is a cure, and his name was something like Pontmarie or Montpercy.
모모He had a fine sword-cut, on my honor."
모모"Pontmercy," suggested Marius, turning pale.
모모"Precisely, Pontmercy.
모모Did you know him?"
모모"Sir," said Marius, "he was my father."
모모The old warden clasped his hands and exclaimed:--
모모"Ah! you are the child!
모모Yes, that's true, he must be a man by this time.
모모Well! poor child, you may say that you had a father who loved you dearly!"
모모Marius offered his arm to the old man and conducted him to his lodgings.
모모On the following day, he said to M. Gillenormand:--
모모"I have arranged a hunting-party with some friends.
모모Will you permit me to be absent for three days?"
모모"Four!" replied his grandfather.
모모"Go and amuse yourself."
모모And he said to his daughter in a low tone, and with a wink, "Some love affair!"


BOOK THIRD.--THE GRANDFATHER AND THE GRANDSON
CHAPTER VI 
모모THE CONSEQUENCES OF HAVING MET A WARDEN
모모 Where it was that Marius went will be disclosed a little further on.
모모Marius was absent for three days, then he returned to Paris, went straight to the library of the law-school and asked for the files of the Moniteur.
모모He read the Moniteur, he read all the histories of the Republic and the Empire, the Memorial de Sainte-Helene, all the memoirs, all the newspapers, the bulletins, the proclamations; he devoured everything.
모모The first time that he came across his father's name in the bulletins of the grand army, he had a fever for a week. He went to see the generals under whom Georges Pontmercy had served, among others, Comte H. Church-warden Mabeuf, whom he went to see again, told him about the life at Vernon, the colonel's retreat, his flowers, his solitude.
모모Marius came to a full knowledge of that rare, sweet, and sublime man, that species of lion-lamb who had been his father.
모모In the meanwhile, occupied as he was with this study which absorbed all his moments as well as his thoughts, he hardly saw the Gillenormands at all.
모모He made his appearance at meals; then they searched for him, and he was not to be found.
모모Father Gillenormand smiled.
모모"Bah! bah! He is just of the age for the girls!"
모모Sometimes the old man added: "The deuce!
모모I thought it was only an affair of gallantry, It seems that it is an affair of passion!"
모모It was a passion, in fact.
모모Marius was on the high road to adoring his father.
모모At the same time, his ideas underwent an extraordinary change. The phases of this change were numerous and successive.
모모As this is the history of many minds of our day, we think it will prove useful to follow these phases step by step and to indicate them all.
모모That history upon which he had just cast his eyes appalled him.
모모The first effect was to dazzle him.
모모Up to that time, the Republic, the Empire, had been to him only monstrous words.
모모The Republic, a guillotine in the twilight; the Empire, a sword in the night.
모모He had just taken a look at it, and where he had expected to find only a chaos of shadows, he had beheld, with a sort of unprecedented surprise, mingled with fear and joy, stars sparkling, Mirabeau, Vergniaud, Saint-Just, Robespierre, Camille, Desmoulins, Danton, and a sun arise, Napoleon.
모모He did not know where he stood.
모모He recoiled, blinded by the brilliant lights. Little by little, when his astonishment had passed off, he grew accustomed to this radiance, he contemplated these deeds without dizziness, he examined these personages without terror; the Revolution and the Empire presented themselves luminously, in perspective, before his mind's eye; he beheld each of these groups of events and of men summed up in two tremendous facts: the Republic in the sovereignty of civil right restored to the masses, the Empire in the sovereignty of the French idea imposed on Europe; he beheld the grand figure of the people emerge from the Revolution, and the grand figure of France spring forth from the Empire. He asserted in his conscience, that all this had been good. What his dazzled state neglected in this, his first far too synthetic estimation, we do not think it necessary to point out here. It is the state of a mind on the march that we are recording. Progress is not accomplished in one stage.
모모That stated, once for all, in connection with what precedes as well as with what is to follow, we continue.
모모He then perceived that, up to that moment, he had comprehended his country no more than he had comprehended his father.
모모He had not known either the one or the other, and a sort of voluntary night had obscured his eyes.
모모Now he saw, and on the one hand he admired, while on the other he adored.
모모He was filled with regret and remorse, and he reflected in despair that all he had in his soul could now be said only to the tomb. Oh! if his father had still been in existence, if he had still had him, if God, in his compassion and his goodness, had permitted his father to be still among the living, how he would have run, how he would have precipitated himself, how he would have cried to his father:
모모"Father!
모모Here I am!
모모It is I!
모모I have the same heart as thou!
모모I am thy son!"
모모How he would have embraced that white head, bathed his hair in tears, gazed upon his scar, pressed his hands, adored his garment, kissed his feet!
모모Oh!
모모Why had his father died so early, before his time, before the justice, the love of his son had come to him?
모모Marius had a continual sob in his heart, which said to him every moment:
모모"Alas!"
모모At the same time, he became more truly serious, more truly grave, more sure of his thought and his faith.
모모At each instant, gleams of the true came to complete his reason.
모모An inward growth seemed to be in progress within him.
모모He was conscious of a sort of natural enlargement, which gave him two things that were new to him--his father and his country.
모모As everything opens when one has a key, so he explained to himself that which he had hated, he penetrated that which he had abhorred; henceforth he plainly perceived the providential, divine and human sense of the great things which he had been taught to detest, and of the great men whom he had been instructed to curse.
모모When he reflected on his former opinions, which were but those of yesterday, and which, nevertheless, seemed to him already so very ancient, he grew indignant, yet he smiled.
모모From the rehabilitation of his father, he naturally passed to the rehabilitation of Napoleon.
모모But the latter, we will confess, was not effected without labor.
모모From his infancy, he had been imbued with the judgments of the party of 1814, on Bonaparte.
모모Now, all the prejudices of the Restoration, all its interests, all its instincts tended to disfigure Napoleon. It execrated him even more than it did Robespierre.
모모It had very cleverly turned to sufficiently good account the fatigue of the nation, and the hatred of mothers.
모모Bonaparte had become an almost fabulous monster, and in order to paint him to the imagination of the people, which, as we lately pointed out, resembles the imagination of children, the party of 1814 made him appear under all sorts of terrifying masks in succession, from that which is terrible though it remains grandiose to that which is terrible and becomes grotesque, from Tiberius to the bugaboo.
모모Thus, in speaking of Bonaparte, one was free to sob or to puff up with laughter, provided that hatred lay at the bottom.
모모Marius had never entertained-- about that man, as he was called--any other ideas in his mind. They had combined with the tenacity which existed in his nature. There was in him a headstrong little man who hated Napoleon.
모모On reading history, on studying him, especially in the documents and materials for history, the veil which concealed Napoleon from the eyes of Marius was gradually rent.
모모He caught a glimpse of something immense, and he suspected that he had been deceived up to that moment, on the score of Bonaparte as about all the rest; each day he saw more distinctly; and he set about mounting, slowly, step by step, almost regretfully in the beginning, then with intoxication and as though attracted by an irresistible fascination, first the sombre steps, then the vaguely illuminated steps, at last the luminous and splendid steps of enthusiasm.
모모One night, he was alone in his little chamber near the roof. His candle was burning; he was reading, with his elbows resting on his table close to the open window.
모모All sorts of reveries reached him from space, and mingled with his thoughts.
모모What a spectacle is the night!
모모One hears dull sounds, without knowing whence they proceed; one beholds Jupiter, which is twelve hundred times larger than the earth, glowing like a firebrand, the azure is black, the stars shine; it is formidable.
모모He was perusing the bulletins of the grand army, those heroic strophes penned on the field of battle; there, at intervals, he beheld his father's name, always the name of the Emperor; the whole of that great Empire presented itself to him; he felt a flood swelling and rising within him; it seemed to him at moments that his father passed close to him like a breath, and whispered in his ear; he gradually got into a singular state; he thought that he heard drums, cannon, trumpets, the measured tread of battalions, the dull and distant gallop of the cavalry; from time to time, his eyes were raised heavenward, and gazed upon the colossal constellations as they gleamed in the measureless depths of space, then they fell upon his book once more, and there they beheld other colossal things moving confusedly.
모모His heart contracted within him. He was in a transport, trembling, panting.
모모All at once, without himself knowing what was in him, and what impulse he was obeying, he sprang to his feet, stretched both arms out of the window, gazed intently into the gloom, the silence, the infinite darkness, the eternal immensity, and exclaimed:
모모"Long live the Emperor!"
모모From that moment forth, all was over; the Ogre of Corsica,-- the usurper,--the tyrant,--the monster who was the lover of his own sisters,--the actor who took lessons of Talma,--the poisoner of Jaffa,--the tiger,--Buonaparte,--all this vanished, and gave place in his mind to a vague and brilliant radiance in which shone, at an inaccessible height, the pale marble phantom of Caesar. The Emperor had been for his father only the well-beloved captain whom one admires, for whom one sacrifices one's self; he was something more to Marius.
모모He was the predestined constructor of the French group, succeeding the Roman group in the domination of the universe. He was a prodigious architect, of a destruction, the continuer of Charlemagne, of Louis XI., of Henry IV., of Richelieu, of Louis XIV., and of the Committee of Public Safety, having his spots, no doubt, his faults, his crimes even, being a man, that is to say; but august in his faults, brilliant in his spots, powerful in his crime.
모모He was the predestined man, who had forced all nations to say: "The great nation!"
모모He was better than that, he was the very incarnation of France, conquering Europe by the sword which he grasped, and the world by the light which he shed.
모모Marius saw in Bonaparte the dazzling spectre which will always rise upon the frontier, and which will guard the future.
모모Despot but dictator; a despot resulting from a republic and summing up a revolution. Napoleon became for him the man-people as Jesus Christ is the man-God.
모모It will be perceived, that like all new converts to a religion, his conversion intoxicated him, he hurled himself headlong into adhesion and he went too far.
모모His nature was so constructed; once on the downward slope, it was almost impossible for him to put on the drag.
모모Fanaticism for the sword took possession of him, and complicated in his mind his enthusiasm for the idea. He did not perceive that, along with genius, and pell-mell, he was admitting force, that is to say, that he was installing in two compartments of his idolatry, on the one hand that which is divine, on the other that which is brutal.
모모In many respects, he had set about deceiving himself otherwise.
모모He admitted everything. There is a way of encountering error while on one's way to the truth. He had a violent sort of good faith which took everything in the lump. In the new path which he had entered on, in judging the mistakes of the old regime, as in measuring the glory of Napoleon, he neglected the attenuating circumstances.
모모At all events, a tremendous step had been taken.
모모Where he had formerly beheld the fall of the monarchy, he now saw the advent of France. His orientation had changed.
모모What had been his East became the West. He had turned squarely round.
모모All these revolutions were accomplished within him, without his family obtaining an inkling of the case.
모모When, during this mysterious labor, he had entirely shed his old Bourbon and ultra skin, when he had cast off the aristocrat, the Jacobite and the Royalist, when he had become thoroughly a revolutionist, profoundly democratic and republican, he went to an engraver on the Quai des Orfevres and ordered a hundred cards bearing this name: Le Baron Marius Pontmercy.
모모This was only the strictly logical consequence of the change which had taken place in him, a change in which everything gravitated round his father.
모모Only, as he did not know any one and could not sow his cards with any porter, he put them in his pocket.
모모By another natural consequence, in proportion as he drew nearer to his father, to the latter's memory, and to the things for which the colonel had fought five and twenty years before, he receded from his grandfather.
모모We have long ago said, that M. Gillenormand's temper did not please him.
모모There already existed between them all the dissonances of the grave young man and the frivolous old man. The gayety of Geronte shocks and exasperates the melancholy of Werther.
모모So long as the same political opinions and the same ideas had been common to them both, Marius had met M. Gillenormand there as on a bridge.
모모When the bridge fell, an abyss was formed. And then, over and above all, Marius experienced unutterable impulses to revolt, when he reflected that it was M. Gillenormand who had, from stupid motives, torn him ruthlessly from the colonel, thus depriving the father of the child, and the child of the father.
모모By dint of pity for his father, Marius had nearly arrived at aversion for his grandfather.
모모Nothing of this sort, however, was betrayed on the exterior, as we have already said.
모모Only he grew colder and colder; laconic at meals, and rare in the house.
모모When his aunt scolded him for it, he was very gentle and alleged his studies, his lectures, the examinations, etc., as a pretext.
모모His grandfather never departed from his infallible diagnosis:
모모"In love!
모모I know all about it."
모모From time to time Marius absented himself.
모모"Where is it that he goes off like this?" said his aunt.
모모On one of these trips, which were always very brief, he went to Montfermeil, in order to obey the injunction which his father had left him, and he sought the old sergeant to Waterloo, the inn-keeper Thenardier.
모모Thenardier had failed, the inn was closed, and no one knew what had become of him. Marius was away from the house for four days on this quest.
모모"He is getting decidedly wild," said his grandfather.
모모They thought they had noticed that he wore something on his breast, under his shirt, which was attached to his neck by a black ribbon.


BOOK THIRD.--THE GRANDFATHER AND THE GRANDSON
CHAPTER VII 
모모 We have mentioned a lancer.
모모He was a great-grand-nephew of M. Gillenormand, on the paternal side, who led a garrison life, outside the family and far from the domestic hearth.
모모Lieutenant Theodule Gillenormand fulfilled all the conditions required to make what is called a fine officer. He had "a lady's waist," a victorious manner of trailing his sword and of twirling his mustache in a hook.
모모He visited Paris very rarely, and so rarely that Marius had never seen him. The cousins knew each other only by name.
모모We think we have said that Theodule was the favorite of Aunt Gillenormand, who preferred him because she did not see him.
모모Not seeing people permits one to attribute to them all possible perfections.
모모One morning, Mademoiselle Gillenormand the elder returned to her apartment as much disturbed as her placidity was capable of allowing. Marius had just asked his grandfather's permission to take a little trip, adding that he meant to set out that very evening. "Go!" had been his grandfather's reply, and M. Gillenormand had added in an aside, as he raised his eyebrows to the top of his forehead:
모모"Here he is passing the night out again." Mademoiselle Gillenormand had ascended to her chamber greatly puzzled, and on the staircase had dropped this exclamation:
모모"This is too much!"--and this interrogation:
모모"But where is it that he goes?" She espied some adventure of the heart, more or less illicit, a woman in the shadow, a rendezvous, a mystery, and she would not have been sorry to thrust her spectacles into the affair. Tasting a mystery resembles getting the first flavor of a scandal; sainted souls do not detest this.
모모There is some curiosity about scandal in the secret compartments of bigotry.
모모So she was the prey of a vague appetite for learning a history.
모모In order to get rid of this curiosity which agitated her a little beyond her wont, she took refuge in her talents, and set about scalloping, with one layer of cotton after another, one of those embroideries of the Empire and the Restoration, in which there are numerous cart-wheels. The work was clumsy, the worker cross.
모모She had been seated at this for several hours when the door opened.
모모Mademoiselle Gillenormand raised her nose. Lieutenant Theodule stood before her, making the regulation salute. She uttered a cry of delight.
모모One may be old, one may be a prude, one may be pious, one may be an aunt, but it is always agreeable to see a lancer enter one's chamber.
모모"You here, Theodule!" she exclaimed.
모모"On my way through town, aunt."
모모"Embrace me."
모모"Here goes!" said Theodule.
모모And he kissed her.
모모Aunt Gillenormand went to her writing-desk and opened it.
모모"You will remain with us a week at least?"
모모"I leave this very evening, aunt."
모모"It is not possible!"
모모"Mathematically!"
모모"Remain, my little Theodule, I beseech you."
모모"My heart says `yes,' but my orders say `no.' The matter is simple. They are changing our garrison; we have been at Melun, we are being transferred to Gaillon.
모모It is necessary to pass through Paris in order to get from the old post to the new one.
모모I said:
모모`I am going to see my aunt.'"
모모"Here is something for your trouble."
모모And she put ten louis into his hand.
모모"For my pleasure, you mean to say, my dear aunt."
모모Theodule kissed her again, and she experienced the joy of having some of the skin scratched from her neck by the braidings on his uniform.
모모"Are you making the journey on horseback, with your regiment?" she asked him.
모모"No, aunt.
모모I wanted to see you.
모모I have special permission. My servant is taking my horse; I am travelling by diligence. And, by the way, I want to ask you something."
모모"What is it?"
모모"Is my cousin Marius Pontmercy travelling so, too?"
모모"How do you know that?" said his aunt, suddenly pricked to the quick with a lively curiosity.
모모"On my arrival, I went to the diligence to engage my seat in the coupe."
모모"Well?"
모모"A traveller had already come to engage a seat in the imperial. I saw his name on the card."
모모"What name?"
모모"Marius Pontmercy."
모모"The wicked fellow!" exclaimed his aunt.
모모"Ah! your cousin is not a steady lad like yourself.
모모To think that he is to pass the night in a diligence!"
모모"Just as I am going to do."
모모"But you--it is your duty; in his case, it is wildness."
모모"Bosh!" said Theodule.
모모Here an event occurred to Mademoiselle Gillenormand the elder,-- an idea struck her.
모모If she had been a man, she would have slapped her brow.
모모She apostrophized Theodule:--
모모"Are you aware whether your cousin knows you?"
모모"No. I have seen him; but he has never deigned to notice me."
모모"So you are going to travel together?"
모모"He in the imperial, I in the coupe."
모모"Where does this diligence run?"
모모"To Andelys."
모모"Then that is where Marius is going?"
모모"Unless, like myself, he should stop on the way.
모모I get down at Vernon, in order to take the branch coach for Gaillon.
모모I know nothing of Marius' plan of travel."
모모"Marius! what an ugly name! what possessed them to name him Marius? While you, at least, are called Theodule."
모모"I would rather be called Alfred," said the officer.
모모"Listen, Theodule."
모모"I am listening, aunt."
모모"Pay attention."
모모"I am paying attention."
모모"You understand?"
모모"Yes."
모모"Well, Marius absents himself!"
모모"Eh! eh!"
모모"He travels."
모모"Ah! ah!"
모모"He spends the night out."
모모"Oh! oh!"
모모"We should like to know what there is behind all this."
모모Theodule replied with the composure of a man of bronze:--
모모"Some petticoat or other."
모모And with that inward laugh which denotes certainty, he added:--
모모"A lass."
모모"That is evident," exclaimed his aunt, who thought she heard M. Gillenormand speaking, and who felt her conviction become irresistible at that word fillette, accentuated in almost the very same fashion by the granduncle and the grandnephew.
모모She resumed:--
모모"Do us a favor.
모모Follow Marius a little.
모모He does not know you, it will be easy.
모모Since a lass there is, try to get a sight of her. You must write us the tale.
모모It will amuse his grandfather."
모모Theodule had no excessive taste for this sort of spying; but he was much touched by the ten louis, and he thought he saw a chance for a possible sequel.
모모He accepted the commission and said: "As you please, aunt."
모모And he added in an aside, to himself:
모모"Here I am a duenna."
모모Mademoiselle Gillenormand embraced him.
모모"You are not the man to play such pranks, Theodule.
모모You obey discipline, you are the slave of orders, you are a man of scruples and duty, and you would not quit your family to go and see a creature."
모모The lancer made the pleased grimace of Cartouche when praised for his probity.
모모Marius, on the evening following this dialogue, mounted the diligence without suspecting that he was watched.
모모As for the watcher, the first thing he did was to fall asleep.
모모His slumber was complete and conscientious.
모모Argus snored all night long.
모모At daybreak, the conductor of the diligence shouted:
모모"Vernon! relay of Vernon!
모모Travellers for Vernon!"
모모And Lieutenant Theodule woke.
모모"Good," he growled, still half asleep, "this is where I get out."
모모Then, as his memory cleared by degrees, the effect of waking, he recalled his aunt, the ten louis, and the account which he had undertaken to render of the deeds and proceedings of Marius. This set him to laughing.
모모"Perhaps he is no longer in the coach," he thought, as he rebuttoned the waistcoat of his undress uniform.
모모"He may have stopped at Poissy; he may have stopped at Triel; if he did not get out at Meulan, he may have got out at Mantes, unless he got out at Rolleboise, or if he did not go on as far as Pacy, with the choice of turning to the left at Evreus, or to the right at Laroche-Guyon. Run after him, aunty.
모모What the devil am I to write to that good old soul?"
모모At that moment a pair of black trousers descending from the imperial, made its appearance at the window of the coupe.
모모"Can that be Marius?" said the lieutenant.
모모It was Marius.
모모A little peasant girl, all entangled with the horses and the postilions at the end of the vehicle, was offering flowers to the travellers. "Give your ladies flowers!" she cried.
모모Marius approached her and purchased the finest flowers in her flat basket.
모모"Come now," said Theodule, leaping down from the coupe, "this piques my curiosity.
모모Who the deuce is he going to carry those flowers to? She must be a splendidly handsome woman for so fine a bouquet. I want to see her."
모모And no longer in pursuance of orders, but from personal curiosity, like dogs who hunt on their own account, he set out to follow Marius.
모모Marius paid no attention to Theodule.
모모Elegant women descended from the diligence; he did not glance at them.
모모He seemed to see nothing around him.
모모"He is pretty deeply in love!" thought Theodule.
모모Marius directed his steps towards the church.
모모"Capital," said Theodule to himself.
모모"Rendezvous seasoned with a bit of mass are the best sort.
모모Nothing is so exquisite as an ogle which passes over the good God's head."
모모On arriving at the church, Marius did not enter it, but skirted the apse.
모모He disappeared behind one of the angles of the apse.
모모"The rendezvous is appointed outside," said Theodule.
모모"Let's have a look at the lass."
모모And he advanced on the tips of his boots towards the corner which Marius had turned.
모모On arriving there, he halted in amazement.
모모Marius, with his forehead clasped in his hands, was kneeling upon the grass on a grave.
모모He had strewn his bouquet there.
모모At the extremity of the grave, on a little swelling which marked the head, there stood a cross of black wood with this name in white letters: COLONEL BARON PONTMERCY.
모모Marius' sobs were audible.
모모The "lass" was a grave.


BOOK THIRD.--THE GRANDFATHER AND THE GRANDSON
CHAPTER VIII 
모모MARBLE AGAINST GRANITE
모모 It was hither that Marius had come on the first occasion of his absenting himself from Paris.
모모It was hither that he had come every time that M. Gillenormand had said:
모모"He is sleeping out."
모모Lieutenant Theodule was absolutely put out of countenance by this unexpected encounter with a sepulchre; he experienced a singular and disagreeable sensation which he was incapable of analyzing, and which was composed of respect for the tomb, mingled with respect for the colonel.
모모He retreated, leaving Marius alone in the cemetery, and there was discipline in this retreat.
모모Death appeared to him with large epaulets, and he almost made the military salute to him. Not knowing what to write to his aunt, he decided not to write at all; and it is probable that nothing would have resulted from the discovery made by Theodule as to the love affairs of Marius, if, by one of those mysterious arrangements which are so frequent in chance, the scene at Vernon had not had an almost immediate counter-shock at Paris.
모모Marius returned from Vernon on the third day, in the middle of the morning, descended at his grandfather's door, and, wearied by the two nights spent in the diligence, and feeling the need of repairing his loss of sleep by an hour at the swimming-school, he mounted rapidly to his chamber, took merely time enough to throw off his travelling-coat, and the black ribbon which he wore round his neck, and went off to the bath.
모모M.Gillenormand, who had risen betimes like all old men in good health, had heard his entrance, and had made haste to climb, as quickly as his old legs permitted, the stairs to the upper story where Marius lived, in order to embrace him, and to question him while so doing, and to find out where he had been.
모모But the youth had taken less time to descend than the old man had to ascend, and when Father Gillenormand entered the attic, Marius was no longer there.
모모The bed had not been disturbed, and on the bed lay, outspread, but not defiantly the great-coat and the black ribbon.
모모"I like this better," said M. Gillenormand.
모모And a moment later, he made his entrance into the salon, where Mademoiselle Gillenormand was already seated, busily embroidering her cart-wheels.
모모The entrance was a triumphant one.
모모M. Gillenormand held in one hand the great-coat, and in the other the neck-ribbon, and exclaimed:--
모모"Victory!
모모We are about to penetrate the mystery!
모모We are going to learn the most minute details; we are going to lay our finger on the debaucheries of our sly friend!
모모Here we have the romance itself. I have the portrait!"
모모In fact, a case of black shagreen, resembling a medallion portrait, was suspended from the ribbon.
모모The old man took this case and gazed at it for some time without opening it, with that air of enjoyment, rapture, and wrath, with which a poor hungry fellow beholds an admirable dinner which is not for him, pass under his very nose.
모모"For this evidently is a portrait.
모모I know all about such things. That is worn tenderly on the heart.
모모How stupid they are! Some abominable fright that will make us shudder, probably!
모모Young men have such bad taste nowadays!"
모모"Let us see, father," said the old spinster.
모모The case opened by the pressure of a spring.
모모They found in it nothing but a carefully folded paper.
모모"From the same to the same," said M. Gillenormand, bursting with laughter.
모모"I know what it is.
모모A billet-doux."
모모"Ah! let us read it!" said the aunt.
모모And she put on her spectacles.
모모They unfolded the paper and read as follows:--
모모"For my son.--The Emperor made me a Baron on the battlefield of Waterloo.
모모Since the Restoration disputes my right to this title which I purchased with my blood, my son shall take it and bear it. That he will be worthy of it is a matter of course."
모모The feelings of father and daughter cannot be described.
모모They felt chilled as by the breath of a death's-head. They did not exchange a word.
모모Only, M. Gillenormand said in a low voice and as though speaking to himself:--
모모"It is the slasher's handwriting."
모모The aunt examined the paper, turned it about in all directions, then put it back in its case.
모모At the same moment a little oblong packet, enveloped in blue paper, fell from one of the pockets of the great-coat. Mademoiselle Gillenormand picked it up and unfolded the blue paper.
모모It contained Marius' hundred cards.
모모She handed one of them to M. Gillenormand, who read:
모모Le Baron Marius Pontmercy.
모모The old man rang the bell.
모모Nicolette came.
모모M. Gillenormand took the ribbon, the case, and the coat, flung them all on the floor in the middle of the room, and said:--
모모"Carry those duds away."
모모A full hour passed in the most profound silence.
모모The old man and the old spinster had seated themselves with their backs to each other, and were thinking, each on his own account, the same things, in all probability.
모모At the expiration of this hour, Aunt Gillenormand said:--"A pretty state of things!"
모모A few moments later, Marius made his appearance.
모모He entered. Even before he had crossed the threshold, he saw his grandfather holding one of his own cards in his hand, and on catching sight of him, the latter exclaimed with his air of bourgeois and grinning superiority which was something crushing:--
모모"Well! well! well! well! well! so you are a baron now.
모모I present you my compliments.
모모What is the meaning of this?"
모모Marius reddened slightly and replied:--
모모"It means that I am the son of my father."
모모M. Gillenormand ceased to laugh, and said harshly:--
모모"I am your father."
모모"My father," retorted Marius, with downcast eyes and a severe air, "was a humble and heroic man, who served the Republic and France gloriously, who was great in the greatest history that men have ever made, who lived in the bivouac for a quarter of a century, beneath grape-shot and bullets, in snow and mud by day, beneath rain at night, who captured two flags, who received twenty wounds, who died forgotten and abandoned, and who never committed but one mistake, which was to love too fondly two ingrates, his country and myself."
모모This was more than M. Gillenormand could bear to hear.
모모At the word republic, he rose, or, to speak more correctly, he sprang to his feet.
모모Every word that Marius had just uttered produced on the visage of the old Royalist the effect of the puffs of air from a forge upon a blazing brand.
모모From a dull hue he had turned red, from red, purple, and from purple, flame-colored.
모모"Marius!" he cried.
모모"Abominable child!
모모I do not know what your father was!
모모I do not wish to know!
모모I know nothing about that, and I do not know him!
모모But what I do know is, that there never was anything but scoundrels among those men!
모모They were all rascals, assassins, red-caps, thieves!
모모I say all!
모모I say all! I know not one!
모모I say all!
모모Do you hear me, Marius!
모모See here, you are no more a baron than my slipper is!
모모They were all bandits in the service of Robespierre!
모모All who served B-u-o-naparte were brigands!
모모They were all traitors who betrayed, betrayed, betrayed their legitimate king!
모모All cowards who fled before the Prussians and the English at Waterloo!
모모That is what I do know! Whether Monsieur your father comes in that category, I do not know! I am sorry for it, so much the worse, your humble servant!"
모모In his turn, it was Marius who was the firebrand and M. Gillenormand who was the bellows.
모모Marius quivered in every limb, he did not know what would happen next, his brain was on fire.
모모He was the priest who beholds all his sacred wafers cast to the winds, the fakir who beholds a passer-by spit upon his idol.
모모It could not be that such things had been uttered in his presence. What was he to do?
모모His father had just been trampled under foot and stamped upon in his presence, but by whom?
모모By his grandfather. How was he to avenge the one without outraging the other? It was impossible for him to insult his grandfather and it was equally impossible for him to leave his father unavenged. On the one hand was a sacred grave, on the other hoary locks.
모모He stood there for several moments, staggering as though intoxicated, with all this whirlwind dashing through his head; then he raised his eyes, gazed fixedly at his grandfather, and cried in a voice of thunder:--
모모"Down with the Bourbons, and that great hog of a Louis XVIII.!"
모모Louis XVIII.
모모had been dead for four years; but it was all the same to him.
모모The old man, who had been crimson, turned whiter than his hair. He wheeled round towards a bust of M. le Duc de Berry, which stood on the chimney-piece, and made a profound bow, with a sort of peculiar majesty.
모모Then he paced twice, slowly and in silence, from the fireplace to the window and from the window to the fireplace, traversing the whole length of the room, and making the polished floor creak as though he had been a stone statue walking.
모모On his second turn, he bent over his daughter, who was watching this encounter with the stupefied air of an antiquated lamb, and said to her with a smile that was almost calm:
모모"A baron like this gentleman, and a bourgeois like myself cannot remain under the same roof."
모모And drawing himself up, all at once, pallid, trembling, terrible, with his brow rendered more lofty by the terrible radiance of wrath, he extended his arm towards Marius and shouted to him:--
모모"Be off!"
모모Marius left the house.
모모On the following day, M. Gillenormand said to his daughter:
모모"You will send sixty pistoles every six months to that blood-drinker, and you will never mention his name to me."
모모Having an immense reserve fund of wrath to get rid of, and not knowing what to do with it, he continued to address his daughter as you instead of thou for the next three months.
모모Marius, on his side, had gone forth in indignation.
모모There was one circumstance which, it must be admitted, aggravated his exasperation. There are always petty fatalities of the sort which complicate domestic dramas.
모모They augment the grievances in such cases, although, in reality, the wrongs are not increased by them. While carrying Marius' "duds" precipitately to his chamber, at his grandfather's command, Nicolette had, inadvertently, let fall, probably, on the attic staircase, which was dark, that medallion of black shagreen which contained the paper penned by the colonel. Neither paper nor case could afterwards be found.
모모Marius was convinced that "Monsieur Gillenormand"--from that day forth he never alluded to him otherwise--had flung "his father's testament" in the fire.
모모He knew by heart the few lines which the colonel had written, and, consequently, nothing was lost.
모모But the paper, the writing, that sacred relic,--all that was his very heart. What had been done with it?
모모Marius had taken his departure without saying whither he was going, and without knowing where, with thirty francs, his watch, and a few clothes in a hand-bag. He had entered a hackney-coach, had engaged it by the hour, and had directed his course at hap-hazard towards the Latin quarter.
모모What was to become of Marius? 


BOOK FOURTH.--THE FRIENDS OF THE A B C
CHAPTER I 
모모A GROUP WHICH BARELY MISSED BECOMING HISTORIC 
모모At that epoch, which was, to all appearances indifferent, a certain revolutionary quiver was vaguely current.
모모Breaths which had started forth from the depths of '89 and '93 were in the air.
모모Youth was on the point, may the reader pardon us the word, of moulting. People were undergoing a transformation, almost without being conscious of it, through the movement of the age.
모모The needle which moves round the compass also moves in souls.
모모Each person was taking that step in advance which he was bound to take. The Royalists were becoming liberals, liberals were turning democrats. It was a flood tide complicated with a thousand ebb movements; the peculiarity of ebbs is to create intermixtures; hence the combination of very singular ideas; people adored both Napoleon and liberty. We are making history here.
모모These were the mirages of that period. Opinions traverse phases.
모모Voltairian royalism, a quaint variety, had a no less singular sequel, Bonapartist liberalism.
모모Other groups of minds were more serious.
모모In that direction, they sounded principles, they attached themselves to the right. They grew enthusiastic for the absolute, they caught glimpses of infinite realizations; the absolute, by its very rigidity, urges spirits towards the sky and causes them to float in illimitable space. There is nothing like dogma for bringing forth dreams.
모모And there is nothing like dreams for engendering the future.
모모Utopia to-day, flesh and blood to-morrow.
모모These advanced opinions had a double foundation.
모모A beginning of mystery menaced "the established order of things," which was suspicious and underhand.
모모A sign which was revolutionary to the highest degree.
모모The second thoughts of power meet the second thoughts of the populace in the mine.
모모The incubation of insurrections gives the retort to the premeditation of coups d'etat.
모모There did not, as yet, exist in France any of those vast underlying organizations, like the German tugendbund and Italian Carbonarism; but here and there there were dark underminings, which were in process of throwing off shoots.
모모The Cougourde was being outlined at Aix; there existed at Paris, among other affiliations of that nature, the society of the Friends of the A B C.
모모What were these Friends of the A B C?
모모A society which had for its object apparently the education of children, in reality the elevation of man.
모모They declared themselves the Friends of the A B C,--the Abaisse,-- the debased,--that is to say, the people.
모모They wished to elevate the people.
모모It was a pun which we should do wrong to smile at. Puns are sometimes serious factors in politics; witness the Castratus ad castra, which made a general of the army of Narses; witness: Barbari et Barberini; witness:
모모Tu es Petrus et super hanc petram, etc., etc.
모모The Friends of the A B C were not numerous, it was a secret society in the state of embryo, we might almost say a coterie, if coteries ended in heroes.
모모They assembled in Paris in two localities, near the fish-market, in a wine-shop called Corinthe, of which more will be heard later on, and near the Pantheon in a little cafe in the Rue Saint-Michel called the Cafe Musain, now torn down; the first of these meeting-places was close to the workingman, the second to the students.
모모The assemblies of the Friends of the A B C were usually held in a back room of the Cafe Musain.
모모This hall, which was tolerably remote from the cafe, with which it was connected by an extremely long corridor, had two windows and an exit with a private stairway on the little Rue des Gres.
모모There they smoked and drank, and gambled and laughed.
모모There they conversed in very loud tones about everything, and in whispers of other things. An old map of France under the Republic was nailed to the wall,-- a sign quite sufficient to excite the suspicion of a police agent.
모모The greater part of the Friends of the A B C were students, who were on cordial terms with the working classes.
모모Here are the names of the principal ones.
모모They belong, in a certain measure, to history:
모모Enjolras, Combeferre, Jean Prouvaire, Feuilly, Courfeyrac, Bahorel, Lesgle or Laigle, Joly, Grantaire.
모모These young men formed a sort of family, through the bond of friendship.
모모All, with the exception of Laigle, were from the South.
모모This was a remarkable group.
모모It vanished in the invisible depths which lie behind us.
모모At the point of this drama which we have now reached, it will not perhaps be superfluous to throw a ray of light upon these youthful heads, before the reader beholds them plunging into the shadow of a tragic adventure.
모모Enjolras, whose name we have mentioned first of all,--the reader shall see why later on,--was an only son and wealthy.
모모Enjolras was a charming young man, who was capable of being terrible. He was angelically handsome.
모모He was a savage Antinous.
모모One would have said, to see the pensive thoughtfulness of his glance, that he had already, in some previous state of existence, traversed the revolutionary apocalypse.
모모He possessed the tradition of it as though he had been a witness.
모모He was acquainted with all the minute details of the great affair.
모모A pontifical and warlike nature, a singular thing in a youth.
모모He was an officiating priest and a man of war; from the immediate point of view, a soldier of the democracy; above the contemporary movement, the priest of the ideal.
모모His eyes were deep, his lids a little red, his lower lip was thick and easily became disdainful, his brow was lofty.
모모A great deal of brow in a face is like a great deal of horizon in a view.
모모Like certain young men at the beginning of this century and the end of the last, who became illustrious at an early age, he was endowed with excessive youth, and was as rosy as a young girl, although subject to hours of pallor. Already a man, he still seemed a child.
모모His two and twenty years appeared to be but seventeen; he was serious, it did not seem as though he were aware there was on earth a thing called woman. He had but one passion--the right; but one thought--to overthrow the obstacle.
모모On Mount Aventine, he would have been Gracchus; in the Convention, he would have been Saint-Just. He hardly saw the roses, he ignored spring, he did not hear the carolling of the birds; the bare throat of Evadne would have moved him no more than it would have moved Aristogeiton; he, like Harmodius, thought flowers good for nothing except to conceal the sword. He was severe in his enjoyments.
모모He chastely dropped his eyes before everything which was not the Republic.
모모He was the marble lover of liberty.
모모His speech was harshly inspired, and had the thrill of a hymn.
모모He was subject to unexpected outbursts of soul. Woe to the love-affair which should have risked itself beside him! If any grisette of the Place Cambrai or the Rue Saint-Jean-de-Beauvais, seeing that face of a youth escaped from college, that page's mien, those long, golden lashes, those blue eyes, that hair billowing in the wind, those rosy cheeks, those fresh lips, those exquisite teeth, had conceived an appetite for that complete aurora, and had tried her beauty on Enjolras, an astounding and terrible glance would have promptly shown her the abyss, and would have taught her not to confound the mighty cherub of Ezekiel with the gallant Cherubino of Beaumarchais.
모모By the side of Enjolras, who represented the logic of the Revolution, Combeferre represented its philosophy.
모모Between the logic of the Revolution and its philosophy there exists this difference--that its logic may end in war, whereas its philosophy can end only in peace. Combeferre complemented and rectified Enjolras.
모모He was less lofty, but broader.
모모He desired to pour into all minds the extensive principles of general ideas:
모모he said:
모모"Revolution, but civilization"; and around the mountain peak he opened out a vast view of the blue sky. The Revolution was more adapted for breathing with Combeferre than with Enjolras.
모모Enjolras expressed its divine right, and Combeferre its natural right.
모모The first attached himself to Robespierre; the second confined himself to Condorcet.
모모Combeferre lived the life of all the rest of the world more than did Enjolras. If it had been granted to these two young men to attain to history, the one would have been the just, the other the wise man. Enjolras was the more virile, Combeferre the more humane.
모모Homo and vir, that was the exact effect of their different shades.
모모Combeferre was as gentle as Enjolras was severe, through natural whiteness. He loved the word citizen, but he preferred the word man.
모모He would gladly have said:
모모Hombre, like the Spanish.
모모He read everything, went to the theatres, attended the courses of public lecturers, learned the polarization of light from Arago, grew enthusiastic over a lesson in which Geoffrey Sainte-Hilaire explained the double function of the external carotid artery, and the internal, the one which makes the face, and the one which makes the brain; he kept up with what was going on, followed science step by step, compared Saint-Simon with Fourier, deciphered hieroglyphics, broke the pebble which he found and reasoned on geology, drew from memory a silkworm moth, pointed out the faulty French in the Dictionary of the Academy, studied Puysegur and Deleuze, affirmed nothing, not even miracles; denied nothing, not even ghosts; turned over the files of the Moniteur, reflected.
모모He declared that the future lies in the hand of the schoolmaster, and busied himself with educational questions.
모모He desired that society should labor without relaxation at the elevation of the moral and intellectual level, at coining science, at putting ideas into circulation, at increasing the mind in youthful persons, and he feared lest the present poverty of method, the paltriness from a literary point of view confined to two or three centuries called classic, the tyrannical dogmatism of official pedants, scholastic prejudices and routines should end by converting our colleges into artificial oyster beds.
모모He was learned, a purist, exact, a graduate of the Polytechnic, a close student, and at the same time, thoughtful "even to chimaeras," so his friends said. He believed in all dreams, railroads, the suppression of suffering in chirurgical operations, the fixing of images in the dark chamber, the electric telegraph, the steering of balloons.
모모Moreover, he was not much alarmed by the citadels erected against the human mind in every direction, by superstition, despotism, and prejudice. He was one of those who think that science will eventually turn the position.
모모Enjolras was a chief, Combeferre was a guide. One would have liked to fight under the one and to march behind the other.
모모It is not that Combeferre was not capable of fighting, he did not refuse a hand-to-hand combat with the obstacle, and to attack it by main force and explosively; but it suited him better to bring the human race into accord with its destiny gradually, by means of education, the inculcation of axioms, the promulgation of positive laws; and, between two lights, his preference was rather for illumination than for conflagration. A conflagration can create an aurora, no doubt, but why not await the dawn?
모모A volcano illuminates, but daybreak furnishes a still better illumination.
모모Possibly, Combeferre preferred the whiteness of the beautiful to the blaze of the sublime.
모모A light troubled by smoke, progress purchased at the expense of violence, only half satisfied this tender and serious spirit.
모모The headlong precipitation of a people into the truth, a '93, terrified him; nevertheless, stagnation was still more repulsive to him, in it he detected putrefaction and death; on the whole, he preferred scum to miasma, and he preferred the torrent to the cesspool, and the falls of Niagara to the lake of Montfaucon.
모모In short, he desired neither halt nor haste.
모모While his tumultuous friends, captivated by the absolute, adored and invoked splendid revolutionary adventures, Combeferre was inclined to let progress, good progress, take its own course; he may have been cold, but he was pure; methodical, but irreproachable; phlegmatic, but imperturbable.
모모Combeferre would have knelt and clasped his hands to enable the future to arrive in all its candor, and that nothing might disturb the immense and virtuous evolution of the races.
모모The good must be innocent, he repeated incessantly. And in fact, if the grandeur of the Revolution consists in keeping the dazzling ideal fixedly in view, and of soaring thither athwart the lightnings, with fire and blood in its talons, the beauty of progress lies in being spotless; and there exists between Washington, who represents the one, and Danton, who incarnates the other, that difference which separates the swan from the angel with the wings of an eagle.
모모Jean Prouvaire was a still softer shade than Combeferre.
모모His name was Jehan, owing to that petty momentary freak which mingled with the powerful and profound movement whence sprang the very essential study of the Middle Ages.
모모Jean Prouvaire was in love; he cultivated a pot of flowers, played on the flute, made verses, loved the people, pitied woman, wept over the child, confounded God and the future in the same confidence, and blamed the Revolution for having caused the fall of a royal head, that of Andre Chenier. His voice was ordinarily delicate, but suddenly grew manly. He was learned even to erudition, and almost an Orientalist. Above all, he was good; and, a very simple thing to those who know how nearly goodness borders on grandeur, in the matter of poetry, he preferred the immense.
모모He knew Italian, Latin, Greek, and Hebrew; and these served him only for the perusal of four poets: Dante, Juvenal, AEschylus, and Isaiah.
모모In French, he preferred Corneille to Racine, and Agrippa d'Aubigne to Corneille. He loved to saunter through fields of wild oats and corn-flowers, and busied himself with clouds nearly as much as with events. His mind had two attitudes, one on the side towards man, the other on that towards God; he studied or he contemplated.
모모All day long, he buried himself in social questions, salary, capital, credit, marriage, religion, liberty of thought, education, penal servitude, poverty, association, property, production and sharing, the enigma of this lower world which covers the human ant-hill with darkness; and at night, he gazed upon the planets, those enormous beings. Like Enjolras, he was wealthy and an only son.
모모He spoke softly, bowed his head, lowered his eyes, smiled with embarrassment, dressed badly, had an awkward air, blushed at a mere nothing, and was very timid.
모모Yet he was intrepid.
모모Feuilly was a workingman, a fan-maker, orphaned both of father and mother, who earned with difficulty three francs a day, and had but one thought, to deliver the world.
모모He had one other preoccupation, to educate himself; he called this also, delivering himself. He had taught himself to read and write; everything that he knew, he had learned by himself.
모모Feuilly had a generous heart.
모모The range of his embrace was immense.
모모This orphan had adopted the peoples. As his mother had failed him, he meditated on his country. He brooded with the profound divination of the man of the people, over what we now call the idea of the nationality, had learned history with the express object of raging with full knowledge of the case. In this club of young Utopians, occupied chiefly with France, he represented the outside world.
모모He had for his specialty Greece, Poland, Hungary, Roumania, Italy.
모모He uttered these names incessantly, appropriately and inappropriately, with the tenacity of right. The violations of Turkey on Greece and Thessaly, of Russia on Warsaw, of Austria on Venice, enraged him.
모모Above all things, the great violence of 1772 aroused him.
모모There is no more sovereign eloquence than the true in indignation; he was eloquent with that eloquence.
모모He was inexhaustible on that infamous date of 1772, on the subject of that noble and valiant race suppressed by treason, and that three-sided crime, on that monstrous ambush, the prototype and pattern of all those horrible suppressions of states, which, since that time, have struck many a noble nation, and have annulled their certificate of birth, so to speak. All contemporary social crimes have their origin in the partition of Poland.
모모The partition of Poland is a theorem of which all present political outrages are the corollaries.
모모There has not been a despot, nor a traitor for nearly a century back, who has not signed, approved, counter-signed, and copied, ne variatur, the partition of Poland. When the record of modern treasons was examined, that was the first thing which made its appearance.
모모The congress of Vienna consulted that crime before consummating its own.
모모1772 sounded the onset; 1815 was the death of the game.
모모Such was Feuilly's habitual text. This poor workingman had constituted himself the tutor of Justice, and she recompensed him by rendering him great.
모모The fact is, that there is eternity in right.
모모Warsaw can no more be Tartar than Venice can be Teuton.
모모Kings lose their pains and their honor in the attempt to make them so.
모모Sooner or later, the submerged part floats to the surface and reappears.
모모Greece becomes Greece again, Italy is once more Italy.
모모The protest of right against the deed persists forever.
모모The theft of a nation cannot be allowed by prescription.
모모These lofty deeds of rascality have no future. A nation cannot have its mark extracted like a pocket handkerchief.
모모Courfeyrac had a father who was called M. de Courfeyrac.
모모One of the false ideas of the bourgeoisie under the Restoration as regards aristocracy and the nobility was to believe in the particle. The particle, as every one knows, possesses no significance. But the bourgeois of the epoch of la Minerve estimated so highly that poor de, that they thought themselves bound to abdicate it. M. de Chauvelin had himself called M. Chauvelin; M. de Caumartin, M. Caumartin; M. de Constant de Robecque, Benjamin Constant; M. de Lafayette, M. Lafayette.
모모Courfeyrac had not wished to remain behind the rest, and called himself plain Courfeyrac.
모모We might almost, so far as Courfeyrac is concerned, stop here, and confine ourselves to saying with regard to what remains: "For Courfeyrac, see Tholomyes."
모모Courfeyrac had, in fact, that animation of youth which may be called the beaute du diable of the mind.
모모Later on, this disappears like the playfulness of the kitten, and all this grace ends, with the bourgeois, on two legs, and with the tomcat, on four paws.
모모This sort of wit is transmitted from generation to generation of the successive levies of youth who traverse the schools, who pass it from hand to hand, quasi cursores, and is almost always exactly the same; so that, as we have just pointed out, any one who had listened to Courfeyrac in 1828 would have thought he heard Tholomyes in 1817.
모모Only, Courfeyrac was an honorable fellow. Beneath the apparent similarities of the exterior mind, the difference between him and Tholomyes was very great.
모모The latent man which existed in the two was totally different in the first from what it was in the second.
모모There was in Tholomyes a district attorney, and in Courfeyrac a paladin.
모모Enjolras was the chief, Combeferre was the guide, Courfeyrac was the centre.
모모The others gave more light, he shed more warmth; the truth is, that he possessed all the qualities of a centre, roundness and radiance.
모모Bahorel had figured in the bloody tumult of June, 1822, on the occasion of the burial of young Lallemand.
모모Bahorel was a good-natured mortal, who kept bad company, brave, a spendthrift, prodigal, and to the verge of generosity, talkative, and at times eloquent, bold to the verge of effrontery; the best fellow possible; he had daring waistcoats, and scarlet opinions; a wholesale blusterer, that is to say, loving nothing so much as a quarrel, unless it were an uprising; and nothing so much as an uprising, unless it were a revolution; always ready to smash a window-pane, then to tear up the pavement, then to demolish a government, just to see the effect of it; a student in his eleventh year. He had nosed about the law, but did not practise it.
모모He had taken for his device:
모모"Never a lawyer," and for his armorial bearings a nightstand in which was visible a square cap.
모모Every time that he passed the law-school, which rarely happened, he buttoned up his frock-coat,--the paletot had not yet been invented,--and took hygienic precautions.
모모Of the school porter he said:
모모"What a fine old man!" and of the dean, M. Delvincourt:
모모"What a monument!" In his lectures he espied subjects for ballads, and in his professors occasions for caricature.
모모He wasted a tolerably large allowance, something like three thousand francs a year, in doing nothing.
모모He had peasant parents whom he had contrived to imbue with respect for their son.
모모He said of them:
모모"They are peasants and not bourgeois; that is the reason they are intelligent."
모모Bahorel, a man of caprice, was scattered over numerous cafes; the others had habits, he had none.
모모He sauntered.
모모To stray is human. To saunter is Parisian.
모모In reality, he had a penetrating mind and was more of a thinker than appeared to view.
모모He served as a connecting link between the Friends of the A B C and other still unorganized groups, which were destined to take form later on.
모모In this conclave of young heads, there was one bald member.
모모The Marquis d'Avaray, whom Louis XVIII.
모모made a duke for having assisted him to enter a hackney-coach on the day when he emigrated, was wont to relate, that in 1814, on his return to France, as the King was disembarking at Calais, a man handed him a petition.
모모"What is your request?" said the King.
모모"Sire, a post-office."
모모"What is your name?"
모모"L'Aigle."
모모The King frowned, glanced at the signature of the petition and beheld the name written thus:
모모LESGLE.
모모This non-Bonoparte orthography touched the King and he began to smile.
모모"Sire," resumed the man with the petition, "I had for ancestor a keeper of the hounds surnamed Lesgueules.
모모This surname furnished my name.
모모I am called Lesgueules, by contraction Lesgle, and by corruption l'Aigle." This caused the King to smile broadly.
모모Later on he gave the man the posting office of Meaux, either intentionally or accidentally.
모모The bald member of the group was the son of this Lesgle, or Legle, and he signed himself, Legle [de Meaux]. As an abbreviation, his companions called him Bossuet.
모모Bossuet was a gay but unlucky fellow.
모모His specialty was not to succeed in anything.
모모As an offset, he laughed at everything. At five and twenty he was bald.
모모His father had ended by owning a house and a field; but he, the son, had made haste to lose that house and field in a bad speculation.
모모He had nothing left. He possessed knowledge and wit, but all he did miscarried. Everything failed him and everybody deceived him; what he was building tumbled down on top of him.
모모If he were splitting wood, he cut off a finger.
모모If he had a mistress, he speedily discovered that he had a friend also.
모모Some misfortune happened to him every moment, hence his joviality.
모모He said:
모모"I live under falling tiles." He was not easily astonished, because, for him, an accident was what he had foreseen, he took his bad luck serenely, and smiled at the teasing of fate, like a person who is listening to pleasantries. He was poor, but his fund of good humor was inexhaustible. He soon reached his last sou, never his last burst of laughter. When adversity entered his doors, he saluted this old acquaintance cordially, he tapped all catastrophes on the stomach; he was familiar with fatality to the point of calling it by its nickname: "Good day, Guignon," he said to it.
모모These persecutions of fate had rendered him inventive.
모모He was full of resources.
모모He had no money, but he found means, when it seemed good to him, to indulge in "unbridled extravagance."
모모One night, he went so far as to eat a "hundred francs" in a supper with a wench, which inspired him to make this memorable remark in the midst of the orgy:
모모"Pull off my boots, you five-louis jade."
모모Bossuet was slowly directing his steps towards the profession of a lawyer; he was pursuing his law studies after the manner of Bahorel.
모모Bossuet had not much domicile, sometimes none at all. He lodged now with one, now with another, most often with Joly. Joly was studying medicine.
모모He was two years younger than Bossuet.
모모Joly was the "malade imaginaire" junior.
모모What he had won in medicine was to be more of an invalid than a doctor.
모모At three and twenty he thought himself a valetudinarian, and passed his life in inspecting his tongue in the mirror.
모모He affirmed that man becomes magnetic like a needle, and in his chamber he placed his bed with its head to the south, and the foot to the north, so that, at night, the circulation of his blood might not be interfered with by the great electric current of the globe.
모모During thunder storms, he felt his pulse.
모모Otherwise, he was the gayest of them all. All these young, maniacal, puny, merry incoherences lived in harmony together, and the result was an eccentric and agreeable being whom his comrades, who were prodigal of winged consonants, called Jolllly . "You may fly away on the four L's," Jean Prouvaire said to him.[23]
모모[23] L'Aile, wing.
모모 Joly had a trick of touching his nose with the tip of his cane, which is an indication of a sagacious mind.
모모All these young men who differed so greatly, and who, on the whole, can only be discussed seriously, held the same religion:
모모Progress.
모모All were the direct sons of the French Revolution.
모모The most giddy of them became solemn when they pronounced that date:
모모'89.
모모Their fathers in the flesh had been, either royalists, doctrinaires, it matters not what; this confusion anterior to themselves, who were young, did not concern them at all; the pure blood of principle ran in their veins.
모모They attached themselves, without intermediate shades, to incorruptible right and absolute duty.
모모Affiliated and initiated, they sketched out the ideal underground.
모모Among all these glowing hearts and thoroughly convinced minds, there was one sceptic.
모모How came he there?
모모By juxtaposition. This sceptic's name was Grantaire, and he was in the habit of signing himself with this rebus:
모모R. Grantaire was a man who took good care not to believe in anything.
모모Moreover, he was one of the students who had learned the most during their course at Paris; he knew that the best coffee was to be had at the Cafe Lemblin, and the best billiards at the Cafe Voltaire, that good cakes and lasses were to be found at the Ermitage, on the Boulevard du Maine, spatchcocked chickens at Mother Sauget's, excellent matelotes at the Barriere de la Cunette, and a certain thin white wine at the Barriere du Com pat.
모모He knew the best place for everything; in addition, boxing and foot-fencing and some dances; and he was a thorough single-stick player.
모모He was a tremendous drinker to boot. He was inordinately homely:
모모the prettiest boot-stitcher of that day, Irma Boissy, enraged with his homeliness, pronounced sentence on him as follows:
모모"Grantaire is impossible"; but Grantaire's fatuity was not to be disconcerted.
모모He stared tenderly and fixedly at all women, with the air of saying to them all:
모모"If I only chose!" and of trying to make his comrades believe that he was in general demand.
모모All those words:
모모rights of the people, rights of man, the social contract, the French Revolution, the Republic, democracy, humanity, civilization, religion, progress, came very near to signifying nothing whatever to Grantaire.
모모He smiled at them. Scepticism, that caries of the intelligence, had not left him a single whole idea.
모모He lived with irony.
모모This was his axiom: "There is but one certainty, my full glass."
모모He sneered at all devotion in all parties, the father as well as the brother, Robespierre junior as well as Loizerolles.
모모"They are greatly in advance to be dead," he exclaimed.
모모He said of the crucifix:
모모"There is a gibbet which has been a success."
모모A rover, a gambler, a libertine, often drunk, he displeased these young dreamers by humming incessantly: "J'aimons les filles, et j'aimons le bon vin."
모모Air:
모모Vive Henri IV.
모모However, this sceptic had one fanaticism.
모모This fanaticism was neither a dogma, nor an idea, nor an art, nor a science; it was a man:
모모Enjolras.
