모모Grantaire admired, loved, and venerated Enjolras. To whom did this anarchical scoffer unite himself in this phalanx of absolute minds?
모모To the most absolute.
모모In what manner had Enjolras subjugated him?
모모By his ideas?
모모No. By his character. A phenomenon which is often observable.
모모A sceptic who adheres to a believer is as simple as the law of complementary colors.
모모That which we lack attracts us.
모모No one loves the light like the blind man. The dwarf adores the drum-major. The toad always has his eyes fixed on heaven.
모모Why?
모모In order to watch the bird in its flight. Grantaire, in whom writhed doubt, loved to watch faith soar in Enjolras. He had need of Enjolras.
모모That chaste, healthy, firm, upright, hard, candid nature charmed him, without his being clearly aware of it, and without the idea of explaining it to himself having occurred to him.
모모He admired his opposite by instinct.
모모His soft, yielding, dislocated, sickly, shapeless ideas attached themselves to Enjolras as to a spinal column.
모모His moral backbone leaned on that firmness. Grantaire in the presence of Enjolras became some one once more. He was, himself, moreover, composed of two elements, which were, to all appearance, incompatible.
모모He was ironical and cordial. His indifference loved.
모모His mind could get along without belief, but his heart could not get along without friendship. A profound contradiction; for an affection is a conviction. His nature was thus constituted.
모모There are men who seem to be born to be the reverse, the obverse, the wrong side.
모모They are Pollux, Patrocles, Nisus, Eudamidas, Ephestion, Pechmeja.
모모They only exist on condition that they are backed up with another man; their name is a sequel, and is only written preceded by the conjunction and; and their existence is not their own; it is the other side of an existence which is not theirs.
모모Grantaire was one of these men. He was the obverse of Enjolras.
모모One might almost say that affinities begin with the letters of the alphabet.
모모In the series O and P are inseparable.
모모You can, at will, pronounce O and P or Orestes and Pylades.
모모Grantaire, Enjolras' true satellite, inhabited this circle of young men; he lived there, he took no pleasure anywhere but there; he followed them everywhere.
모모His joy was to see these forms go and come through the fumes of wine.
모모They tolerated him on account of his good humor.
모모Enjolras, the believer, disdained this sceptic; and, a sober man himself, scorned this drunkard.
모모He accorded him a little lofty pity.
모모Grantaire was an unaccepted Pylades.
모모Always harshly treated by Enjolras, roughly repulsed, rejected yet ever returning to the charge, he said of Enjolras:
모모"What fine marble!"
모모A GROUP WHICH BARELY MISSED BECOMING HISTORIC 
모모At that epoch, which was, to all appearances indifferent, a certain revolutionary quiver was vaguely current.
모모Breaths which had started forth from the depths of '89 and '93 were in the air.
모모Youth was on the point, may the reader pardon us the word, of moulting. People were undergoing a transformation, almost without being conscious of it, through the movement of the age.
모모The needle which moves round the compass also moves in souls.
모모Each person was taking that step in advance which he was bound to take. The Royalists were becoming liberals, liberals were turning democrats. It was a flood tide complicated with a thousand ebb movements; the peculiarity of ebbs is to create intermixtures; hence the combination of very singular ideas; people adored both Napoleon and liberty. We are making history here.
모모These were the mirages of that period. Opinions traverse phases.
모모Voltairian royalism, a quaint variety, had a no less singular sequel, Bonapartist liberalism.
모모Other groups of minds were more serious.
모모In that direction, they sounded principles, they attached themselves to the right. They grew enthusiastic for the absolute, they caught glimpses of infinite realizations; the absolute, by its very rigidity, urges spirits towards the sky and causes them to float in illimitable space. There is nothing like dogma for bringing forth dreams.
모모And there is nothing like dreams for engendering the future.
모모Utopia to-day, flesh and blood to-morrow.
모모These advanced opinions had a double foundation.
모모A beginning of mystery menaced "the established order of things," which was suspicious and underhand.
모모A sign which was revolutionary to the highest degree.
모모The second thoughts of power meet the second thoughts of the populace in the mine.
모모The incubation of insurrections gives the retort to the premeditation of coups d'etat.
모모There did not, as yet, exist in France any of those vast underlying organizations, like the German tugendbund and Italian Carbonarism; but here and there there were dark underminings, which were in process of throwing off shoots.
모모The Cougourde was being outlined at Aix; there existed at Paris, among other affiliations of that nature, the society of the Friends of the A B C.
모모What were these Friends of the A B C?
모모A society which had for its object apparently the education of children, in reality the elevation of man.
모모They declared themselves the Friends of the A B C,--the Abaisse,-- the debased,--that is to say, the people.
모모They wished to elevate the people.
모모It was a pun which we should do wrong to smile at. Puns are sometimes serious factors in politics; witness the Castratus ad castra, which made a general of the army of Narses; witness: Barbari et Barberini; witness:
모모Tu es Petrus et super hanc petram, etc., etc.
모모The Friends of the A B C were not numerous, it was a secret society in the state of embryo, we might almost say a coterie, if coteries ended in heroes.
모모They assembled in Paris in two localities, near the fish-market, in a wine-shop called Corinthe, of which more will be heard later on, and near the Pantheon in a little cafe in the Rue Saint-Michel called the Cafe Musain, now torn down; the first of these meeting-places was close to the workingman, the second to the students.
모모The assemblies of the Friends of the A B C were usually held in a back room of the Cafe Musain.
모모This hall, which was tolerably remote from the cafe, with which it was connected by an extremely long corridor, had two windows and an exit with a private stairway on the little Rue des Gres.
모모There they smoked and drank, and gambled and laughed.
모모There they conversed in very loud tones about everything, and in whispers of other things. An old map of France under the Republic was nailed to the wall,-- a sign quite sufficient to excite the suspicion of a police agent.
모모The greater part of the Friends of the A B C were students, who were on cordial terms with the working classes.
모모Here are the names of the principal ones.
모모They belong, in a certain measure, to history:
모모Enjolras, Combeferre, Jean Prouvaire, Feuilly, Courfeyrac, Bahorel, Lesgle or Laigle, Joly, Grantaire.
모모These young men formed a sort of family, through the bond of friendship.
모모All, with the exception of Laigle, were from the South.
모모This was a remarkable group.
모모It vanished in the invisible depths which lie behind us.
모모At the point of this drama which we have now reached, it will not perhaps be superfluous to throw a ray of light upon these youthful heads, before the reader beholds them plunging into the shadow of a tragic adventure.
모모Enjolras, whose name we have mentioned first of all,--the reader shall see why later on,--was an only son and wealthy.
모모Enjolras was a charming young man, who was capable of being terrible. He was angelically handsome.
모모He was a savage Antinous.
모모One would have said, to see the pensive thoughtfulness of his glance, that he had already, in some previous state of existence, traversed the revolutionary apocalypse.
모모He possessed the tradition of it as though he had been a witness.
모모He was acquainted with all the minute details of the great affair.
모모A pontifical and warlike nature, a singular thing in a youth.
모모He was an officiating priest and a man of war; from the immediate point of view, a soldier of the democracy; above the contemporary movement, the priest of the ideal.
모모His eyes were deep, his lids a little red, his lower lip was thick and easily became disdainful, his brow was lofty.
모모A great deal of brow in a face is like a great deal of horizon in a view.
모모Like certain young men at the beginning of this century and the end of the last, who became illustrious at an early age, he was endowed with excessive youth, and was as rosy as a young girl, although subject to hours of pallor. Already a man, he still seemed a child.
모모His two and twenty years appeared to be but seventeen; he was serious, it did not seem as though he were aware there was on earth a thing called woman. He had but one passion--the right; but one thought--to overthrow the obstacle.
모모On Mount Aventine, he would have been Gracchus; in the Convention, he would have been Saint-Just. He hardly saw the roses, he ignored spring, he did not hear the carolling of the birds; the bare throat of Evadne would have moved him no more than it would have moved Aristogeiton; he, like Harmodius, thought flowers good for nothing except to conceal the sword. He was severe in his enjoyments.
모모He chastely dropped his eyes before everything which was not the Republic.
모모He was the marble lover of liberty.
모모His speech was harshly inspired, and had the thrill of a hymn.
모모He was subject to unexpected outbursts of soul. Woe to the love-affair which should have risked itself beside him! If any grisette of the Place Cambrai or the Rue Saint-Jean-de-Beauvais, seeing that face of a youth escaped from college, that page's mien, those long, golden lashes, those blue eyes, that hair billowing in the wind, those rosy cheeks, those fresh lips, those exquisite teeth, had conceived an appetite for that complete aurora, and had tried her beauty on Enjolras, an astounding and terrible glance would have promptly shown her the abyss, and would have taught her not to confound the mighty cherub of Ezekiel with the gallant Cherubino of Beaumarchais.
모모By the side of Enjolras, who represented the logic of the Revolution, Combeferre represented its philosophy.
모모Between the logic of the Revolution and its philosophy there exists this difference--that its logic may end in war, whereas its philosophy can end only in peace. Combeferre complemented and rectified Enjolras.
모모He was less lofty, but broader.
모모He desired to pour into all minds the extensive principles of general ideas:
모모he said:
모모"Revolution, but civilization"; and around the mountain peak he opened out a vast view of the blue sky. The Revolution was more adapted for breathing with Combeferre than with Enjolras.
모모Enjolras expressed its divine right, and Combeferre its natural right.
모모The first attached himself to Robespierre; the second confined himself to Condorcet.
모모Combeferre lived the life of all the rest of the world more than did Enjolras. If it had been granted to these two young men to attain to history, the one would have been the just, the other the wise man. Enjolras was the more virile, Combeferre the more humane.
모모Homo and vir, that was the exact effect of their different shades.
모모Combeferre was as gentle as Enjolras was severe, through natural whiteness. He loved the word citizen, but he preferred the word man.
모모He would gladly have said:
모모Hombre, like the Spanish.
모모He read everything, went to the theatres, attended the courses of public lecturers, learned the polarization of light from Arago, grew enthusiastic over a lesson in which Geoffrey Sainte-Hilaire explained the double function of the external carotid artery, and the internal, the one which makes the face, and the one which makes the brain; he kept up with what was going on, followed science step by step, compared Saint-Simon with Fourier, deciphered hieroglyphics, broke the pebble which he found and reasoned on geology, drew from memory a silkworm moth, pointed out the faulty French in the Dictionary of the Academy, studied Puysegur and Deleuze, affirmed nothing, not even miracles; denied nothing, not even ghosts; turned over the files of the Moniteur, reflected.
모모He declared that the future lies in the hand of the schoolmaster, and busied himself with educational questions.
모모He desired that society should labor without relaxation at the elevation of the moral and intellectual level, at coining science, at putting ideas into circulation, at increasing the mind in youthful persons, and he feared lest the present poverty of method, the paltriness from a literary point of view confined to two or three centuries called classic, the tyrannical dogmatism of official pedants, scholastic prejudices and routines should end by converting our colleges into artificial oyster beds.
모모He was learned, a purist, exact, a graduate of the Polytechnic, a close student, and at the same time, thoughtful "even to chimaeras," so his friends said. He believed in all dreams, railroads, the suppression of suffering in chirurgical operations, the fixing of images in the dark chamber, the electric telegraph, the steering of balloons.
모모Moreover, he was not much alarmed by the citadels erected against the human mind in every direction, by superstition, despotism, and prejudice. He was one of those who think that science will eventually turn the position.
모모Enjolras was a chief, Combeferre was a guide. One would have liked to fight under the one and to march behind the other.
모모It is not that Combeferre was not capable of fighting, he did not refuse a hand-to-hand combat with the obstacle, and to attack it by main force and explosively; but it suited him better to bring the human race into accord with its destiny gradually, by means of education, the inculcation of axioms, the promulgation of positive laws; and, between two lights, his preference was rather for illumination than for conflagration. A conflagration can create an aurora, no doubt, but why not await the dawn?
모모A volcano illuminates, but daybreak furnishes a still better illumination.
모모Possibly, Combeferre preferred the whiteness of the beautiful to the blaze of the sublime.
모모A light troubled by smoke, progress purchased at the expense of violence, only half satisfied this tender and serious spirit.
모모The headlong precipitation of a people into the truth, a '93, terrified him; nevertheless, stagnation was still more repulsive to him, in it he detected putrefaction and death; on the whole, he preferred scum to miasma, and he preferred the torrent to the cesspool, and the falls of Niagara to the lake of Montfaucon.
모모In short, he desired neither halt nor haste.
모모While his tumultuous friends, captivated by the absolute, adored and invoked splendid revolutionary adventures, Combeferre was inclined to let progress, good progress, take its own course; he may have been cold, but he was pure; methodical, but irreproachable; phlegmatic, but imperturbable.
모모Combeferre would have knelt and clasped his hands to enable the future to arrive in all its candor, and that nothing might disturb the immense and virtuous evolution of the races.
모모The good must be innocent, he repeated incessantly. And in fact, if the grandeur of the Revolution consists in keeping the dazzling ideal fixedly in view, and of soaring thither athwart the lightnings, with fire and blood in its talons, the beauty of progress lies in being spotless; and there exists between Washington, who represents the one, and Danton, who incarnates the other, that difference which separates the swan from the angel with the wings of an eagle.
모모Jean Prouvaire was a still softer shade than Combeferre.
모모His name was Jehan, owing to that petty momentary freak which mingled with the powerful and profound movement whence sprang the very essential study of the Middle Ages.
모모Jean Prouvaire was in love; he cultivated a pot of flowers, played on the flute, made verses, loved the people, pitied woman, wept over the child, confounded God and the future in the same confidence, and blamed the Revolution for having caused the fall of a royal head, that of Andre Chenier. His voice was ordinarily delicate, but suddenly grew manly. He was learned even to erudition, and almost an Orientalist. Above all, he was good; and, a very simple thing to those who know how nearly goodness borders on grandeur, in the matter of poetry, he preferred the immense.
모모He knew Italian, Latin, Greek, and Hebrew; and these served him only for the perusal of four poets: Dante, Juvenal, AEschylus, and Isaiah.
모모In French, he preferred Corneille to Racine, and Agrippa d'Aubigne to Corneille. He loved to saunter through fields of wild oats and corn-flowers, and busied himself with clouds nearly as much as with events. His mind had two attitudes, one on the side towards man, the other on that towards God; he studied or he contemplated.
모모All day long, he buried himself in social questions, salary, capital, credit, marriage, religion, liberty of thought, education, penal servitude, poverty, association, property, production and sharing, the enigma of this lower world which covers the human ant-hill with darkness; and at night, he gazed upon the planets, those enormous beings. Like Enjolras, he was wealthy and an only son.
모모He spoke softly, bowed his head, lowered his eyes, smiled with embarrassment, dressed badly, had an awkward air, blushed at a mere nothing, and was very timid.
모모Yet he was intrepid.
모모Feuilly was a workingman, a fan-maker, orphaned both of father and mother, who earned with difficulty three francs a day, and had but one thought, to deliver the world.
모모He had one other preoccupation, to educate himself; he called this also, delivering himself. He had taught himself to read and write; everything that he knew, he had learned by himself.
모모Feuilly had a generous heart.
모모The range of his embrace was immense.
모모This orphan had adopted the peoples. As his mother had failed him, he meditated on his country. He brooded with the profound divination of the man of the people, over what we now call the idea of the nationality, had learned history with the express object of raging with full knowledge of the case. In this club of young Utopians, occupied chiefly with France, he represented the outside world.
모모He had for his specialty Greece, Poland, Hungary, Roumania, Italy.
모모He uttered these names incessantly, appropriately and inappropriately, with the tenacity of right. The violations of Turkey on Greece and Thessaly, of Russia on Warsaw, of Austria on Venice, enraged him.
모모Above all things, the great violence of 1772 aroused him.
모모There is no more sovereign eloquence than the true in indignation; he was eloquent with that eloquence.
모모He was inexhaustible on that infamous date of 1772, on the subject of that noble and valiant race suppressed by treason, and that three-sided crime, on that monstrous ambush, the prototype and pattern of all those horrible suppressions of states, which, since that time, have struck many a noble nation, and have annulled their certificate of birth, so to speak. All contemporary social crimes have their origin in the partition of Poland.
모모The partition of Poland is a theorem of which all present political outrages are the corollaries.
모모There has not been a despot, nor a traitor for nearly a century back, who has not signed, approved, counter-signed, and copied, ne variatur, the partition of Poland. When the record of modern treasons was examined, that was the first thing which made its appearance.
모모The congress of Vienna consulted that crime before consummating its own.
모모1772 sounded the onset; 1815 was the death of the game.
모모Such was Feuilly's habitual text. This poor workingman had constituted himself the tutor of Justice, and she recompensed him by rendering him great.
모모The fact is, that there is eternity in right.
모모Warsaw can no more be Tartar than Venice can be Teuton.
모모Kings lose their pains and their honor in the attempt to make them so.
모모Sooner or later, the submerged part floats to the surface and reappears.
모모Greece becomes Greece again, Italy is once more Italy.
모모The protest of right against the deed persists forever.
모모The theft of a nation cannot be allowed by prescription.
모모These lofty deeds of rascality have no future. A nation cannot have its mark extracted like a pocket handkerchief.
모모Courfeyrac had a father who was called M. de Courfeyrac.
모모One of the false ideas of the bourgeoisie under the Restoration as regards aristocracy and the nobility was to believe in the particle. The particle, as every one knows, possesses no significance. But the bourgeois of the epoch of la Minerve estimated so highly that poor de, that they thought themselves bound to abdicate it. M. de Chauvelin had himself called M. Chauvelin; M. de Caumartin, M. Caumartin; M. de Constant de Robecque, Benjamin Constant; M. de Lafayette, M. Lafayette.
모모Courfeyrac had not wished to remain behind the rest, and called himself plain Courfeyrac.
모모We might almost, so far as Courfeyrac is concerned, stop here, and confine ourselves to saying with regard to what remains: "For Courfeyrac, see Tholomyes."
모모Courfeyrac had, in fact, that animation of youth which may be called the beaute du diable of the mind.
모모Later on, this disappears like the playfulness of the kitten, and all this grace ends, with the bourgeois, on two legs, and with the tomcat, on four paws.
모모This sort of wit is transmitted from generation to generation of the successive levies of youth who traverse the schools, who pass it from hand to hand, quasi cursores, and is almost always exactly the same; so that, as we have just pointed out, any one who had listened to Courfeyrac in 1828 would have thought he heard Tholomyes in 1817.
모모Only, Courfeyrac was an honorable fellow. Beneath the apparent similarities of the exterior mind, the difference between him and Tholomyes was very great.
모모The latent man which existed in the two was totally different in the first from what it was in the second.
모모There was in Tholomyes a district attorney, and in Courfeyrac a paladin.
모모Enjolras was the chief, Combeferre was the guide, Courfeyrac was the centre.
모모The others gave more light, he shed more warmth; the truth is, that he possessed all the qualities of a centre, roundness and radiance.
모모Bahorel had figured in the bloody tumult of June, 1822, on the occasion of the burial of young Lallemand.
모모Bahorel was a good-natured mortal, who kept bad company, brave, a spendthrift, prodigal, and to the verge of generosity, talkative, and at times eloquent, bold to the verge of effrontery; the best fellow possible; he had daring waistcoats, and scarlet opinions; a wholesale blusterer, that is to say, loving nothing so much as a quarrel, unless it were an uprising; and nothing so much as an uprising, unless it were a revolution; always ready to smash a window-pane, then to tear up the pavement, then to demolish a government, just to see the effect of it; a student in his eleventh year. He had nosed about the law, but did not practise it.
모모He had taken for his device:
모모"Never a lawyer," and for his armorial bearings a nightstand in which was visible a square cap.
모모Every time that he passed the law-school, which rarely happened, he buttoned up his frock-coat,--the paletot had not yet been invented,--and took hygienic precautions.
모모Of the school porter he said:
모모"What a fine old man!" and of the dean, M. Delvincourt:
모모"What a monument!" In his lectures he espied subjects for ballads, and in his professors occasions for caricature.
모모He wasted a tolerably large allowance, something like three thousand francs a year, in doing nothing.
모모He had peasant parents whom he had contrived to imbue with respect for their son.
모모He said of them:
모모"They are peasants and not bourgeois; that is the reason they are intelligent."
모모Bahorel, a man of caprice, was scattered over numerous cafes; the others had habits, he had none.
모모He sauntered.
모모To stray is human. To saunter is Parisian.
모모In reality, he had a penetrating mind and was more of a thinker than appeared to view.
모모He served as a connecting link between the Friends of the A B C and other still unorganized groups, which were destined to take form later on.
모모In this conclave of young heads, there was one bald member.
모모The Marquis d'Avaray, whom Louis XVIII.
모모made a duke for having assisted him to enter a hackney-coach on the day when he emigrated, was wont to relate, that in 1814, on his return to France, as the King was disembarking at Calais, a man handed him a petition.
모모"What is your request?" said the King.
모모"Sire, a post-office."
모모"What is your name?"
모모"L'Aigle."
모모The King frowned, glanced at the signature of the petition and beheld the name written thus:
모모LESGLE.
모모This non-Bonoparte orthography touched the King and he began to smile.
모모"Sire," resumed the man with the petition, "I had for ancestor a keeper of the hounds surnamed Lesgueules.
모모This surname furnished my name.
모모I am called Lesgueules, by contraction Lesgle, and by corruption l'Aigle." This caused the King to smile broadly.
모모Later on he gave the man the posting office of Meaux, either intentionally or accidentally.
모모The bald member of the group was the son of this Lesgle, or Legle, and he signed himself, Legle [de Meaux]. As an abbreviation, his companions called him Bossuet.
모모Bossuet was a gay but unlucky fellow.
모모His specialty was not to succeed in anything.
모모As an offset, he laughed at everything. At five and twenty he was bald.
모모His father had ended by owning a house and a field; but he, the son, had made haste to lose that house and field in a bad speculation.
모모He had nothing left. He possessed knowledge and wit, but all he did miscarried. Everything failed him and everybody deceived him; what he was building tumbled down on top of him.
모모If he were splitting wood, he cut off a finger.
모모If he had a mistress, he speedily discovered that he had a friend also.
모모Some misfortune happened to him every moment, hence his joviality.
모모He said:
모모"I live under falling tiles." He was not easily astonished, because, for him, an accident was what he had foreseen, he took his bad luck serenely, and smiled at the teasing of fate, like a person who is listening to pleasantries. He was poor, but his fund of good humor was inexhaustible. He soon reached his last sou, never his last burst of laughter. When adversity entered his doors, he saluted this old acquaintance cordially, he tapped all catastrophes on the stomach; he was familiar with fatality to the point of calling it by its nickname: "Good day, Guignon," he said to it.
모모These persecutions of fate had rendered him inventive.
모모He was full of resources.
모모He had no money, but he found means, when it seemed good to him, to indulge in "unbridled extravagance."
모모One night, he went so far as to eat a "hundred francs" in a supper with a wench, which inspired him to make this memorable remark in the midst of the orgy:
모모"Pull off my boots, you five-louis jade."
모모Bossuet was slowly directing his steps towards the profession of a lawyer; he was pursuing his law studies after the manner of Bahorel.
모모Bossuet had not much domicile, sometimes none at all. He lodged now with one, now with another, most often with Joly. Joly was studying medicine.
모모He was two years younger than Bossuet.
모모Joly was the "malade imaginaire" junior.
모모What he had won in medicine was to be more of an invalid than a doctor.
모모At three and twenty he thought himself a valetudinarian, and passed his life in inspecting his tongue in the mirror.
모모He affirmed that man becomes magnetic like a needle, and in his chamber he placed his bed with its head to the south, and the foot to the north, so that, at night, the circulation of his blood might not be interfered with by the great electric current of the globe.
모모During thunder storms, he felt his pulse.
모모Otherwise, he was the gayest of them all. All these young, maniacal, puny, merry incoherences lived in harmony together, and the result was an eccentric and agreeable being whom his comrades, who were prodigal of winged consonants, called Jolllly . "You may fly away on the four L's," Jean Prouvaire said to him.[23]
모모[23] L'Aile, wing.
모모 Joly had a trick of touching his nose with the tip of his cane, which is an indication of a sagacious mind.
모모All these young men who differed so greatly, and who, on the whole, can only be discussed seriously, held the same religion:
모모Progress.
모모All were the direct sons of the French Revolution.
모모The most giddy of them became solemn when they pronounced that date:
모모'89.
모모Their fathers in the flesh had been, either royalists, doctrinaires, it matters not what; this confusion anterior to themselves, who were young, did not concern them at all; the pure blood of principle ran in their veins.
모모They attached themselves, without intermediate shades, to incorruptible right and absolute duty.
모모Affiliated and initiated, they sketched out the ideal underground.
모모Among all these glowing hearts and thoroughly convinced minds, there was one sceptic.
모모How came he there?
모모By juxtaposition. This sceptic's name was Grantaire, and he was in the habit of signing himself with this rebus:
모모R. Grantaire was a man who took good care not to believe in anything.
모모Moreover, he was one of the students who had learned the most during their course at Paris; he knew that the best coffee was to be had at the Cafe Lemblin, and the best billiards at the Cafe Voltaire, that good cakes and lasses were to be found at the Ermitage, on the Boulevard du Maine, spatchcocked chickens at Mother Sauget's, excellent matelotes at the Barriere de la Cunette, and a certain thin white wine at the Barriere du Com pat.
모모He knew the best place for everything; in addition, boxing and foot-fencing and some dances; and he was a thorough single-stick player.
모모He was a tremendous drinker to boot. He was inordinately homely:
모모the prettiest boot-stitcher of that day, Irma Boissy, enraged with his homeliness, pronounced sentence on him as follows:
모모"Grantaire is impossible"; but Grantaire's fatuity was not to be disconcerted.
모모He stared tenderly and fixedly at all women, with the air of saying to them all:
모모"If I only chose!" and of trying to make his comrades believe that he was in general demand.
모모All those words:
모모rights of the people, rights of man, the social contract, the French Revolution, the Republic, democracy, humanity, civilization, religion, progress, came very near to signifying nothing whatever to Grantaire.
모모He smiled at them. Scepticism, that caries of the intelligence, had not left him a single whole idea.
모모He lived with irony.
모모This was his axiom: "There is but one certainty, my full glass."
모모He sneered at all devotion in all parties, the father as well as the brother, Robespierre junior as well as Loizerolles.
모모"They are greatly in advance to be dead," he exclaimed.
모모He said of the crucifix:
모모"There is a gibbet which has been a success."
모모A rover, a gambler, a libertine, often drunk, he displeased these young dreamers by humming incessantly: "J'aimons les filles, et j'aimons le bon vin."
모모Air:
모모Vive Henri IV.
모모However, this sceptic had one fanaticism.
모모This fanaticism was neither a dogma, nor an idea, nor an art, nor a science; it was a man:
모모Enjolras.
모모Grantaire admired, loved, and venerated Enjolras. To whom did this anarchical scoffer unite himself in this phalanx of absolute minds?
모모To the most absolute.
모모In what manner had Enjolras subjugated him?
모모By his ideas?
모모No. By his character. A phenomenon which is often observable.
모모A sceptic who adheres to a believer is as simple as the law of complementary colors.
모모That which we lack attracts us.
모모No one loves the light like the blind man. The dwarf adores the drum-major. The toad always has his eyes fixed on heaven.
모모Why?
모모In order to watch the bird in its flight. Grantaire, in whom writhed doubt, loved to watch faith soar in Enjolras. He had need of Enjolras.
모모That chaste, healthy, firm, upright, hard, candid nature charmed him, without his being clearly aware of it, and without the idea of explaining it to himself having occurred to him.
모모He admired his opposite by instinct.
모모His soft, yielding, dislocated, sickly, shapeless ideas attached themselves to Enjolras as to a spinal column.
모모His moral backbone leaned on that firmness. Grantaire in the presence of Enjolras became some one once more. He was, himself, moreover, composed of two elements, which were, to all appearance, incompatible.
모모He was ironical and cordial. His indifference loved.
모모His mind could get along without belief, but his heart could not get along without friendship. A profound contradiction; for an affection is a conviction. His nature was thus constituted.
모모There are men who seem to be born to be the reverse, the obverse, the wrong side.
모모They are Pollux, Patrocles, Nisus, Eudamidas, Ephestion, Pechmeja.
모모They only exist on condition that they are backed up with another man; their name is a sequel, and is only written preceded by the conjunction and; and their existence is not their own; it is the other side of an existence which is not theirs.
모모Grantaire was one of these men. He was the obverse of Enjolras.
모모One might almost say that affinities begin with the letters of the alphabet.
모모In the series O and P are inseparable.
모모You can, at will, pronounce O and P or Orestes and Pylades.
모모Grantaire, Enjolras' true satellite, inhabited this circle of young men; he lived there, he took no pleasure anywhere but there; he followed them everywhere.
모모His joy was to see these forms go and come through the fumes of wine.
모모They tolerated him on account of his good humor.
모모Enjolras, the believer, disdained this sceptic; and, a sober man himself, scorned this drunkard.
모모He accorded him a little lofty pity.
모모Grantaire was an unaccepted Pylades.
모모Always harshly treated by Enjolras, roughly repulsed, rejected yet ever returning to the charge, he said of Enjolras:
모모"What fine marble!"


BOOK FOURTH.--THE FRIENDS OF THE A B C
CHAPTER II 
모모BLONDEAU'S FUNERAL ORATION BY BOSSUET
모모 On a certain afternoon, which had, as will be seen hereafter, some coincidence with the events heretofore related, Laigle de Meaux was to be seen leaning in a sensual manner against the doorpost of the Cafe Musain.
모모He had the air of a caryatid on a vacation; he carried nothing but his revery, however.
모모He was staring at the Place Saint-Michel. To lean one's back against a thing is equivalent to lying down while standing erect, which attitude is not hated by thinkers.
모모Laigle de Meaux was pondering without melancholy, over a little misadventure which had befallen him two days previously at the law-school, and which had modified his personal plans for the future, plans which were rather indistinct in any case.
모모Revery does not prevent a cab from passing by, nor the dreamer from taking note of that cab.
모모Laigle de Meaux, whose eyes were straying about in a sort of diffuse lounging, perceived, athwart his somnambulism, a two-wheeled vehicle proceeding through the place, at a foot pace and apparently in indecision. For whom was this cabriolet?
모모Why was it driving at a walk? Laigle took a survey.
모모In it, beside the coachman, sat a young man, and in front of the young man lay a rather bulky hand-bag. The bag displayed to passers-by the following name inscribed in large black letters on a card which was sewn to the stuff:
모모MARIUS PONTMERCY.
모모This name caused Laigle to change his attitude.
모모He drew himself up and hurled this apostrophe at the young man in the cabriolet:--
모모"Monsieur Marius Pontmercy!"
모모The cabriolet thus addressed came to a halt.
모모The young man, who also seemed deeply buried in thought, raised his eyes:--
모모"Hey?" said he.
모모"You are M. Marius Pontmercy?"
모모"Certainly."
모모"I was looking for you," resumed Laigle de Meaux.
모모"How so?" demanded Marius; for it was he:
모모in fact, he had just quitted his grandfather's, and had before him a face which he now beheld for the first time.
모모"I do not know you."
모모"Neither do I know you," responded Laigle.
모모Marius thought he had encountered a wag, the beginning of a mystification in the open street.
모모He was not in a very good humor at the moment. He frowned.
모모Laigle de Meaux went on imperturbably:--
모모"You were not at the school day before yesterday."
모모"That is possible."
모모"That is certain."
모모"You are a student?" demanded Marius.
모모"Yes, sir.
모모Like yourself.
모모Day before yesterday, I entered the school, by chance.
모모You know, one does have such freaks sometimes. The professor was just calling the roll.
모모You are not unaware that they are very ridiculous on such occasions.
모모At the third call, unanswered, your name is erased from the list.
모모Sixty francs in the gulf."
모모Marius began to listen.
모모"It was Blondeau who was making the call.
모모You know Blondeau, he has a very pointed and very malicious nose, and he delights to scent out the absent.
모모He slyly began with the letter P. I was not listening, not being compromised by that letter.
모모The call was not going badly. No erasures; the universe was present.
모모Blondeau was grieved. I said to myself:
모모`Blondeau, my love, you will not get the very smallest sort of an execution to-day.' All at once Blondeau calls, `Marius Pontmercy!'
모모No one answers.
모모Blondeau, filled with hope, repeats more loudly:
모모`Marius Pontmercy!'
모모And he takes his pen. Monsieur, I have bowels of compassion.
모모I said to myself hastily: `Here's a brave fellow who is going to get scratched out.
모모Attention. Here is a veritable mortal who is not exact.
모모He's not a good student. Here is none of your heavy-sides, a student who studies, a greenhorn pedant, strong on letters, theology, science, and sapience, one of those dull wits cut by the square; a pin by profession. He is an honorable idler who lounges, who practises country jaunts, who cultivates the grisette, who pays court to the fair sex, who is at this very moment, perhaps, with my mistress.
모모Let us save him.
모모Death to Blondeau!'
모모At that moment, Blondeau dipped his pen in, all black with erasures in the ink, cast his yellow eyes round the audience room, and repeated for the third time: `Marius Pontmercy!'
모모I replied:
모모`Present!' This is why you were not crossed off."
모모"Monsieur!--" said Marius.
모모"And why I was," added Laigle de Meaux.
모모"I do not understand you," said Marius.
모모Laigle resumed:--
모모"Nothing is more simple.
모모I was close to the desk to reply, and close to the door for the purpose of flight.
모모The professor gazed at me with a certain intensity.
모모All of a sudden, Blondeau, who must be the malicious nose alluded to by Boileau, skipped to the letter L. L is my letter.
모모I am from Meaux, and my name is Lesgle."
모모"L'Aigle!" interrupted Marius, "what fine name!"
모모"Monsieur, Blondeau came to this fine name, and called: `Laigle!' I reply:
모모`Present!' Then Blondeau gazes at me, with the gentleness of a tiger, and says to me:
모모`lf you are Pontmercy, you are not Laigle.'
모모A phrase which has a disobliging air for you, but which was lugubrious only for me.
모모That said, he crossed me off."
모모Marius exclaimed:--
모모"I am mortified, sir--"
모모"First of all," interposed Laigle, "I demand permission to embalm Blondeau in a few phrases of deeply felt eulogium.
모모I will assume that he is dead.
모모There will be no great change required in his gauntness, in his pallor, in his coldness, and in his smell. And I say:
모모`Erudimini qui judicatis terram.
모모Here lies Blondeau, Blondeau the Nose, Blondeau Nasica, the ox of discipline, bos disciplinae, the bloodhound of the password, the angel of the roll-call, who was upright, square exact, rigid, honest, and hideous. God crossed him off as he crossed me off.'"
모모Marius resumed:--
모모"I am very sorry--"
모모"Young man," said Laigle de Meaux, "let this serve you as a lesson. In future, be exact."
모모"I really beg you a thousand pardons."
모모"Do not expose your neighbor to the danger of having his name erased again."
모모"I am extremely sorry--"
모모Laigle burst out laughing.
모모"And I am delighted.
모모I was on the brink of becoming a lawyer. This erasure saves me.
모모I renounce the triumphs of the bar. I shall not defend the widow, and I shall not attack the orphan. No more toga, no more stage.
모모Here is my erasure all ready for me. It is to you that I am indebted for it, Monsieur Pontmercy. I intend to pay a solemn call of thanks upon you.
모모Where do you live?"
모모"In this cab," said Marius.
모모"A sign of opulence," retorted Laigle calmly.
모모"I congratulate you. You have there a rent of nine thousand francs per annum."
모모At that moment, Courfeyrac emerged from the cafe.
모모Marius smiled sadly.
모모"I have paid this rent for the last two hours, and I aspire to get rid of it; but there is a sort of history attached to it, and I don't know where to go."
모모"Come to my place, sir," said Courfeyrac.
모모"I have the priority," observed Laigle, "but I have no home."
모모"Hold your tongue, Bossuet," said Courfeyrac.
모모"Bossuet," said Marius, "but I thought that your name was Laigle."
모모"De Meaux," replied Laigle; "by metaphor, Bossuet."
모모Courfeyrac entered the cab.
모모"Coachman," said he, "hotel de la Porte-Saint-Jacques."
모모And that very evening, Marius found himself installed in a chamber of the hotel de la Porte-Saint-Jacques side by side with Courfeyrac.


BOOK FOURTH.--THE FRIENDS OF THE A B C
CHAPTER III 
모모MARIUS' ASTONISHMENTS
모모 In a few days, Marius had become Courfeyrac's friend.
모모Youth is the season for prompt welding and the rapid healing of scars. Marius breathed freely in Courfeyrac's society, a decidedly new thing for him.
모모Courfeyrac put no questions to him.
모모He did not even think of such a thing.
모모At that age, faces disclose everything on the spot.
모모Words are superfluous.
모모There are young men of whom it can be said that their countenances chatter.
모모One looks at them and one knows them.
모모One morning, however, Courfeyrac abruptly addressed this interrogation to him:--
모모"By the way, have you any political opinions?"
모모"The idea!" said Marius, almost affronted by the question.
모모"What are you?"
모모"A democrat-Bonapartist."
모모"The gray hue of a reassured rat," said Courfeyrac.
모모On the following day, Courfeyrac introduced Marius at the Cafe Musain. Then he whispered in his ear, with a smile:
모모"I must give you your entry to the revolution."
모모And he led him to the hall of the Friends of the A B C. He presented him to the other comrades, saying this simple word which Marius did not understand:
모모"A pupil."
모모Marius had fallen into a wasps'-nest of wits.
모모However, although he was silent and grave, he was, none the less, both winged and armed.
모모Marius, up to that time solitary and inclined to soliloquy, and to asides, both by habit and by taste, was a little fluttered by this covey of young men around him.
모모All these various initiatives solicited his attention at once, and pulled him about. The tumultuous movements of these minds at liberty and at work set his ideas in a whirl.
모모Sometimes, in his trouble, they fled so far from him, that he had difficulty in recovering them. He heard them talk of philosophy, of literature, of art, of history, of religion, in unexpected fashion.
모모He caught glimpses of strange aspects; and, as he did not place them in proper perspective, he was not altogether sure that it was not chaos that he grasped. On abandoning his grandfather's opinions for the opinions of his father, he had supposed himself fixed; he now suspected, with uneasiness, and without daring to avow it to himself, that he was not. The angle at which he saw everything began to be displaced anew. A certain oscillation set all the horizons of his brains in motion. An odd internal upsetting.
모모He almost suffered from it.
모모It seemed as though there were no "consecrated things" for those young men.
모모Marius heard singular propositions on every sort of subject, which embarrassed his still timid mind.
모모A theatre poster presented itself, adorned with the title of a tragedy from the ancient repertory called classic:
모모"Down with tragedy dear to the bourgeois!" cried Bahorel.
모모And Marius heard Combeferre reply:--
모모"You are wrong, Bahorel.
모모The bourgeoisie loves tragedy, and the bourgeoisie must be left at peace on that score. Bewigged tragedy has a reason for its existence, and I am not one of those who, by order of AEschylus, contest its right to existence. There are rough outlines in nature; there are, in creation, ready-made parodies; a beak which is not a beak, wings which are not wings, gills which are not gills, paws which are not paws, a cry of pain which arouses a desire to laugh, there is the duck. Now, since poultry exists by the side of the bird, I do not see why classic tragedy should not exist in the face of antique tragedy."
모모Or chance decreed that Marius should traverse Rue Jean-Jacques Rousseau between Enjolras and Courfeyrac.
모모Courfeyrac took his arm:--
모모"Pay attention.
모모This is the Rue Platriere, now called Rue Jean-Jacques Rousseau, on account of a singular household which lived in it sixty years ago.
모모This consisted of Jean-Jacques and Therese. From time to time, little beings were born there.
모모Therese gave birth to them, Jean-Jacques represented them as foundlings."
모모And Enjolras addressed Courfeyrac roughly:--
모모"Silence in the presence of Jean-Jacques! I admire that man. He denied his own children, that may be; but he adopted the people."
모모Not one of these young men articulated the word:
모모The Emperor. Jean Prouvaire alone sometimes said Napoleon; all the others said "Bonaparte."
모모Enjolras pronounced it "Buonaparte."
모모Marius was vaguely surprised.
모모Initium sapientiae.


BOOK FOURTH.--THE FRIENDS OF THE A B C
CHAPTER IV 
모모THE BACK ROOM OF THE CAFE MUSAIN
모모 One of the conversations among the young men, at which Marius was present and in which he sometimes joined, was a veritable shock to his mind.
모모This took place in the back room of the Cafe Musain.
모모Nearly all the Friends of the A B C had convened that evening.
모모The argand lamp was solemnly lighted.
모모They talked of one thing and another, without passion and with noise.
모모With the exception of Enjolras and Marius, who held their peace, all were haranguing rather at hap-hazard. Conversations between comrades sometimes are subject to these peaceable tumults.
모모It was a game and an uproar as much as a conversation.
모모They tossed words to each other and caught them up in turn.
모모They were chattering in all quarters.
모모No woman was admitted to this back room, except Louison, the dish-washer of the cafe, who passed through it from time to time, to go to her washing in the "lavatory."
모모Grantaire, thoroughly drunk, was deafening the corner of which he had taken possession, reasoning and contradicting at the top of his lungs, and shouting:--
모모"I am thirsty.
모모Mortals, I am dreaming:
모모that the tun of Heidelberg has an attack of apoplexy, and that I am one of the dozen leeches which will be applied to it.
모모I want a drink.
모모I desire to forget life. Life is a hideous invention of I know not whom.
모모It lasts no time at all, and is worth nothing.
모모One breaks one's neck in living. Life is a theatre set in which there are but few practicable entrances. Happiness is an antique reliquary painted on one side only. Ecclesiastes says:
모모`All is vanity.'
모모I agree with that good man, who never existed, perhaps.
모모Zero not wishing to go stark naked, clothed himself in vanity.
모모O vanity!
모모The patching up of everything with big words! a kitchen is a laboratory, a dancer is a professor, an acrobat is a gymnast, a boxer is a pugilist, an apothecary is a chemist, a wigmaker is an artist, a hodman is an architect, a jockey is a sportsman, a wood-louse is a pterigybranche.
모모Vanity has a right and a wrong side; the right side is stupid, it is the negro with his glass beads; the wrong side is foolish, it is the philosopher with his rags.
모모I weep over the one and I laugh over the other. What are called honors and dignities, and even dignity and honor, are generally of pinchbeck.
모모Kings make playthings of human pride. Caligula made a horse a consul; Charles II.
모모made a knight of a sirloin.
모모Wrap yourself up now, then, between Consul Incitatus and Baronet Roastbeef.
모모As for the intrinsic value of people, it is no longer respectable in the least.
모모Listen to the panegyric which neighbor makes of neighbor.
모모White on white is ferocious; if the lily could speak, what a setting down it would give the dove! A bigoted woman prating of a devout woman is more venomous than the asp and the cobra.
모모It is a shame that I am ignorant, otherwise I would quote to you a mass of things; but I know nothing. For instance, I have always been witty; when I was a pupil of Gros, instead of daubing wretched little pictures, I passed my time in pilfering apples; rapin[24] is the masculine of rapine.
모모So much for myself; as for the rest of you, you are worth no more than I am. I scoff at your perfections, excellencies, and qualities. Every good quality tends towards a defect; economy borders on avarice, the generous man is next door to the prodigal, the brave man rubs elbows with the braggart; he who says very pious says a trifle bigoted; there are just as many vices in virtue as there are holes in Diogenes' cloak.
모모Whom do you admire, the slain or the slayer, Caesar or Brutus?
모모Generally men are in favor of the slayer. Long live Brutus, he has slain!
모모There lies the virtue.
모모Virtue, granted, but madness also.
모모There are queer spots on those great men. The Brutus who killed Caesar was in love with the statue of a little boy. This statue was from the hand of the Greek sculptor Strongylion, who also carved that figure of an Amazon known as the Beautiful Leg, Eucnemos, which Nero carried with him in his travels.
모모This Strongylion left but two statues which placed Nero and Brutus in accord. Brutus was in love with the one, Nero with the other.
모모All history is nothing but wearisome repetition.
모모One century is the plagiarist of the other.
모모The battle of Marengo copies the battle of Pydna; the Tolbiac of Clovis and the Austerlitz of Napoleon are as like each other as two drops of water.
모모I don't attach much importance to victory. Nothing is so stupid as to conquer; true glory lies in convincing. But try to prove something!
모모If you are content with success, what mediocrity, and with conquering, what wretchedness!
모모Alas, vanity and cowardice everywhere.
모모Everything obeys success, even grammar. Si volet usus, says Horace.
모모Therefore I disdain the human race. Shall we descend to the party at all?
모모Do you wish me to begin admiring the peoples?
모모What people, if you please?
모모Shall it be Greece? The Athenians, those Parisians of days gone by, slew Phocion, as we might say Coligny, and fawned upon tyrants to such an extent that Anacephorus said of Pisistratus:
모모"His urine attracts the bees." The most prominent man in Greece for fifty years was that grammarian Philetas, who was so small and so thin that he was obliged to load his shoes with lead in order not to be blown away by the wind. There stood on the great square in Corinth a statue carved by Silanion and catalogued by Pliny; this statue represented Episthates. What did Episthates do?
모모He invented a trip.
모모That sums up Greece and glory.
모모Let us pass on to others.
모모Shall I admire England? Shall I admire France?
모모France?
모모Why?
모모Because of Paris?
모모I have just told you my opinion of Athens.
모모England?
모모Why?
모모Because of London? I hate Carthage.
모모And then, London, the metropolis of luxury, is the headquarters of wretchedness.
모모There are a hundred deaths a year of hunger in the parish of Charing-Cross alone.
모모Such is Albion. I add, as the climax, that I have seen an Englishwoman dancing in a wreath of roses and blue spectacles.
모모A fig then for England! If I do not admire John Bull, shall I admire Brother Jonathan? I have but little taste for that slave-holding brother.
모모Take away Time is money, what remains of England?
모모Take away Cotton is king, what remains of America?
모모Germany is the lymph, Italy is the bile. Shall we go into ecstasies over Russia?
모모Voltaire admired it.
모모He also admired China.
모모I admit that Russia has its beauties, among others, a stout despotism; but I pity the despots.
모모Their health is delicate. A decapitated Alexis, a poignarded Peter, a strangled Paul, another Paul crushed flat with kicks, divers Ivans strangled, with their throats cut, numerous Nicholases and Basils poisoned, all this indicates that the palace of the Emperors of Russia is in a condition of flagrant insalubrity.
모모All civilized peoples offer this detail to the admiration of the thinker; war; now, war, civilized war, exhausts and sums up all the forms of ruffianism, from the brigandage of the Trabuceros in the gorges of Mont Jaxa to the marauding of the Comanche Indians in the Doubtful Pass. `Bah!' you will say to me, `but Europe is certainly better than Asia?' I admit that Asia is a farce; but I do not precisely see what you find to laugh at in the Grand Lama, you peoples of the west, who have mingled with your fashions and your elegances all the complicated filth of majesty, from the dirty chemise of Queen Isabella to the chamber-chair of the Dauphin.
모모Gentlemen of the human race, I tell you, not a bit of it!
모모It is at Brussels that the most beer is consumed, at Stockholm the most brandy, at Madrid the most chocolate, at Amsterdam the most gin, at London the most wine, at Constantinople the most coffee, at Paris the most absinthe; there are all the useful notions.
모모Paris carries the day, in short. In Paris, even the rag-pickers are sybarites; Diogenes would have loved to be a rag-picker of the Place Maubert better than to be a philosopher at the Piraeus.
모모Learn this in addition; the wineshops of the ragpickers are called bibines; the most celebrated are the Saucepan and The Slaughter-House. Hence, tea-gardens, goguettes, caboulots, bouibuis, mastroquets, bastringues, manezingues, bibines of the rag-pickers, caravanseries of the caliphs, I certify to you, I am a voluptuary, I eat at Richard's at forty sous a head, I must have Persian carpets to roll naked Cleopatra in!
모모Where is Cleopatra?
모모Ah!
모모So it is you, Louison.
모모Good day."
모모 [24] The slang term for a painter's assistant.
모모 Thus did Grantaire, more than intoxicated, launch into speech, catching at the dish-washer in her passage, from his corner in the back room of the Cafe Musain.
모모Bossuet, extending his hand towards him, tried to impose silence on him, and Grantaire began again worse than ever:--
모모"Aigle de Meaux, down with your paws.
모모You produce on me no effect with your gesture of Hippocrates refusing Artaxerxes' bric-a-brac. I excuse you from the task of soothing me.
모모Moreover, I am sad. What do you wish me to say to you?
모모Man is evil, man is deformed; the butterfly is a success, man is a failure.
모모God made a mistake with that animal.
모모A crowd offers a choice of ugliness. The first comer is a wretch, Femme--woman--rhymes with infame,-- infamous.
모모Yes, I have the spleen, complicated with melancholy, with homesickness, plus hypochondria, and I am vexed and I rage, and I yawn, and I am bored, and I am tired to death, and I am stupid! Let God go to the devil!"
모모"Silence then, capital R!" resumed Bossuet, who was discussing a point of law behind the scenes, and who was plunged more than waist high in a phrase of judicial slang, of which this is the conclusion:--
모모"--And as for me, although I am hardly a legist, and at the most, an amateur attorney, I maintain this:
모모that, in accordance with the terms of the customs of Normandy, at Saint-Michel, and for each year, an equivalent must be paid to the profit of the lord of the manor, saving the rights of others, and by all and several, the proprietors as well as those seized with inheritance, and that, for all emphyteuses, leases, freeholds, contracts of domain, mortgages--"
모모"Echo, plaintive nymph," hummed Grantaire.
모모Near Grantaire, an almost silent table, a sheet of paper, an inkstand and a pen between two glasses of brandy, announced that a vaudeville was being sketched out.
모모This great affair was being discussed in a low voice, and the two heads at work touched each other:
모모"Let us begin by finding names. When one has the names, one finds the subject."
모모"That is true.
모모Dictate.
모모I will write."
모모"Monsieur Dorimon."
모모"An independent gentleman?"
모모"Of course."
모모"His daughter, Celestine."
모모"--tine.
모모What next?"
모모"Colonel Sainval."
모모"Sainval is stale.
모모I should say Valsin."
모모Beside the vaudeville aspirants, another group, which was also taking advantage of the uproar to talk low, was discussing a duel. An old fellow of thirty was counselling a young one of eighteen, and explaining to him what sort of an adversary he had to deal with.
모모"The deuce!
모모Look out for yourself.
모모He is a fine swordsman.
모모His play is neat.
모모He has the attack, no wasted feints, wrist, dash, lightning, a just parade, mathematical parries, bigre! and he is left-handed."
모모In the angle opposite Grantaire, Joly and Bahorel were playing dominoes, and talking of love.
모모"You are in luck, that you are," Joly was saying.
모모"You have a mistress who is always laughing."
모모"That is a fault of hers," returned Bahorel.
모모"One's mistress does wrong to laugh.
모모That encourages one to deceive her.
모모To see her gay removes your remorse; if you see her sad, your conscience pricks you."
모모"Ingrate! a woman who laughs is such a good thing!
모모And you never quarrel!"
모모"That is because of the treaty which we have made.
모모On forming our little Holy Alliance we assigned ourselves each our frontier, which we never cross.
모모What is situated on the side of winter belongs to Vaud, on the side of the wind to Gex.
모모Hence the peace."
모모"Peace is happiness digesting."
모모"And you, Jolllly, where do you stand in your entanglement with Mamselle-- you know whom I mean?"
모모"She sulks at me with cruel patience."
모모"Yet you are a lover to soften the heart with gauntness."
모모"Alas!"
모모"In your place, I would let her alone."
모모"That is easy enough to say."
모모"And to do.
모모Is not her name Musichetta?"
모모"Yes.
모모Ah! my poor Bahorel, she is a superb girl, very literary, with tiny feet, little hands, she dresses well, and is white and dimpled, with the eyes of a fortune-teller. I am wild over her."
모모"My dear fellow, then in order to please her, you must be elegant, and produce effects with your knees.
모모Buy a good pair of trousers of double-milled cloth at Staub's. That will assist."
모모"At what price?" shouted Grantaire.
모모The third corner was delivered up to a poetical discussion. Pagan mythology was giving battle to Christian mythology. The question was about Olympus, whose part was taken by Jean Prouvaire, out of pure romanticism.
모모Jean Prouvaire was timid only in repose.
모모Once excited, he burst forth, a sort of mirth accentuated his enthusiasm, and he was at once both laughing and lyric.
모모"Let us not insult the gods," said he.
모모"The gods may not have taken their departure.
모모Jupiter does not impress me as dead. The gods are dreams, you say.
모모Well, even in nature, such as it is to-day, after the flight of these dreams, we still find all the grand old pagan myths.
모모Such and such a mountain with the profile of a citadel, like the Vignemale, for example, is still to me the headdress of Cybele; it has not been proved to me that Pan does not come at night to breathe into the hollow trunks of the willows, stopping up the holes in turn with his fingers, and I have always believed that Io had something to do with the cascade of Pissevache."
모모In the last corner, they were talking politics.
모모The Charter which had been granted was getting roughly handled.
모모Combeferre was upholding it weakly.
모모Courfeyrac was energetically making a breach in it. On the table lay an unfortunate copy of the famous Touquet Charter. Courfeyrac had seized it, and was brandishing it, mingling with his arguments the rattling of this sheet of paper.
모모"In the first place, I won't have any kings; if it were only from an economical point of view, I don't want any; a king is a parasite.
모모One does not have kings gratis.
모모Listen to this: the dearness of kings.
모모At the death of Francois I., the national debt of France amounted to an income of thirty thousand livres; at the death of Louis XIV.
모모it was two milliards, six hundred millions, at twenty-eight livres the mark, which was equivalent in 1760, according to Desmarets, to four milliards, five hundred millions, which would to-day be equivalent to twelve milliards.
모모In the second place, and no offence to Combeferre, a charter granted is but a poor expedient of civilization.
모모To save the transition, to soften the passage, to deaden the shock, to cause the nation to pass insensibly from the monarchy to democracy by the practice of constitutional fictions,--what detestable reasons all those are! No! no! let us never enlighten the people with false daylight. Principles dwindle and pale in your constitutional cellar. No illegitimacy, no compromise, no grant from the king to the people. In all such grants there is an Article 14.
모모By the side of the hand which gives there is the claw which snatches back.
모모I refuse your charter point-blank. A charter is a mask; the lie lurks beneath it. A people which accepts a charter abdicates.
모모The law is only the law when entire.
모모No! no charter!"
모모It was winter; a couple of fagots were crackling in the fireplace. This was tempting, and Courfeyrac could not resist.
모모He crumpled the poor Touquet Charter in his fist, and flung it in the fire. The paper flashed up.
모모Combeferre watched the masterpiece of Louis XVIII. burn philosophically, and contented himself with saying:--
모모"The charter metamorphosed into flame."
And sarcasms, sallies, jests, that French thing which is called entrain, and that English thing which is called humor, good and bad taste, good and bad reasons, all the wild pyrotechnics of dialogue, mounting together and crossing from all points of the room, produced a sort of merry bombardment over their heads.


BOOK FOURTH.--THE FRIENDS OF THE A B C
CHAPTER V 
모모ENLARGEMENT OF HORIZON
모모 The shocks of youthful minds among themselves have this admirable property, that one can never foresee the spark, nor divine the lightning flash.
모모What will dart out presently?
모모No one knows. The burst of laughter starts from a tender feeling.
모모At the moment of jest, the serious makes its entry.
모모Impulses depend on the first chance word.
모모The spirit of each is sovereign, jest suffices to open the field to the unexpected.
모모These are conversations with abrupt turns, in which the perspective changes suddenly. Chance is the stage-manager of such conversations.
모모A severe thought, starting oddly from a clash of words, suddenly traversed the conflict of quips in which Grantaire, Bahorel, Prouvaire, Bossuet, Combeferre, and Courfeyrac were confusedly fencing.
모모How does a phrase crop up in a dialogue?
모모Whence comes it that it suddenly impresses itself on the attention of those who hear it? We have just said, that no one knows anything about it.
모모In the midst of the uproar, Bossuet all at once terminated some apostrophe to Combeferre, with this date:--
모모"June 18th, 1815, Waterloo."
모모At this name of Waterloo, Marius, who was leaning his elbows on a table, beside a glass of water, removed his wrist from beneath his chin, and began to gaze fixedly at the audience.
모모"Pardieu!" exclaimed Courfeyrac ("Parbleu" was falling into disuse at this period), "that number 18 is strange and strikes me.
모모It is Bonaparte's fatal number.
모모Place Louis in front and Brumaire behind, you have the whole destiny of the man, with this significant peculiarity, that the end treads close on the heels of the commencement."
모모Enjolras, who had remained mute up to that point, broke the silence and addressed this remark to Combeferre:--
모모"You mean to say, the crime and the expiation."
모모This word crime overpassed the measure of what Marius, who was already greatly agitated by the abrupt evocation of Waterloo, could accept.
모모He rose, walked slowly to the map of France spread out on the wall, and at whose base an island was visible in a separate compartment, laid his finger on this compartment and said:--
모모"Corsica, a little island which has rendered France very great."
모모This was like a breath of icy air.
모모All ceased talking.
모모They felt that something was on the point of occurring.
모모Bahorel, replying to Bossuet, was just assuming an attitude of the torso to which he was addicted.
모모He gave it up to listen.
모모Enjolras, whose blue eye was not fixed on any one, and who seemed to be gazing at space, replied, without glancing at Marius:--
모모"France needs no Corsica to be great.
모모France is great because she is France.
모모Quia nomina leo."
모모Marius felt no desire to retreat; he turned towards Enjolras, and his voice burst forth with a vibration which came from a quiver of his very being:--
모모"God forbid that I should diminish France!
모모But amalgamating Napoleon with her is not diminishing her.
모모Come! let us argue the question. I am a new comer among you, but I will confess that you amaze me. Where do we stand?
모모Who are we?
모모Who are you?
모모Who am I?
모모Let us come to an explanation about the Emperor.
모모I hear you say Buonaparte, accenting the u like the Royalists.
모모I warn you that my grandfather does better still; he says Buonaparte'. I thought you were young men.
모모Where, then, is your enthusiasm?
모모And what are you doing with it?
모모Whom do you admire, if you do not admire the Emperor? And what more do you want?
모모If you will have none of that great man, what great men would you like?
모모He had everything.
모모He was complete. He had in his brain the sum of human faculties.
모모He made codes like Justinian, he dictated like Caesar, his conversation was mingled with the lightning-flash of Pascal, with the thunderclap of Tacitus, he made history and he wrote it, his bulletins are Iliads, he combined the cipher of Newton with the metaphor of Mahomet, he left behind him in the East words as great as the pyramids, at Tilsit he taught Emperors majesty, at the Academy of Sciences he replied to Laplace, in the Council of State be held his own against Merlin, he gave a soul to the geometry of the first, and to the chicanery of the last, he was a legist with the attorneys and sidereal with the astronomers; like Cromwell blowing out one of two candles, he went to the Temple to bargain for a curtain tassel; he saw everything; he knew everything; which did not prevent him from laughing good-naturedly beside the cradle of his little child; and all at once, frightened Europe lent an ear, armies put themselves in motion, parks of artillery rumbled, pontoons stretched over the rivers, clouds of cavalry galloped in the storm, cries, trumpets, a trembling of thrones in every direction, the frontiers of kingdoms oscillated on the map, the sound of a superhuman sword was heard, as it was drawn from its sheath; they beheld him, him, rise erect on the horizon with a blazing brand in his hand, and a glow in his eyes, unfolding amid the thunder, his two wings, the grand army and the old guard, and he was the archangel of war!"
모모All held their peace, and Enjolras bowed his head.
모모Silence always produces somewhat the effect of acquiescence, of the enemy being driven to the wall.
모모Marius continued with increased enthusiasm, and almost without pausing for breath:--
모모"Let us be just, my friends!
모모What a splendid destiny for a nation to be the Empire of such an Emperor, when that nation is France and when it adds its own genius to the genius of that man!
모모To appear and to reign, to march and to triumph, to have for halting-places all capitals, to take his grenadiers and to make kings of them, to decree the falls of dynasties, and to transfigure Europe at the pace of a charge; to make you feel that when you threaten you lay your hand on the hilt of the sword of God; to follow in a single man, Hannibal, Caesar, Charlemagne; to be the people of some one who mingles with your dawns the startling announcement of a battle won, to have the cannon of the Invalides to rouse you in the morning, to hurl into abysses of light prodigious words which flame forever, Marengo, Arcola, Austerlitz, Jena, Wagram! To cause constellations of victories to flash forth at each instant from the zenith of the centuries, to make the French Empire a pendant to the Roman Empire, to be the great nation and to give birth to the grand army, to make its legions fly forth over all the earth, as a mountain sends out its eagles on all sides to conquer, to dominate, to strike with lightning, to be in Europe a sort of nation gilded through glory, to sound athwart the centuries a trumpet-blast of Titans, to conquer the world twice, by conquest and by dazzling, that is sublime; and what greater thing is there?"
모모"To be free," said Combeferre.
모모Marius lowered his head in his turn; that cold and simple word had traversed his epic effusion like a blade of steel, and he felt it vanishing within him.
모모When he raised his eyes, Combeferre was no longer there.
모모Probably satisfied with his reply to the apotheosis, he had just taken his departure, and all, with the exception of Enjolras, had followed him.
모모The room had been emptied.
모모Enjolras, left alone with Marius, was gazing gravely at him.
모모Marius, however, having rallied his ideas to some extent, did not consider himself beaten; there lingered in him a trace of inward fermentation which was on the point, no doubt, of translating itself into syllogisms arrayed against Enjolras, when all of a sudden, they heard some one singing on the stairs as he went.
모모It was Combeferre, and this is what he was singing:-- "Si Cesar m'avait donne[25] La gloire et la guerre, 
모모 Et qu'il me fallait quitter L'amour de ma mere, 
모모 Je dirais au grand Cesar: Reprends ton sceptre et ton char, 
모모 J'aime mieux ma mere, o gue! 
모모 J'aime mieux ma mere!"
모모 [25] If Cesar had given me glory and war, and I were obliged to quit my mother's love, I would say to great Caesar, "Take back thy sceptre and thy chariot; I prefer the love of my mother."
모모 The wild and tender accents with which Combeferre sang communicated to this couplet a sort of strange grandeur.
모모Marius, thoughtfully, and with his eyes diked on the ceiling, repeated almost mechanically: "My mother?--"
모모At that moment, he felt Enjolras' hand on his shoulder.
모모"Citizen," said Enjolras to him, "my mother is the Republic."


BOOK FOURTH.--THE FRIENDS OF THE A B C
CHAPTER VI 
모모RES ANGUSTA
모모 That evening left Marius profoundly shaken, and with a melancholy shadow in his soul.
모모He felt what the earth may possibly feel, at the moment when it is torn open with the iron, in order that grain may be deposited within it; it feels only the wound; the quiver of the germ and the joy of the fruit only arrive later.
모모Marius was gloomy.
모모He had but just acquired a faith; must he then reject it already?
모모He affirmed to himself that he would not. He declared to himself that he would not doubt, and he began to doubt in spite of himself.
모모To stand between two religions, from one of which you have not as yet emerged, and another into which you have not yet entered, is intolerable; and twilight is pleasing only to bat-like souls.
모모Marius was clear-eyed, and he required the true light.
모모The half-lights of doubt pained him. Whatever may have been his desire to remain where he was, he could not halt there, he was irresistibly constrained to continue, to advance, to examine, to think, to march further.
모모Whither would this lead him? He feared, after having taken so many steps which had brought him nearer to his father, to now take a step which should estrange him from that father.
모모His discomfort was augmented by all the reflections which occurred to him.
모모An escarpment rose around him. He was in accord neither with his grandfather nor with his friends; daring in the eyes of the one, he was behind the times in the eyes of the others, and he recognized the fact that he was doubly isolated, on the side of age and on the side of youth.
모모He ceased to go to the Cafe Musain.
모모In the troubled state of his conscience, he no longer thought of certain serious sides of existence.
모모The realities of life do not allow themselves to be forgotten.
모모They soon elbowed him abruptly.
모모One morning, the proprietor of the hotel entered Marius' room and said to him:--
모모"Monsieur Courfeyrac answered for you."
모모"Yes."
모모"But I must have my money."
모모"Request Courfeyrac to come and talk with me," said Marius.
모모Courfeyrac having made his appearance, the host left them. Marius then told him what it had not before occurred to him to relate, that he was the same as alone in the world, and had no relatives.
모모"What is to become of you?" said Courfeyrac.
모모"I do not know in the least," replied Marius.
모모"What are you going to do?"
모모"I do not know."
모모"Have you any money?"
모모"Fifteen francs."
모모"Do you want me to lend you some?"
모모"Never."
모모"Have you clothes?"
모모"Here is what I have."
모모"Have you trinkets?"
모모"A watch."
모모"Silver?"
모모"Gold; here it is."
모모"I know a clothes-dealer who will take your frock-coat and a pair of trousers."
모모"That is good."
모모"You will then have only a pair of trousers, a waistcoat, a hat and a coat."
모모"And my boots."
모모"What! you will not go barefoot?
모모What opulence!"
모모"That will be enough."
모모"I know a watchmaker who will buy your watch."
모모"That is good."
모모"No; it is not good.
모모What will you do after that?"
모모"Whatever is necessary.
모모Anything honest, that is to say."
모모"Do you know English?"
모모"No."
모모"Do you know German?"
모모"No."
모모"So much the worse."
모모"Why?"
모모"Because one of my friends, a publisher, is getting up a sort of an encyclopaedia, for which you might have translated English or German articles.
모모It is badly paid work, but one can live by it."
모모"I will learn English and German."
모모"And in the meanwhile?"
모모"In the meanwhile I will live on my clothes and my watch."
모모The clothes-dealer was sent for.
모모He paid twenty francs for the cast-off garments.
모모They went to the watchmaker's. He bought the watch for forty-five francs.
모모"That is not bad," said Marius to Courfeyrac, on their return to the hotel, "with my fifteen francs, that makes eighty."
모모"And the hotel bill?" observed Courfeyrac.
모모"Hello, I had forgotten that," said Marius.
모모The landlord presented his bill, which had to be paid on the spot. It amounted to seventy francs.
모모"I have ten francs left," said Marius.
모모"The deuce," exclaimed Courfeyrac, "you will eat up five francs while you are learning English, and five while learning German. That will be swallowing a tongue very fast, or a hundred sous very slowly."
모모In the meantime Aunt Gillenormand, a rather good-hearted person at bottom in difficulties, had finally hunted up Marius' abode.
모모One morning, on his return from the law-school, Marius found a letter from his aunt, and the sixty pistoles, that is to say, six hundred francs in gold, in a sealed box.
모모Marius sent back the thirty louis to his aunt, with a respectful letter, in which he stated that he had sufficient means of subsistence and that he should be able thenceforth to supply all his needs. At that moment, he had three francs left.
모모His aunt did not inform his grandfather of this refusal for fear of exasperating him.
모모Besides, had he not said:
모모"Let me never hear the name of that blood-drinker again!"
모모Marius left the hotel de la Porte Saint-Jacques, as he did not wish to run in debt there. 
Index

BOOK FIFTH.--THE EXCELLENCE OF MISFORTUNE
CHAPTER I 
모모MARIUS INDIGENT 
모모Life became hard for Marius.
모모It was nothing to eat his clothes and his watch.
모모He ate of that terrible, inexpressible thing that is called de la vache enrage; that is to say, he endured great hardships and privations.
모모A terrible thing it is, containing days without bread, nights without sleep, evenings without a candle, a hearth without a fire, weeks without work, a future without hope, a coat out at the elbows, an old hat which evokes the laughter of young girls, a door which one finds locked on one at night because one's rent is not paid, the insolence of the porter and the cook-shop man, the sneers of neighbors, humiliations, dignity trampled on, work of whatever nature accepted, disgusts, bitterness, despondency.
모모Marius learned how all this is eaten, and how such are often the only things which one has to devour.
모모At that moment of his existence when a man needs his pride, because he needs love, he felt that he was jeered at because he was badly dressed, and ridiculous because he was poor. At the age when youth swells the heart with imperial pride, he dropped his eyes more than once on his dilapidated boots, and he knew the unjust shame and the poignant blushes of wretchedness. Admirable and terrible trial from which the feeble emerge base, from which the strong emerge sublime.
모모A crucible into which destiny casts a man, whenever it desires a scoundrel or a demi-god.
모모For many great deeds are performed in petty combats.
모모There are instances of bravery ignored and obstinate, which defend themselves step by step in that fatal onslaught of necessities and turpitudes. Noble and mysterious triumphs which no eye beholds, which are requited with no renown, which are saluted with no trumpet blast. Life, misfortune, isolation, abandonment, poverty, are the fields of battle which have their heroes; obscure heroes, who are, sometimes, grander than the heroes who win renown.
모모Firm and rare natures are thus created; misery, almost always a step-mother, is sometimes a mother; destitution gives birth to might of soul and spirit; distress is the nurse of pride; unhappiness is a good milk for the magnanimous.
모모There came a moment in Marius' life, when he swept his own landing, when he bought his sou's worth of Brie cheese at the fruiterer's, when he waited until twilight had fallen to slip into the baker's and purchase a loaf, which he carried off furtively to his attic as though he had stolen it.
모모Sometimes there could be seen gliding into the butcher's shop on the corner, in the midst of the bantering cooks who elbowed him, an awkward young man, carrying big books under his arm, who had a timid yet angry air, who, on entering, removed his hat from a brow whereon stood drops of perspiration, made a profound bow to the butcher's astonished wife, asked for a mutton cutlet, paid six or seven sous for it, wrapped it up in a paper, put it under his arm, between two books, and went away. It was Marius.
모모On this cutlet, which he cooked for himself, he lived for three days.
모모On the first day he ate the meat, on the second he ate the fat, on the third he gnawed the bone.
모모Aunt Gillenormand made repeated attempts, and sent him the sixty pistoles several times. Marius returned them on every occasion, saying that he needed nothing.
모모He was still in mourning for his father when the revolution which we have just described was effected within him.
모모From that time forth, he had not put off his black garments.
모모But his garments were quitting him.
모모The day came when he had no longer a coat. The trousers would go next.
모모What was to be done?
모모Courfeyrac, to whom he had, on his side, done some good turns, gave him an old coat. For thirty sous, Marius got it turned by some porter or other, and it was a new coat.
모모But this coat was green.
모모Then Marius ceased to go out until after nightfall.
모모This made his coat black. As he wished always to appear in mourning, he clothed himself with the night.
