모모It was a veteran, very much bent, extremely wrinkled, and pale, in a uniform of the Louis XV. pattern, bearing on his breast the little oval plaque of red cloth, with the crossed swords, the soldier's cross of Saint-Louis, and adorned, in addition, with a coat-sleeve, which had no arm within it, with a silver chin and a wooden leg.
모모Marius thought he perceived that this man had an extremely well satisfied air. It even struck him that the aged cynic, as he hobbled along past him, addressed to him a very fraternal and very merry wink, as though some chance had created an understanding between them, and as though they had shared some piece of good luck together. What did that relic of Mars mean by being so contented?
모모What had passed between that wooden leg and the other?
모모Marius reached a paroxysm of jealousy.--"Perhaps he was there!" he said to himself; "perhaps he saw!"--And he felt a desire to exterminate the veteran.
모모With the aid of time, all points grow dull.
모모Marius' wrath against "Ursule," just and legitimate as it was, passed off.
모모He finally pardoned her; but this cost him a great effort; he sulked for three days.
모모Nevertheless, in spite of all this, and because of all this, his passion augmented and grew to madness.

BOOK SIXTH.--THE CONJUNCTION OF TWO STARS
CHAPTER IX 
모모ECLIPSE
모모 The reader has just seen how Marius discovered, or thought that he discovered, that She was named Ursule.
모모Appetite grows with loving.
모모To know that her name was Ursule was a great deal; it was very little.
모모In three or four weeks, Marius had devoured this bliss.
모모He wanted another.
모모He wanted to know where she lived.
모모He had committed his first blunder, by falling into the ambush of the bench by the Gladiator.
모모He had committed a second, by not remaining at the Luxembourg when M. Leblanc came thither alone. He now committed a third, and an immense one.
모모He followed "Ursule."
모모She lived in the Rue de l'Ouest, in the most unfrequented spot, in a new, three-story house, of modest appearance.
모모From that moment forth, Marius added to his happiness of seeing her at the Luxembourg the happiness of following her home.
모모His hunger was increasing.
모모He knew her first name, at least, a charming name, a genuine woman's name; he knew where she lived; he wanted to know who she was.
모모One evening, after he had followed them to their dwelling, and had seen them disappear through the carriage gate, he entered in their train and said boldly to the porter:--
모모"Is that the gentleman who lives on the first floor, who has just come in?"
모모"No," replied the porter.
모모"He is the gentleman on the third floor."
모모Another step gained.
모모This success emboldened Marius.
모모"On the front?" he asked.
모모"Parbleu!" said the porter, "the house is only built on the street."
모모"And what is that gentleman's business?" began Marius again.
모모"He is a gentleman of property, sir.
모모A very kind man who does good to the unfortunate, though not rich himself."
모모"What is his name?" resumed Marius.
모모The porter raised his head and said:--
모모"Are you a police spy, sir?"
모모Marius went off quite abashed, but delighted.
모모He was getting on.
모모"Good," thought he, "I know that her name is Ursule, that she is the daughter of a gentleman who lives on his income, and that she lives there, on the third floor, in the Rue de l'Ouest."
모모On the following day, M. Leblanc and his daughter made only a very brief stay in the Luxembourg; they went away while it was still broad daylight.
모모Marius followed them to the Rue de l'Ouest, as he had taken up the habit of doing.
모모On arriving at the carriage entrance M. Leblanc made his daughter pass in first, then paused, before crossing the threshold, and stared intently at Marius.
모모On the next day they did not come to the Luxembourg.
모모Marius waited for them all day in vain.
모모At nightfall, he went to the Rue de l'Ouest, and saw a light in the windows of the third story.
모모He walked about beneath the windows until the light was extinguished.
모모The next day, no one at the Luxembourg.
모모Marius waited all day, then went and did sentinel duty under their windows.
모모This carried him on to ten o'clock in the evening.
모모His dinner took care of itself.
모모Fever nourishes the sick man, and love the lover.
모모He spent a week in this manner.
모모M. Leblanc no longer appeared at the Luxembourg.
모모Marius indulged in melancholy conjectures; he dared not watch the porte cochere during the day; he contented himself with going at night to gaze upon the red light of the windows.
모모At times he saw shadows flit across them, and his heart began to beat.
모모On the eighth day, when he arrived under the windows, there was no light in them.
모모"Hello!" he said, "the lamp is not lighted yet.
모모But it is dark. Can they have gone out?"
모모He waited until ten o'clock. Until midnight. Until one in the morning.
모모Not a light appeared in the windows of the third story, and no one entered the house.
모모He went away in a very gloomy frame of mind.
모모On the morrow,--for he only existed from morrow to morrow, there was, so to speak, no to-day for him,--on the morrow, he found no one at the Luxembourg; he had expected this.
모모At dusk, he went to the house.
모모No light in the windows; the shades were drawn; the third floor was totally dark.
모모Marius rapped at the porte cochere, entered, and said to the porter:--
모모"The gentleman on the third floor?"
모모"Has moved away," replied the porter.
모모Marius reeled and said feebly:--
모모"How long ago?"
모모"Yesterday."
모모"Where is he living now?"
모모"I don't know anything about it."
모모"So he has not left his new address?"
모모"No."
모모And the porter, raising his eyes, recognized Marius.
모모"Come!
모모So it's you!" said he; "but you are decidedly a spy then?"

BOOK SEVENTH.--PATRON MINETTE
CHAPTER I 
모모MINES AND MINERS 
모모Human societies all have what is called in theatrical parlance, a third lower floor.
모모The social soil is everywhere undermined, sometimes for good, sometimes for evil.
모모These works are superposed one upon the other.
모모There are superior mines and inferior mines. There is a top and a bottom in this obscure sub-soil, which sometimes gives way beneath civilization, and which our indifference and heedlessness trample under foot.
모모The Encyclopedia, in the last century, was a mine that was almost open to the sky.
모모The shades, those sombre hatchers of primitive Christianity, only awaited an opportunity to bring about an explosion under the Caesars and to inundate the human race with light.
모모For in the sacred shadows there lies latent light. Volcanoes are full of a shadow that is capable of flashing forth. Every form begins by being night.
모모The catacombs, in which the first mass was said, were not alone the cellar of Rome, they were the vaults of the world.
모모Beneath the social construction, that complicated marvel of a structure, there are excavations of all sorts.
모모There is the religious mine, the philosophical mine, the economic mine, the revolutionary mine. Such and such a pick-axe with the idea, such a pick with ciphers. Such another with wrath.
모모People hail and answer each other from one catacomb to another.
모모Utopias travel about underground, in the pipes. There they branch out in every direction.
모모They sometimes meet, and fraternize there.
모모Jean-Jacques lends his pick to Diogenes, who lends him his lantern.
모모Sometimes they enter into combat there. Calvin seizes Socinius by the hair.
모모But nothing arrests nor interrupts the tension of all these energies toward the goal, and the vast, simultaneous activity, which goes and comes, mounts, descends, and mounts again in these obscurities, and which immense unknown swarming slowly transforms the top and the bottom and the inside and the outside.
모모Society hardly even suspects this digging which leaves its surface intact and changes its bowels.
모모There are as many different subterranean stages as there are varying works, as there are extractions.
모모What emerges from these deep excavations? The future.
모모The deeper one goes, the more mysterious are the toilers. The work is good, up to a degree which the social philosophies are able to recognize; beyond that degree it is doubtful and mixed; lower down, it becomes terrible.
모모At a certain depth, the excavations are no longer penetrable by the spirit of civilization, the limit breathable by man has been passed; a beginning of monsters is possible.
모모The descending scale is a strange one; and each one of the rungs of this ladder corresponds to a stage where philosophy can find foothold, and where one encounters one of these workmen, sometimes divine, sometimes misshapen.
모모Below John Huss, there is Luther; below Luther, there is Descartes; below Descartes, there is Voltaire; below Voltaire, there is Condorcet; below Condorcet, there is Robespierre; below Robespierre, there is Marat; below Marat there is Babeuf. And so it goes on.
모모Lower down, confusedly, at the limit which separates the indistinct from the invisible, one perceives other gloomy men, who perhaps do not exist as yet.
모모The men of yesterday are spectres; those of to-morrow are forms.
모모The eye of the spirit distinguishes them but obscurely.
모모The embryonic work of the future is one of the visions of philosophy.
모모A world in limbo, in the state of foetus, what an unheard-of spectre!
모모Saint-Simon, Owen, Fourier, are there also, in lateral galleries.
모모Surely, although a divine and invisible chain unknown to themselves, binds together all these subterranean pioneers who, almost always, think themselves isolated, and who are not so, their works vary greatly, and the light of some contrasts with the blaze of others.
모모The first are paradisiacal, the last are tragic.
모모Nevertheless, whatever may be the contrast, all these toilers, from the highest to the most nocturnal, from the wisest to the most foolish, possess one likeness, and this is it:
모모disinterestedness.
모모Marat forgets himself like Jesus. They throw themselves on one side, they omit themselves, they think not of themselves.
모모They have a glance, and that glance seeks the absolute.
모모The first has the whole heavens in his eyes; the last, enigmatical though he may be, has still, beneath his eyelids, the pale beam of the infinite.
모모Venerate the man, whoever he may be, who has this sign--the starry eye.
모모The shadowy eye is the other sign.
모모With it, evil commences.
모모Reflect and tremble in the presence of any one who has no glance at all.
모모The social order has its black miners.
모모There is a point where depth is tantamount to burial, and where light becomes extinct.
모모Below all these mines which we have just mentioned, below all these galleries, below this whole immense, subterranean, venous system of progress and utopia, much further on in the earth, much lower than Marat, lower than Babeuf, lower, much lower, and without any connection with the upper levels, there lies the last mine. A formidable spot.
모모This is what we have designated as the le troisieme dessous.
모모It is the grave of shadows.
모모It is the cellar of the blind.
모모Inferi.
모모This communicates with the abyss.
모모MINES AND MINERS 
모모Human societies all have what is called in theatrical parlance, a third lower floor.
모모The social soil is everywhere undermined, sometimes for good, sometimes for evil.

모모At a certain depth, the excavations are no longer penetrable by the spirit of civilization, the limit breathable by man has been passed; a beginning of monsters is possible.
모모The descending scale is a strange one; and each one of the rungs of this ladder corresponds to a stage where philosophy can find foothold, and where one encounters one of these workmen, sometimes divine, sometimes misshapen.
모모Below John Huss, there is Luther; below Luther, there is Descartes; below Descartes, there is Voltaire; below Voltaire, there is Condorcet; below Condorcet, there is Robespierre; below Robespierre, there is Marat; below Marat there is Babeuf. And so it goes on.
모모Lower down, confusedly, at the limit which separates the indistinct from the invisible, one perceives other gloomy men, who perhaps do not exist as yet.
모모The men of yesterday are spectres; those of to-morrow are forms.
모모The eye of the spirit distinguishes them but obscurely.
모모The embryonic work of the future is one of the visions of philosophy.
모모A world in limbo, in the state of foetus, what an unheard-of spectre!
모모Saint-Simon, Owen, Fourier, are there also, in lateral galleries.
모모Surely, although a divine and invisible chain unknown to themselves, binds together all these subterranean pioneers who, almost always, think themselves isolated, and who are not so, their works vary greatly, and the light of some contrasts with the blaze of others.
모모The first are paradisiacal, the last are tragic.
모모Nevertheless, whatever may be the contrast, all these toilers, from the highest to the most nocturnal, from the wisest to the most foolish, possess one likeness, and this is it:
모모disinterestedness.
모모Marat forgets himself like Jesus. They throw themselves on one side, they omit themselves, they think not of themselves.
모모They have a glance, and that glance seeks the absolute.
모모The first has the whole heavens in his eyes; the last, enigmatical though he may be, has still, beneath his eyelids, the pale beam of the infinite.
모모Venerate the man, whoever he may be, who has this sign--the starry eye.
모모The shadowy eye is the other sign.
모모With it, evil commences.
모모Reflect and tremble in the presence of any one who has no glance at all.
모모The social order has its black miners.
모모There is a point where depth is tantamount to burial, and where light becomes extinct.
모모Below all these mines which we have just mentioned, below all these galleries, below this whole immense, subterranean, venous system of progress and utopia, much further on in the earth, much lower than Marat, lower than Babeuf, lower, much lower, and without any connection with the upper levels, there lies the last mine. A formidable spot.
모모This is what we have designated as the le troisieme dessous.
모모It is the grave of shadows.
모모It is the cellar of the blind.
모모Inferi.
모모This communicates with the abyss.


BOOK SEVENTH.--PATRON MINETTE CHAPTER I
CHAPTER II 
모모THE LOWEST DEPTHS
모모 There disinterestedness vanishes.
모모The demon is vaguely outlined; each one is for himself.
모모The _I_ in the eyes howls, seeks, fumbles, and gnaws.
모모The social Ugolino is in this gulf.
모모The wild spectres who roam in this grave, almost beasts, almost phantoms, are not occupied with universal progress; they are ignorant both of the idea and of the word; they take no thought for anything but the satisfaction of their individual desires. They are almost unconscious, and there exists within them a sort of terrible obliteration.
모모They have two mothers, both step-mothers, ignorance and misery.
모모They have a guide, necessity; and for all forms of satisfaction, appetite.
모모They are brutally voracious, that is to say, ferocious, not after the fashion of the tyrant, but after the fashion of the tiger.
모모From suffering these spectres pass to crime; fatal affiliation, dizzy creation, logic of darkness. That which crawls in the social third lower level is no longer complaint stifled by the absolute; it is the protest of matter. Man there becomes a dragon.
모모To be hungry, to be thirsty--that is the point of departure; to be Satan--that is the point reached. From that vault Lacenaire emerges.
모모We have just seen, in Book Fourth, one of the compartments of the upper mine, of the great political, revolutionary, and philosophical excavation.
모모There, as we have just said, all is pure, noble, dignified, honest.
모모There, assuredly, one might be misled; but error is worthy of veneration there, so thoroughly does it imply heroism.
모모The work there effected, taken as a whole has a name:
모모Progress.
모모The moment has now come when we must take a look at other depths, hideous depths.
모모There exists beneath society, we insist upon this point, and there will exist, until that day when ignorance shall be dissipated, the great cavern of evil.
모모This cavern is below all, and is the foe of all.
모모It is hatred, without exception.
모모This cavern knows no philosophers; its dagger has never cut a pen.
모모Its blackness has no connection with the sublime blackness of the inkstand.
모모Never have the fingers of night which contract beneath this stifling ceiling, turned the leaves of a book nor unfolded a newspaper.
모모Babeuf is a speculator to Cartouche; Marat is an aristocrat to Schinderhannes.
모모This cavern has for its object the destruction of everything.
모모Of everything.
모모Including the upper superior mines, which it execrates. It not only undermines, in its hideous swarming, the actual social order; it undermines philosophy, it undermines human thought, it undermines civilization, it undermines revolution, it undermines progress. Its name is simply theft, prostitution, murder, assassination. It is darkness, and it desires chaos.
모모Its vault is formed of ignorance.
모모All the others, those above it, have but one object--to suppress it. It is to this point that philosophy and progress tend, with all their organs simultaneously, by their amelioration of the real, as well as by their contemplation of the absolute.
모모Destroy the cavern Ignorance and you destroy the lair Crime.
모모Let us condense, in a few words, a part of what we have just written. The only social peril is darkness.
모모Humanity is identity.
모모All men are made of the same clay. There is no difference, here below, at least, in predestination. The same shadow in front, the same flesh in the present, the same ashes afterwards.
모모But ignorance, mingled with the human paste, blackens it.
모모This incurable blackness takes possession of the interior of a man and is there converted into evil.


BOOK SEVENTH.--PATRON MINETTE CHAPTER I
CHAPTER III 
모모BABET, GUEULEMER, CLAQUESOUS, AND MONTPARNASSE
모모 A quartette of ruffians, Claquesous, Gueulemer, Babet, and Montparnasse governed the third lower floor of Paris, from 1830 to 1835.
모모Gueulemer was a Hercules of no defined position.
모모For his lair he had the sewer of the Arche-Marion. He was six feet high, his pectoral muscles were of marble, his biceps of brass, his breath was that of a cavern, his torso that of a colossus, his head that of a bird.
모모One thought one beheld the Farnese Hercules clad in duck trousers and a cotton velvet waistcoat.
모모Gueulemer, built after this sculptural fashion, might have subdued monsters; he had found it more expeditious to be one.
모모A low brow, large temples, less than forty years of age, but with crow's-feet, harsh, short hair, cheeks like a brush, a beard like that of a wild boar; the reader can see the man before him. His muscles called for work, his stupidity would have none of it. He was a great, idle force.
모모He was an assassin through coolness. He was thought to be a creole.
모모He had, probably, somewhat to do with Marshal Brune, having been a porter at Avignon in 1815. After this stage, he had turned ruffian.
모모The diaphaneity of Babet contrasted with the grossness of Gueulemer. Babet was thin and learned.
모모He was transparent but impenetrable. Daylight was visible through his bones, but nothing through his eyes. He declared that he was a chemist.
모모He had been a jack of all trades. He had played in vaudeville at Saint-Mihiel. He was a man of purpose, a fine talker, who underlined his smiles and accentuated his gestures. His occupation consisted in selling, in the open air, plaster busts and portraits of "the head of the State."
모모In addition to this, he extracted teeth.
모모He had exhibited phenomena at fairs, and he had owned a booth with a trumpet and this poster: "Babet, Dental Artist, Member of the Academies, makes physical experiments on metals and metalloids, extracts teeth, undertakes stumps abandoned by his brother practitioners.
모모Price:
모모one tooth, one franc, fifty centimes; two teeth, two francs; three teeth, two francs, fifty.
모모Take advantage of this opportunity." This Take advantage of this opportunity meant:
모모Have as many teeth extracted as possible.
모모He had been married and had had children. He did not know what had become of his wife and children.
모모He had lost them as one loses his handkerchief.
모모Babet read the papers, a striking exception in the world to which he belonged.
모모One day, at the period when he had his family with him in his booth on wheels, he had read in the Messager, that a woman had just given birth to a child, who was doing well, and had a calf's muzzle, and he exclaimed: "There's a fortune! my wife has not the wit to present me with a child like that!"
모모Later on he had abandoned everything, in order to "undertake Paris." This was his expression.
모모Who was Claquesous?
모모He was night.
모모He waited until the sky was daubed with black, before he showed himself.
모모At nightfall he emerged from the hole whither he returned before daylight.
모모Where was this hole? No one knew.
모모He only addressed his accomplices in the most absolute darkness, and with his back turned to them.
모모Was his name Claquesous? Certainly not.
모모If a candle was brought, he put on a mask. He was a ventriloquist.
모모Babet said:
모모"Claquesous is a nocturne for two voices."
모모Claquesous was vague, terrible, and a roamer. No one was sure whether he had a name, Claquesous being a sobriquet; none was sure that he had a voice, as his stomach spoke more frequently than his voice; no one was sure that he had a face, as he was never seen without his mask.
모모He disappeared as though he had vanished into thin air; when he appeared, it was as though he sprang from the earth.
모모A lugubrious being was Montparnasse.
모모Montparnasse was a child; less than twenty years of age, with a handsome face, lips like cherries, charming black hair, the brilliant light of springtime in his eyes; he had all vices and aspired to all crimes.
모모The digestion of evil aroused in him an appetite for worse.
모모It was the street boy turned pickpocket, and a pickpocket turned garroter. He was genteel, effeminate, graceful, robust, sluggish, ferocious. The rim of his hat was curled up on the left side, in order to make room for a tuft of hair, after the style of 1829.
모모He lived by robbery with violence.
모모His coat was of the best cut, but threadbare. Montparnasse was a fashion-plate in misery and given to the commission of murders.
모모The cause of all this youth's crimes was the desire to be well-dressed. The first grisette who had said to him: "You are handsome!" had cast the stain of darkness into his heart, and had made a Cain of this Abel.
모모Finding that he was handsome, he desired to be elegant:
모모now, the height of elegance is idleness; idleness in a poor man means crime.
모모Few prowlers were so dreaded as Montparnasse.
모모At eighteen, he had already numerous corpses in his past.
모모More than one passer-by lay with outstretched arms in the presence of this wretch, with his face in a pool of blood. Curled, pomaded, with laced waist, the hips of a woman, the bust of a Prussian officer, the murmur of admiration from the boulevard wenches surrounding him, his cravat knowingly tied, a bludgeon in his pocket, a flower in his buttonhole; such was this dandy of the sepulchre.


BOOK SEVENTH.--PATRON MINETTE CHAPTER I
CHAPTER IV 
모모 These four ruffians formed a sort of Proteus, winding like a serpent among the police, and striving to escape Vidocq's indiscreet glances "under divers forms, tree, flame, fountain," lending each other their names and their traps, hiding in their own shadows, boxes with secret compartments and refuges for each other, stripping off their personalities, as one removes his false nose at a masked ball, sometimes simplifying matters to the point of consisting of but one individual, sometimes multiplying themselves to such a point that Coco-Latour himself took them for a whole throng.
모모These four men were not four men; they were a sort of mysterious robber with four heads, operating on a grand scale on Paris; they were that monstrous polyp of evil, which inhabits the crypt of society.
모모Thanks to their ramifications, and to the network underlying their relations, Babet, Gueulemer, Claquesous, and Montparnasse were charged with the general enterprise of the ambushes of the department of the Seine.
모모The inventors of ideas of that nature, men with nocturnal imaginations, applied to them to have their ideas executed.
모모They furnished the canvas to the four rascals, and the latter undertook the preparation of the scenery.
모모They labored at the stage setting.
모모They were always in a condition to lend a force proportioned and suitable to all crimes which demanded a lift of the shoulder, and which were sufficiently lucrative. When a crime was in quest of arms, they under-let their accomplices. They kept a troupe of actors of the shadows at the disposition of all underground tragedies.
모모They were in the habit of assembling at nightfall, the hour when they woke up, on the plains which adjoin the Salpetriere.
모모There they held their conferences.
모모They had twelve black hours before them; they regulated their employment accordingly.
모모Patron-Minette,--such was the name which was bestowed in the subterranean circulation on the association of these four men. In the fantastic, ancient, popular parlance, which is vanishing day by day, Patron-Minette signifies the morning, the same as entre chien et loup--between dog and wolf--signifies the evening.
모모This appellation, Patron-Minette, was probably derived from the hour at which their work ended, the dawn being the vanishing moment for phantoms and for the separation of ruffians.
모모These four men were known under this title. When the President of the Assizes visited Lacenaire in his prison, and questioned him concerning a misdeed which Lacenaire denied, "Who did it?" demanded the President.
모모Lacenaire made this response, enigmatical so far as the magistrate was concerned, but clear to the police:
모모"Perhaps it was Patron-Minette."
모모A piece can sometimes be divined on the enunciation of the personages; in the same manner a band can almost be judged from the list of ruffians composing it.
모모Here are the appellations to which the principal members of Patron-Minette answered,--for the names have survived in special memoirs.
모모Panchaud, alias Printanier, alias Bigrenaille.
모모Brujon.
모모[There was a Brujon dynasty; we cannot refrain from interpolating this word.]
모모Boulatruelle, the road-mender already introduced.
모모Laveuve.
모모Finistere.
모모Homere-Hogu, a negro.
모모Mardisoir.
모모(Tuesday evening.)
모모Depeche.
모모(Make haste.)
모모Fauntleroy, alias Bouquetiere (the Flower Girl).
모모Glorieux, a discharged convict.
모모Barrecarrosse (Stop-carriage), called Monsieur Dupont.
모모L'Esplanade-du-Sud.
모모Poussagrive.
모모Carmagnolet.
모모Kruideniers, called Bizarro.
모모Mangedentelle.
모모(Lace-eater.)
모모Les-pieds-en-l'Air. (Feet in the air.)
모모Demi-Liard, called Deux-Milliards.
모모Etc., etc.
모모We pass over some, and not the worst of them.
모모These names have faces attached.
모모They do not express merely beings, but species. Each one of these names corresponds to a variety of those misshapen fungi from the under side of civilization.
모모Those beings, who were not very lavish with their countenances, were not among the men whom one sees passing along the streets. Fatigued by the wild nights which they passed, they went off by day to sleep, sometimes in the lime-kilns, sometimes in the abandoned quarries of Montmatre or Montrouge, sometimes in the sewers. They ran to earth.
모모What became of these men?
모모They still exist.
모모They have always existed. Horace speaks of them:
모모Ambubaiarum collegia, pharmacopolae, mendici, mimae; and so long as society remains what it is, they will remain what they are.
모모Beneath the obscure roof of their cavern, they are continually born again from the social ooze. They return, spectres, but always identical; only, they no longer bear the same names and they are no longer in the same skins. The individuals extirpated, the tribe subsists.
모모They always have the same faculties.
모모From the vagrant to the tramp, the race is maintained in its purity.
모모They divine purses in pockets, they scent out watches in fobs.
모모Gold and silver possess an odor for them.
모모There exist ingenuous bourgeois, of whom it might be said, that they have a "stealable" air.
모모These men patiently pursue these bourgeois.
모모They experience the quivers of a spider at the passage of a stranger or of a man from the country.
모모These men are terrible, when one encounters them, or catches a glimpse of them, towards midnight, on a deserted boulevard. They do not seem to be men but forms composed of living mists; one would say that they habitually constitute one mass with the shadows, that they are in no wise distinct from them, that they possess no other soul than the darkness, and that it is only momentarily and for the purpose of living for a few minutes a monstrous life, that they have separated from the night.
모모What is necessary to cause these spectres to vanish?
모모Light. Light in floods.
모모Not a single bat can resist the dawn. Light up society from below.


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER I 
모모MARIUS, WHILE SEEKING A GIRL IN A BONNET, ENCOUNTERS A MAN IN A CAP 
모모Summer passed, then the autumn; winter came.
모모Neither M. Leblanc nor the young girl had again set foot in the Luxembourg garden. Thenceforth, Marius had but one thought,--to gaze once more on that sweet and adorable face.
모모He sought constantly, he sought everywhere; he found nothing.
모모He was no longer Marius, the enthusiastic dreamer, the firm, resolute, ardent man, the bold defier of fate, the brain which erected future on future, the young spirit encumbered with plans, with projects, with pride, with ideas and wishes; he was a lost dog. He fell into a black melancholy.
모모All was over.
모모Work disgusted him, walking tired him.
모모Vast nature, formerly so filled with forms, lights, voices, counsels, perspectives, horizons, teachings, now lay empty before him.
모모It seemed to him that everything had disappeared.
모모He thought incessantly, for he could not do otherwise; but he no longer took pleasure in his thoughts.
모모To everything that they proposed to him in a whisper, he replied in his darkness: "What is the use?"
모모He heaped a hundred reproaches on himself.
모모"Why did I follow her? I was so happy at the mere sight of her!
모모She looked at me; was not that immense?
모모She had the air of loving me.
모모Was not that everything?
모모I wished to have, what?
모모There was nothing after that.
모모I have been absurd.
모모It is my own fault," etc., etc. Courfeyrac, to whom he confided nothing,--it was his nature,-- but who made some little guess at everything,--that was his nature,-- had begun by congratulating him on being in love, though he was amazed at it; then, seeing Marius fall into this melancholy state, he ended by saying to him:
모모"I see that you have been simply an animal.
모모Here, come to the Chaumiere."
모모Once, having confidence in a fine September sun, Marius had allowed himself to be taken to the ball at Sceaux by Courfeyrac, Bossuet, and Grantaire, hoping, what a dream! that he might, perhaps, find her there.
모모Of course he did not see the one he sought.--"But this is the place, all the same, where all lost women are found," grumbled Grantaire in an aside.
모모Marius left his friends at the ball and returned home on foot, alone, through the night, weary, feverish, with sad and troubled eyes, stunned by the noise and dust of the merry wagons filled with singing creatures on their way home from the feast, which passed close to him, as he, in his discouragement, breathed in the acrid scent of the walnut-trees, along the road, in order to refresh his head.
모모He took to living more and more alone, utterly overwhelmed, wholly given up to his inward anguish, going and coming in his pain like the wolf in the trap, seeking the absent one everywhere, stupefied by love.
모모On another occasion, he had an encounter which produced on him a singular effect.
모모He met, in the narrow streets in the vicinity of the Boulevard des Invalides, a man dressed like a workingman and wearing a cap with a long visor, which allowed a glimpse of locks of very white hair.
모모Marius was struck with the beauty of this white hair, and scrutinized the man, who was walking slowly and as though absorbed in painful meditation.
모모Strange to say, he thought that he recognized M. Leblanc.
모모The hair was the same, also the profile, so far as the cap permitted a view of it, the mien identical, only more depressed.
모모But why these workingman's clothes? What was the meaning of this?
모모What signified that disguise? Marius was greatly astonished.
모모When he recovered himself, his first impulse was to follow the man; who knows whether he did not hold at last the clue which he was seeking?
모모In any case, he must see the man near at hand, and clear up the mystery. But the idea occurred to him too late, the man was no longer there. He had turned into some little side street, and Marius could not find him.
모모This encounter occupied his mind for three days and then was effaced.
모모"After all," he said to himself, "it was probably only a resemblance."


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER II 
모모TREASURE TROVE
모모Marius had not left the Gorbeau house.
모모He paid no attention to any one there.
모모At that epoch, to tell the truth, there were no other inhabitants in the house, except himself and those Jondrettes whose rent he had once paid, without, moreover, ever having spoken to either father, mother, or daughters.
모모The other lodgers had moved away or had died, or had been turned out in default of payment.
모모One day during that winter, the sun had shown itself a little in the afternoon, but it was the 2d of February, that ancient Candlemas day whose treacherous sun, the precursor of a six weeks' cold spell, inspired Mathieu Laensberg with these two lines, which have with justice remained classic:-- 
모모 Qu'il luise ou qu'il luiserne, 
모모 L'ours rentre dans en sa caverne.[26]
모모[26] Whether the sun shines brightly or dim, the bear returns to his cave.
모모Marius had just emerged from his:
모모night was falling.
모모It was the hour for his dinner; for he had been obliged to take to dining again, alas! oh, infirmities of ideal passions!
모모He had just crossed his threshold, where Ma'am Bougon was sweeping at the moment, as she uttered this memorable monologue:--
모모"What is there that is cheap now?
모모Everything is dear.
모모There is nothing in the world that is cheap except trouble; you can get that for nothing, the trouble of the world!"
모모Marius slowly ascended the boulevard towards the barrier, in order to reach the Rue Saint-Jacques. He was walking along with drooping head.
모모All at once, he felt some one elbow him in the dusk; he wheeled round, and saw two young girls clad in rags, the one tall and slim, the other a little shorter, who were passing rapidly, all out of breath, in terror, and with the appearance of fleeing; they had been coming to meet him, had not seen him, and had jostled him as they passed. Through the twilight, Marius could distinguish their livid faces, their wild heads, their dishevelled hair, their hideous bonnets, their ragged petticoats, and their bare feet.
모모They were talking as they ran.
모모The taller said in a very low voice:--
모모"The bobbies have come.
모모They came near nabbing me at the half-circle." The other answered:
모모"I saw them.
모모I bolted, bolted, bolted!"
모모Through this repulsive slang, Marius understood that gendarmes or the police had come near apprehending these two children, and that the latter had escaped.
모모They plunged among the trees of the boulevard behind him, and there created, for a few minutes, in the gloom, a sort of vague white spot, then disappeared.
모모Marius had halted for a moment.
모모He was about to pursue his way, when his eye lighted on a little grayish package lying on the ground at his feet.
모모He stooped and picked it up.
모모It was a sort of envelope which appeared to contain papers.
모모"Good," he said to himself, "those unhappy girls dropped it."
모모He retraced his steps, he called, he did not find them; he reflected that they must already be far away, put the package in his pocket, and went off to dine.
모모On the way, he saw in an alley of the Rue Mouffetard, a child's coffin, covered with a black cloth resting on three chairs, and illuminated by a candle.
모모The two girls of the twilight recurred to his mind.
모모"Poor mothers!" he thought.
모모"There is one thing sadder than to see one's children die; it is to see them leading an evil life."
모모Then those shadows which had varied his melancholy vanished from his thoughts, and he fell back once more into his habitual preoccupations.
모모He fell to thinking once more of his six months of love and happiness in the open air and the broad daylight, beneath the beautiful trees of Luxembourg.
모모"How gloomy my life has become!" he said to himself.
모모"Young girls are always appearing to me, only formerly they were angels and now they are ghouls."


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER III 
모모QUADRIFRONS
모모That evening, as he was undressing preparatory to going to bed, his hand came in contact, in the pocket of his coat, with the packet which he had picked up on the boulevard.
모모He had forgotten it. He thought that it would be well to open it, and that this package might possibly contain the address of the young girls, if it really belonged to them, and, in any case, the information necessary to a restitution to the person who had lost it.
모모He opened the envelope.
모모It was not sealed and contained four letters, also unsealed.
모모They bore addresses.
모모All four exhaled a horrible odor of tobacco.
모모The first was addressed:
모모"To Madame, Madame la Marquise de Grucheray, the place opposite the Chamber of Deputies, No.--"
모모Marius said to himself, that he should probably find in it the information which he sought, and that, moreover, the letter being open, it was probable that it could be read without impropriety.
모모It was conceived as follows:--
모모Madame la Marquise:
모모The virtue of clemency and piety is that which most closely unites sosiety.
모모Turn your Christian spirit and cast a look of compassion on this unfortunate Spanish victim of loyalty and attachment to the sacred cause of legitimacy, who has given with his blood, consecrated his fortune, evverything, to defend that cause, and to-day finds himself in the greatest missery. He doubts not that your honorable person will grant succor to preserve an existence exteremely painful for a military man of education and honor full of wounds, counts in advance on the humanity which animates you and on the interest which Madame la Marquise bears to a nation so unfortunate.
모모Their prayer will not be in vain, and their gratitude will preserve theirs charming souvenir.
모모My respectful sentiments, with which I have the honor to be 
모모Madame, 
모모 Don Alvares, Spanish Captain 
모모 of Cavalry, a royalist who 
모모 has take refuge in France,
모모 who finds himself on travells 
모모 for his country, and the 
모모 resources are lacking him to 
모모 continue his travells.
모모No address was joined to the signature.
모모Marius hoped to find the address in the second letter, whose superscription read: A Madame, Madame la Comtesse de Montvernet, Rue Cassette, No. 9. This is what Marius read in it:--
모모Madame la Comtesse:
모모It is an unhappy mother of a family of six children the last of which is only eight months old.
모모I sick since my last confinement, abandoned by my husband five months ago, haveing no resources in the world the most frightful indigance.
모모In the hope of Madame la Comtesse, she has the honor to be, Madame, with profound respect, 
모모 Mistress Balizard.
모모Marius turned to the third letter, which was a petition like the preceding; he read:-- 
모모Monsieur Pabourgeot, Elector, wholesale stocking merchant, 
모모 Rue Saint-Denis on the corner of the Rue aux Fers.
모모I permit myself to address you this letter to beg you to grant me the pretious favor of your simpaties and to interest yourself in a man of letters who has just sent a drama to the Theatre-Francais. The subject is historical, and the action takes place in Auvergne in the time of the Empire; the style, I think, is natural, laconic, and may have some merit.
모모There are couplets to be sung in four places.
모모The comic, the serious, the unexpected, are mingled in a variety of characters, and a tinge of romanticism lightly spread through all the intrigue which proceeds misteriously, and ends, after striking altarations, in the midst of many beautiful strokes of brilliant scenes.
모모My principal object is to satisfi the desire which progressively animates the man of our century, that is to say, the fashion, that capritious and bizarre weathervane which changes at almost every new wind.
모모In spite of these qualities I have reason to fear that jealousy, the egotism of priviliged authors, may obtaine my exclusion from the theatre, for I am not ignorant of the mortifications with which new-comers are treated.
모모Monsiuer Pabourgeot, your just reputation as an enlightened protector of men of litters emboldens me to send you my daughter who will explain our indigant situation to you, lacking bread and fire in this wynter season.
모모When I say to you that I beg you to accept the dedication of my drama which I desire to make to you and of all those that I shall make, is to prove to you how great is my ambition to have the honor of sheltering myself under your protection, and of adorning my writings with your name.
모모If you deign to honor me with the most modest offering, I shall immediately occupy myself in making a piesse of verse to pay you my tribute of gratitude. Which I shall endeavor to render this piesse as perfect as possible, will be sent to you before it is inserted at the beginning of the drama and delivered on the stage. 
모모To Monsieur
모모 and Madame Pabourgeot, 
모모My most respectful complements, 
모모 Genflot, man of letters. 
모모P. S. Even if it is only forty sous.
모모Excuse me for sending my daughter and not presenting myself, but sad motives connected with the toilet do not permit me, alas! to go out.
모모Finally, Marius opened the fourth letter.
모모The address ran: To the benevolent Gentleman of the church of Saint-Jacquesdu-haut-Pas. It contained the following lines:--
모모Benevolent Man:
모모If you deign to accompany my daughter, you will behold a misserable calamity, and I will show you my certificates.
모모At the aspect of these writings your generous soul will be moved with a sentiment of obvious benevolence, for true philosophers always feel lively emotions.
모모Admit, compassionate man, that it is necessary to suffer the most cruel need, and that it is very painful, for the sake of obtaining a little relief, to get oneself attested by the authorities as though one were not free to suffer and to die of inanition while waiting to have our misery relieved.
모모Destinies are very fatal for several and too prodigal or too protecting for others.
모모I await your presence or your offering, if you deign to make one, and I beseech you to accept the respectful sentiments with which I have the honor to be, truly magnanimous man, your very humble and very obedient servant, P. Fabantou, dramatic artist.
모모After perusing these four letters, Marius did not find himself much further advanced than before.
모모In the first place, not one of the signers gave his address.
모모Then, they seemed to come from four different individuals, Don Alveras, Mistress Balizard, the poet Genflot, and dramatic artist Fabantou; but the singular thing about these letters was, that all four were written by the same hand.
모모What conclusion was to be drawn from this, except that they all come from the same person?
모모Moreover, and this rendered the conjecture all the more probable, the coarse and yellow paper was the same in all four, the odor of tobacco was the same, and, although an attempt had been made to vary the style, the same orthographical faults were reproduced with the greatest tranquillity, and the man of letters Genflot was no more exempt from them than the Spanish captain.
모모It was waste of trouble to try to solve this petty mystery.
모모Had it not been a chance find, it would have borne the air of a mystification. Marius was too melancholy to take even a chance pleasantry well, and to lend himself to a game which the pavement of the street seemed desirous of playing with him.
모모It seemed to him that he was playing the part of the blind man in blind man's buff between the four letters, and that they were making sport of him.
모모Nothing, however, indicated that these letters belonged to the two young girls whom Marius had met on the boulevard.
모모After all, they were evidently papers of no value.
모모Marius replaced them in their envelope, flung the whole into a corner and went to bed. About seven o'clock in the morning, he had just risen and breakfasted, and was trying to settle down to work, when there came a soft knock at his door.
모모As he owned nothing, he never locked his door, unless occasionally, though very rarely, when he was engaged in some pressing work. Even when absent he left his key in the lock.
모모"You will be robbed," said Ma'am Bougon.
모모"Of what?" said Marius.
모모The truth is, however, that he had, one day, been robbed of an old pair of boots, to the great triumph of Ma'am Bougon.
모모There came a second knock, as gentle as the first.
모모"Come in," said Marius.
모모The door opened.
모모"What do you want, Ma'am Bougon?" asked Marius, without raising his eyes from the books and manuscripts on his table.
모모A voice which did not belong to Ma'am Bougon replied:--
모모"Excuse me, sir--"
모모It was a dull, broken, hoarse, strangled voice, the voice of an old man, roughened with brandy and liquor.
모모Marius turned round hastily, and beheld a young girl.


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER IV 
모모A ROSE IN MISERY
모모A very young girl was standing in the half-open door.
모모The dormer window of the garret, through which the light fell, was precisely opposite the door, and illuminated the figure with a wan light. She was a frail, emaciated, slender creature; there was nothing but a chemise and a petticoat upon that chilled and shivering nakedness. Her girdle was a string, her head ribbon a string, her pointed shoulders emerged from her chemise, a blond and lymphatic pallor, earth-colored collar-bones, red hands, a half-open and degraded mouth, missing teeth, dull, bold, base eyes; she had the form of a young girl who has missed her youth, and the look of a corrupt old woman; fifty years mingled with fifteen; one of those beings which are both feeble and horrible, and which cause those to shudder whom they do not cause to weep.
모모Marius had risen, and was staring in a sort of stupor at this being, who was almost like the forms of the shadows which traverse dreams.
모모The most heart-breaking thing of all was, that this young girl had not come into the world to be homely.
모모In her early childhood she must even have been pretty.
모모The grace of her age was still struggling against the hideous, premature decrepitude of debauchery and poverty. The remains of beauty were dying away in that face of sixteen, like the pale sunlight which is extinguished under hideous clouds at dawn on a winter's day.
모모That face was not wholly unknown to Marius.
모모He thought he remembered having seen it somewhere.
모모"What do you wish, Mademoiselle?" he asked.
모모The young girl replied in her voice of a drunken convict:--
모모"Here is a letter for you, Monsieur Marius."
모모She called Marius by his name; he could not doubt that he was the person whom she wanted; but who was this girl?
모모How did she know his name?
모모Without waiting for him to tell her to advance, she entered. She entered resolutely, staring, with a sort of assurance that made the heart bleed, at the whole room and the unmade bed.
모모Her feet were bare.
모모Large holes in her petticoat permitted glimpses of her long legs and her thin knees.
모모She was shivering.
모모She held a letter in her hand, which she presented to Marius.
모모Marius, as he opened the letter, noticed that the enormous wafer which sealed it was still moist.
모모The message could not have come from a distance.
모모He read:--
모모My amiable neighbor, young man:
모모I have learned of your goodness to me, that you paid my rent six months ago.
모모I bless you, young man. My eldest daughter will tell you that we have been without a morsel of bread for two days, four persons and my spouse ill.
모모If I am not deseaved in my opinion, I think I may hope that your generous heart will melt at this statement and the desire will subjugate you to be propitious to me by daigning to lavish on me a slight favor.
모모I am with the distinguished consideration which is due to the benefactors of humanity,-- 
모모Jondrette.
모모P.S. My eldest daughter will await your orders, dear Monsieur Marius.
모모This letter, coming in the very midst of the mysterious adventure which had occupied Marius' thoughts ever since the preceding evening, was like a candle in a cellar.
모모All was suddenly illuminated.
모모This letter came from the same place as the other four. There was the same writing, the same style, the same orthography, the same paper, the same odor of tobacco.
모모There were five missives, five histories, five signatures, and a single signer.
모모The Spanish Captain Don Alvares, the unhappy Mistress Balizard, the dramatic poet Genflot, the old comedian Fabantou, were all four named Jondrette, if, indeed, Jondrette himself were named Jondrette.
모모Marius had lived in the house for a tolerably long time, and he had had, as we have said, but very rare occasion to see, to even catch a glimpse of, his extremely mean neighbors.
모모His mind was elsewhere, and where the mind is, there the eyes are also. He had been obliged more than once to pass the Jondrettes in the corridor or on the stairs; but they were mere forms to him; he had paid so little heed to them, that, on the preceding evening, he had jostled the Jondrette girls on the boulevard, without recognizing them, for it had evidently been they, and it was with great difficulty that the one who had just entered his room had awakened in him, in spite of disgust and pity, a vague recollection of having met her elsewhere.
모모Now he saw everything clearly.
모모He understood that his neighbor Jondrette, in his distress, exercised the industry of speculating on the charity of benevolent persons, that he procured addresses, and that he wrote under feigned names to people whom he judged to be wealthy and compassionate, letters which his daughters delivered at their risk and peril, for this father had come to such a pass, that he risked his daughters; he was playing a game with fate, and he used them as the stake.
모모Marius understood that probably, judging from their flight on the evening before, from their breathless condition, from their terror and from the words of slang which he had overheard, these unfortunate creatures were plying some inexplicably sad profession, and that the result of the whole was, in the midst of human society, as it is now constituted, two miserable beings who were neither girls nor women, a species of impure and innocent monsters produced by misery.
모모Sad creatures, without name, or sex, or age, to whom neither good nor evil were any longer possible, and who, on emerging from childhood, have already nothing in this world, neither liberty, nor virtue, nor responsibility.
모모Souls which blossomed out yesterday, and are faded to-day, like those flowers let fall in the streets, which are soiled with every sort of mire, while waiting for some wheel to crush them. Nevertheless, while Marius bent a pained and astonished gaze on her, the young girl was wandering back and forth in the garret with the audacity of a spectre.
모모She kicked about, without troubling herself as to her nakedness.
모모Occasionally her chemise, which was untied and torn, fell almost to her waist.
모모She moved the chairs about, she disarranged the toilet articles which stood on the commode, she handled Marius' clothes, she rummaged about to see what there was in the corners.
모모"Hullo!" said she, "you have a mirror!"
모모And she hummed scraps of vaudevilles, as though she had been alone, frolicsome refrains which her hoarse and guttural voice rendered lugubrious.
모모An indescribable constraint, weariness, and humiliation were perceptible beneath this hardihood.
모모Effrontery is a disgrace.
모모Nothing could be more melancholy than to see her sport about the room, and, so to speak, flit with the movements of a bird which is frightened by the daylight, or which has broken its wing. One felt that under other conditions of education and destiny, the gay and over-free mien of this young girl might have turned out sweet and charming.
모모Never, even among animals, does the creature born to be a dove change into an osprey.
모모That is only to be seen among men.
모모Marius reflected, and allowed her to have her way.
모모She approached the table.
모모"Ah!" said she, "books!"
모모A flash pierced her glassy eye.
모모She resumed, and her accent expressed the happiness which she felt in boasting of something, to which no human creature is insensible:--
모모"I know how to read, I do!"
모모She eagerly seized a book which lay open on the table, and read with tolerable fluency:--
모모"--General Bauduin received orders to take the chateau of Hougomont which stands in the middle of the plain of Waterloo, with five battalions of his brigade."
모모She paused.
모모"Ah!
모모Waterloo!
모모I know about that.
모모It was a battle long ago. My father was there.
모모My father has served in the armies.
모모We are fine Bonapartists in our house, that we are!
모모Waterloo was against the English."
모모She laid down the book, caught up a pen, and exclaimed:--
모모"And I know how to write, too!"
모모She dipped her pen in the ink, and turning to Marius:--
모모"Do you want to see?
모모Look here, I'm going to write a word to show you."
모모And before he had time to answer, she wrote on a sheet of white paper, which lay in the middle of the table:
모모"The bobbies are here."
모모Then throwing down the pen:--
모모"There are no faults of orthography.
모모You can look.
모모We have received an education, my sister and I. We have not always been as we are now. We were not made--"
모모Here she paused, fixed her dull eyes on Marius, and burst out laughing, saying, with an intonation which contained every form of anguish, stifled by every form of cynicism:--
모모"Bah!"
모모And she began to hum these words to a gay air:--"J'ai faim, mon pere."
모모I am hungry, father. 
모모 Pas de fricot. I have no food. 
모모 J'ai froid, ma mere.
모모 I am cold, mother. 
모모 Pas de tricot. I have no clothes. 
모모 Grelotte,
모모Lolotte! Lolotte!
모모 Shiver, Sanglote,
모모Sob, Jacquot!"
모모Jacquot!"
모모She had hardly finished this couplet, when she exexclaimed:--
모모"Do you ever go to the play, Monsieur Marius?
모모I do.
모모I have a little brother who is a friend of the artists, and who gives me tickets sometimes.
모모But I don't like the benches in the galleries. One is cramped and uncomfortable there.
모모There are rough people there sometimes; and people who smell bad."
모모Then she scrutinized Marius, assumed a singular air and said:--
모모"Do you know, Mr. Marius, that you are a very handsome fellow?"
모모And at the same moment the same idea occurred to them both, and made her smile and him blush.
모모She stepped up to him, and laid her hand on his shoulder:
모모"You pay no heed to me, but I know you, Mr. Marius.
모모I meet you here on the staircase, and then I often see you going to a person named Father Mabeuf who lives in the direction of Austerlitz, sometimes when I have been strolling in that quarter. It is very becoming to you to have your hair tumbled thus."
모모She tried to render her voice soft, but only succeeded in making it very deep.
모모A portion of her words was lost in the transit from her larynx to her lips, as though on a piano where some notes are missing.
모모Marius had retreated gently.
모모"Mademoiselle," said he, with his cool gravity, "I have here a package which belongs to you, I think.
모모Permit me to return it to you."
모모And he held out the envelope containing the four letters.
모모She clapped her hands and exclaimed:--
모모"We have been looking everywhere for that!"
모모Then she eagerly seized the package and opened the envelope, saying as she did so:--
모모"Dieu de Dieu! how my sister and I have hunted!
모모And it was you who found it!
모모On the boulevard, was it not?
모모It must have been on the boulevard?
모모You see, we let it fall when we were running. It was that brat of a sister of mine who was so stupid.
모모When we got home, we could not find it anywhere.
모모As we did not wish to be beaten, as that is useless, as that is entirely useless, as that is absolutely useless, we said that we had carried the letters to the proper persons, and that they had said to us: `Nix.' So here they are, those poor letters!
모모And how did you find out that they belonged to me?
모모Ah! yes, the writing.
모모So it was you that we jostled as we passed last night.
모모We couldn't see. I said to my sister:
모모`Is it a gentleman?'
모모My sister said to me: `I think it is a gentleman.'"
모모In the meanwhile she had unfolded the petition addressed to "the benevolent gentleman of the church of Saint-Jacquesdu-Haut-Pas."
모모"Here!" said she, "this is for that old fellow who goes to mass. By the way, this is his hour.
모모I'll go and carry it to him. Perhaps he will give us something to breakfast on."
모모Then she began to laugh again, and added:--
모모"Do you know what it will mean if we get a breakfast today? It will mean that we shall have had our breakfast of the day before yesterday, our breakfast of yesterday, our dinner of to-day, and all that at once, and this morning.
모모Come!
모모Parbleu! if you are not satisfied, dogs, burst!"
모모This reminded Marius of the wretched girl's errand to himself. He fumbled in his waistcoat pocket, and found nothing there.
모모The young girl went on, and seemed to have no consciousness of Marius' presence.
모모"I often go off in the evening.
모모Sometimes I don't come home again.  winter, before we came here, we lived under the arches of the bridges.
모모We huddled together to keep from freezing. My little sister cried.
모모How melancholy the water is!
모모When I thought of drowning myself, I said to myself:
모모`No, it's too cold.' I go out alone, whenever I choose, I sometimes sleep in the ditches. Do you know, at night, when I walk along the boulevard, I see the trees like forks, I see houses, all black and as big as Notre Dame, I fancy that the white walls are the river, I say to myself:
모모`Why, there's water there!'
모모The stars are like the lamps in illuminations, one would say that they smoked and that the wind blew them out, I am bewildered, as though horses were breathing in my ears; although it is night, I hear hand-organs and spinning-machines, and I don't know what all.
모모I think people are flinging stones at me, I flee without knowing whither, everything whirls and whirls. You feel very queer when you have had no food."
모모And then she stared at him with a bewildered air.
모모By dint of searching and ransacking his pockets, Marius had finally collected five francs sixteen sous.
모모This was all he owned in the world for the moment.
모모"At all events," he thought, "there is my dinner for to-day, and to-morrow we will see."
모모He kept the sixteen sous, and handed the five francs to the young girl.
모모She seized the coin.
모모"Good!" said she, "the sun is shining!"
모모And, as though the sun had possessed the property of melting the avalanches of slang in her brain, she went on:--
모모"Five francs! the shiner! a monarch! in this hole!
모모Ain't this fine! You're a jolly thief!
모모I'm your humble servant!
모모Bravo for the good fellows!
모모Two days' wine! and meat! and stew! we'll have a royal feast! and a good fill!"
모모She pulled her chemise up on her shoulders, made a low bow to Marius, then a familiar sign with her hand, and went towards the door, saying:--
모모"Good morning, sir.
모모It's all right.
모모I'll go and find my old man."
모모As she passed, she caught sight of a dry crust of bread on the commode, which was moulding there amid the dust; she flung herself upon it and bit into it, muttering:--
모모"That's good! it's hard! it breaks my teeth!"
모모Then she departed.
모모A ROSE IN MISERY 
모모A very young girl was standing in the half-open door.
모모The dormer window of the garret, through which the light fell, was precisely opposite the door, and illuminated the figure with a wan light. She was a frail, emaciated, slender creature; there was nothing but a chemise and a petticoat upon that chilled and shivering nakedness. Her girdle was a string, her head ribbon a string, her pointed shoulders emerged from her chemise, a blond and lymphatic pallor, earth-colored collar-bones, red hands, a half-open and degraded mouth, missing teeth, dull, bold, base eyes; she had the form of a young girl who has missed her youth, and the look of a corrupt old woman; fifty years mingled with fifteen; one of those beings which are both feeble and horrible, and which cause those to shudder whom they do not cause to weep.

모모That face was not wholly unknown to Marius.
모모He thought he remembered having seen it somewhere.
모모"What do you wish, Mademoiselle?" he asked.
모모The young girl replied in her voice of a drunken convict:--
모모"Here is a letter for you, Monsieur Marius."
모모She called Marius by his name; he could not doubt that he was the person whom she wanted; but who was this girl?
모모How did she know his name?
모모Without waiting for him to tell her to advance, she entered. She entered resolutely, staring, with a sort of assurance that made the heart bleed, at the whole room and the unmade bed.
모모Her feet were bare.
모모Large holes in her petticoat permitted glimpses of her long legs and her thin knees.
모모She was shivering.
모모She held a letter in her hand, which she presented to Marius.
모모Marius, as he opened the letter, noticed that the enormous wafer which sealed it was still moist.
모모The message could not have come from a distance.
모모He read:--
모모My amiable neighbor, young man:
모모I have learned of your goodness to me, that you paid my rent six months ago.
모모I bless you, young man. My eldest daughter will tell you that we have been without a morsel of bread for two days, four persons and my spouse ill.
모모If I am not deseaved in my opinion, I think I may hope that your generous heart will melt at this statement and the desire will subjugate you to be propitious to me by daigning to lavish on me a slight favor.
모모I am with the distinguished consideration which is due to the benefactors of humanity,-- 
모모Jondrette.
모모P.S. My eldest daughter will await your orders, dear Monsieur Marius.
모모This letter, coming in the very midst of the mysterious adventure which had occupied Marius' thoughts ever since the preceding evening, was like a candle in a cellar.
모모All was suddenly illuminated.
모모This letter came from the same place as the other four. There was the same writing, the same style, the same orthography, the same paper, the same odor of tobacco.
모모There were five missives, five histories, five signatures, and a single signer.
모모The Spanish Captain Don Alvares, the unhappy Mistress Balizard, the dramatic poet Genflot, the old comedian Fabantou, were all four named Jondrette, if, indeed, Jondrette himself were named Jondrette.
모모Marius had lived in the house for a tolerably long time, and he had had, as we have said, but very rare occasion to see, to even catch a glimpse of, his extremely mean neighbors.
모모His mind was elsewhere, and where the mind is, there the eyes are also. He had been obliged more than once to pass the Jondrettes in the corridor or on the stairs; but they were mere forms to him; he had paid so little heed to them, that, on the preceding evening, he had jostled the Jondrette girls on the boulevard, without recognizing them, for it had evidently been they, and it was with great difficulty that the one who had just entered his room had awakened in him, in spite of disgust and pity, a vague recollection of having met her elsewhere.
모모Now he saw everything clearly.
모모He understood that his neighbor Jondrette, in his distress, exercised the industry of speculating on the charity of benevolent persons, that he procured addresses, and that he wrote under feigned names to people whom he judged to be wealthy and compassionate, letters which his daughters delivered at their risk and peril, for this father had come to such a pass, that he risked his daughters; he was playing a game with fate, and he used them as the stake.
모모Marius understood that probably, judging from their flight on the evening before, from their breathless condition, from their terror and from the words of slang which he had overheard, these unfortunate creatures were plying some inexplicably sad profession, and that the result of the whole was, in the midst of human society, as it is now constituted, two miserable beings who were neither girls nor women, a species of impure and innocent monsters produced by misery.
모모Sad creatures, without name, or sex, or age, to whom neither good nor evil were any longer possible, and who, on emerging from childhood, have already nothing in this world, neither liberty, nor virtue, nor responsibility.
모모Souls which blossomed out yesterday, and are faded to-day, like those flowers let fall in the streets, which are soiled with every sort of mire, while waiting for some wheel to crush them. Nevertheless, while Marius bent a pained and astonished gaze on her, the young girl was wandering back and forth in the garret with the audacity of a spectre.
모모She kicked about, without troubling herself as to her nakedness.
모모Occasionally her chemise, which was untied and torn, fell almost to her waist.
모모She moved the chairs about, she disarranged the toilet articles which stood on the commode, she handled Marius' clothes, she rummaged about to see what there was in the corners.
모모"Hullo!" said she, "you have a mirror!"
모모And she hummed scraps of vaudevilles, as though she had been alone, frolicsome refrains which her hoarse and guttural voice rendered lugubrious.
모모An indescribable constraint, weariness, and humiliation were perceptible beneath this hardihood.
모모Effrontery is a disgrace.
모모Nothing could be more melancholy than to see her sport about the room, and, so to speak, flit with the movements of a bird which is frightened by the daylight, or which has broken its wing. One felt that under other conditions of education and destiny, the gay and over-free mien of this young girl might have turned out sweet and charming.
모모Never, even among animals, does the creature born to be a dove change into an osprey.
모모That is only to be seen among men.
모모Marius reflected, and allowed her to have her way.
모모She approached the table.
모모"Ah!" said she, "books!"
모모A flash pierced her glassy eye.
모모She resumed, and her accent expressed the happiness which she felt in boasting of something, to which no human creature is insensible:--
모모"I know how to read, I do!"
모모She eagerly seized a book which lay open on the table, and read with tolerable fluency:--
모모"--General Bauduin received orders to take the chateau of Hougomont which stands in the middle of the plain of Waterloo, with five battalions of his brigade."
모모She paused.
모모"Ah!
모모Waterloo!
모모I know about that.
모모It was a battle long ago. My father was there.
모모My father has served in the armies.
모모We are fine Bonapartists in our house, that we are!
모모Waterloo was against the English."
모모She laid down the book, caught up a pen, and exclaimed:--
모모"And I know how to write, too!"
모모She dipped her pen in the ink, and turning to Marius:--
모모"Do you want to see?
모모Look here, I'm going to write a word to show you."
모모And before he had time to answer, she wrote on a sheet of white paper, which lay in the middle of the table:
모모"The bobbies are here."
모모Then throwing down the pen:--
모모"There are no faults of orthography.
모모You can look.
모모We have received an education, my sister and I. We have not always been as we are now. We were not made--"
모모Here she paused, fixed her dull eyes on Marius, and burst out laughing, saying, with an intonation which contained every form of anguish, stifled by every form of cynicism:--
모모"Bah!"
모모And she began to hum these words to a gay air:--"J'ai faim, mon pere."
모모I am hungry, father. 
모모 Pas de fricot. I have no food. 
모모 J'ai froid, ma mere.
모모 I am cold, mother. 
모모 Pas de tricot. I have no clothes. 
모모 Grelotte,
모모Lolotte! Lolotte!
모모 Shiver, Sanglote,
모모Sob, Jacquot!"
모모Jacquot!"
모모She had hardly finished this couplet, when she exexclaimed:--
모모"Do you ever go to the play, Monsieur Marius?
모모I do.
모모I have a little brother who is a friend of the artists, and who gives me tickets sometimes.
모모But I don't like the benches in the galleries. One is cramped and uncomfortable there.
모모There are rough people there sometimes; and people who smell bad."
모모Then she scrutinized Marius, assumed a singular air and said:--
모모"Do you know, Mr. Marius, that you are a very handsome fellow?"
모모And at the same moment the same idea occurred to them both, and made her smile and him blush.
모모She stepped up to him, and laid her hand on his shoulder:
모모"You pay no heed to me, but I know you, Mr. Marius.
모모I meet you here on the staircase, and then I often see you going to a person named Father Mabeuf who lives in the direction of Austerlitz, sometimes when I have been strolling in that quarter. It is very becoming to you to have your hair tumbled thus."
모모She tried to render her voice soft, but only succeeded in making it very deep.
모모A portion of her words was lost in the transit from her larynx to her lips, as though on a piano where some notes are missing.
모모Marius had retreated gently.
모모"Mademoiselle," said he, with his cool gravity, "I have here a package which belongs to you, I think.
모모Permit me to return it to you."
모모And he held out the envelope containing the four letters.
모모She clapped her hands and exclaimed:--
모모"We have been looking everywhere for that!"
모모Then she eagerly seized the package and opened the envelope, saying as she did so:--
모모"Dieu de Dieu! how my sister and I have hunted!
모모And it was you who found it!
모모On the boulevard, was it not?
모모It must have been on the boulevard?
모모You see, we let it fall when we were running. It was that brat of a sister of mine who was so stupid.
모모When we got home, we could not find it anywhere.
모모As we did not wish to be beaten, as that is useless, as that is entirely useless, as that is absolutely useless, we said that we had carried the letters to the proper persons, and that they had said to us: `Nix.' So here they are, those poor letters!
모모And how did you find out that they belonged to me?
모모Ah! yes, the writing.
모모So it was you that we jostled as we passed last night.
모모We couldn't see. I said to my sister:
모모`Is it a gentleman?'
모모My sister said to me: `I think it is a gentleman.'"
모모In the meanwhile she had unfolded the petition addressed to "the benevolent gentleman of the church of Saint-Jacquesdu-Haut-Pas."
모모"Here!" said she, "this is for that old fellow who goes to mass. By the way, this is his hour.
모모I'll go and carry it to him. Perhaps he will give us something to breakfast on."
모모Then she began to laugh again, and added:--
모모"Do you know what it will mean if we get a breakfast today? It will mean that we shall have had our breakfast of the day before yesterday, our breakfast of yesterday, our dinner of to-day, and all that at once, and this morning.
모모Come!
모모Parbleu! if you are not satisfied, dogs, burst!"
모모This reminded Marius of the wretched girl's errand to himself. He fumbled in his waistcoat pocket, and found nothing there.
모모The young girl went on, and seemed to have no consciousness of Marius' presence.
모모"I often go off in the evening.
모모Sometimes I don't come home again.  winter, before we came here, we lived under the arches of the bridges.
모모We huddled together to keep from freezing. My little sister cried.
모모How melancholy the water is!
모모When I thought of drowning myself, I said to myself:
모모`No, it's too cold.' I go out alone, whenever I choose, I sometimes sleep in the ditches. Do you know, at night, when I walk along the boulevard, I see the trees like forks, I see houses, all black and as big as Notre Dame, I fancy that the white walls are the river, I say to myself:
모모`Why, there's water there!'
모모The stars are like the lamps in illuminations, one would say that they smoked and that the wind blew them out, I am bewildered, as though horses were breathing in my ears; although it is night, I hear hand-organs and spinning-machines, and I don't know what all.
모모I think people are flinging stones at me, I flee without knowing whither, everything whirls and whirls. You feel very queer when you have had no food."
모모And then she stared at him with a bewildered air.
모모By dint of searching and ransacking his pockets, Marius had finally collected five francs sixteen sous.
모모This was all he owned in the world for the moment.
모모"At all events," he thought, "there is my dinner for to-day, and to-morrow we will see."
모모He kept the sixteen sous, and handed the five francs to the young girl.
모모She seized the coin.
모모"Good!" said she, "the sun is shining!"
모모And, as though the sun had possessed the property of melting the avalanches of slang in her brain, she went on:--
모모"Five francs! the shiner! a monarch! in this hole!
모모Ain't this fine! You're a jolly thief!
모모I'm your humble servant!
모모Bravo for the good fellows!
모모Two days' wine! and meat! and stew! we'll have a royal feast! and a good fill!"
모모She pulled her chemise up on her shoulders, made a low bow to Marius, then a familiar sign with her hand, and went towards the door, saying:--
모모"Good morning, sir.
모모It's all right.
모모I'll go and find my old man."
모모As she passed, she caught sight of a dry crust of bread on the commode, which was moulding there amid the dust; she flung herself upon it and bit into it, muttering:--
모모"That's good! it's hard! it breaks my teeth!"
모모Then she departed.


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER V 
모모A PROVIDENTIAL PEEP-HOLE
모모Marius had lived for five years in poverty, in destitution, even in distress, but he now perceived that he had not known real misery.
모모True misery he had but just had a view of. It was its spectre which had just passed before his eyes. In fact, he who has only beheld the misery of man has seen nothing; the misery of woman is what he must see; he who has seen only the misery of woman has seen nothing; he must see the misery of the child.
모모When a man has reached his last extremity, he has reached his last resources at the same time.
모모Woe to the defenceless beings who surround him!
모모Work, wages, bread, fire, courage, good will, all fail him simultaneously.
모모The light of day seems extinguished without, the moral light within; in these shadows man encounters the feebleness of the woman and the child, and bends them violently to ignominy.
모모Then all horrors become possible.
모모Despair is surrounded with fragile partitions which all open on either vice or crime.
모모Health, youth, honor, all the shy delicacies of the young body, the heart, virginity, modesty, that epidermis of the soul, are manipulated in sinister wise by that fumbling which seeks resources, which encounters opprobrium, and which accomodates itself to it. Fathers, mothers, children, brothers, sisters, men, women, daughters, adhere and become incorporated, almost like a mineral formation, in that dusky promiscuousness of sexes, relationships, ages, infamies, and innocences.
모모They crouch, back to back, in a sort of hut of fate. They exchange woe-begone glances.
모모Oh, the unfortunate wretches! How pale they are!
모모How cold they are!
모모It seems as though they dwelt in a planet much further from the sun than ours.
모모This young girl was to Marius a sort of messenger from the realm 
of sad shadows.
모모She revealed to him a hideous side of the night.
모모Marius almost reproached himself for the preoccupations of revery and passion which had prevented his bestowing a glance on his neighbors up to that day.
모모The payment of their rent had been a mechanical movement, which any one would have yielded to; but he, Marius, should have done better than that.
모모What! only a wall separated him from those abandoned beings who lived gropingly in the dark outside the pale of the rest of the world, he was elbow to elbow with them, he was, in some sort, the last link of the human race which they touched, he heard them live, or rather, rattle in the death agony beside him, and he paid no heed to them! Every day, every instant, he heard them walking on the other side of the wall, he heard them go, and come, and speak, and he did not even lend an ear!
모모And groans lay in those words, and he did not even listen to them, his thoughts were elsewhere, given up to dreams, to impossible radiances, to loves in the air, to follies; and all the while, human creatures, his brothers in Jesus Christ, his brothers in the people, were agonizing in vain beside him! He even formed a part of their misfortune, and he aggravated it. For if they had had another neighbor who was less chimerical and more attentive, any ordinary and charitable man, evidently their indigence would have been noticed, their signals of distress would have been perceived, and they would have been taken hold of and rescued! They appeared very corrupt and very depraved, no doubt, very vile, very odious even; but those who fall without becoming degraded are rare; besides, there is a point where the unfortunate and the infamous unite and are confounded in a single word, a fatal word, the miserable; whose fault is this?
모모And then should not the charity be all the more profound, in proportion as the fall is great?
모모While reading himself this moral lesson, for there were occasions on which Marius, like all truly honest hearts, was his own pedagogue and scolded himself more than he deserved, he stared at the wall which separated him from the Jondrettes, as though he were able to make his gaze, full of pity, penetrate that partition and warm these wretched people.
모모The wall was a thin layer of plaster upheld by lathes and beams, and, as the reader had just learned, it allowed the sound of voices and words to be clearly distinguished. Only a man as dreamy as Marius could have failed to perceive this long before.
모모There was no paper pasted on the wall, either on the side of the Jondrettes or on that of Marius; the coarse construction was visible in its nakedness.
모모Marius examined the partition, almost unconsciously; sometimes revery examines, observes, and scrutinizes as thought would.
모모All at once he sprang up; he had just perceived, near the top, close to the ceiling, a triangular hole, which resulted from the space between three lathes. The plaster which should have filled this cavity was missing, and by mounting on the commode, a view could be had through this aperture into the Jondrettes' attic.
모모Commiseration has, and should have, its curiosity.
모모This aperture formed a sort of peep-hole. It is permissible to gaze at misfortune like a traitor in order to succor it.[27]
모모[27] The peep-hole is a Judas in French.
모모Hence the half-punning allusion.
모모"Let us get some little idea of what these people are like," thought Marius, "and in what condition they are."
모모He climbed upon the commode, put his eye to the crevice, and looked.


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER VI 
모모THE WILD MAN IN HIS LAIR
모모Cities, like forests, have their caverns in which all the most wicked and formidable creatures which they contain conceal themselves.
