모모Only, in cities, that which thus conceals itself is ferocious, unclean, and petty, that is to say, ugly; in forests, that which conceals itself is ferocious, savage, and grand, that is to say, beautiful.
모모Taking one lair with another, the beast's is preferable to the man's. Caverns are better than hovels.
모모What Marius now beheld was a hovel.
모모Marius was poor, and his chamber was poverty-stricken, but as his poverty was noble, his garret was neat.
모모The den upon which his eye now rested was abject, dirty, fetid, pestiferous, mean, sordid.
모모The only furniture consisted of a straw chair, an infirm table, some old bits of crockery, and in two of the corners, two indescribable pallets; all the light was furnishd by a dormer window of four panes, draped with spiders' webs.
모모Through this aperture there penetrated just enough light to make the face of a man appear like the face of a phantom.
모모The walls had a leprous aspect, and were covered with seams and scars, like a visage disfigured by some horrible malady; a repulsive moisture exuded from them.
모모Obscene sketches roughly sketched with charcoal could be distinguished upon them.
모모The chamber which Marius occupied had a dilapidated brick pavement; this one was neither tiled nor planked; its inhabitants stepped directly on the antique plaster of the hovel, which had grown black under the long-continued pressure of feet.
모모Upon this uneven floor, where the dirt seemed to be fairly incrusted, and which possessed but one virginity, that of the broom, were capriciously grouped constellations of old shoes, socks, and repulsive rags; however, this room had a fireplace, so it was let for forty francs a year. There was every sort of thing in that fireplace, a brazier, a pot, broken boards, rags suspended from nails, a bird-cage, ashes, and even a little fire.
모모Two brands were smouldering there in a melancholy way.
모모One thing which added still more to the horrors of this garret was, that it was large.
모모It had projections and angles and black holes, the lower sides of roofs, bays, and promontories.
모모Hence horrible, unfathomable nooks where it seemed as though spiders as big as one's fist, wood-lice as large as one's foot, and perhaps even--who knows?-- some monstrous human beings, must be hiding.
모모One of the pallets was near the door, the other near the window. One end of each touched the fireplace and faced Marius.
모모In a corner near the aperture through which Marius was gazing, a colored engraving in a black frame was suspended to a nail on the wall, and at its bottom, in large letters, was the inscription:
모모THE DREAM. This represented a sleeping woman, and a child, also asleep, the child on the woman's lap, an eagle in a cloud, with a crown in his beak, and the woman thrusting the crown away from the child's head, without awaking the latter; in the background, Napoleon in a glory, leaning on a very blue column with a yellow capital ornamented with this inscription:
모모MARINGO 
모모 AUSTERLITS 
모모IENA WAGRAMME 
모모ELOT
모모Beneath this frame, a sort of wooden panel, which was no longer than it was broad, stood on the ground and rested in a sloping attitude against the wall.
모모It had the appearance of a picture with its face turned to the wall, of a frame probably showing a daub on the other side, of some pier-glass detached from a wall and lying forgotten there while waiting to be rehung.
모모Near the table, upon which Marius descried a pen, ink, and paper, sat a man about sixty years of age, small, thin, livid, haggard, with a cunning, cruel, and uneasy air; a hideous scoundrel.
모모If Lavater had studied this visage, he would have found the vulture mingled with the attorney there, the bird of prey and the pettifogger rendering each other mutually hideous and complementing each other; the pettifogger making the bird of prey ignoble, the bird of prey making the pettifogger horrible.
모모This man had a long gray beard.
모모He was clad in a woman's chemise, which allowed his hairy breast and his bare arms, bristling with gray hair, to be seen.
모모Beneath this chemise, muddy trousers and boots through which his toes projected were visible.
모모He had a pipe in his mouth and was smoking.
모모There was no bread in the hovel, but there was still tobacco.
모모He was writing probably some more letters like those which Marius had read.
모모On the corner of the table lay an ancient, dilapidated, reddish volume, and the size, which was the antique 12mo of reading-rooms, betrayed a romance.
모모On the cover sprawled the following title, printed in large capitals:
모모GOD; THE KING; HONOR AND THE LADIES; BY DUCRAY DUMINIL, 1814.
모모As the man wrote, he talked aloud, and Marius heard his words:--
모모"The idea that there is no equality, even when you are dead! Just look at Pere Lachaise!
모모The great, those who are rich, are up above, in the acacia alley, which is paved.
모모They can reach it in a carriage. The little people, the poor, the unhappy, well, what of them? they are put down below, where the mud is up to your knees, in the damp places.
모모They are put there so that they will decay the sooner! You cannot go to see them without sinking into the earth."
모모He paused, smote the table with his fist, and added, as he ground his teeth:--
모모"Oh!
모모I could eat the whole world!"
모모A big woman, who might be forty years of age, or a hundred, was crouching near the fireplace on her bare heels.
모모She, too, was clad only in a chemise and a knitted petticoat patched with bits of old cloth.
모모A coarse linen apron concealed the half of her petticoat.
모모Although this woman was doubled up and bent together, it could be seen that she was of very lofty stature. She was a sort of giant, beside her husband.
모모She had hideous hair, of a reddish blond which was turning gray, and which she thrust back from time to time, with her enormous shining hands, with their flat nails.
모모Beside her, on the floor, wide open, lay a book of the same form as the other, and probably a volume of the same romance.
모모On one of the pallets, Marius caught a glimpse of a sort of tall pale young girl, who sat there half naked and with pendant feet, and who did not seem to be listening or seeing or living.
모모No doubt the younger sister of the one who had come to his room.
모모She seemed to be eleven or twelve years of age.
모모On closer scrutiny it was evident that she really was fourteen.
모모She was the child who had said, on the boulevard the evening before: "I bolted, bolted, bolted!"
모모She was of that puny sort which remains backward for a long time, then suddenly starts up rapidly.
모모It is indigence which produces these melancholy human plants.
모모These creatures have neither childhood nor youth.
모모At fifteen years of age they appear to be twelve, at sixteen they seem twenty.
모모To-day a little girl, to-morrow a woman. One might say that they stride through life, in order to get through with it the more speedily.
모모At this moment, this being had the air of a child.
모모Moreover, no trace of work was revealed in that dwelling; no handicraft, no spinning-wheel, not a tool.
모모In one corner lay some ironmongery of dubious aspect.
모모It was the dull listlessness which follows despair and precedes the death agony.
모모Marius gazed for a while at this gloomy interior, more terrifying than the interior of a tomb, for the human soul could be felt fluttering there, and life was palpitating there.
모모The garret, the cellar, the lowly ditch where certain indigent wretches crawl at the very bottom of the social edifice, is not exactly the sepulchre, but only its antechamber; but, as the wealthy display their greatest magnificence at the entrance of their palaces, it seems that death, which stands directly side by side with them, places its greatest miseries in that vestibule.
모모The man held his peace, the woman spoke no word, the young girl did not even seem to breathe.
모모The scratching of the pen on the paper was audible.
모모The man grumbled, without pausing in his writing.
모모"Canaille! canaille! everybody is canaille!"
모모This variation to Solomon's exclamation elicited a sigh from the woman.
모모"Calm yourself, my little friend," she said.
모모"Don't hurt yourself, my dear.
모모You are too good to write to all those people, husband."
모모Bodies press close to each other in misery, as in cold, but hearts draw apart.
모모This woman must have loved this man, to all appearance, judging from the amount of love within her; but probably, in the daily and reciprocal reproaches of the horrible distress which weighed on the whole group, this had become extinct.
모모There no longer existed in her anything more than the ashes of affection for her husband.
모모Nevertheless, caressing appellations had survived, as is often the case.
모모She called him:
모모My dear, my little friend, my good man, etc., with her mouth while her heart was silent.
모모The man resumed his writing.


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER VII 
모모STRATEGY AND TACTICS
모모Marius, with a load upon his breast, was on the point of descending from the species of observatory which he had improvised, when a sound attracted his attention and caused him to remain at his post.
모모The door of the attic had just burst open abruptly.
모모The eldest girl made her appearance on the threshold.
모모On her feet, she had large, coarse, men's shoes, bespattered with mud, which had splashed even to her red ankles, and she was wrapped in an old mantle which hung in tatters.
모모Marius had not seen it on her an hour previously, but she had probably deposited it at his door, in order that she might inspire the more pity, and had picked it up again on emerging. She entered, pushed the door to behind her, paused to take breath, for she was completely breathless, then exclaimed with an expression of triumph and joy:--
모모"He is coming!"
모모The father turned his eyes towards her, the woman turned her head, the little sister did not stir.
모모"Who?" demanded her father.
모모"The gentleman!"
모모"The philanthropist?"
모모"Yes."
모모"From the church of Saint-Jacques?"
모모"Yes."
모모"That old fellow?"
모모"Yes."
모모"And he is coming?"
모모"He is following me."
모모"You are sure?"
모모"I am sure."
모모"There, truly, he is coming?"
모모"He is coming in a fiacre."
모모"In a fiacre.
모모He is Rothschild."
모모The father rose.
모모"How are you sure?
모모If he is coming in a fiacre, how is it that you arrive before him?
모모You gave him our address at least?
모모Did you tell him that it was the last door at the end of the corridor, on the right? If he only does not make a mistake!
모모So you found him at the church? Did he read my letter?
모모What did he say to you?"
모모"Ta, ta, ta," said the girl, "how you do gallop on, my good man! See here:
모모I entered the church, he was in his usual place, I made him a reverence, and I handed him the letter; he read it and said to me: `Where do you live, my child?'
모모I said:
모모`Monsieur, I will show you.' He said to me:
모모`No, give me your address, my daughter has some purchases to make, I will take a carriage and reach your house at the same time that you do.'
모모I gave him the address.
모모When I mentioned the house, he seemed surprised and hesitated for an instant, then he said: `Never mind, I will come.'
모모When the mass was finished, I watched him leave the church with his daughter, and I saw them enter a carriage.
모모I certainly did tell him the last door in the corridor, on the right."
모모"And what makes you think that he will come?"
모모"I have just seen the fiacre turn into the Rue Petit-Banquier. That is what made me run so."
모모"How do you know that it was the same fiacre?"
모모"Because I took notice of the number, so there!"
모모"What was the number?"
모모"440."
모모"Good, you are a clever girl."
모모The girl stared boldly at her father, and showing the shoes which she had on her feet:--
모모"A clever girl, possibly; but I tell you I won't put these shoes on again, and that I won't, for the sake of my health, in the first place, and for the sake of cleanliness, in the next. I don't know anything more irritating than shoes that squelch, and go ghi, ghi, ghi, the whole time.
모모I prefer to go barefoot."
모모"You are right," said her father, in a sweet tone which contrasted with the young girl's rudeness, "but then, you will not be allowed to enter churches, for poor people must have shoes to do that. One cannot go barefoot to the good God," he added bitterly.
모모Then, returning to the subject which absorbed him:--
모모"So you are sure that he will come?"
모모"He is following on my heels," said she.
모모The man started up.
모모A sort of illumination appeared on his countenance.
모모"Wife!" he exclaimed, "you hear.
모모Here is the philanthropist. Extinguish the fire."
모모The stupefied mother did not stir.
모모The father, with the agility of an acrobat, seized a broken-nosed jug which stood on the chimney, and flung the water on the brands.
모모Then, addressing his eldest daughter:--
모모"Here you!
모모Pull the straw off that chair!"
모모His daughter did not understand.
모모He seized the chair, and with one kick he rendered it seatless. His leg passed through it.
모모As he withdrew his leg, he asked his daughter:--
모모"Is it cold?"
모모"Very cold.
모모It is snowing."
모모The father turned towards the younger girl who sat on the bed near the window, and shouted to her in a thundering voice:--
모모"Quick! get off that bed, you lazy thing! will you never do anything? Break a pane of glass!"
모모The little girl jumped off the bed with a shiver.
모모"Break a pane!" he repeated.
모모The child stood still in bewilderment.
모모"Do you hear me?" repeated her father, "I tell you to break a pane!"
모모The child, with a sort of terrified obedience, rose on tiptoe, and struck a pane with her fist.
모모The glass broke and fell with a loud clatter.
모모"Good," said the father.
모모He was grave and abrupt.
모모His glance swept rapidly over all the crannies of the garret.
모모One would have said that he was a general making the final preparation at the moment when the battle is on the point of beginning.
모모The mother, who had not said a word so far, now rose and demanded in a dull, slow, languid voice, whence her words seemed to emerge in a congealed state:--
모모"What do you mean to do, my dear?"
모모"Get into bed," replied the man.
모모His intonation admitted of no deliberation.
모모The mother obeyed, and threw herself heavily on one of the pallets.
모모In the meantime, a sob became audible in one corner.
모모"What's that?" cried the father.
모모The younger daughter exhibited her bleeding fist, without quitting the corner in which she was cowering.
모모She had wounded herself while breaking the window; she went off, near her mother's pallet and wept silently.
모모It was now the mother's turn to start up and exclaim:--
모모"Just see there!
모모What follies you commit!
모모She has cut herself breaking that pane for you!"
모모"So much the better!" said the man.
모모"I foresaw that."
모모"What?
모모So much the better?" retorted his wife.
모모"Peace!" replied the father, "I suppress the liberty of the press."
모모Then tearing the woman's chemise which he was wearing, he made a strip of cloth with which he hastily swathed the little girl's bleeding wrist.
모모That done, his eye fell with a satisfied expression on his torn chemise.
모모"And the chemise too," said he, "this has a good appearance."
모모An icy breeze whistled through the window and entered the room. The outer mist penetrated thither and diffused itself like a whitish sheet of wadding vaguely spread by invisible fingers.
모모Through the broken pane the snow could be seen falling.
모모The snow promised by the Candlemas sun of the preceding day had actually come.
모모The father cast a glance about him as though to make sure that he had forgotten nothing.
모모He seized an old shovel and spread ashes over the wet brands in such a manner as to entirely conceal them.
모모Then drawing himself up and leaning against the chimney-piece:--
모모"Now," said he, "we can receive the philanthropist."


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER VIII 
모모THE RAY OF LIGHT IN THE HOVEL
모모The big girl approached and laid her hand in her father's.
모모"Feel how cold I am," said she.
모모"Bah!" replied the father, "I am much colder than that."
모모The mother exclaimed impetuously:--
모모"You always have something better than any one else, so you do! even bad things."
모모"Down with you!" said the man.
모모The mother, being eyed after a certain fashion, held her tongue.
모모Silence reigned for a moment in the hovel.
모모The elder girl was removing the mud from the bottom of her mantle, with a careless air; her younger sister continued to sob; the mother had taken the latter's head between her hands, and was covering it with kisses, whispering to her the while:--
모모"My treasure, I entreat you, it is nothing of consequence, don't cry, you will anger your father."
모모"No!" exclaimed the father, "quite the contrary! sob! sob! that's right."
모모Then turning to the elder:--
모모"There now!
모모He is not coming!
모모What if he were not to come! I shall have extinguished my fire, wrecked my chair, torn my shirt, and broken my pane all for nothing."
모모"And wounded the child!" murmured the mother.
모모"Do you know," went on the father, "that it's beastly cold in this devil's garret!
모모What if that man should not come!
모모Oh!
모모See there, you!
모모He makes us wait!
모모He says to himself:
모모`Well! they will wait for me!
모모That's what they're there for.'
모모Oh! how I hate them, and with what joy, jubilation, enthusiasm, and satisfaction I could strangle all those rich folks! all those rich folks! These men who pretend to be charitable, who put on airs, who go to mass, who make presents to the priesthood, preachy, preachy, in their skullcaps, and who think themselves above us, and who come for the purpose of humiliating us, and to bring us `clothes,' as they say! old duds that are not worth four sous!
모모And bread! That's not what I want, pack of rascals that they are, it's money! Ah! money!
모모Never!
모모Because they say that we would go off and drink it up, and that we are drunkards and idlers!
모모And they! What are they, then, and what have they been in their time!
모모Thieves! They never could have become rich otherwise!
모모Oh!
모모Society ought to be grasped by the four corners of the cloth and tossed into the air, all of it!
모모It would all be smashed, very likely, but at least, no one would have anything, and there would be that much gained! But what is that blockhead of a benevolent gentleman doing? Will he come?
모모Perhaps the animal has forgotten the address! I'll bet that that old beast--"
모모At that moment there came a light tap at the door, the man rushed to it and opened it, exclaiming, amid profound bows and smiles of adoration:--
모모"Enter, sir!
모모Deign to enter, most respected benefactor, and your charming young lady, also."
모모A man of ripe age and a young girl made their appearance on the threshold of the attic.
모모Marius had not quitted his post.
모모His feelings for the moment surpassed the powers of the human tongue.
모모It was She!
모모Whoever has loved knows all the radiant meanings contained in those three letters of that word:
모모She.
모모It was certainly she.
모모Marius could hardly distinguish her through the luminous vapor which had suddenly spread before his eyes. It was that sweet, absent being, that star which had beamed upon him for six months; it was those eyes, that brow, that mouth, that lovely vanished face which had created night by its departure. The vision had been eclipsed, now it reappeared.
모모It reappeared in that gloom, in that garret, in that misshapen attic, in all that horror.
모모Marius shuddered in dismay.
모모What!
모모It was she!
모모The palpitations of his heart troubled his sight.
모모He felt that he was on the brink of bursting into tears!
모모What!
모모He beheld her again at last, after having sought her so long!
모모It seemed to him that he had lost his soul, and that he had just found it again.
모모She was the same as ever, only a little pale; her delicate face was framed in a bonnet of violet velvet, her figure was concealed beneath a pelisse of black satin.
모모Beneath her long dress, a glimpse could be caught of her tiny foot shod in a silken boot.
모모She was still accompanied by M. Leblanc.
모모She had taken a few steps into the room, and had deposited a tolerably bulky parcel on the table.
모모The eldest Jondrette girl had retired behind the door, and was staring with sombre eyes at that velvet bonnet, that silk mantle, and that charming, happy face.


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER IX 
모모JONDRETTE COMES NEAR WEEPING
모모The hovel was so dark, that people coming from without felt on entering it the effect produced on entering a cellar. The two new-comers advanced, therefore, with a certain hesitation, being hardly able to distinguish the vague forms surrounding them, while they could be clearly seen and scrutinized by the eyes of the inhabitants of the garret, who were accustomed to this twilight.
모모M. Leblanc approached, with his sad but kindly look, and said to Jondrette the father:--
모모"Monsieur, in this package you will find some new clothes and some woollen stockings and blankets."
모모"Our angelic benefactor overwhelms us," said Jondrette, bowing to the very earth.
모모Then, bending down to the ear of his eldest daughter, while the two visitors were engaged in examining this lamentable interior, he added in a low and rapid voice:--
모모"Hey?
모모What did I say?
모모Duds!
모모No money!
모모They are all alike! By the way, how was the letter to that old blockhead signed?"
모모"Fabantou," replied the girl.
모모"The dramatic artist, good!"
모모It was lucky for Jondrette, that this had occurred to him, for at the very moment, M. Leblanc turned to him, and said to him with the air of a person who is seeking to recall a name:--
모모"I see that you are greatly to be pitied, Monsieur--"
모모"Fabantou," replied Jondrette quickly.
모모"Monsieur Fabantou, yes, that is it.
모모I remember."
모모"Dramatic artist, sir, and one who has had some success."
모모Here Jondrette evidently judged the moment propitious for capturing the "philanthropist."
모모He exclaimed with an accent which smacked at the same time of the vainglory of the mountebank at fairs, and the humility of the mendicant on the highway:--
모모"A pupil of Talma!
모모Sir!
모모I am a pupil of Talma!
모모Fortune formerly smiled on me--Alas!
모모Now it is misfortune's turn.
모모You see, my benefactor, no bread, no fire.
모모My poor babes have no fire! My only chair has no seat!
모모A broken pane!
모모And in such weather! My spouse in bed!
모모Ill!"
모모"Poor woman!" said M. Leblanc.
모모"My child wounded!" added Jondrette.
모모The child, diverted by the arrival of the strangers, had fallen to contemplating "the young lady," and had ceased to sob.
모모"Cry! bawl!" said Jondrette to her in a low voice.
모모At the same time he pinched her sore hand.
모모All this was done with the talent of a juggler.
모모The little girl gave vent to loud shrieks.
모모The adorable young girl, whom Marius, in his heart, called "his Ursule," approached her hastily.
모모"Poor, dear child!" said she.
모모"You see, my beautiful young lady," pursued Jondrette "her bleeding wrist!
모모It came through an accident while working at a machine to earn six sous a day.
모모It may be necessary to cut off her arm."
모모"Really?" said the old gentleman, in alarm.
모모The little girl, taking this seriously, fell to sobbing more violently than ever.
모모"Alas! yes, my benefactor!" replied the father.
모모For several minutes, Jondrette had been scrutinizing "the benefactor" in a singular fashion.
모모As he spoke, he seemed to be examining the other attentively, as though seeking to summon up his recollections. All at once, profiting by a moment when the new-comers were questioning the child with interest as to her injured hand, he passed near his wife, who lay in her bed with a stupid and dejected air, and said to her in a rapid but very low tone:--
모모"Take a look at that man!"
모모Then, turning to M. Leblanc, and continuing his lamentations:--
모모"You see, sir!
모모All the clothing that I have is my wife's chemise! And all torn at that!
모모In the depths of winter!
모모I can't go out for lack of a coat.
모모If I had a coat of any sort, I would go and see Mademoiselle Mars, who knows me and is very fond of me.
모모Does she not still reside in the Rue de la Tour-des-Dames? Do you know, sir? We played together in the provinces.
모모I shared her laurels. Celimene would come to my succor, sir!
모모Elmire would bestow alms on Belisaire!
모모But no, nothing!
모모And not a sou in the house! My wife ill, and not a sou!
모모My daughter dangerously injured, not a sou!
모모My wife suffers from fits of suffocation.
모모It comes from her age, and besides, her nervous system is affected. She ought to have assistance, and my daughter also!
모모But the doctor! But the apothecary!
모모How am I to pay them?
모모I would kneel to a penny, sir!
모모Such is the condition to which the arts are reduced. And do you know, my charming young lady, and you, my generous protector, do you know, you who breathe forth virtue and goodness, and who perfume that church where my daughter sees you every day when she says her prayers?--For I have brought up my children religiously, sir. I did not want them to take to the theatre.
모모Ah! the hussies! If I catch them tripping!
모모I do not jest, that I don't! I read them lessons on honor, on morality, on virtue!
모모Ask them!
모모They have got to walk straight.
모모They are none of your unhappy wretches who begin by having no family, and end by espousing the public. One is Mamselle Nobody, and one becomes Madame Everybody. Deuce take it!
모모None of that in the Fabantou family!
모모I mean to bring them up virtuously, and they shall be honest, and nice, and believe in God, by the sacred name!
모모Well, sir, my worthy sir, do you know what is going to happen to-morrow? To-morrow is the fourth day of February, the fatal day, the last day of grace allowed me by my landlord; if by this evening I have not paid my rent, to-morrow my oldest daughter, my spouse with her fever, my child with her wound,-- we shall all four be turned out of here and thrown into the street, on the boulevard, without shelter, in the rain, in the snow. There, sir.
모모I owe for four quarters--a whole year! that is to say, sixty francs."
모모Jondrette lied.
모모Four quarters would have amounted to only forty francs, and he could not owe four, because six months had not elapsed since Marius had paid for two.
모모M. Leblanc drew five francs from his pocket and threw them on the table.
모모Jondrette found time to mutter in the ear of his eldest daughter:--
모모"The scoundrel!
모모What does he think I can do with his five francs? That won't pay me for my chair and pane of glass!
모모That's what comes of incurring expenses!"
모모In the meanwhile, M. Leblanc had removed the large brown great-coat which he wore over his blue coat, and had thrown it over the back of the chair.
모모"Monsieur Fabantou," he said, "these five francs are all that I have about me, but I shall now take my daughter home, and I will return this evening,--it is this evening that you must pay, is it not?"
모모Jondrette's face lighted up with a strange expression. He replied vivaciously:--
모모"Yes, respected sir.
모모At eight o'clock, I must be at my landlord's."
모모"I will be here at six, and I will fetch you the sixty francs."
모모"My benefactor!" exclaimed Jondrette, overwhelmed.
모모And he added, in a low tone:
모모"Take a good look at him, wife!"
모모M. Leblanc had taken the arm of the young girl, once more, and had turned towards the door.
모모"Farewell until this evening, my friends!" said he.
모모"Six o'clock?" said Jondrette.
모모"Six o'clock precisely."
모모At that moment, the overcoat lying on the chair caught the eye of the elder Jondrette girl.
모모"You are forgetting your coat, sir," said she.
모모Jondrette darted an annihilating look at his daughter, accompanied by a formidable shrug of the shoulders.
모모M. Leblanc turned back and said, with a smile:--
모모"I have not forgotten it, I am leaving it."
모모"O my protector!" said Jondrette, "my august benefactor, I melt into tears!
모모Permit me to accompany you to your carriage."
모모"If you come out," answered M. Leblanc, "put on this coat. It really is very cold."
모모Jondrette did not need to be told twice.
모모He hastily donned the brown great-coat. And all three went out, Jondrette preceding the two strangers.


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER X 
모모TARIFF OF LICENSED CABS:
모모TWO FRANCS AN HOUR
모모Marius had lost nothing of this entire scene, and yet, in reality, had seen nothing.
모모His eyes had remained fixed on the young girl, his heart had, so to speak, seized her and wholly enveloped her from the moment of her very first step in that garret.
모모During her entire stay there, he had lived that life of ecstasy which suspends material perceptions and precipitates the whole soul on a single point. He contemplated, not that girl, but that light which wore a satin pelisse and a velvet bonnet.
모모The star Sirius might have entered the room, and he would not have been any more dazzled.
모모While the young girl was engaged in opening the package, unfolding the clothing and the blankets, questioning the sick mother kindly, and the little injured girl tenderly, he watched her every movement, he sought to catch her words.
모모He knew her eyes, her brow, her beauty, her form, her walk, he did not know the sound of her voice. He had once fancied that he had caught a few words at the Luxembourg, but he was not absolutely sure of the fact.
모모He would have given ten years of his life to hear it, in order that he might bear away in his soul a little of that music.
모모But everything was drowned in the lamentable exclamations and trumpet bursts of Jondrette. This added a touch of genuine wrath to Marius' ecstasy.
모모He devoured her with his eyes.
모모He could not believe that it really was that divine creature whom he saw in the midst of those vile creatures in that monstrous lair.
모모It seemed to him that he beheld a humming-bird in the midst of toads.
모모When she took her departure, he had but one thought, to follow her, to cling to her trace, not to quit her until he learned where she lived, not to lose her again, at least, after having so miraculously re-discovered her.
모모He leaped down from the commode and seized his hat.
모모As he laid his hand on the lock of the door, and was on the point of opening it, a sudden reflection caused him to pause. The corridor was long, the staircase steep, Jondrette was talkative, M. Leblanc had, no doubt, not yet regained his carriage; if, on turning round in the corridor, or on the staircase, he were to catch sight of him, Marius, in that house, he would, evidently, take the alarm, and find means to escape from him again, and this time it would be final.
모모What was he to do?
모모Should he wait a little?
모모But while he was waiting, the carriage might drive off.
모모Marius was perplexed. At last he accepted the risk and quitted his room.
모모There was no one in the corridor.
모모He hastened to the stairs. There was no one on the staircase.
모모He descended in all haste, and reached the boulevard in time to see a fiacre turning the corner of the Rue du Petit-Banquier, on its way back to Paris.
모모Marius rushed headlong in that direction.
모모On arriving at the angle of the boulevard, he caught sight of the fiacre again, rapidly descending the Rue Mouffetard; the carriage was already a long way off, and there was no means of overtaking it; what! run after it? Impossible; and besides, the people in the carriage would assuredly notice an individual running at full speed in pursuit of a fiacre, and the father would recognize him.
모모At that moment, wonderful and unprecedented good luck, Marius perceived an empty cab passing along the boulevard.
모모There was but one thing to be done, to jump into this cab and follow the fiacre.
모모That was sure, efficacious, and free from danger.
모모Marius made the driver a sign to halt, and called to him:--
모모"By the hour?"
모모Marius wore no cravat, he had on his working-coat, which was destitute of buttons, his shirt was torn along one of the plaits on the bosom.
모모The driver halted, winked, and held out his left hand to Marius, rubbing his forefinger gently with his thumb.
모모"What is it?" said Marius.
모모"Pay in advance," said the coachman.
모모Marius recollected that he had but sixteen sous about him.
모모"How much?" he demanded.
모모"Forty sous."
모모"I will pay on my return."
모모The driver's only reply was to whistle the air of La Palisse and to whip up his horse.
모모Marius stared at the retreating cabriolet with a bewildered air. For the lack of four and twenty sous, he was losing his joy, his happiness, his love!
모모He had seen, and he was becoming blind again.
모모He reflected bitterly, and it must be confessed, with profound regret, on the five francs which he had bestowed, that very morning, on that miserable girl.
모모If he had had those five francs, he would have been saved, he would have been born again, he would have emerged from the limbo and darkness, he would have made his escape from isolation and spleen, from his widowed state; he might have re-knotted the black thread of his destiny to that beautiful golden thread, which had just floated before his eyes and had broken at the same instant, once more!
모모He returned to his hovel in despair.
모모He might have told himself that M. Leblanc had promised to return in the evening, and that all he had to do was to set about the matter more skilfully, so that he might follow him on that occasion; but, in his contemplation, it is doubtful whether he had heard this.
모모As he was on the point of mounting the staircase, he perceived, on the other side of the boulevard, near the deserted wall skirting the Rue De la Barriere-des-Gobelins, Jondrette, wrapped in the "philanthropist's" great-coat, engaged in conversation with one of those men of disquieting aspect who have been dubbed by common consent, prowlers of the barriers; people of equivocal face, of suspicious monologues, who present the air of having evil minds, and who generally sleep in the daytime, which suggests the supposition that they work by night.
모모These two men, standing there motionless and in conversation, in the snow which was falling in whirlwinds, formed a group that a policeman would surely have observed, but which Marius hardly noticed.
모모Still, in spite of his mournful preoccupation, he could not refrain from saying to himself that this prowler of the barriers with whom Jondrette was talking resembled a certain Panchaud, alias Printanier, alias Bigrenaille, whom Courfeyrac had once pointed out to him as a very dangerous nocturnal roamer. This man's name the reader has learned in the preceding book. This Panchaud, alias Printanier, alias Bigrenaille, figured later on in many criminal trials, and became a notorious rascal. He was at that time only a famous rascal.
모모To-day he exists in the state of tradition among ruffians and assassins.
모모He was at the head of a school towards the end of the last reign.
모모And in the evening, at nightfall, at the hour when groups form and talk in whispers, he was discussed at La Force in the Fosse-aux-Lions. One might even, in that prison, precisely at the spot where the sewer which served the unprecedented escape, in broad daylight, of thirty prisoners, in 1843, passes under the culvert, read his name, PANCHAUD, audaciously carved by his own hand on the wall of the sewer, during one of his attempts at flight.
모모In 1832, the police already had their eye on him, but he had not as yet made a serious beginning.


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER XI 
모모OFFERS OF SERVICE FROM MISERY TO WRETCHEDNESS
모모Marius ascended the stairs of the hovel with slow steps; at the moment when he was about to re-enter his cell, he caught sight of the elder Jondrette girl following him through the corridor.
모모The very sight of this girl was odious to him; it was she who had his five francs, it was too late to demand them back, the cab was no longer there, the fiacre was far away.
모모Moreover, she would not have given them back. As for questioning her about the residence of the persons who had just been there, that was useless; it was evident that she did not know, since the letter signed Fabantou had been addressed "to the benevolent gentleman of the church of Saint-Jacquesdu-Haut-Pas."
모모Marius entered his room and pushed the door to after him.
모모It did not close; he turned round and beheld a hand which held the door half open.
모모"What is it?" he asked, "who is there?"
모모It was the Jondrette girl.
모모"Is it you?" resumed Marius almost harshly, "still you!
모모What do you want with me?"
모모She appeared to be thoughtful and did not look at him.
모모She no longer had the air of assurance which had characterized her that morning. She did not enter, but held back in the darkness of the corridor, where Marius could see her through the half-open door.
모모"Come now, will you answer?" cried Marius.
모모"What do you want with me?"
모모She raised her dull eyes, in which a sort of gleam seemed to flicker vaguely, and said:--
모모"Monsieur Marius, you look sad.
모모What is the matter with you?"
모모"With me!" said Marius.
모모"Yes, you."
모모"There is nothing the matter with me."
모모"Yes, there is!"
모모"No."
모모"I tell you there is!"
모모"Let me alone!"
모모Marius gave the door another push, but she retained her hold on it.
모모"Stop," said she, "you are in the wrong.
모모Although you are not rich, you were kind this morning.
모모Be so again now. You gave me something to eat, now tell me what ails you. You are grieved, that is plain.
모모I do not want you to be grieved. What can be done for it?
모모Can I be of any service?
모모Employ me. I do not ask for your secrets, you need not tell them to me, but I may be of use, nevertheless.
모모I may be able to help you, since I help my father.
모모When it is necessary to carry letters, to go to houses, to inquire from door to door, to find out an address, to follow any one, I am of service.
모모Well, you may assuredly tell me what is the matter with you, and I will go and speak to the persons; sometimes it is enough if some one speaks to the persons, that suffices to let them understand matters, and everything comes right. Make use of me."
모모An idea flashed across Marius' mind.
모모What branch does one disdain when one feels that one is falling?
모모He drew near to the Jondrette girl.
모모"Listen--" he said to her.
모모She interrupted him with a gleam of joy in her eyes.
모모"Oh yes, do call me thou!
모모I like that better."
모모"Well," he resumed, "thou hast brought hither that old gentleman and his daughter!"
모모"Yes."
모모"Dost thou know their address?"
모모"No."
모모"Find it for me."
모모The Jondrette's dull eyes had grown joyous, and they now became gloomy.
모모"Is that what you want?" she demanded.
모모"Yes."
모모"Do you know them?"
모모"No."
모모"That is to say," she resumed quickly, "you do not know her, but you wish to know her."
모모This them which had turned into her had something indescribably significant and bitter about it.
모모"Well, can you do it?" said Marius.
모모"You shall have the beautiful lady's address."
모모There was still a shade in the words "the beautiful lady" which troubled Marius.
모모He resumed:--
모모"Never mind, after all, the address of the father and daughter. Their address, indeed!"
모모She gazed fixedly at him.
모모"What will you give me?"
모모"Anything you like."
모모"Anything I like?"
모모"Yes."
모모"You shall have the address."
모모She dropped her head; then, with a brusque movement, she pulled to the door, which closed behind her.
모모Marius found himself alone.
모모He dropped into a chair, with his head and both elbows on his bed, absorbed in thoughts which he could not grasp, and as though a prey to vertigo.
모모All that had taken place since the morning, the appearance of the angel, her disappearance, what that creature had just said to him, a gleam of hope floating in an immense despair,-- this was what filled his brain confusedly.
모모All at once he was violently aroused from his revery.
모모He heard the shrill, hard voice of Jondrette utter these words, which were fraught with a strange interest for him:--
모모"I tell you that I am sure of it, and that I recognized him."
모모Of whom was Jondrette speaking?
모모Whom had he recognized?
모모M. Leblanc? The father of "his Ursule"? What!
모모Did Jondrette know him? Was Marius about to obtain in this abrupt and unexpected fashion all the information without which his life was so dark to him? Was he about to learn at last who it was that he loved, who that young girl was?
모모Who her father was?
모모Was the dense shadow which enwrapped them on the point of being dispelled?
모모Was the veil about to be rent?
모모Ah!
모모Heavens!
모모He bounded rather than climbed upon his commode, and resumed his post near the little peep-hole in the partition wall.
모모Again he beheld the interior of Jondrette's hovel.


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER XII 
모모THE USE MADE OF M. LEBLANC'S FIVE-FRANC PIECE
모모Nothing in the aspect of the family was altered, except that the wife and daughters had levied on the package and put on woollen stockings and jackets.
모모Two new blankets were thrown across the two beds.
모모Jondrette had evidently just returned.
모모He still had the breathlessness of out of doors.
모모His daughters were seated on the floor near the fireplace, the elder engaged in dressing the younger's wounded hand.
모모His wife had sunk back on the bed near the fireplace, with a face indicative of astonishment.
모모Jondrette was pacing up and down the garret with long strides.
모모His eyes were extraordinary.
모모The woman, who seemed timid and overwhelmed with stupor in the presence of her husband, turned to say:--
모모"What, really?
모모You are sure?"
모모"Sure!
모모Eight years have passed!
모모But I recognize him!
모모Ah!
모모I recognize him.
모모I knew him at once!
모모What!
모모Didn't it force itself on you?"
모모"No."
모모"But I told you:
모모`Pay attention!'
모모Why, it is his figure, it is his face, only older,--there are people who do not grow old, I don't know how they manage it,--it is the very sound of his voice. He is better dressed, that is all!
모모Ah! you mysterious old devil, I've got you, that I have!"
모모He paused, and said to his daughters:--
모모"Get out of here, you!--It's queer that it didn't strike you!"
모모They arose to obey.
모모The mother stammered:--
모모"With her injured hand."
모모"The air will do it good," said Jondrette.
모모"Be off."
모모It was plain that this man was of the sort to whom no one offers to reply.
모모The two girls departed.
모모At the moment when they were about to pass through the door, the father detained the elder by the arm, and said to her with a peculiar accent:--
모모"You will be here at five o'clock precisely.
모모Both of you. I shall need you."
모모Marius redoubled his attention.
모모On being left alone with his wife, Jondrette began to pace the room again, and made the tour of it two or three times in silence. Then he spent several minutes in tucking the lower part of the woman's chemise which he wore into his trousers.
모모All at once, he turned to the female Jondrette, folded his arms and exclaimed:--
모모"And would you like to have me tell you something?
모모The young lady--"
모모"Well, what?" retorted his wife, "the young lady?"
모모Marius could not doubt that it was really she of whom they were speaking. He listened with ardent anxiety.
모모His whole life was in his ears.
모모But Jondrette had bent over and spoke to his wife in a whisper. Then he straightened himself up and concluded aloud:--
모모"It is she!"
모모"That one?" said his wife.
모모"That very one," said the husband.
모모No expression can reproduce the significance of the mother's words. Surprise, rage, hate, wrath, were mingled and combined in one monstrous intonation.
모모The pronunciation of a few words, the name, no doubt, which her husband had whispered in her ear, had sufficed to rouse this huge, somnolent woman, and from being repulsive she became terrible.
모모"It is not possible!" she cried.
모모"When I think that my daughters are going barefoot, and have not a gown to their backs!
모모What! A satin pelisse, a velvet bonnet, boots, and everything; more than two hundred francs' worth of clothes! so that one would think she was a lady!
모모No, you are mistaken!
모모Why, in the first place, the other was hideous, and this one is not so bad-looking! She really is not bad-looking! It can't be she!"
모모"I tell you that it is she.
모모You will see."
모모At this absolute assertion, the Jondrette woman raised her large, red, blonde face and stared at the ceiling with a horrible expression. At that moment, she seemed to Marius even more to be feared than her husband.
모모She was a sow with the look of a tigress.
모모"What!" she resumed, "that horrible, beautiful young lady, who gazed at my daughters with an air of pity,--she is that beggar brat!
모모Oh!
모모I should like to kick her stomach in for her!"
모모She sprang off of the bed, and remained standing for a moment, her hair in disorder, her nostrils dilating, her mouth half open, her fists clenched and drawn back.
모모Then she fell back on the bed once more.
모모The man paced to and fro and paid no attention to his female.
모모After a silence lasting several minutes, he approached the female Jondrette, and halted in front of her, with folded arms, as he had done a moment before:--
모모"And shall I tell you another thing?"
모모"What is it?" she asked.
모모He answered in a low, curt voice:--
모모"My fortune is made."
모모The woman stared at him with the look that signifies:
모모"Is the person who is addressing me on the point of going mad?"
모모He went on:--
모모"Thunder!
모모It was not so very long ago that I was a parishioner of the parish of die-of-hunger-if-you-have-a-fire,-die-of-cold-if-you-have-bread! I have had enough of misery! my share and other people's share! I am not joking any longer, I don't find it comic any more, I've had enough of puns, good God! no more farces, Eternal Father! I want to eat till I am full, I want to drink my fill! to gormandize! to sleep! to do nothing!
모모I want to have my turn, so I do, come now! before I die!
모모I want to be a bit of a millionnaire!"
모모He took a turn round the hovel, and added:--
모모"Like other people."
모모"What do you mean by that?" asked the woman.
모모He shook his head, winked, screwed up one eye, and raised his voice like a medical professor who is about to make a demonstration:--
모모"What do I mean by that?
모모Listen!"
모모"Hush!" muttered the woman, "not so loud!
모모These are matters which must not be overheard."
모모"Bah!
모모Who's here?
모모Our neighbor?
모모I saw him go out a little while ago.
모모Besides, he doesn't listen, the big booby. And I tell you that I saw him go out."
모모Nevertheless, by a sort of instinct, Jondrette lowered his voice, although not sufficiently to prevent Marius hearing his words. One favorable circumstance, which enabled Marius not to lose a word of this conversation was the falling snow which deadened the sound of vehicles on the boulevard.
모모This is what Marius heard:--
모모"Listen carefully.
모모The Croesus is caught, or as good as caught! That's all settled already.
모모Everything is arranged.
모모I have seen some people.
모모He will come here this evening at six o'clock. To bring sixty francs, the rascal!
모모Did you notice how I played that game on him, my sixty francs, my landlord, my fourth of February? I don't even owe for one quarter!
모모Isn't he a fool!
모모So he will come at six o'clock! That's the hour when our neighbor goes to his dinner. Mother Bougon is off washing dishes in the city.
모모There's not a soul in the house.
모모The neighbor never comes home until eleven o'clock. The children shall stand on watch.
모모You shall help us.
모모He will give in."
모모"And what if he does not give in?" demanded his wife.
모모Jondrette made a sinister gesture, and said:--
모모"We'll fix him."
모모And he burst out laughing.
모모This was the first time Marius had seen him laugh.
모모The laugh was cold and sweet, and provoked a shudder.
모모Jondrette opened a cupboard near the fireplace, and drew from it an old cap, which he placed on his head, after brushing it with his sleeve.
모모"Now," said he, "I'm going out.
모모I have some more people that I must see.
모모Good ones.
모모You'll see how well the whole thing will work. I shall be away as short a time as possible, it's a fine stroke of business, do you look after the house."
모모And with both fists thrust into the pockets of his trousers, he stood for a moment in thought, then exclaimed:--
모모"Do you know, it's mighty lucky, by the way, that he didn't recognize me!
모모If he had recognized me on his side, he would not have come back again.
모모He would have slipped through our fingers! It was my beard that saved us! my romantic beard! my pretty little romantic beard!"
모모And again he broke into a laugh.
모모He stepped to the window.
모모The snow was still falling, and streaking the gray of the sky.
모모"What beastly weather!" said he.
모모Then lapping his overcoat across his breast:--
모모"This rind is too large for me.
모모Never mind," he added, "he did a devilish good thing in leaving it for me, the old scoundrel! If it hadn't been for that, I couldn't have gone out, and everything would have gone wrong!
모모What small points things hang on, anyway!"
모모And pulling his cap down over his eyes, he quitted the room.
모모He had barely had time to take half a dozen steps from the door, when the door opened again, and his savage but intelligent face made its appearance once more in the opening.
모모"I came near forgetting," said he.
모모"You are to have a brazier of charcoal ready."
모모And he flung into his wife's apron the five-franc piece which the "philanthropist" had left with him.
모모"A brazier of charcoal?" asked his wife.
모모"Yes."
모모"How many bushels?"
모모"Two good ones."
모모"That will come to thirty sous.
모모With the rest I will buy something for dinner."
모모"The devil, no."
모모"Why?"
모모"Don't go and spend the hundred-sou piece."
모모"Why?"
모모"Because I shall have to buy something, too."
모모"What?"
모모"Something."
모모"How much shall you need?"
모모"Whereabouts in the neighborhood is there an ironmonger's shop?"
모모"Rue Mouffetard."
모모"Ah! yes, at the corner of a street; I can see the shop."
모모"But tell me how much you will need for what you have to purchase?"
모모"Fifty sous--three francs."
모모"There won't be much left for dinner."
모모"Eating is not the point to-day. There's something better to be done."
모모"That's enough, my jewel."
모모At this word from his wife, Jondrette closed the door again, and this time, Marius heard his step die away in the corridor of the hovel, and descend the staircase rapidly.
모모At that moment, one o'clock struck from the church of Saint-Medard.


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER XIII 
모모SOLUS CUM SOLO, IN LOCO REMOTO, NON COGITABUNTUR ORARE PATER NOSTER
모모Marius, dreamer as he was, was, as we have said, firm and energetic by nature.
모모His habits of solitary meditation, while they had developed in him sympathy and compassion, had, perhaps, diminished the faculty for irritation, but had left intact the power of waxing indignant; he had the kindliness of a brahmin, and the severity of a judge; he took pity upon a toad, but he crushed a viper.
모모Now, it was into a hole of vipers that his glance had just been directed, it was a nest of monsters that he had beneath his eyes.
모모"These wretches must be stamped upon," said he.
모모Not one of the enigmas which he had hoped to see solved had been elucidated; on the contrary, all of them had been rendered more dense, if anything; he knew nothing more about the beautiful maiden of the Luxembourg and the man whom he called M. Leblanc, except that Jondrette was acquainted with them.
모모Athwart the mysterious words which had been uttered, the only thing of which he caught a distinct glimpse was the fact that an ambush was in course of preparation, a dark but terrible trap; that both of them were incurring great danger, she probably, her father certainly; that they must be saved; that the hideous plots of the Jondrettes must be thwarted, and the web of these spiders broken.
모모He scanned the female Jondrette for a moment.
모모She had pulled an old sheet-iron stove from a corner, and she was rummaging among the old heap of iron.
모모He descended from the commode as softly as possible, taking care not to make the least noise.
모모Amid his terror as to what was in preparation, and in the horror with which the Jondrettes had inspired him, he experienced a sort of joy at the idea that it might be granted to him perhaps to render a service to the one whom he loved.
모모But how was it to be done?
모모How warn the persons threatened? He did not know their address.
모모They had reappeared for an instant before his eyes, and had then plunged back again into the immense depths of Paris.
모모Should he wait for M. Leblanc at the door that evening at six o'clock, at the moment of his arrival, and warn him of the trap?
모모But Jondrette and his men would see him on the watch, the spot was lonely, they were stronger than he, they would devise means to seize him or to get him away, and the man whom Marius was anxious to save would be lost.
모모One o'clock had just struck, the trap was to be sprung at six.
모모Marius had five hours before him.
모모There was but one thing to be done.
모모He put on his decent coat, knotted a silk handkerchief round his neck, took his hat, and went out, without making any more noise than if he had been treading on moss with bare feet.
모모Moreover, the Jondrette woman continued to rummage among her old iron.
모모Once outside of the house, he made for the Rue du Petit-Banquier.
모모He had almost reached the middle of this street, near a very low wall which a man can easily step over at certain points, and which abuts on a waste space, and was walking slowly, in consequence of his preoccupied condition, and the snow deadened the sound of his steps; all at once he heard voices talking very close by.
모모He turned his head, the street was deserted, there was not a soul in it, it was broad daylight, and yet he distinctly heard voices.
모모It occurred to him to glance over the wall which he was skirting.
모모There, in fact, sat two men, flat on the snow, with their backs against the wall, talking together in subdued tones.
모모These two persons were strangers to him; one was a bearded man in a blouse, and the other a long-haired individual in rags. The bearded man had on a fez, the other's head was bare, and the snow had lodged in his hair.
모모By thrusting his head over the wall, Marius could hear their remarks.
모모The hairy one jogged the other man's elbow and said:--
모모"--With the assistance of Patron-Minette, it can't fail."
모모"Do you think so?" said the bearded man.
모모And the long-haired one began again:--
모모"It's as good as a warrant for each one, of five hundred balls, and the worst that can happen is five years, six years, ten years at the most!"
모모The other replied with some hesitation, and shivering beneath his fez:--
모모"That's a real thing.
모모You can't go against such things."
모모"I tell you that the affair can't go wrong," resumed the long-haired man. "Father What's-his-name's team will be already harnessed."
모모Then they began to discuss a melodrama that they had seen on the preceding evening at the Gaite Theatre.
모모Marius went his way.
모모It seemed to him that the mysterious words of these men, so strangely hidden behind that wall, and crouching in the snow, could not but bear some relation to Jondrette's abominable projects. That must be the affair.
모모He directed his course towards the faubourg Saint-Marceau and asked at the first shop he came to where he could find a commissary of police.
모모He was directed to Rue de Pontoise, No. 14.
모모Thither Marius betook himself.
모모As he passed a baker's shop, he bought a two-penny roll, and ate it, foreseeing that he should not dine.
모모On the way, he rendered justice to Providence.
모모He reflected that had he not given his five francs to the Jondrette girl in the morning, he would have followed M. Leblanc's fiacre, and consequently have remained ignorant of everything, and that there would have been no obstacle to the trap of the Jondrettes and that M. Leblanc would have been lost, and his daughter with him, no doubt.


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER XIV 
모모IN WHICH A POLICE AGENT BESTOWS TWO FISTFULS ON A LAWYER
모모On arriving at No. 14, Rue de Pontoise, he ascended to the first floor and inquired for the commissary of police.
모모"The commissary of police is not here," said a clerk; "but there is an inspector who takes his place.
모모Would you like to speak to him? Are you in haste?"
모모"Yes," said Marius.
모모The clerk introduced him into the commissary's office.
모모There stood a tall man behind a grating, leaning against a stove, and holding up with both hands the tails of a vast topcoat, with three collars. His face was square, with a thin, firmmouth, thick, gray, and very ferocious whiskers, and a look that was enough to turn your pockets inside out.
모모Of that glance it might have been well said, not that it penetrated, but that it searched.
모모This man's air was not much less ferocious nor less terrible than Jondrette's; the dog is, at times, no less terrible to meet than the wolf.
모모"What do you want?" he said to Marius, without adding "monsieur."
모모"Is this Monsieur le Commissaire de Police?"
모모"He is absent.
모모I am here in his stead."
모모"The matter is very private."'
모모"Then speak."
모모"And great haste is required."
모모"Then speak quick."
모모This calm, abrupt man was both terrifying and reassuring at one and the same time.
모모He inspired fear and confidence. Marius related the adventure to him:
모모That a person with whom he was not acquainted otherwise than by sight, was to be inveigled into a trap that very evening; that, as he occupied the room adjoining the den, he, Marius Pontmercy, a lawyer, had heard the whole plot through the partition; that the wretch who had planned the trap was a certain Jondrette; that there would be accomplices, probably some prowlers of the barriers, among others a certain Panchaud, alias Printanier, alias Bigrenaille; that Jondrette's daughters were to lie in wait; that there was no way of warning the threatened man, since he did not even know his name; and that, finally, all this was to be carried out at six o'clock that evening, at the most deserted point of the Boulevard de l'Hopital, in house No. 50-52.
모모At the sound of this number, the inspector raised his head, and said coldly:--
모모"So it is in the room at the end of the corridor?"
모모"Precisely," answered Marius, and he added:
모모"Are you acquainted with that house?"
모모The inspector remained silent for a moment, then replied, as he warmed the heel of his boot at the door of the stove:--
모모"Apparently."
모모He went on, muttering between his teeth, and not addressing Marius so much as his cravat:--
모모"Patron-Minette must have had a hand in this."
모모This word struck Marius.
모모"Patron-Minette," said he, "I did hear that word pronounced, in fact."
모모And he repeated to the inspector the dialogue between the long-haired man and the bearded man in the snow behind the wall of the Rue du Petit-Banquier.
모모The inspector muttered:--
모모"The long-haired man must be Brujon, and the bearded one Demi-Liard, alias Deux-Milliards."
모모He had dropped his eyelids again, and became absorbed in thought.
모모"As for Father What's-his-name, I think I recognize him. Here, I've burned my coat.
모모They always have too much fire in these cursed stoves.
모모Number 50-52. Former property of Gorbeau."
모모Then he glanced at Marius.
모모"You saw only that bearded and that long-haired man?"
모모"And Panchaud."
모모"You didn't see a little imp of a dandy prowling about the premises?"
모모"No."
모모"Nor a big lump of matter, resembling an elephant in the Jardin des Plantes?"
모모"No."
모모"Nor a scamp with the air of an old red tail?"
모모"No."
모모"As for the fourth, no one sees him, not even his adjutants, clerks, and employees.
모모It is not surprising that you did not see him."
모모"No. Who are all those persons?" asked Marius.
모모The inspector answered:--
모모"Besides, this is not the time for them."
모모He relapsed into silence, then resumed:--
모모"50-52. I know that barrack.
모모Impossible to conceal ourselves inside it without the artists seeing us, and then they will get off simply by countermanding the vaudeville.
모모They are so modest! An audience embarrasses them.
모모None of that, none of that.
모모I want to hear them sing and make them dance."
모모This monologue concluded, he turned to Marius, and demanded, gazing at him intently the while:--
모모"Are you afraid?"
모모"Of what?" said Marius.
모모"Of these men?"
모모"No more than yourself!" retorted Marius rudely, who had begun to notice that this police agent had not yet said "monsieur" to him.
모모The inspector stared still more intently at Marius, and continued with sententious solemnity:--
모모"There, you speak like a brave man, and like an honest man. Courage does not fear crime, and honesty does not fear authority."
모모Marius interrupted him:--
모모"That is well, but what do you intend to do?"
모모The inspector contented himself with the remark:--
모모"The lodgers have pass-keys with which to get in at night. You must have one."
모모"Yes," said Marius.
모모"Have you it about you?"
모모"Yes."
모모"Give it to me," said the inspector.
모모Marius took his key from his waistcoat pocket, handed it to the inspector and added:--
모모"If you will take my advice, you will come in force."
모모The inspector cast on Marius such a glance as Voltaire might have bestowed on a provincial academician who had suggested a rhyme to him; with one movement he plunged his hands, which were enormous, into the two immense pockets of his top-coat, and pulled out two small steel pistols, of the sort called "knock-me-downs." Then he presented them to Marius, saying rapidly, in a curt tone:--
모모"Take these.
모모Go home.
모모Hide in your chamber, so that you may be supposed to have gone out.
모모They are loaded.
모모Each one carries two balls.
모모You will keep watch; there is a hole in the wall, as you have informed me.
모모These men will come.
모모Leave them to their own devices for a time.
모모When you think matters have reached a crisis, and that it is time to put a stop to them, fire a shot. Not too soon.
모모The rest concerns me.
모모A shot into the ceiling, the air, no matter where.
모모Above all things, not too soon.
모모Wait until they begin to put their project into execution; you are a lawyer; you know the proper point."
모모Marius took the pistols and put them in the side pocket of his coat.
모모"That makes a lump that can be seen," said the inspector. "Put them in your trousers pocket."
모모Marius hid the pistols in his trousers pockets.
모모"Now," pursued the inspector, "there is not a minute more to be lost by any one.
모모What time is it?
모모Half-past two.
모모Seven o'clock is the hour?"
모모"Six o'clock," answered Marius.
모모"I have plenty of time," said the inspector, "but no more than enough. Don't forget anything that I have said to you.
모모Bang.
모모A pistol shot."
모모"Rest easy," said Marius.
모모And as Marius laid his hand on the handle of the door on his way out, the inspector called to him:--
모모"By the way, if you have occasion for my services between now and then, come or send here.
모모You will ask for Inspector Javert."


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER XV 
모모JONDRETTE MAKES HIS PURCHASES
모모A few moments later, about three o'clock, Courfeyrac chanced to be passing along the Rue Mouffetard in company with Bossuet. The snow had redoubled in violence, and filled the air.
모모Bossuet was just saying to Courfeyrac:--
모모"One would say, to see all these snow-flakes fall, that there was a plague of white butterflies in heaven."
모모All at once, Bossuet caught sight of Marius coming up the street towards the barrier with a peculiar air.
모모"Hold!" said Bossuet.
모모"There's Marius."
모모"I saw him," said Courfeyrac.
모모"Don't let's speak to him."
모모"Why?"
모모"He is busy."
모모"With what?"
모모"Don't you see his air?"
모모"What air?"
모모"He has the air of a man who is following some one."
모모"That's true," said Bossuet.
모모"Just see the eyes he is making!" said Courfeyrac.
모모"But who the deuce is he following?"
모모"Some fine, flowery bonneted wench!
모모He's in love."
모모"But," observed Bossuet, "I don't see any wench nor any flowery bonnet in the street.
모모There's not a woman round."
모모Courfeyrac took a survey, and exclaimed:--
모모"He's following a man!"
모모A man, in fact, wearing a gray cap, and whose gray beard could be distinguished, although they only saw his back, was walking along about twenty paces in advance of Marius.
모모This man was dressed in a great-coat which was perfectly new and too large for him, and in a frightful pair of trousers all hanging in rags and black with mud.
모모Bossuet burst out laughing.
모모"Who is that man?"
모모"He?" retorted Courfeyrac, "he's a poet.
모모Poets are very fond of wearing the trousers of dealers in rabbit skins and the overcoats of peers of France."
모모"Let's see where Marius will go," said Bossuet; "let's see where the man is going, let's follow them, hey?"
모모"Bossuet!" exclaimed Courfeyrac, "eagle of Meaux!
모모You are a prodigious brute.
모모Follow a man who is following another man, indeed!"
모모They retraced their steps.
모모Marius had, in fact, seen Jondrette passing along the Rue Mouffetard, and was spying on his proceedings.
모모Jondrette walked straight ahead, without a suspicion that he was already held by a glance.
모모He quitted the Rue Mouffetard, and Marius saw him enter one of the most terrible hovels in the Rue Gracieuse; he remained there about a quarter of an hour, then returned to the Rue Mouffetard. He halted at an ironmonger's shop, which then stood at the corner of the Rue Pierre-Lombard, and a few minutes later Marius saw him emerge from the shop, holding in his hand a huge cold chisel with a white wood handle, which he concealed beneath his great-coat. At the top of the Rue Petit-Gentilly he turned to the left and proceeded rapidly to the Rue du Petit-Banquier. The day was declining; the snow, which had ceased for a moment, had just begun again. Marius posted himself on the watch at the very corner of the Rue du Petit-Banquier, which was deserted, as usual, and did not follow Jondrette into it.
모모It was lucky that he did so, for, on arriving in the vicinity of the wall where Marius had heard the long-haired man and the bearded man conversing, Jondrette turned round, made sure that no one was following him, did not see him, then sprang across the wall and disappeared.
모모The waste land bordered by this wall communicated with the back yard of an ex-livery stable-keeper of bad repute, who had failed and who still kept a few old single-seated berlins under his sheds.
모모Marius thought that it would be wise to profit by Jondrette's absence to return home; moreover, it was growing late; every evening, Ma'am Bougon when she set out for her dish-washing in town, had a habit of locking the door, which was always closed at dusk. Marius had given his key to the inspector of police; it was important, therefore, that he should make haste.
모모Evening had arrived, night had almost closed in; on the horizon and in the immensity of space, there remained but one spot illuminated by the sun, and that was the moon.
모모It was rising in a ruddy glow behind the low dome of Salpetriere.
모모Marius returned to No. 50-52 with great strides.
모모The door was still open when he arrived.
모모He mounted the stairs on tip-toe and glided along the wall of the corridor to his chamber.
모모This corridor, as the reader will remember, was bordered on both sides by attics, all of which were, for the moment, empty and to let.
모모Ma'am Bougon was in the habit of leaving all the doors open.
모모As he passed one of these attics, Marius thought he perceived in the uninhabited cell the motionless heads of four men, vaguely lighted up by a remnant of daylight, falling through a dormer window,
모모Marius made no attempt to see, not wishing to be seen himself. He succeeded in reaching his chamber without being seen and without making any noise.
모모It was high time.
모모A moment later he heard Ma'am Bougon take her departure, locking the door of the house behind her.


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER XVI 
모모IN WHICH WILL BE FOUND THE WORDS TO AN ENGLISH AIR WHICH WAS IN FASHION IN 1832
모모Marius seated himself on his bed.
모모It might have been half-past five o'clock. Only half an hour separated him from what was about to happen. He heard the beating of his arteries as one hears the ticking of a watch in the dark.
모모He thought of the double march which was going on at that moment in the dark,--crime advancing on one side, justice coming up on the other.
모모He was not afraid, but he could not think without a shudder of what was about to take place. As is the case with all those who are suddenly assailed by an unforeseen adventure, the entire day produced upon him the effect of a dream, and in order to persuade himself that he was not the prey of a nightmare, he had to feel the cold barrels of the steel pistols in his trousers pockets.
모모It was no longer snowing; the moon disengaged itself more and more clearly from the mist, and its light, mingled with the white reflection of the snow which had fallen, communicated to the chamber a sort of twilight aspect.
모모There was a light in the Jondrette den.
모모Marius saw the hole in the wall shining with a reddish glow which seemed bloody to him.
모모It was true that the light could not be produced by a candle. However, there was not a sound in the Jondrette quarters, not a soul was moving there, not a soul speaking, not a breath; the silence was glacial and profound, and had it not been for that light, he might have thought himself next door to a sepulchre.
모모Marius softly removed his boots and pushed them under his bed.
모모Several minutes elapsed.
모모Marius heard the lower door turn on its hinges; a heavy step mounted the staircase, and hastened along the corridor; the latch of the hovel was noisily lifted; it was Jondrette returning.
모모Instantly, several voices arose.
모모The whole family was in the garret.
모모Only, it had been silent in the master's absence, like wolf whelps in the absence of the wolf.
모모"It's I," said he.
모모"Good evening, daddy," yelped the girls.
모모"Well?" said the mother.
모모"All's going first-rate," responded Jondrette, "but my feet are beastly cold.
모모Good!
모모You have dressed up.
모모You have done well! You must inspire confidence."
모모"All ready to go out."
모모"Don't forget what I told you.
모모You will do everything sure?"
모모"Rest easy."
모모"Because--" said Jondrette.
모모And he left the phrase unfinished.
모모Marius heard him lay something heavy on the table, probably the chisel which he had purchased.
모모"By the way," said Jondrette, "have you been eating here?"
모모"Yes," said the mother.
모모"I got three large potatoes and some salt. I took advantage of the fire to cook them."
모모"Good," returned Jondrette.
모모"To-morrow I will take you out to dine with me.
모모We will have a duck and fixings.
모모You shall dine like Charles the Tenth; all is going well!"
모모Then he added:--
모모"The mouse-trap is open.
모모The cats are there."
모모He lowered his voice still further, and said:--
모모"Put this in the fire."
모모Marius heard a sound of charcoal being knocked with the tongs or some iron utensil, and Jondrette continued:--
모모"Have you greased the hinges of the door so that they will not squeak?"
모모"Yes," replied the mother.
모모"What time is it?"
모모"Nearly six.
모모The half-hour struck from Saint-Medard a while ago."
모모"The devil!" ejaculated Jondrette; "the children must go and watch. Come you, do you listen here."
모모A whispering ensued.
모모Jondrette's voice became audible again:--
모모"Has old Bougon left?"
모모"Yes," said the mother.
모모"Are you sure that there is no one in our neighbor's room?"
모모"He has not been in all day, and you know very well that this is his dinner hour."
모모"You are sure?"
모모"Sure."
모모"All the same," said Jondrette, "there's no harm in going to see whether he is there.
모모Here, my girl, take the candle and go there."
모모Marius fell on his hands and knees and crawled silently under his bed.
모모Hardly had he concealed himself, when he perceived a light through the crack of his door.
모모"P'pa," cried a voice, "he is not in here."
모모He recognized the voice of the eldest daughter.
모모"Did you go in?" demanded her father.
모모"No," replied the girl, "but as his key is in the door, he must be out."
모모The father exclaimed:--
모모"Go in, nevertheless."
모모The door opened, and Marius saw the tall Jondrette come in with a candle in her hand.
모모She was as she had been in the morning, only still more repulsive in this light.
모모She walked straight up to the bed.
모모Marius endured an indescribable moment of anxiety; but near the bed there was a mirror nailed to the wall, and it was thither that she was directing her steps. She raised herself on tiptoe and looked at herself in it. In the neighboring room, the sound of iron articles being moved was audible.
모모She smoothed her hair with the palm of her hand, and smiled into the mirror, humming with her cracked and sepulchral voice:--Nos amours ont dure toute une semaine,[28] 
모모Mais que du bonheur les instants sont courts! 
모모S'adorer huit jours, c' etait bien la peine! 
모모Le temps des amours devait durer toujours! 
모모Devrait durer toujours! devrait durer toujours!
모모[28] Our love has lasted a whole week, but how short are the instants of happiness!
모모To adore each other for eight days was hardly worth the while!
모모The time of love should last forever.
모모In the meantime, Marius trembled.
모모It seemed impossible to him that she should not hear his breathing.
모모She stepped to the window and looked out with the half-foolish way she had.
모모"How ugly Paris is when it has put on a white chemise!" said she.
모모She returned to the mirror and began again to put on airs before it, scrutinizing herself full-face and three-quarters face in turn.
모모"Well!" cried her father, "what are you about there?"
모모"I am looking under the bed and the furniture," she replied, continuing to arrange her hair; "there's no one here."
모모"Booby!" yelled her father.
모모"Come here this minute!
모모And don't waste any time about it!"
모모"Coming!
모모Coming!" said she.
모모"One has no time for anything in this hovel!"
모모She hummed:--Vous me quittez pour aller a la gloire;[29] 
모모Mon triste coeur suivra partout.
모모[29] You leave me to go to glory; my sad heart will follow you everywhere.
모모She cast a parting glance in the mirror and went out, shutting the door behind her.
모모A moment more, and Marius heard the sound of the two young girls' bare feet in the corridor, and Jondrette's voice shouting to them:--
모모"Pay strict heed!
모모One on the side of the barrier, the other at the corner of the Rue du Petit-Banquier. Don't lose sight for a moment of the door of this house, and the moment you see anything, rush here on the instant! as hard as you can go!
모모You have a key to get in."
모모The eldest girl grumbled:--
모모"The idea of standing watch in the snow barefoot!"
모모"To-morrow you shall have some dainty little green silk boots!" said the father.
모모They ran down stairs, and a few seconds later the shock of the outer door as it banged to announced that they were outside.
모모There now remained in the house only Marius, the Jondrettes and probably, also, the mysterious persons of whom Marius had caught a glimpse in the twilight, behind the door of the unused attic.


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER XVII 
모모THE USE MADE OF MARIUS' FIVE-FRANC PIECE
모모Marius decided that the moment had now arrived when he must resume his post at his observatory.
모모In a twinkling, and with the agility of his age, he had reached the hole in the partition.
모모He looked.
모모The interior of the Jondrette apartment presented a curious aspect, and Marius found an explanation of the singular light which he had noticed.
모모A candle was burning in a candlestick covered with verdigris, but that was not what really lighted the chamber. The hovel was completely illuminated, as it were, by the reflection from a rather large sheet-iron brazier standing in the fireplace, and filled with burning charcoal, the brazier prepared by the Jondrette woman that morning.
모모The charcoal was glowing hot and the brazier was red; a blue flame flickered over it, and helped him to make out the form of the chisel purchased by Jondrette in the Rue Pierre-Lombard, where it had been thrust into the brazier to heat.
모모In one corner, near the door, and as though prepared for some definite use, two heaps were visible, which appeared to be, the one a heap of old iron, the other a heap of ropes.
모모All this would have caused the mind of a person who knew nothing of what was in preparation, to waver between a very sinister and a very simple idea.
모모The lair thus lighted up more resembled a forge than a mouth of hell, but Jondrette, in this light, had rather the air of a demon than of a smith.
모모The heat of the brazier was so great, that the candle on the table was melting on the side next the chafing-dish, and was drooping over. An old dark-lantern of copper, worthy of Diogenes turned Cartouche, stood on the chimney-piece.
모모The brazier, placed in the fireplace itself, beside the nearly extinct brands, sent its vapors up the chimney, and gave out no odor.
모모The moon, entering through the four panes of the window, cast its whiteness into the crimson and flaming garret; and to the poetic spirit of Marius, who was dreamy even in the moment of action, it was like a thought of heaven mingled with the misshapen reveries of earth.
모모A breath of air which made its way in through the open pane, helped to dissipate the smell of the charcoal and to conceal the presence of the brazier.
모모The Jondrette lair was, if the reader recalls what we have said of the Gorbeau building, admirably chosen to serve as the theatre of a violent and sombre deed, and as the envelope for a crime. It was the most retired chamber in the most isolated house on the most deserted boulevard in Paris.
모모If the system of ambush and traps had not already existed, they would have been invented there.
모모The whole thickness of a house and a multitude of uninhabited rooms separated this den from the boulevard, and the only window that existed opened on waste lands enclosed with walls and palisades.
모모Jondrette had lighted his pipe, seated himself on the seatless chair, and was engaged in smoking.
모모His wife was talking to him in a low tone.
모모If Marius had been Courfeyrac, that is to say, one of those men who laugh on every occasion in life, he would have burst with laughter when his gaze fell on the Jondrette woman.
모모She had on a black bonnet with plumes not unlike the hats of the heralds-at-arms at the coronation of Charles X., an immense tartan shawl over her knitted petticoat, and the man's shoes which her daughter had scorned in the morning.
모모It was this toilette which had extracted from Jondrette the exclamation:
모모"Good!
모모You have dressed up. You have done well.
모모You must inspire confidence!"
모모As for Jondrette, he had not taken off the new surtout, which was too large for him, and which M. Leblanc had given him, and his costume continued to present that contrast of coat and trousers which constituted the ideal of a poet in Courfeyrac's eyes.
모모All at once, Jondrette lifted up his voice:--
모모"By the way!
모모Now that I think of it.
모모In this weather, he will come in a carriage.
모모Light the lantern, take it and go down stairs. You will stand behind the lower door.
모모The very moment that you hear the carriage stop, you will open the door, instantly, he will come up, you will light the staircase and the corridor, and when he enters here, you will go down stairs again as speedily as possible, you will pay the coachman, and dismiss the fiacre.
모모"And the money?" inquired the woman.
모모Jondrette fumbled in his trousers pocket and handed her five francs.
모모"What's this?" she exclaimed.
모모Jondrette replied with dignity:--
모모"That is the monarch which our neighbor gave us this morning."
모모And he added:--
모모"Do you know what?
모모Two chairs will be needed here."
모모"What for?"
모모"To sit on."
모모Marius felt a cold chill pass through his limbs at hearing this mild answer from Jondrette.
모모"Pardieu!
모모I'll go and get one of our neighbor's."
