모모And with a rapid movement, she opened the door of the den, and went out into the corridor.
모모Marius absolutely had not the time to descend from the commode, reach his bed, and conceal himself beneath it.
모모"Take the candle," cried Jondrette.
모모"No," said she, "it would embarrass me, I have the two chairs to carry. There is moonlight."
모모Marius heard Mother Jondrette's heavy hand fumbling at his lock in the dark.
모모The door opened.
모모He remained nailed to the spot with the shock and with horror.
모모The Jondrette entered.
모모The dormer window permitted the entrance of a ray of moonlight between two blocks of shadow.
모모One of these blocks of shadow entirely covered the wall against which Marius was leaning, so that he disappeared within it.
모모Mother Jondrette raised her eyes, did not see Marius, took the two chairs, the only ones which Marius possessed, and went away, letting the door fall heavily to behind her.
모모She re-entered the lair.
모모"Here are the two chairs."
모모"And here is the lantern.
모모Go down as quick as you can."
모모She hastily obeyed, and Jondrette was left alone.
모모He placed the two chairs on opposite sides of the table, turned the chisel in the brazier, set in front of the fireplace an old screen which masked the chafing-dish, then went to the corner where lay the pile of rope, and bent down as though to examine something. Marius then recognized the fact, that what he had taken for a shapeless mass was a very well-made rope-ladder, with wooden rungs and two hooks with which to attach it.
모모This ladder, and some large tools, veritable masses of iron, which were mingled with the old iron piled up behind the door, had not been in the Jondrette hovel in the morning, and had evidently been brought thither in the afternoon, during Marius' absence.
모모"Those are the utensils of an edge-tool maker," thought Marius.
모모Had Marius been a little more learned in this line, he would have recognized in what he took for the engines of an edge-tool maker, certain instruments which will force a lock or pick a lock, and others which will cut or slice, the two families of tools which burglars call cadets and fauchants.
모모The fireplace and the two chairs were exactly opposite Marius. The brazier being concealed, the only light in the room was now furnished by the candle; the smallest bit of crockery on the table or on the chimney-piece cast a large shadow.
모모There was something indescribably calm, threatening, and hideous about this chamber. One felt that there existed in it the anticipation of something terrible.
모모Jondrette had allowed his pipe to go out, a serious sign of preoccupation, and had again seated himself.
모모The candle brought out the fierce and the fine angles of his countenance.
모모He indulged in scowls and in abrupt unfoldings of the right hand, as though he were responding to the last counsels of a sombre inward monologue.
모모In the course of one of these dark replies which he was making to himself, he pulled the table drawer rapidly towards him, took out a long kitchen knife which was concealed there, and tried the edge of its blade on his nail.
모모That done, he put the knife back in the drawer and shut it.
모모Marius, on his side, grasped the pistol in his right pocket, drew it out and cocked it.
모모The pistol emitted a sharp, clear click, as he cocked it.
모모Jondrette started, half rose, listened a moment, then began to laugh and said:--
모모"What a fool I am!
모모It's the partition cracking!"
모모Marius kept the pistol in his hand.


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER XVIII 
모모MARIUS' TWO CHAIRS FORM A VIS-A-VIS
모모Suddenly, the distant and melancholy vibration of a clock shook the panes.
모모Six o'clock was striking from Saint-Medard.
모모Jondrette marked off each stroke with a toss of his head. When the sixth had struck, he snuffed the candle with his fingers.
모모Then he began to pace up and down the room, listened at the corridor, walked on again, then listened once more.
모모"Provided only that he comes!" he muttered, then he returned to his chair.
모모He had hardly reseated himself when the door opened.
모모Mother Jondrette had opened it, and now remained in the corridor making a horrible, amiable grimace, which one of the holes of the dark-lantern illuminated from below.
모모"Enter, sir," she said.
모모"Enter, my benefactor," repeated Jondrette, rising hastily.
모모M. Leblanc made his appearance.
모모He wore an air of serenity which rendered him singularly venerable.
모모He laid four louis on the table.
모모"Monsieur Fabantou," said he, "this is for your rent and your most pressing necessities.
모모We will attend to the rest hereafter."
모모"May God requite it to you, my generous benefactor!" said Jondrette.
모모And rapidly approaching his wife:--
모모"Dismiss the carriage!"
모모She slipped out while her husband was lavishing salutes and offering M. Leblanc a chair.
모모An instant later she returned and whispered in his ear:--
모모"'Tis done."
모모The snow, which had not ceased falling since the morning, was so deep that the arrival of the fiacre had not been audible, and they did not now hear its departure.
모모Meanwhile, M. Leblanc had seated himself.
모모Jondrette had taken possession of the other chair, facing M. Leblanc.
모모Now, in order to form an idea of the scene which is to follow, let the reader picture to himself in his own mind, a cold night, the solitudes of the Salpetriere covered with snow and white as winding-sheets in the moonlight, the taper-like lights of the street lanterns which shone redly here and there along those tragic boulevards, and the long rows of black elms, not a passer-by for perhaps a quarter of a league around, the Gorbeau hovel, at its highest pitch of silence, of horror, and of darkness; in that building, in the midst of those solitudes, in the midst of that darkness, the vast Jondrette garret lighted by a single candle, and in that den two men seated at a table, M. Leblanc tranquil, Jondrette smiling and alarming, the Jondrette woman, the female wolf, in one corner, and, behind the partition, Marius, invisible, erect, not losing a word, not missing a single movement, his eye on the watch, and pistol in hand.
모모However, Marius experienced only an emotion of horror, but no fear. He clasped the stock of the pistol firmly and felt reassured. "I shall be able to stop that wretch whenever I please," he thought.
모모He felt that the police were there somewhere in ambuscade, waiting for the signal agreed upon and ready to stretch out their arm.
모모Moreover, he was in hopes, that this violent encounter between Jondrette and M. Leblanc would cast some light on all the things which he was interested in learning.


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER XIX 
모모OCCUPYING ONE'S SELF WITH OBSCURE DEPTHS
모모Hardly was M. Leblanc seated, when he turned his eyes towards the pallets, which were empty.
모모"How is the poor little wounded girl?" he inquired.
모모"Bad," replied Jondrette with a heart-broken and grateful smile, "very bad, my worthy sir.
모모Her elder sister has taken her to the Bourbe to have her hurt dressed.
모모You will see them presently; they will be back immediately."
모모"Madame Fabantou seems to me to be better," went on M. Leblanc, casting his eyes on the eccentric costume of the Jondrette woman, as she stood between him and the door, as though already guarding the exit, and gazed at him in an attitude of menace and almost of combat.
모모"She is dying," said Jondrette.
모모"But what do you expect, sir! She has so much courage, that woman has!
모모She's not a woman, she's an ox."
모모The Jondrette, touched by his compliment, deprecated it with the affected airs of a flattered monster.
모모"You are always too good to me, Monsieur Jondrette!"
모모"Jondrette!" said M. Leblanc, "I thought your name was Fabantou?"
모모"Fabantou, alias Jondrette!" replied the husband hurriedly. "An artistic sobriquet!"
모모And launching at his wife a shrug of the shoulders which M. Leblanc did not catch, he continued with an emphatic and caressing inflection of voice:--
모모"Ah! we have had a happy life together, this poor darling and I! What would there be left for us if we had not that?
모모We are so wretched, my respectable sir!
모모We have arms, but there is no work!
모모We have the will, no work!
모모I don't know how the government arranges that, but, on my word of honor, sir, I am not Jacobin, sir, I am not a bousingot.[30] I don't wish them any evil, but if I were the ministers, on my most sacred word, things would be different.
모모Here, for instance, I wanted to have my girls taught the trade of paper-box makers. You will say to me:
모모`What! a trade?'
모모Yes!
모모A trade!
모모A simple trade! A bread-winner! What a fall, my benefactor!
모모What a degradation, when one has been what we have been!
모모Alas!
모모There is nothing left to us of our days of prosperity!
모모One thing only, a picture, of which I think a great deal, but which I am willing to part with, for I must live!
모모Item, one must live!"
모모[30] A democrat.
모모While Jondrette thus talked, with an apparent incoherence which detracted nothing from the thoughtful and sagacious expression of his physiognomy, Marius raised his eyes, and perceived at the other end of the room a person whom he had not seen before. A man had just entered, so softly that the door had not been heard to turn on its hinges.
모모This man wore a violet knitted vest, which was old, worn, spotted, cut and gaping at every fold, wide trousers of cotton velvet, wooden shoes on his feet, no shirt, had his neck bare, his bare arms tattooed, and his face smeared with black.
모모He had seated himself in silence on the nearest bed, and, as he was behind Jondrette, he could only be indistinctly seen.
모모That sort of magnetic instinct which turns aside the gaze, caused M. Leblanc to turn round almost at the same moment as Marius. He could not refrain from a gesture of surprise which did not escape Jondrette.
모모"Ah!
모모I see!" exclaimed Jondrette, buttoning up his coat with an air of complaisance, "you are looking at your overcoat?
모모It fits me! My faith, but it fits me!"
모모"Who is that man?" said M. Leblanc.
모모"Him?" ejaculated Jondrette, "he's a neighbor of mine.
모모Don't pay any attention to him."
모모The neighbor was a singular-looking individual.
모모However, manufactories of chemical products abound in the Faubourg Saint-Marceau. Many of the workmen might have black faces.
모모Besides this, M. Leblanc's whole person was expressive of candid and intrepid confidence.
모모He went on:--
모모"Excuse me; what were you saying, M. Fabantou?"
모모"I was telling you, sir, and dear protector," replied Jondrette placing his elbows on the table and contemplating M. Leblanc with steady and tender eyes, not unlike the eyes of the boa-constrictor, "I was telling you, that I have a picture to sell."
모모A slight sound came from the door.
모모A second man had just entered and seated himself on the bed, behind Jondrette.
모모Like the first, his arms were bare, and he had a mask of ink or lampblack.
모모Although this man had, literally, glided into the room, he had not been able to prevent M. Leblanc catching sight of him.
모모"Don't mind them," said Jondrette, "they are people who belong in the house.
모모So I was saying, that there remains in my possession a valuable picture.
모모But stop, sir, take a look at it."
모모He rose, went to the wall at the foot of which stood the panel which we have already mentioned, and turned it round, still leaving it supported against the wall.
모모It really was something which resembled a picture, and which the candle illuminated, somewhat.
모모Marius could make nothing out of it, as Jondrette stood between the picture and him; he only saw a coarse daub, and a sort of principal personage colored with the harsh crudity of foreign canvasses and screen paintings.
모모"What is that?" asked M. Leblanc.
모모Jondrette exclaimed:--
모모"A painting by a master, a picture of great value, my benefactor! I am as much attached to it as I am to my two daughters; it recalls souvenirs to me!
모모But I have told you, and I will not take it back, that I am so wretched that I will part with it."
모모Either by chance, or because he had begun to feel a dawning uneasiness, M. Leblanc's glance returned to the bottom of the room as he examined the picture.
모모There were now four men, three seated on the bed, one standing near the door-post, all four with bare arms and motionless, with faces smeared with black.
모모One of those on the bed was leaning against the wall, with closed eyes, and it might have been supposed that he was asleep. He was old; his white hair contrasting with his blackened face produced a horrible effect.
모모The other two seemed to be young; one wore a beard, the other wore his hair long.
모모None of them had on shoes; those who did not wear socks were barefooted.
모모Jondrette noticed that M. Leblanc's eye was fixed on these men.
모모"They are friends.
모모They are neighbors," said he.
모모"Their faces are black because they work in charcoal.
모모They are chimney-builders. Don't trouble yourself about them, my benefactor, but buy my picture. Have pity on my misery.
모모I will not ask you much for it.
모모How much do you think it is worth?"
모모"Well," said M. Leblanc, looking Jondrette full in the eye, and with the manner of a man who is on his guard, "it is some signboard for a tavern, and is worth about three francs."
모모Jondrette replied sweetly:--
모모"Have you your pocket-book with you?
모모I should be satisfied with a thousand crowns."
모모M. Leblanc sprang up, placed his back against the wall, and cast a rapid glance around the room.
모모He had Jondrette on his left, on the side next the window, and the Jondrette woman and the four men on his right, on the side next the door.
모모The four men did not stir, and did not even seem to be looking on.
모모Jondrette had again begun to speak in a plaintive tone, with so vague an eye, and so lamentable an intonation, that M. Leblanc might have supposed that what he had before him was a man who had simply gone mad with misery.
모모"If you do not buy my picture, my dear benefactor," said Jondrette, "I shall be left without resources; there will be nothing left for me but to throw myself into the river.
모모When I think that I wanted to have my two girls taught the middle-class paper-box trade, the making of boxes for New Year's gifts!
모모Well!
모모A table with a board at the end to keep the glasses from falling off is required, then a special stove is needed, a pot with three compartments for the different degrees of strength of the paste, according as it is to be used for wood, paper, or stuff, a paring-knife to cut the cardboard, a mould to adjust it, a hammer to nail the steels, pincers, how the devil do I know what all?
모모And all that in order to earn four sous a day!
모모And you have to work fourteen hours a day! And each box passes through the workwoman's hands thirteen times! And you can't wet the paper!
모모And you mustn't spot anything!
모모And you must keep the paste hot.
모모The devil, I tell you!
모모Four sous a day! How do you suppose a man is to live?"
모모As he spoke, Jondrette did not look at M. Leblanc, who was observing him. M. Leblanc's eye was fixed on Jondrette, and Jondrette's eye was fixed on the door.
모모Marius' eager attention was transferred from one to the other. M. Leblanc seemed to be asking himself:
모모"Is this man an idiot?" Jondrette repeated two or three distinct times, with all manner of varying inflections of the whining and supplicating order: "There is nothing left for me but to throw myself into the river! I went down three steps at the side of the bridge of Austerlitz the other day for that purpose."
모모All at once his dull eyes lighted up with a hideous flash; the little man drew himself up and became terrible, took a step toward M. Leblanc and cried in a voice of thunder:
모모"That has nothing to do with the question!
모모Do you know me?"


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER XX (1)
모모THE TRAP
모모The door of the garret had just opened abruptly, and allowed a view of three men clad in blue linen blouses, and masked with masks of black paper.
모모The first was thin, and had a long, iron-tipped cudgel; the second, who was a sort of colossus, carried, by the middle of the handle, with the blade downward, a butcher's pole-axe for slaughtering cattle.
모모The third, a man with thick-set shoulders, not so slender as the first, held in his hand an enormous key stolen from the door of some prison.
모모It appeared that the arrival of these men was what Jondrette had been waiting for.
모모A rapid dialogue ensued between him and the man with the cudgel, the thin one.
모모"Is everything ready?" said Jondrette.
모모"Yes," replied the thin man.
모모"Where is Montparnasse?"
모모"The young principal actor stopped to chat with your girl."
모모"Which?"
모모"The eldest."
모모"Is there a carriage at the door?"
모모"Yes."
모모"Is the team harnessed?"
모모"Yes."
모모"With two good horses?"
모모"Excellent."
모모"Is it waiting where I ordered?"
모모"Yes."
모모"Good," said Jondrette.
모모M. Leblanc was very pale.
모모He was scrutinizing everything around him in the den, like a man who understands what he has fallen into, and his head, directed in turn toward all the heads which surrounded him, moved on his neck with an astonished and attentive slowness, but there was nothing in his air which resembled fear.
모모He had improvised an intrenchment out of the table; and the man, who but an instant previously, had borne merely the appearance of a kindly old man, had suddenly become a sort of athlete, and placed his robust fist on the back of his chair, with a formidable and surprising gesture.
모모This old man, who was so firm and so brave in the presence of such a danger, seemed to possess one of those natures which are as courageous as they are kind, both easily and simply. The father of a woman whom we love is never a stranger to us. Marius felt proud of that unknown man.
모모Three of the men, of whom Jondrette had said:
모모"They are chimney-builders," had armed themselves from the pile of old iron, one with a heavy pair of shears, the second with weighing-tongs, the third with a hammer, and had placed themselves across the entrance without uttering a syllable.
모모The old man had remained on the bed, and had merely opened his eyes.
모모The Jondrette woman had seated herself beside him.
모모Marius decided that in a few seconds more the moment for intervention would arrive, and he raised his right hand towards the ceiling, in the direction of the corridor, in readiness to discharge his pistol.
모모Jondrette having terminated his colloquy with the man with the cudgel, turned once more to M. Leblanc, and repeated his question, accompanying it with that low, repressed, and terrible laugh which was peculiar to him:--
모모"So you do not recognize me?"
모모M. Leblanc looked him full in the face, and replied:--
모모"No."
모모Then Jondrette advanced to the table.
모모He leaned across the candle, crossing his arms, putting his angular and ferocious jaw close to M. Leblanc's calm face, and advancing as far as possible without forcing M. Leblanc to retreat, and, in this posture of a wild beast who is about to bite, he exclaimed:--
모모"My name is not Fabantou, my name is not Jondrette, my name is Thenardier.
모모I am the inn-keeper of Montfermeil! Do you understand?
모모Thenardier!
모모Now do you know me?"
모모An almost imperceptible flush crossed M. Leblanc's brow, and he replied with a voice which neither trembled nor rose above its ordinary level, with his accustomed placidity:--
모모"No more than before."
모모Marius did not hear this reply.
모모Any one who had seen him at that moment through the darkness would have perceived that he was haggard, stupid, thunder-struck. At the moment when Jondrette said: "My name is Thenardier," Marius had trembled in every limb, and had leaned against the wall, as though he felt the cold of a steel blade through his heart.
모모Then his right arm, all ready to discharge the signal shot, dropped slowly, and at the moment when Jondrette repeated, "Thenardier, do you understand?" Marius's faltering fingers had come near letting the pistol fall. Jondrette, by revealing his identity, had not moved M. Leblanc, but he had quite upset Marius.
모모That name of Thenardier, with which M. Leblanc did not seem to be acquainted, Marius knew well. Let the reader recall what that name meant to him!
모모That name he had worn on his heart, inscribed in his father's testament! He bore it at the bottom of his mind, in the depths of his memory, in that sacred injunction:
모모"A certain Thenardier saved my life. If my son encounters him, he will do him all the good that lies in his power."
모모That name, it will be remembered, was one of the pieties of his soul; he mingled it with the name of his father in his worship.
모모What!
모모This man was that Thenardier, that inn-keeper of Montfermeil whom he had so long and so vainly sought!
모모He had found him at last, and how?
모모His father's saviour was a ruffian! That man, to whose service Marius was burning to devote himself, was a monster!
모모That liberator of Colonel Pontmercy was on the point of committing a crime whose scope Marius did not, as yet, clearly comprehend, but which resembled an assassination! And against whom, great God! what a fatality!
모모What a bitter mockery of fate!
모모His father had commanded him from the depths of his coffin to do all the good in his power to this Thenardier, and for four years Marius had cherished no other thought than to acquit this debt of his father's, and at the moment when he was on the eve of having a brigand seized in the very act of crime by justice, destiny cried to him:
모모"This is Thenardier!"
모모He could at last repay this man for his father's life, saved amid a hail-storm of grape-shot on the heroic field of Waterloo, and repay it with the scaffold! He had sworn to himself that if ever he found that Thenardier, he would address him only by throwing himself at his feet; and now he actually had found him, but it was only to deliver him over to the executioner!
모모His father said to him:
모모"Succor Thenardier!" And he replied to that adored and sainted voice by crushing Thenardier! He was about to offer to his father in his grave the spectacle of that man who had torn him from death at the peril of his own life, executed on the Place Saint-Jacques through the means of his son, of that Marius to whom he had entrusted that man by his will! And what a mockery to have so long worn on his breast his father's last commands, written in his own hand, only to act in so horribly contrary a sense!
모모But, on the other hand, now look on that trap and not prevent it!
모모Condemn the victim and to spare the assassin! Could one be held to any gratitude towards so miserable a wretch? All the ideas which Marius had cherished for the last four years were pierced through and through, as it were, by this unforeseen blow.
모모He shuddered.
모모Everything depended on him.
모모Unknown to themselves, he held in his hand all those beings who were moving about there before his eyes.
모모If he fired his pistol, M. Leblanc was saved, and Thenardier lost; if he did not fire, M. Leblanc would be sacrificed, and, who knows?
모모Thenardier would escape.
모모Should he dash down the one or allow the other to fall?
모모Remorse awaited him in either case.
모모What was he to do?
모모What should he choose?
모모Be false to the most imperious souvenirs, to all those solemn vows to himself, to the most sacred duty, to the most venerated text!
모모Should he ignore his father's testament, or allow the perpetration of a crime! On the one hand, it seemed to him that he heard "his Ursule" supplicating for her father and on the other, the colonel commending Thenardier to his care.
모모He felt that he was going mad.
모모His knees gave way beneath him.
모모And he had not even the time for deliberation, so great was the fury with which the scene before his eyes was hastening to its catastrophe.
모모It was like a whirlwind of which he had thought himself the master, and which was now sweeping him away. He was on the verge of swooning.
모모In the meantime, Thenardier, whom we shall henceforth call by no other name, was pacing up and down in front of the table in a sort of frenzy and wild triumph.
모모He seized the candle in his fist, and set it on the chimney-piece with so violent a bang that the wick came near being extinguished, and the tallow bespattered the wall.
모모Then he turned to M. Leblanc with a horrible look, and spit out these words:--
모모"Done for!
모모Smoked brown!
모모Cooked!
모모Spitchcocked!"
모모And again he began to march back and forth, in full eruption.
모모"Ah!" he cried, "so I've found you again at last, Mister philanthropist! Mister threadbare millionnaire!
모모Mister giver of dolls! you old ninny! Ah! so you don't recognize me!
모모No, it wasn't you who came to Montfermeil, to my inn, eight years ago, on Christmas eve, 1823! It wasn't you who carried off that Fantine's child from me! The Lark!
모모It wasn't you who had a yellow great-coat! No! Nor a package of duds in your hand, as you had this morning here! Say, wife, it seems to be his mania to carry packets of woollen stockings into houses!
모모Old charity monger, get out with you! Are you a hosier, Mister millionnaire?
모모You give away your stock in trade to the poor, holy man!
모모What bosh! merry Andrew! Ah! and you don't recognize me?
모모Well, I recognize you, that I do! I recognized you the very moment you poked your snout in here. Ah! you'll find out presently, that it isn't all roses to thrust yourself in that fashion into people's houses, under the pretext that they are taverns, in wretched clothes, with the air of a poor man, to whom one would give a sou, to deceive persons, to play the generous, to take away their means of livelihood, and to make threats in the woods, and you can't call things quits because afterwards, when people are ruined, you bring a coat that is too large, and two miserable hospital blankets, you old blackguard, you child-stealer!"
모모He paused, and seemed to be talking to himself for a moment. One would have said that his wrath had fallen into some hole, like the Rhone; then, as though he were concluding aloud the things which he had been saying to himself in a whisper, he smote the table with his fist, and shouted:--
모모"And with his goody-goody air!"
모모And, apostrophizing M. Leblanc:--
모모"Parbleu!
모모You made game of me in the past!
모모You are the cause of all my misfortunes!
모모For fifteen hundred francs you got a girl whom I had, and who certainly belonged to rich people, and who had already brought in a great deal of money, and from whom I might have extracted enough to live on all my life!
모모A girl who would have made up to me for everything that I lost in that vile cook-shop, where there was nothing but one continual row, and where, like a fool, I ate up my last farthing!
모모Oh!
모모I wish all the wine folks drank in my house had been poison to those who drank it! Well, never mind!
모모Say, now!
모모You must have thought me ridiculous when you went off with the Lark!
모모You had your cudgel in the forest. You were the stronger.
모모Revenge.
모모I'm the one to hold the trumps to-day! You're in a sorry case, my good fellow!
모모Oh, but I can laugh!
모모Really, I laugh!
모모Didn't he fall into the trap! I told him that I was an actor, that my name was Fabantou, that I had played comedy with Mamselle Mars, with Mamselle Muche, that my landlord insisted on being paid tomorrow, the 4th of February, and he didn't even notice that the 8th of January, and not the 4th of February is the time when the quarter runs out!
모모Absurd idiot! And the four miserable Philippes which he has brought me!
모모Scoundrel! He hadn't the heart even to go as high as a hundred francs!
모모And how he swallowed my platitudes!
모모That did amuse me.
모모I said to myself: `Blockhead! Come, I've got you!
모모I lick your paws this morning, but I'll gnaw your heart this evening!'"
모모Thenardier paused.
모모He was out of breath.
모모His little, narrow chest panted like a forge bellows.
모모His eyes were full of the ignoble happiness of a feeble, cruel, and cowardly creature, which finds that it can, at last, harass what it has feared, and insult what it has flattered, the joy of a dwarf who should be able to set his heel on the head of Goliath, the joy of a jackal which is beginning to rend a sick bull, so nearly dead that he can no longer defend himself, but sufficiently alive to suffer still.
모모M. Leblanc did not interrupt him, but said to him when he paused:--
모모"I do not know what you mean to say.
모모You are mistaken in me.
모모I am a very poor man, and anything but a millionnaire.
모모I do not know you. You are mistaking me for some other person."
모모"Ah!" roared Thenardier hoarsely, "a pretty lie!
모모You stick to that pleasantry, do you!
모모You're floundering, my old buck! Ah!
모모You don't remember!
모모You don't see who I am?"
모모"Excuse me, sir," said M. Leblanc with a politeness of accent, which at that moment seemed peculiarly strange and powerful, "I see that you are a villain!"
모모Who has not remarked the fact that odious creatures possess a susceptibility of their own, that monsters are ticklish!
모모At this word "villain," the female Thenardier sprang from the bed, Thenardier grasped his chair as though he were about to crush it in his hands. "Don't you stir!" he shouted to his wife; and, turning to M. Leblanc:--
모모"Villain!
모모Yes, I know that you call us that, you rich gentlemen! Stop! it's true that I became bankrupt, that I am in hiding, that I have no bread, that I have not a single sou, that I am a villain! It's three days since I have had anything to eat, so I'm a villain! Ah! you folks warm your feet, you have Sakoski boots, you have wadded great-coats, like archbishops, you lodge on the first floor in houses that have porters, you eat truffles, you eat asparagus at forty francs the bunch in the month of January, and green peas, you gorge yourselves, and when you want to know whether it is cold, you look in the papers to see what the engineer Chevalier's thermometer says about it.
모모We, it is we who are thermometers. We don't need to go out and look on the quay at the corner of the Tour de l'Horologe, to find out the number of degrees of cold; we feel our blood congealing in our veins, and the ice forming round our hearts, and we say:
모모`There is no God!'
모모And you come to our caverns, yes our caverns, for the purpose of calling us villains! But we'll devour you!
모모But we'll devour you, poor little things! Just see here, Mister millionnaire:
모모I have been a solid man, I have held a license, I have been an elector, I am a bourgeois, that I am!
모모And it's quite possible that you are not!"
모모Here Thenardier took a step towards the men who stood near the door, and added with a shudder:--
모모"When I think that he has dared to come here and talk to me like a cobbler!"
모모Then addressing M. Leblanc with a fresh outburst of frenzy:--
모모"And listen to this also, Mister philanthropist!
모모I'm not a suspicious character, not a bit of it!
모모I'm not a man whose name nobody knows, and who comes and abducts children from houses! I'm an old French soldier, I ought to have been decorated! I was at Waterloo, so I was!
모모And in the battle I saved a general called the Comte of I don't know what.
모모He told me his name, but his beastly voice was so weak that I didn't hear.
모모All I caught was Merci [thanks]. I'd rather have had his name than his thanks. That would have helped me to find him again.
모모The picture that you see here, and which was painted by David at Bruqueselles,--do you know what it represents?
모모It represents me.
모모David wished to immortalize that feat of prowess.
모모I have that general on my back, and I am carrying him through the grape-shot. There's the history of it! That general never did a single thing for me; he was no better than the rest!
모모But none the less, I saved his life at the risk of my own, and I have the certificate of the fact in my pocket! I am a soldier of Waterloo, by all the furies!
모모And now that I have had the goodness to tell you all this, let's have an end of it. I want money, I want a deal of money, I must have an enormous lot of money, or I'll exterminate you, by the thunder of the good God!"
모모Marius had regained some measure of control over his anguish, and was listening.
모모The last possibility of doubt had just vanished. It certainly was the Thenardier of the will.
모모Marius shuddered at that reproach of ingratitude directed against his father, and which he was on the point of so fatally justifying.
모모His perplexity was redoubled.
모모Moreover, there was in all these words of Thenardier, in his accent, in his gesture, in his glance which darted flames at every word, there was, in this explosion of an evil nature disclosing everything, in that mixture of braggadocio and abjectness, of pride and pettiness, of rage and folly, in that chaos of real griefs and false sentiments, in that immodesty of a malicious man tasting the voluptuous delights of violence, in that shameless nudity of a repulsive soul, in that conflagration of all sufferings combined with all hatreds, something which was as hideous as evil, and as heart-rending as the truth.
모모The picture of the master, the painting by David which he had proposed that M. Leblanc should purchase, was nothing else, as the reader has divined, than the sign of his tavern painted, as it will be remembered, by himself, the only relic which he had preserved from his shipwreck at Montfermeil.
모모As he had ceased to intercept Marius' visual ray, Marius could examine this thing, and in the daub, he actually did recognize a battle, a background of smoke, and a man carrying another man. It was the group composed of Pontmercy and Thenardier; the sergeant the rescuer, the colonel rescued.
모모Marius was like a drunken man; this picture restored his father to life in some sort; it was no longer the signboard of the wine-shop at Montfermeil, it was a resurrection; a tomb had yawned, a phantom had risen there.
모모Marius heard his heart beating in his temples, he had the cannon of Waterloo in his ears, his bleeding father, vaguely depicted on that sinister panel terrified him, and it seemed to him that the misshapen spectre was gazing intently at him.
모모When Thenardier had recovered his breath, he turned his bloodshot eyes on M. Leblanc, and said to him in a low, curt voice:--
모모"What have you to say before we put the handcuffs on you?"
모모M. Leblanc held his peace.
모모In the midst of this silence, a cracked voice launched this lugubrious sarcasm from the corridor:--
모모"If there's any wood to be split, I'm there!"
모모It was the man with the axe, who was growing merry.
모모At the same moment, an enormous, bristling, and clayey face made its appearance at the door, with a hideous laugh which exhibited not teeth, but fangs.
모모It was the face of the man with the butcher's axe.
모모"Why have you taken off your mask?" cried Thenardier in a rage.
모모"For fun," retorted the man.
모모For the last few minutes M. Leblanc had appeared to be watching and following all the movements of Thenardier, who, blinded and dazzled by his own rage, was stalking to and fro in the den with full confidence that the door was guarded, and of holding an unarmed man fast, he being armed himself, of being nine against one, supposing that the female Thenardier counted for but one man.
모모During his address to the man with the pole-axe, he had turned his back to M. Leblanc.
모모M. Leblanc seized this moment, overturned the chair with his foot and the table with his fist, and with one bound, with prodigious agility, before Thenardier had time to turn round, he had reached the window. To open it, to scale the frame, to bestride it, was the work of a second only.
모모He was half out when six robust fists seized him and dragged him back energetically into the hovel.
모모These were the three "chimney-builders," who had flung themselves upon him. At the same time the Thenardier woman had wound her hands in his hair.
모모At the trampling which ensued, the other ruffians rushed up from the corridor.
모모The old man on the bed, who seemed under the influence of wine, descended from the pallet and came reeling up, with a stone-breaker's hammer in his hand.
모모One of the "chimney-builders," whose smirched face was lighted up by the candle, and in whom Marius recognized, in spite of his daubing, Panchaud, alias Printanier, alias Bigrenaille, lifted above M. Leblanc's head a sort of bludgeon made of two balls of lead, at the two ends of a bar of iron.
모모Marius could not resist this sight.
모모"My father," he thought, "forgive me!"
모모And his finger sought the trigger of his pistol.
모모The shot was on the point of being discharged when Thenardier's voice shouted:--
모모"Don't harm him!"
모모This desperate attempt of the victim, far from exasperating Thenardier, had calmed him.
모모There existed in him two men, the ferocious man and the adroit man.
모모Up to that moment, in the excess of his triumph in the presence of the prey which had been brought down, and which did not stir, the ferocious man had prevailed; when the victim struggled and tried to resist, the adroit man reappeared and took the upper hand.
모모"Don't hurt him!" he repeated, and without suspecting it, his first success was to arrest the pistol in the act of being discharged, and to paralyze Marius, in whose opinion the urgency of the case disappeared, and who, in the face of this new phase, saw no inconvenience in waiting a while longer.
모모Who knows whether some chance would not arise which would deliver him from the horrible alternative of allowing Ursule's father to perish, or of destroying the colonel's saviour?
모모A herculean struggle had begun.
모모With one blow full in the chest, M. Leblanc had sent the old man tumbling, rolling in the middle of the room, then with two backward sweeps of his hand he had overthrown two more assailants, and he held one under each of his knees; the wretches were rattling in the throat beneath this pressure as under a granite millstone; but the other four had seized the formidable old man by both arms and the back of his neck, and were holding him doubled up over the two "chimney-builders" on the floor.
모모Thus, the master of some and mastered by the rest, crushing those beneath him and stifling under those on top of him, endeavoring in vain to shake off all the efforts which were heaped upon him, M. Leblanc disappeared under the horrible group of ruffians like the wild boar beneath a howling pile of dogs and hounds.
모모They succeeded in overthrowing him upon the bed nearest the window, and there they held him in awe.
모모The Thenardier woman had not released her clutch on his hair.
모모"Don't you mix yourself up in this affair," said Thenardier. "You'll tear your shawl."
모모The Thenardier obeyed, as the female wolf obeys the male wolf, with a growl.
모모"Now," said Thenardier, "search him, you other fellows!"
모모M. Leblanc seemed to have renounced the idea of resistance.
모모They searched him.
모모He had nothing on his person except a leather purse containing six francs, and his handkerchief.
모모Thenardier put the handkerchief into his own pocket.
모모"What!
모모No pocket-book?" he demanded.
모모"No, nor watch," replied one of the "chimney-builders."
모모"Never mind," murmured the masked man who carried the big key, in the voice of a ventriloquist, "he's a tough old fellow."
모모Thenardier went to the corner near the door, picked up a bundle of ropes and threw them at the men.
모모"Tie him to the leg of the bed," said he.
모모And, catching sight of the old man who had been stretched across the room by the blow from M. Leblanc's fist, and who made no movement, he added:--
모모"Is Boulatruelle dead?"
모모"No," replied Bigrenaille, "he's drunk."
모모"Sweep him into a corner," said Thenardier.
모모Two of the "chimney-builders" pushed the drunken man into the corner near the heap of old iron with their feet.
모모"Babet," said Thenardier in a low tone to the man with the cudgel, "why did you bring so many; they were not needed."
모모"What can you do?" replied the man with the cudgel, "they all wanted to be in it.
모모This is a bad season.
모모There's no business going on."
모모The pallet on which M. Leblanc had been thrown was a sort of hospital bed, elevated on four coarse wooden legs, roughly hewn.
모모M. Leblanc let them take their own course.
모모The ruffians bound him securely, in an upright attitude, with his feet on the ground at the head of the bed, the end which was most remote from the window, and nearest to the fireplace.
모모When the last knot had been tied, Thenardier took a chair and seated himself almost facing M. Leblanc.
모모Thenardier no longer looked like himself; in the course of a few moments his face had passed from unbridled violence to tranquil and cunning sweetness.
모모Marius found it difficult to recognize in that polished smile of a man in official life the almost bestial mouth which had been foaming but a moment before; he gazed with amazement on that fantastic and alarming metamorphosis, and he felt as a man might feel who should behold a tiger converted into a lawyer.
모모"Monsieur--" said Thenardier.
모모And dismissing with a gesture the ruffians who still kept their hands on M. Leblanc:--
모모"Stand off a little, and let me have a talk with the gentleman."
모모All retired towards the door.
모모He went on:--
모모"Monsieur, you did wrong to try to jump out of the window. You might have broken your leg.
모모Now, if you will permit me, we will converse quietly.
모모In the first place, I must communicate to you an observation which I have made which is, that you have not uttered the faintest cry."
모모Thenardier was right, this detail was correct, although it had escaped Marius in his agitation.
모모M. Leblanc had barely pronounced a few words, without raising his voice, and even during his struggle with the six ruffians near the window he had preserved the most profound and singular silence.
모모Thenardier continued:--
모모"Mon Dieu!
모모You might have shouted `stop thief' a bit, and I should not have thought it improper.
모모`Murder!' That, too, is said occasionally, and, so far as I am concerned, I should not have taken it in bad part.
모모It is very natural that you should make a little row when you find yourself with persons who don't inspire you with sufficient confidence.
모모You might have done that, and no one would have troubled you on that account.
모모You would not even have been gagged.
모모And I will tell you why.
모모This room is very private. That's its only recommendation, but it has that in its favor. You might fire off a mortar and it would produce about as much noise at the nearest police station as the snores of a drunken man. Here a cannon would make a boum, and the thunder would make a pouf. It's a handy lodging.
모모But, in short, you did not shout, and it is better so.
모모I present you my compliments, and I will tell you the conclusion that I draw from that fact:
모모My dear sir, when a man shouts, who comes?
모모The police.
모모And after the police? Justice.
모모Well!
모모You have not made an outcry; that is because you don't care to have the police and the courts come in any more than we do. It is because,--I have long suspected it,--you have some interest in hiding something.
모모On our side we have the same interest. So we can come to an understanding."
모모As he spoke thus, it seemed as though Thenardier, who kept his eyes fixed on M. Leblanc, were trying to plunge the sharp points which darted from the pupils into the very conscience of his prisoner. Moreover, his language, which was stamped with a sort of moderated, subdued insolence and crafty insolence, was reserved and almost choice, and in that rascal, who had been nothing but a robber a short time previously, one now felt "the man who had studied for the priesthood."
모모The silence preserved by the prisoner, that precaution which had been carried to the point of forgetting all anxiety for his own life, that resistance opposed to the first impulse of nature, which is to utter a cry, all this, it must be confessed, now that his attention had been called to it, troubled Marius, and affected him with painful astonishment.
모모Thenardier's well-grounded observation still further obscured for Marius the dense mystery which enveloped that grave and singular person on whom Courfeyrac had bestowed the sobriquet of Monsieur Leblanc.
모모But whoever he was, bound with ropes, surrounded with executioners, half plunged, so to speak, in a grave which was closing in upon him to the extent of a degree with every moment that passed, in the presence of Thenardier's wrath, as in the presence of his sweetness, this man remained impassive; and Marius could not refrain from admiring at such a moment the superbly melancholy visage.
모모Here, evidently, was a soul which was inaccessible to terror, and which did not know the meaning of despair.
모모Here was one of those men who command amazement in desperate circumstances. Extreme as was the crisis, inevitable as was the catastrophe, there was nothing here of the agony of the drowning man, who opens his horror-filled eyes under the water.
모모Thenardier rose in an unpretending manner, went to the fireplace, shoved aside the screen, which he leaned against the neighboring pallet, and thus unmasked the brazier full of glowing coals, in which the prisoner could plainly see the chisel white-hot and spotted here and there with tiny scarlet stars.
모모Then Thenardier returned to his seat beside M. Leblanc.
모모"I continue," said he.
모모"We can come to an understanding. Let us arrange this matter in an amicable way.
모모I was wrong to lose my temper just now, I don't know what I was thinking of, I went a great deal too far, I said extravagant things.
모모For example, because you are a millionnaire, I told you that I exacted money, a lot of money, a deal of money.
모모That would not be reasonable. Mon Dieu, in spite of your riches, you have expenses of your own-- who has not?
모모I don't want to ruin you, I am not a greedy fellow, after all.
모모I am not one of those people who, because they have the advantage of the position, profit by the fact to make themselves ridiculous.
모모Why, I'm taking things into consideration and making a sacrifice on my side.
모모I only want two hundred thousand francs."


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER XX (2) 
모모M. Leblanc uttered not a word.
모모Thenardier went on:--
모모"You see that I put not a little water in my wine; I'm very moderate. I don't know the state of your fortune, but I do know that you don't stick at money, and a benevolent man like yourself can certainly give two hundred thousand francs to the father of a family who is out of luck.
모모Certainly, you are reasonable, too; you haven't imagined that I should take all the trouble I have to-day and organized this affair this evening, which has been labor well bestowed, in the opinion of these gentlemen, merely to wind up by asking you for enough to go and drink red wine at fifteen sous and eat veal at Desnoyer's. Two hundred thousand francs--it's surely worth all that. This trifle once out of your pocket, I guarantee you that that's the end of the matter, and that you have no further demands to fear. You will say to me:
모모`But I haven't two hundred thousand francs about me.'
모모Oh!
모모I'm not extortionate.
모모I don't demand that. I only ask one thing of you.
모모Have the goodness to write what I am about to dictate to you."
모모Here Thenardier paused; then he added, emphasizing his words, and casting a smile in the direction of the brazier:--
모모"I warn you that I shall not admit that you don't know how to write."
모모A grand inquisitor might have envied that smile.
모모Thenardier pushed the table close to M. Leblanc, and took an inkstand, a pen, and a sheet of paper from the drawer which he left half open, and in which gleamed the long blade of the knife.
모모He placed the sheet of paper before M. Leblanc.
모모"Write," said he.
모모The prisoner spoke at last.
모모"How do you expect me to write?
모모I am bound."
모모"That's true, excuse me!" ejaculated Thenardier, "you are quite right."
모모And turning to Bigrenaille:--
모모"Untie the gentleman's right arm."
모모Panchaud, alias Printanier, alias Bigrenaille, executed Thenardier's order.
모모When the prisoner's right arm was free, Thenardier dipped the pen in the ink and presented it to him.
모모"Understand thoroughly, sir, that you are in our power, at our discretion, that no human power can get you out of this, and that we shall be really grieved if we are forced to proceed to disagreeable extremities. I know neither your name, nor your address, but I warn you, that you will remain bound until the person charged with carrying the letter which you are about to write shall have returned.
모모Now, be so good as to write."
모모"What?" demanded the prisoner.
모모"I will dictate."
모모M. Leblanc took the pen.
모모Thenardier began to dictate:--
모모"My daughter--"
모모The prisoner shuddered, and raised his eyes to Thenardier.
모모"Put down `My dear daughter'--" said Thenardier.
모모M. Leblanc obeyed.
모모Thenardier continued:--
모모"Come instantly--"
모모He paused:--
모모"You address her as thou, do you not?"
모모"Who?" asked M. Leblanc.
모모"Parbleu!" cried Thenardier, "the little one, the Lark."
모모M. Leblanc replied without the slightest apparent emotion:--
모모"I do not know what you mean."
모모"Go on, nevertheless," ejaculated Thenardier, and he continued to dictate:--
모모"Come immediately, I am in absolute need of thee.
모모The person who will deliver this note to thee is instructed to conduct thee to me. I am waiting for thee.
모모Come with confidence."
모모M. Leblanc had written the whole of this.
모모Thenardier resumed:--
모모"Ah! erase `come with confidence'; that might lead her to suppose that everything was not as it should be, and that distrust is possible."
모모M. Leblanc erased the three words.
모모"Now," pursued Thenardier, "sign it.
모모What's your name?"
모모The prisoner laid down the pen and demanded:--
모모"For whom is this letter?"
모모"You know well," retorted Thenardier, "for the little one I just told you so."
모모It was evident that Thenardier avoided naming the young girl in question.
모모He said "the Lark," he said "the little one," but he did not pronounce her name--the precaution of a clever man guarding his secret from his accomplices.
모모To mention the name was to deliver the whole "affair" into their hands, and to tell them more about it than there was any need of their knowing.
모모He went on:--
모모"Sign.
모모What is your name?"
모모"Urbain Fabre," said the prisoner.
모모Thenardier, with the movement of a cat, dashed his hand into his pocket and drew out the handkerchief which had been seized on M. Leblanc. He looked for the mark on it, and held it close to the candle.
모모"U. F. That's it.
모모Urbain Fabre.
모모Well, sign it U. F."
모모The prisoner signed.
모모"As two hands are required to fold the letter, give it to me, I will fold it."
모모That done, Thenardier resumed:--
모모"Address it, `Mademoiselle Fabre,' at your house.
모모I know that you live a long distance from here, near Saint-Jacquesdu-Haut-Pas, because you go to mass there every day, but I don't know in what street. I see that you understand your situation.
모모As you have not lied about your name, you will not lie about your address.
모모Write it yourself."
모모The prisoner paused thoughtfully for a moment, then he took the pen and wrote:--
모모"Mademoiselle Fabre, at M. Urbain Fabre's, Rue Saint-Dominique-D'Enfer, No. 17."
모모Thenardier seized the letter with a sort of feverish convulsion.
모모"Wife!" he cried.
모모The Thenardier woman hastened to him.
모모"Here's the letter.
모모You know what you have to do.
모모There is a carriage at the door.
모모Set out at once, and return ditto."
모모And addressing the man with the meat-axe:--
모모"Since you have taken off your nose-screen, accompany the mistress. You will get up behind the fiacre.
모모You know where you left the team?"
모모"Yes," said the man.
모모And depositing his axe in a corner, he followed Madame Thenardier.
모모As they set off, Thenardier thrust his head through the half-open door, and shouted into the corridor:--
모모"Above all things, don't lose the letter! remember that you carry two hundred thousand francs with you!"
모모The Thenardier's hoarse voice replied:--
모모"Be easy.
모모I have it in my bosom."
모모A minute had not elapsed, when the sound of the cracking of a whip was heard, which rapidly retreated and died away.
모모"Good!" growled Thenardier.
모모"They're going at a fine pace. At such a gallop, the bourgeoise will be back inside three-quarters of an hour."
모모He drew a chair close to the fireplace, folding his arms, and presenting his muddy boots to the brazier.
모모"My feet are cold!" said he.
모모Only five ruffians now remained in the den with Thenardier and the prisoner.
모모These men, through the black masks or paste which covered their faces, and made of them, at fear's pleasure, charcoal-burners, negroes, or demons, had a stupid and gloomy air, and it could be felt that they perpetrated a crime like a bit of work, tranquilly, without either wrath or mercy, with a sort of ennui.
모모They were crowded together in one corner like brutes, and remained silent.
모모Thenardier warmed his feet.
모모The prisoner had relapsed into his taciturnity.
모모A sombre calm had succeeded to the wild uproar which had filled the garret but a few moments before.
모모The candle, on which a large "stranger" had formed, cast but a dim light in the immense hovel, the brazier had grown dull, and all those monstrous heads cast misshapen shadows on the walls and ceiling.
모모No sound was audible except the quiet breathing of the old drunken man, who was fast asleep.
모모Marius waited in a state of anxiety that was augmented by every trifle. The enigma was more impenetrable than ever.
모모Who was this "little one" whom Thenardier had called the Lark? Was she his "Ursule"? The prisoner had not seemed to be affected by that word, "the Lark," and had replied in the most natural manner in the world:
모모"I do not know what you mean."
모모On the other hand, the two letters U. F. were explained; they meant Urbain Fabre; and Ursule was no longer named Ursule.
모모This was what Marius perceived most clearly of all.
모모A sort of horrible fascination held him nailed to his post, from which he was observing and commanding this whole scene. There he stood, almost incapable of movement or reflection, as though annihilated by the abominable things viewed at such close quarters. He waited, in the hope of some incident, no matter of what nature, since he could not collect his thoughts and did not know upon what course to decide.
모모"In any case," he said, "if she is the Lark, I shall see her, for the Thenardier woman is to bring her hither.
모모That will be the end, and then I will give my life and my blood if necessary, but I will deliver her!
모모Nothing shall stop me."
모모Nearly half an hour passed in this manner.
모모Thenardier seemed to be absorbed in gloomy reflections, the prisoner did not stir. Still, Marius fancied that at intervals, and for the last few moments, he had heard a faint, dull noise in the direction of the prisoner.
모모All at once, Thenardier addressed the prisoner:
모모"By the way, Monsieur Fabre, I might as well say it to you at once."
모모These few words appeared to be the beginning of an explanation. Marius strained his ears.
모모"My wife will be back shortly, don't get impatient.
모모I think that the Lark really is your daughter, and it seems to me quite natural that you should keep her.
모모Only, listen to me a bit.
모모My wife will go and hunt her up with your letter.
모모I told my wife to dress herself in the way she did, so that your young lady might make no difficulty about following her.
모모They will both enter the carriage with my comrade behind.
모모Somewhere, outside the barrier, there is a trap harnessed to two very good horses.
모모Your young lady will be taken to it. She will alight from the fiacre.
모모My comrade will enter the other vehicle with her, and my wife will come back here to tell us: `It's done.'
모모As for the young lady, no harm will be done to her; the trap will conduct her to a place where she will be quiet, and just as soon as you have handed over to me those little two hundred thousand francs, she will be returned to you.
모모If you have me arrested, my comrade will give a turn of his thumb to the Lark, that's all."
모모The prisoner uttered not a syllable.
모모After a pause, Thenardier continued:--
모모"It's very simple, as you see.
모모There'll be no harm done unless you wish that there should be harm done.
모모I'm telling you how things stand. I warn you so that you may be prepared."
모모He paused:
모모the prisoner did not break the silence, and Thenardier resumed:--
모모"As soon as my wife returns and says to me:
모모`The Lark is on the way,' we will release you, and you will be free to go and sleep at home. You see that our intentions are not evil."
모모Terrible images passed through Marius' mind.
모모What!
모모That young girl whom they were abducting was not to be brought back? One of those monsters was to bear her off into the darkness? Whither?
모모And what if it were she!
모모It was clear that it was she.
모모Marius felt his heart stop beating.
모모What was he to do?
모모Discharge the pistol?
모모Place all those scoundrels in the hands of justice?
모모But the horrible man with the meat-axe would, none the less, be out of reach with the young girl, and Marius reflected on Thenardier's words, of which he perceived the bloody significance:
모모"If you have me arrested, my comrade will give a turn of his thumb to the Lark."
모모Now, it was not alone by the colonel's testament, it was by his own love, it was by the peril of the one he loved, that he felt himself restrained.
모모This frightful situation, which had already lasted above half an hour, was changing its aspect every moment.
모모Marius had sufficient strength of mind to review in succession all the most heart-breaking conjectures, seeking hope and finding none.
모모The tumult of his thoughts contrasted with the funereal silence of the den.
모모In the midst of this silence, the door at the bottom of the staircase was heard to open and shut again.
모모The prisoner made a movement in his bonds.
모모"Here's the bourgeoise," said Thenardier.
모모He had hardly uttered the words, when the Thenardier woman did in fact rush hastily into the room, red, panting, breathless, with flaming eyes, and cried, as she smote her huge hands on her thighs simultaneously:--
모모"False address!"
모모The ruffian who had gone with her made his appearance behind her and picked up his axe again.
모모She resumed:--
모모"Nobody there!
모모Rue Saint-Dominique, No. 17, no Monsieur Urbain Fabre! They know not what it means!"
모모She paused, choking, then went on:--
모모"Monsieur Thenardier!
모모That old fellow has duped you!
모모You are too good, you see!
모모If it had been me, I'd have chopped the beast in four quarters to begin with!
모모And if he had acted ugly, I'd have boiled him alive!
모모He would have been obliged to speak, and say where the girl is, and where he keeps his shiners!
모모That's the way I should have managed matters!
모모People are perfectly right when they say that men are a deal stupider than women!
모모Nobody at No. 17. It's nothing but a big carriage gate!
모모No Monsieur Fabre in the Rue Saint-Dominique! And after all that racing and fee to the coachman and all!
모모I spoke to both the porter and the portress, a fine, stout woman, and they know nothing about him!"
모모Marius breathed freely once more.
모모She, Ursule or the Lark, he no longer knew what to call her, was safe.
모모While his exasperated wife vociferated, Thenardier had seated himself on the table.
모모For several minutes he uttered not a word, but swung his right foot, which hung down, and stared at the brazier with an air of savage revery.
모모Finally, he said to the prisoner, with a slow and singularly ferocious tone:
모모"A false address?
모모What did you expect to gain by that?"
모모"To gain time!" cried the prisoner in a thundering voice, and at the same instant he shook off his bonds; they were cut. The prisoner was only attached to the bed now by one leg.
모모Before the seven men had time to collect their senses and dash forward, he had bent down into the fireplace, had stretched out his hand to the brazier, and had then straightened himself up again, and now Thenardier, the female Thenardier, and the ruffians, huddled in amazement at the extremity of the hovel, stared at him in stupefaction, as almost free and in a formidable attitude, he brandished above his head the red-hot chisel, which emitted a threatening glow.
모모The judicial examination to which the ambush in the Gorbeau house eventually gave rise, established the fact that a large sou piece, cut and worked in a peculiar fashion, was found in the garret, when the police made their descent on it.
모모This sou piece was one of those marvels of industry, which are engendered by the patience of the galleys in the shadows and for the shadows, marvels which are nothing else than instruments of escape. These hideous and delicate products of wonderful art are to jewellers' work what the metaphors of slang are to poetry.
모모There are Benvenuto Cellinis in the galleys, just as there are Villons in language. The unhappy wretch who aspires to deliverance finds means sometimes without tools, sometimes with a common wooden-handled knife, to saw a sou into two thin plates, to hollow out these plates without affecting the coinage stamp, and to make a furrow on the edge of the sou in such a manner that the plates will adhere again. This can be screwed together and unscrewed at will; it is a box. In this box he hides a watch-spring, and this watch-spring, properly handled, cuts good-sized chains and bars of iron. The unfortunate convict is supposed to possess merely a sou; not at all, he possesses liberty.
모모It was a large sou of this sort which, during the subsequent search of the police, was found under the bed near the window.
모모They also found a tiny saw of blue steel which would fit the sou.
모모It is probable that the prisoner had this sou piece on his person at the moment when the ruffians searched him, that he contrived to conceal it in his hand, and that afterward, having his right hand free, he unscrewed it, and used it as a saw to cut the cords which fastened him, which would explain the faint noise and almost imperceptible movements which Marius had observed.
모모As he had not been able to bend down, for fear of betraying himself, he had not cut the bonds of his left leg.
모모The ruffians had recovered from their first surprise.
모모"Be easy," said Bigrenaille to Thenardier.
모모"He still holds by one leg, and he can't get away.
모모I'll answer for that.
모모I tied that paw for him."
모모In the meanwhile, the prisoner had begun to speak:--
모모"You are wretches, but my life is not worth the trouble of defending it.
모모When you think that you can make me speak, that you can make me write what I do not choose to write, that you can make me say what I do not choose to say--"
모모He stripped up his left sleeve, and added:--
모모"See here."
모모At the same moment he extended his arm, and laid the glowing chisel which he held in his left hand by its wooden handle on his bare flesh.
모모The crackling of the burning flesh became audible, and the odor peculiar to chambers of torture filled the hovel.
모모Marius reeled in utter horror, the very ruffians shuddered, hardly a muscle of the old man's face contracted, and while the red-hot iron sank into the smoking wound, impassive and almost august, he fixed on Thenardier his beautiful glance, in which there was no hatred, and where suffering vanished in serene majesty.
모모With grand and lofty natures, the revolts of the flesh and the senses when subjected to physical suffering cause the soul to spring forth, and make it appear on the brow, just as rebellions among the soldiery force the captain to show himself.
모모"Wretches!" said he, "have no more fear of me than I have for you!"
모모And, tearing the chisel from the wound, he hurled it through the window, which had been left open; the horrible, glowing tool disappeared into the night, whirling as it flew, and fell far away on the snow.
모모The prisoner resumed:--
모모"Do what you please with me."
모모He was disarmed.
모모"Seize him!" said Thenardier.
모모Two of the ruffians laid their hands on his shoulder, and the masked man with the ventriloquist's voice took up his station in front of him, ready to smash his skull at the slightest movement.
모모At the same time, Marius heard below him, at the base of the partition, but so near that he could not see who was speaking, this colloquy conducted in a low tone:--
모모"There is only one thing left to do."
모모"Cut his throat."
모모"That's it."
모모It was the husband and wife taking counsel together.
모모Thenardier walked slowly towards the table, opened the drawer, and took out the knife.
모모Marius fretted with the handle of his pistol. Unprecedented perplexity!
모모For the last hour he had had two voices in his conscience, the one enjoining him to respect his father's testament, the other crying to him to rescue the prisoner. These two voices continued uninterruptedly that struggle which tormented him to agony.
모모Up to that moment he had cherished a vague hope that he should find some means of reconciling these two duties, but nothing within the limits of possibility had presented itself.
모모However, the peril was urgent, the last bounds of delay had been reached; Thenardier was standing thoughtfully a few paces distant from the prisoner.
모모Marius cast a wild glance about him, the last mechanical resource of despair.
모모All at once a shudder ran through him.
모모At his feet, on the table, a bright ray of light from the full moon illuminated and seemed to point out to him a sheet of paper. On this paper he read the following line written that very morning, in large letters, by the eldest of the Thenardier girls:--
모모"THE BOBBIES ARE HERE."
모모An idea, a flash, crossed Marius' mind; this was the expedient of which he was in search, the solution of that frightful problem which was torturing him, of sparing the assassin and saving the victim.
모모He knelt down on his commode, stretched out his arm, seized the sheet of paper, softly detached a bit of plaster from the wall, wrapped the paper round it, and tossed the whole through the crevice into the middle of the den.
모모It was high time.
모모Thenardier had conquered his last fears or his last scruples, and was advancing on the prisoner.
모모"Something is falling!" cried the Thenardier woman.
모모"What is it?" asked her husband.
모모The woman darted forward and picked up the bit of plaster. She handed it to her husband.
모모"Where did this come from?" demanded Thenardier.
모모"Pardie!" ejaculated his wife, "where do you suppose it came from? Through the window, of course."
모모"I saw it pass," said Bigrenaille.
모모Thenardier rapidly unfolded the paper and held it close to the candle.
모모"It's in Eponine's handwriting.
모모The devil!"
모모He made a sign to his wife, who hastily drew near, and showed her the line written on the sheet of paper, then he added in a subdued voice:--
모모"Quick!
모모The ladder!
모모Let's leave the bacon in the mousetrap and decamp!"
모모"Without cutting that man's throat?" asked, the Thenardier woman.
모모"We haven't the time."
모모"Through what?" resumed Bigrenaille.
모모"Through the window," replied Thenardier.
모모"Since Ponine has thrown the stone through the window, it indicates that the house is not watched on that side."
모모The mask with the ventriloquist's voice deposited his huge key on the floor, raised both arms in the air, and opened and clenched his fists, three times rapidly without uttering a word.
모모This was the signal like the signal for clearing the decks for action on board ship.
모모The ruffians who were holding the prisoner released him; in the twinkling of an eye the rope ladder was unrolled outside the window, and solidly fastened to the sill by the two iron hooks.
모모The prisoner paid no attention to what was going on around him. He seemed to be dreaming or praying.
모모As soon as the ladder was arranged, Thenardier cried:
모모"Come! the bourgeoise first!"
모모And he rushed headlong to the window.
모모But just as he was about to throw his leg over, Bigrenaille seized him roughly by the collar.
모모"Not much, come now, you old dog, after us!"
모모"After us!" yelled the ruffians.
모모"You are children," said Thenardier, "we are losing time. The police are on our heels."
모모"Well, said the ruffians, "let's draw lots to see who shall go down first."
모모Thenardier exclaimed:--
모모"Are you mad!
모모Are you crazy!
모모What a pack of boobies!
모모You want to waste time, do you?
모모Draw lots, do you?
모모By a wet finger, by a short straw!
모모With written names!
모모Thrown into a hat!--"
모모"Would you like my hat?" cried a voice on the threshold.
모모All wheeled round.
모모It was Javert.
모모He had his hat in his hand, and was holding it out to them with a smile.


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER XXI 
모모ONE SHOULD ALWAYS BEGIN BY ARRESTING THE VICTIMS
모모At nightfall, Javert had posted his men and had gone into ambush himself between the trees of the Rue de la Barrieredes-Gobelins which faced the Gorbeau house, on the other side of the boulevard. He had begun operations by opening "his pockets," and dropping into it the two young girls who were charged with keeping a watch on the approaches to the den.
모모But he had only "caged" Azelma. As for Eponine, she was not at her post, she had disappeared, and he had not been able to seize her.
모모Then Javert had made a point and had bent his ear to waiting for the signal agreed upon. The comings and goings of the fiacres had greatly agitated him. At last, he had grown impatient, and, sure that there was a nest there, sure of being in "luck," having recognized many of the ruffians who had entered, he had finally decided to go upstairs without waiting for the pistol-shot.
모모It will be remembered that he had Marius' pass-key.
모모He had arrived just in the nick of time.
모모The terrified ruffians flung themselves on the arms which they had abandoned in all the corners at the moment of flight.
모모In less than a second, these seven men, horrible to behold, had grouped themselves in an attitude of defence, one with his meat-axe, another with his key, another with his bludgeon, the rest with shears, pincers, and hammers.
모모Thenardier had his knife in his fist. The Thenardier woman snatched up an enormous paving-stone which lay in the angle of the window and served her daughters as an ottoman.
모모Javert put on his hat again, and advanced a couple of paces into the room, with arms folded, his cane under one arm, his sword in its sheath.
모모"Halt there," said he.
모모"You shall not go out by the window, you shall go through the door.
모모It's less unhealthy.
모모There are seven of you, there are fifteen of us.
모모Don't let's fall to collaring each other like men of Auvergne."
모모Bigrenaille drew out a pistol which he had kept concealed under his blouse, and put it in Thenardier's hand, whispering in the latter's ear:--
모모"It's Javert.
모모I don't dare fire at that man.
모모Do you dare?"
모모"Parbleu!" replied Thenardier.
모모"Well, then, fire."
모모Thenardier took the pistol and aimed at Javert.
모모Javert, who was only three paces from him, stared intently at him and contented himself with saying:--
모모"Come now, don't fire.
모모You'll miss fire."
모모Thenardier pulled the trigger.
모모The pistol missed fire.
모모"Didn't I tell you so!" ejaculated Javert.
모모Bigrenaille flung his bludgeon at Javert's feet.
모모"You're the emperor of the fiends!
모모I surrender."
모모"And you?"
모모Javert asked the rest of the ruffians.
모모They replied:--
모모"So do we."
모모Javert began again calmly:--
모모"That's right, that's good, I said so, you are nice fellows.
모모"I only ask one thing," said Bigrenaille, "and that is, that I may not be denied tobacco while I am in confinement."
모모"Granted," said Javert.
모모And turning round and calling behind him:--
모모"Come in now!"
모모A squad of policemen, sword in hand, and agents armed with bludgeons and cudgels, rushed in at Javert's summons.
모모They pinioned the ruffians.
모모This throng of men, sparely lighted by the single candle, filled the den with shadows.
모모"Handcuff them all!" shouted Javert.
모모"Come on!" cried a voice which was not the voice of a man, but of which no one would ever have said:
모모"It is a woman's voice."
모모The Thenardier woman had entrenched herself in one of the angles of the window, and it was she who had just given vent to this roar.
모모The policemen and agents recoiled.
모모She had thrown off her shawl.
모모but retained her bonnet; her husband, who was crouching behind her, was almost hidden under the discarded shawl, and she was shielding him with her body, as she elevated the paving-stone above her head with the gesture of a giantess on the point of hurling a rock.
모모"Beware!" she shouted.
모모All crowded back towards the corridor.
모모A broad open space was cleared in the middle of the garret.
모모The Thenardier woman cast a glance at the ruffians who had allowed themselves to be pinioned, and muttered in hoarse and guttural accents:--
모모"The cowards!"
모모Javert smiled, and advanced across the open space which the Thenardier was devouring with her eyes.
모모"Don't come near me," she cried, "or I'll crush you."
모모"What a grenadier!" ejaculated Javert; "you've got a beard like a man, mother, but I have claws like a woman."
모모And he continued to advance.
모모The Thenardier, dishevelled and terrible, set her feet far apart, threw herself backwards, and hurled the paving-stone at Javert's head. Javert ducked, the stone passed over him, struck the wall behind, knocked off a huge piece of plastering, and, rebounding from angle to angle across the hovel, now luckily almost empty, rested at Javert's feet.
모모At the same moment, Javert reached the Thenardier couple. One of his big hands descended on the woman's shoulder; the other on the husband's head.
모모"The handcuffs!" he shouted.
모모The policemen trooped in in force, and in a few seconds Javert's order had been executed.
모모The Thenardier female, overwhelmed, stared at her pinioned hands, and at those of her husband, who had dropped to the floor, and exclaimed, weeping:--
모모"My daughters!"
모모"They are in the jug," said Javert.
모모In the meanwhile, the agents had caught sight of the drunken man asleep behind the door, and were shaking him:--
모모He awoke, stammering:--
모모"Is it all over, Jondrette?"
모모"Yes," replied Javert.
모모The six pinioned ruffians were standing, and still preserved their spectral mien; all three besmeared with black, all three masked.
모모"Keep on your masks," said Javert.
모모And passing them in review with a glance of a Frederick II. at a Potsdam parade, he said to the three "chimney-builders":--
모모"Good day, Bigrenaille! good day, Brujon! good day, Deuxmilliards!"
모모Then turning to the three masked men, he said to the man with the meat-axe:--
모모"Good day, Gueulemer!"
모모And to the man with the cudgel:--
모모"Good day, Babet!"
모모And to the ventriloquist:--
모모"Your health, Claquesous."
모모At that moment, he caught sight of the ruffians' prisoner.
모모who, ever since the entrance of the police, had not uttered a word, and had held his head down.
모모"Untie the gentleman!" said Javert, "and let no one go out!"
모모That said, he seated himself with sovereign dignity before the table, where the candle and the writing-materials still remained, drew a stamped paper from his pocket, and began to prepare his report.
모모When he had written the first lines, which are formulas that never vary, he raised his eyes:--
모모"Let the gentleman whom these gentlemen bound step forward."
모모The policemen glanced round them.
모모"Well," said Javert, "where is he?"
모모The prisoner of the ruffians, M. Leblanc, M. Urbain Fabre, the father of Ursule or the Lark, had disappeared.
모모The door was guarded, but the window was not.
모모As soon as he had found himself released from his bonds, and while Javert was drawing up his report, he had taken advantage of confusion, the crowd, the darkness, and of a moment when the general attention was diverted from him, to dash out of the window.
모모An agent sprang to the opening and looked out.
모모He saw no one outside.
모모The rope ladder was still shaking.
모모"The devil!" ejaculated Javert between his teeth, "he must have been the most valuable of the lot."


BOOK EIGHTH.--THE WICKED POOR MAN
CHAPTER XXII 
모모THE LITTLE ONE WHO WAS CRYING IN VOLUME TWO
모모On the day following that on which these events took place in the house on the Boulevard de l'Hopital, a child, who seemed to be coming from the direction of the bridge of Austerlitz, was ascending the side-alley on the right in the direction of the Barriere de Fontainebleau.
모모Night had fully come.
모모This lad was pale, thin, clad in rags, with linen trousers in the month of February, and was singing at the top of his voice.
모모At the corner of the Rue du Petit-Banquier, a bent old woman was rummaging in a heap of refuse by the light of a street lantern; the child jostled her as he passed, then recoiled, exclaiming:--
모모"Hello!
모모And I took it for an enormous, enormous dog!"
모모He pronounced the word enormous the second time with a jeering swell of the voice which might be tolerably well represented by capitals: "an enormous, ENORMOUS dog."
모모The old woman straightened herself up in a fury.
모모"Nasty brat!" she grumbled.
모모"If I hadn't been bending over, I know well where I would have planted my foot on you."
모모The boy was already far away.
모모"Kisss! kisss!" he cried.
모모"After that, I don't think I was mistaken!"
모모The old woman, choking with indignation, now rose completely upright, and the red gleam of the lantern fully lighted up her livid face, all hollowed into angles and wrinkles, with crow's-feet meeting the corners of her mouth.
모모Her body was lost in the darkness, and only her head was visible. One would have pronounced her a mask of Decrepitude carved out by a light from the night.
모모The boy surveyed her.
모모"Madame," said he, "does not possess that style of beauty which pleases me."
모모He then pursued his road, and resumed his song:-- 
모모 "Le roi Coupdesabot 
모모 S'en allait a la chasse, 
모모 A la chasse aux corbeaux--"
모모At the end of these three lines he paused.
모모He had arrived in front of No. 50-52, and finding the door fastened, he began to assault it with resounding and heroic kicks, which betrayed rather the man's shoes that he was wearing than the child's feet which he owned.
모모In the meanwhile, the very old woman whom he had encountered at the corner of the Rue du Petit-Banquier hastened up behind him, uttering clamorous cries and indulging in lavish and exaggerated gestures.
모모"What's this?
모모What's this?
모모Lord God!
모모He's battering the door down! He's knocking the house down."
모모The kicks continued.
모모The old woman strained her lungs.
모모"Is that the way buildings are treated nowadays?"
모모All at once she paused.
모모She had recognized the gamin.
모모"What! so it's that imp!"
모모"Why, it's the old lady," said the lad.
모모"Good day, Bougonmuche. I have come to see my ancestors."
모모The old woman retorted with a composite grimace, and a wonderful improvisation of hatred taking advantage of feebleness and ugliness, which was, unfortunately, wasted in the dark:--
모모"There's no one here."
모모"Bah!" retorted the boy, "where's my father?"
모모"At La Force."
모모"Come, now!
모모And my mother?"
모모"At Saint-Lazare."
모모"Well!
모모And my sisters?"
모모"At the Madelonettes."
모모The lad scratched his head behind his ear, stared at Ma'am Bougon, and said:--
모모"Ah!"
모모Then he executed a pirouette on his heel; a moment later, the old woman, who had remained on the door-step, heard him singing in his clear, young voice, as he plunged under the black elm-trees, in the wintry wind:-- 
모모 "Le roi Coupdesabot[31] 
모모 S'en allait a la chasse, 
모모 A la chasse aux corbeaux,
모모 Monte sur deux echasses. 
모모 Quand on passait dessous, 
모모 On lui payait deux sous."
모모[31] King Bootkick went a-hunting after crows, mounted on two stilts. When one passed beneath them, one paid him two sous.
모모[The end of Volume III. "Marius"] 


BOOK FIRST.--A FEW PAGES OF HISTORY
CHAPTER I 
모모WELL CUT
