I am capable of that. My shoes are capable of that."
모모"Do you know anything of those comrades who meet at Richefeu's?"
모모"Not much.
모모We only address each other as thou."
모모"What will you say to them?"
모모"I will speak to them of Robespierre, pardi!
모모Of Danton. Of principles."
모모"You?"
모모"I. But I don't receive justice.
모모When I set about it, I am terrible. I have read Prudhomme, I know the Social Contract, I know my constitution of the year Two by heart.
모모`The liberty of one citizen ends where the liberty of another citizen begins.'
모모Do you take me for a brute?
모모I have an old bank-bill of the Republic in my drawer. The Rights of Man, the sovereignty of the people, sapristi!
모모I am even a bit of a Hebertist.
모모I can talk the most superb twaddle for six hours by the clock, watch in hand."
모모"Be serious," said Enjolras.
모모"I am wild," replied Grantaire.
모모Enjolras meditated for a few moments, and made the gesture of a man who has taken a resolution.
모모"Grantaire," he said gravely, "I consent to try you.
모모You shall go to the Barriere du Maine."
모모Grantaire lived in furnished lodgings very near the Cafe Musain. He went out, and five minutes later he returned.
모모He had gone home to put on a Robespierre waistcoat.
모모"Red," said he as he entered, and he looked intently at Enjolras. Then, with the palm of his energetic hand, he laid the two scarlet points of the waistcoat across his breast.
모모And stepping up to Enjolras, he whispered in his ear:--
모모"Be easy."
모모He jammed his hat on resolutely and departed.
모모A quarter of an hour later, the back room of the Cafe Musain was deserted.
모모All the friends of the A B C were gone, each in his own direction, each to his own task.
모모Enjolras, who had reserved the Cougourde of Aix for himself, was the last to leave.
모모Those members of the Cougourde of Aix who were in Paris then met on the plain of Issy, in one of the abandoned quarries which are so numerous in that side of Paris.
모모As Enjolras walked towards this place, he passed the whole situation in review in his own mind.
모모The gravity of events was self-evident. When facts, the premonitory symptoms of latent social malady, move heavily, the slightest complication stops and entangles them. A phenomenon whence arises ruin and new births.
모모Enjolras descried a luminous uplifting beneath the gloomy skirts of the future. Who knows?
모모Perhaps the moment was at hand.
모모The people were again taking possession of right, and what a fine spectacle! The revolution was again majestically taking possession of France and saying to the world:
모모"The sequel to-morrow!" Enjolras was content. The furnace was being heated.
모모He had at that moment a powder train of friends scattered all over Paris.
모모He composed, in his own mind, with Combeferre's philosophical and penetrating eloquence, Feuilly's cosmopolitan enthusiasm, Courfeyrac's dash, Bahorel's smile, Jean Prouvaire's melancholy, Joly's science, Bossuet's sarcasms, a sort of electric spark which took fire nearly everywhere at once. All hands to work.
모모Surely, the result would answer to the effort. This was well.
모모This made him think of Grantaire.
모모"Hold," said he to himself, "the Barriere du Maine will not take me far out of my way.
모모What if I were to go on as far as Richefeu's? Let us have a look at what Grantaire is about, and see how he is getting on."
모모One o'clock was striking from the Vaugirard steeple when Enjolras reached the Richefeu smoking-room.
모모He pushed open the door, entered, folded his arms, letting the door fall to and strike his shoulders, and gazed at that room filled with tables, men, and smoke.
모모A voice broke forth from the mist of smoke, interrupted by another voice. It was Grantaire holding a dialogue with an adversary.
모모Grantaire was sitting opposite another figure, at a marble Saint-Anne table, strewn with grains of bran and dotted with dominos.
모모He was hammering the table with his fist, and this is what Enjolras heard:--
모모"Double-six."
모모"Fours."
모모"The pig!
모모I have no more."
모모"You are dead.
모모A two."
모모"Six."
모모"Three."
모모"One."
모모"It's my move."
모모"Four points."
모모"Not much."
모모"It's your turn."
모모"I have made an enormous mistake."
모모"You are doing well."
모모"Fifteen."
모모"Seven more."
모모"That makes me twenty-two." [Thoughtfully, "Twenty-two!"]
모모"You weren't expecting that double-six. If I had placed it at the beginning, the whole play would have been changed."
모모"A two again."
모모"One."
모모"One!
모모Well, five."
모모"I haven't any."
모모"It was your play, I believe?"
모모"Yes."
모모"Blank."
모모"What luck he has!
모모Ah!
모모You are lucky!
모모[Long revery.] Two."
모모"One."
모모"Neither five nor one.
모모That's bad for you."
모모"Domino."
모모"Plague take it!"


BOOK SECOND.--EPONINE
CHAPTER I 
모모THE LARK'S MEADOW 
모모Marius had witnessed the unexpected termination of the ambush upon whose track he had set Javert; but Javert had no sooner quitted the building, bearing off his prisoners in three hackney-coaches, than Marius also glided out of the house.
모모It was only nine o'clock in the evening.
모모Marius betook himself to Courfeyrac. Courfeyrac was no longer the imperturbable inhabitant of the Latin Quarter, he had gone to live in the Rue de la Verrerie "for political reasons"; this quarter was one where, at that epoch, insurrection liked to install itself.
모모Marius said to Courfeyrac: "I have come to sleep with you."
모모Courfeyrac dragged a mattress off his bed, which was furnished with two, spread it out on the floor, and said:
모모"There."
모모At seven o'clock on the following morning, Marius returned to the hovel, paid the quarter's rent which he owed to Ma'am Bougon, had his books, his bed, his table, his commode, and his two chairs loaded on a hand-cart and went off without leaving his address, so that when Javert returned in the course of the morning, for the purpose of questioning Marius as to the events of the preceding evening, he found only Ma'am Bougon, who answered: "Moved away!"
모모Ma'am Bougon was convinced that Marius was to some extent an accomplice of the robbers who had been seized the night before. "Who would ever have said it?" she exclaimed to the portresses of the quarter, "a young man like that, who had the air of a girl!"
모모Marius had two reasons for this prompt change of residence. The first was, that he now had a horror of that house, where he had beheld, so close at hand, and in its most repulsive and most ferocious development, a social deformity which is, perhaps, even more terrible than the wicked rich man, the wicked poor man. The second was, that he did not wish to figure in the lawsuit which would insue in all probability, and be brought in to testify against Thenardier.
모모Javert thought that the young man, whose name he had forgotten, was afraid, and had fled, or perhaps, had not even returned home at the time of the ambush; he made some efforts to find him, however, but without success.
모모A month passed, then another.
모모Marius was still with Courfeyrac. He had learned from a young licentiate in law, an habitual frequenter of the courts, that Thenardier was in close confinement.
모모Every Monday, Marius had five francs handed in to the clerk's office of La Force for Thenardier.
모모As Marius had no longer any money, he borrowed the five francs from Courfeyrac.
모모It was the first time in his life that he had ever borrowed money.
모모These periodical five francs were a double riddle to Courfeyrac who lent and to Thenardier who received them.
모모"To whom can they go?" thought Courfeyrac.
모모"Whence can this come to me?" Thenardier asked himself.
모모Moreover, Marius was heart-broken. Everything had plunged through a trap-door once more.
모모He no longer saw anything before him; his life was again buried in mystery where he wandered fumblingly. He had for a moment beheld very close at hand, in that obscurity, the young girl whom he loved, the old man who seemed to be her father, those unknown beings, who were his only interest and his only hope in this world; and, at the very moment when he thought himself on the point of grasping them, a gust had swept all these shadows away. Not a spark of certainty and truth had been emitted even in the most terrible of collisions.
모모No conjecture was possible.
모모He no longer knew even the name that he thought he knew.
모모It certainly was not Ursule.
모모And the Lark was a nickname.
모모And what was he to think of the old man?
모모Was he actually in hiding from the police? The white-haired workman whom Marius had encountered in the vicinity of the Invalides recurred to his mind.
모모It now seemed probable that that workingman and M. Leblanc were one and the same person.
모모So he disguised himself?
모모That man had his heroic and his equivocal sides. Why had he not called for help?
모모Why had he fled?
모모Was he, or was he not, the father of the young girl?
모모Was he, in short, the man whom Thenardier thought that he recognized?
모모Thenardier might have been mistaken.
모모These formed so many insoluble problems. All this, it is true, detracted nothing from the angelic charms of the young girl of the Luxembourg.
모모Heart-rending distress; Marius bore a passion in his heart, and night over his eyes. He was thrust onward, he was drawn, and he could not stir. All had vanished, save love.
모모Of love itself he had lost the instincts and the sudden illuminations.
모모Ordinarily, this flame which burns us lights us also a little, and casts some useful gleams without. But Marius no longer even heard these mute counsels of passion. He never said to himself:
모모"What if I were to go to such a place? What if I were to try such and such a thing?"
모모The girl whom he could no longer call Ursule was evidently somewhere; nothing warned Marius in what direction he should seek her.
모모His whole life was now summed up in two words; absolute uncertainty within an impenetrable fog. To see her once again; he still aspired to this, but he no longer expected it.
모모To crown all, his poverty had returned.
모모He felt that icy breath close to him, on his heels.
모모In the midst of his torments, and long before this, he had discontinued his work, and nothing is more dangerous than discontinued work; it is a habit which vanishes. A habit which is easy to get rid of, and difficult to take up again.
모모A certain amount of dreaming is good, like a narcotic in discreet doses. It lulls to sleep the fevers of the mind at labor, which are sometimes severe, and produces in the spirit a soft and fresh vapor which corrects the over-harsh contours of pure thought, fills in gaps here and there, binds together and rounds off the angles of the ideas.
모모But too much dreaming sinks and drowns. Woe to the brain-worker who allows himself to fall entirely from thought into revery!
모모He thinks that he can re-ascend with equal ease, and he tells himself that, after all, it is the same thing.
모모Error!
모모Thought is the toil of the intelligence, revery its voluptuousness. To replace thought with revery is to confound a poison with a food.
모모Marius had begun in that way, as the reader will remember. Passion had supervened and had finished the work of precipitating him into chimaeras without object or bottom.
모모One no longer emerges from one's self except for the purpose of going off to dream. Idle production.
모모Tumultuous and stagnant gulf.
모모And, in proportion as labor diminishes, needs increase.
모모This is a law.
모모Man, in a state of revery, is generally prodigal and slack; the unstrung mind cannot hold life within close bounds.
모모There is, in that mode of life, good mingled with evil, for if enervation is baleful, generosity is good and healthful. But the poor man who is generous and noble, and who does not work, is lost.
모모Resources are exhausted, needs crop up.
모모Fatal declivity down which the most honest and the firmest as well as the most feeble and most vicious are drawn, and which ends in one of two holds, suicide or crime.
모모By dint of going outdoors to think, the day comes when one goes out to throw one's self in the water.
모모Excess of revery breeds men like Escousse and Lebras.
모모Marius was descending this declivity at a slow pace, with his eyes fixed on the girl whom he no longer saw.
모모What we have just written seems strange, and yet it is true.
모모The memory of an absent being kindles in the darkness of the heart; the more it has disappeared, the more it beams; the gloomy and despairing soul sees this light on its horizon; the star of the inner night.
모모She--that was Marius' whole thought.
모모He meditated of nothing else; he was confusedly conscious that his old coat was becoming an impossible coat, and that his new coat was growing old, that his shirts were wearing out, that his hat was wearing out, that his boots were giving out, and he said to himself:
모모"If I could but see her once again before I die!"
모모One sweet idea alone was left to him, that she had loved him, that her glance had told him so, that she did not know his name, but that she did know his soul, and that, wherever she was, however mysterious the place, she still loved him perhaps. Who knows whether she were not thinking of him as he was thinking of her?
모모Sometimes, in those inexplicable hours such as are experienced by every heart that loves, though he had no reasons for anything but sadness and yet felt an obscure quiver of joy, he said to himself: "It is her thoughts that are coming to me!"
모모Then he added: "Perhaps my thoughts reach her also."
모모This illusion, at which he shook his head a moment later, was sufficient, nevertheless, to throw beams, which at times resembled hope, into his soul.
모모From time to time, especially at that evening hour which is the most depressing to even the dreamy, he allowed the purest, the most impersonal, the most ideal of the reveries which filled his brain, to fall upon a notebook which contained nothing else.
모모He called this "writing to her."
모모It must not be supposed that his reason was deranged. Quite the contrary.
모모He had lost the faculty of working and of moving firmly towards any fixed goal, but he was endowed with more clear-sightedness and rectitude than ever.
모모Marius surveyed by a calm and real, although peculiar light, what passed before his eyes, even the most indifferent deeds and men; he pronounced a just criticism on everything with a sort of honest dejection and candid disinterestedness.
모모His judgment, which was almost wholly disassociated from hope, held itself aloof and soared on high.
모모In this state of mind nothing escaped him, nothing deceived him, and every moment he was discovering the foundation of life, of humanity, and of destiny.
모모Happy, even in the midst of anguish, is he to whom God has given a soul worthy of love and of unhappiness! He who has not viewed the things of this world and the heart of man under this double light has seen nothing and knows nothing of the true.
모모The soul which loves and suffers is in a state of sublimity.
모모However, day followed day, and nothing new presented itself. It merely seemed to him, that the sombre space which still remained to be traversed by him was growing shorter with every instant. He thought that he already distinctly perceived the brink of the bottomless abyss.
모모"What!" he repeated to himself, "shall I not see her again before then!"
모모When you have ascended the Rue Saint-Jacques, left the barrier on one side and followed the old inner boulevard for some distance, you reach the Rue de la Sante, then the Glaciere, and, a little while before arriving at the little river of the Gobelins, you come to a sort of field which is the only spot in the long and monotonous chain of the boulevards of Paris, where Ruysdeel would be tempted to sit down.
모모There is something indescribable there which exhales grace, a green meadow traversed by tightly stretched lines, from which flutter rags drying in the wind, and an old market-gardener's house, built in the time of Louis XIII., with its great roof oddly pierced with dormer windows, dilapidated palisades, a little water amid poplar-trees, women, voices, laughter; on the horizon the Pantheon, the pole of the Deaf-Mutes, the Val-de-Grace, black, squat, fantastic, amusing, magnificent, and in the background, the severe square crests of the towers of Notre Dame.
모모As the place is worth looking at, no one goes thither.
모모Hardly one cart or wagoner passes in a quarter of an hour.
모모It chanced that Marius' solitary strolls led him to this plot of ground, near the water.
모모That day, there was a rarity on the boulevard, a passer-by. Marius, vaguely impressed with the almost savage beauty of the place, asked this passer-by:--"What is the name of this spot?"
모모The person replied:
모모"It is the Lark's meadow."
모모And he added:
모모"It was here that Ulbach killed the shepherdess of Ivry."
모모But after the word "Lark" Marius heard nothing more.
모모These sudden congealments in the state of revery, which a single word suffices to evoke, do occur.
모모The entire thought is abruptly condensed around an idea, and it is no longer capable of perceiving anything else.
모모The Lark was the appellation which had replaced Ursule in the depths of Marius' melancholy.--"Stop," said he with a sort of unreasoning stupor peculiar to these mysterious asides, "this is her meadow. I shall know where she lives now."
모모It was absurd, but irresistible.
모모And every day he returned to that meadow of the Lark.
모모THE LARK'S MEADOW 
모모Marius had witnessed the unexpected termination of the ambush upon whose track he had set Javert; but Javert had no sooner quitted the building, bearing off his prisoners in three hackney-coaches, than Marius also glided out of the house.

모모What we have just written seems strange, and yet it is true.
모모The memory of an absent being kindles in the darkness of the heart; the more it has disappeared, the more it beams; the gloomy and despairing soul sees this light on its horizon; the star of the inner night.
모모She--that was Marius' whole thought.
모모He meditated of nothing else; he was confusedly conscious that his old coat was becoming an impossible coat, and that his new coat was growing old, that his shirts were wearing out, that his hat was wearing out, that his boots were giving out, and he said to himself:
모모"If I could but see her once again before I die!"
모모One sweet idea alone was left to him, that she had loved him, that her glance had told him so, that she did not know his name, but that she did know his soul, and that, wherever she was, however mysterious the place, she still loved him perhaps. Who knows whether she were not thinking of him as he was thinking of her?
모모Sometimes, in those inexplicable hours such as are experienced by every heart that loves, though he had no reasons for anything but sadness and yet felt an obscure quiver of joy, he said to himself: "It is her thoughts that are coming to me!"
모모Then he added: "Perhaps my thoughts reach her also."
모모This illusion, at which he shook his head a moment later, was sufficient, nevertheless, to throw beams, which at times resembled hope, into his soul.
모모From time to time, especially at that evening hour which is the most depressing to even the dreamy, he allowed the purest, the most impersonal, the most ideal of the reveries which filled his brain, to fall upon a notebook which contained nothing else.
모모He called this "writing to her."
모모It must not be supposed that his reason was deranged. Quite the contrary.
모모He had lost the faculty of working and of moving firmly towards any fixed goal, but he was endowed with more clear-sightedness and rectitude than ever.
모모Marius surveyed by a calm and real, although peculiar light, what passed before his eyes, even the most indifferent deeds and men; he pronounced a just criticism on everything with a sort of honest dejection and candid disinterestedness.
모모His judgment, which was almost wholly disassociated from hope, held itself aloof and soared on high.
모모In this state of mind nothing escaped him, nothing deceived him, and every moment he was discovering the foundation of life, of humanity, and of destiny.
모모Happy, even in the midst of anguish, is he to whom God has given a soul worthy of love and of unhappiness! He who has not viewed the things of this world and the heart of man under this double light has seen nothing and knows nothing of the true.
모모The soul which loves and suffers is in a state of sublimity.
모모However, day followed day, and nothing new presented itself. It merely seemed to him, that the sombre space which still remained to be traversed by him was growing shorter with every instant. He thought that he already distinctly perceived the brink of the bottomless abyss.
모모"What!" he repeated to himself, "shall I not see her again before then!"
모모When you have ascended the Rue Saint-Jacques, left the barrier on one side and followed the old inner boulevard for some distance, you reach the Rue de la Sante, then the Glaciere, and, a little while before arriving at the little river of the Gobelins, you come to a sort of field which is the only spot in the long and monotonous chain of the boulevards of Paris, where Ruysdeel would be tempted to sit down.
모모There is something indescribable there which exhales grace, a green meadow traversed by tightly stretched lines, from which flutter rags drying in the wind, and an old market-gardener's house, built in the time of Louis XIII., with its great roof oddly pierced with dormer windows, dilapidated palisades, a little water amid poplar-trees, women, voices, laughter; on the horizon the Pantheon, the pole of the Deaf-Mutes, the Val-de-Grace, black, squat, fantastic, amusing, magnificent, and in the background, the severe square crests of the towers of Notre Dame.
모모As the place is worth looking at, no one goes thither.
모모Hardly one cart or wagoner passes in a quarter of an hour.
모모It chanced that Marius' solitary strolls led him to this plot of ground, near the water.
모모That day, there was a rarity on the boulevard, a passer-by. Marius, vaguely impressed with the almost savage beauty of the place, asked this passer-by:--"What is the name of this spot?"
모모The person replied:
모모"It is the Lark's meadow."
모모And he added:
모모"It was here that Ulbach killed the shepherdess of Ivry."
모모But after the word "Lark" Marius heard nothing more.
모모These sudden congealments in the state of revery, which a single word suffices to evoke, do occur.
모모The entire thought is abruptly condensed around an idea, and it is no longer capable of perceiving anything else.
모모The Lark was the appellation which had replaced Ursule in the depths of Marius' melancholy.--"Stop," said he with a sort of unreasoning stupor peculiar to these mysterious asides, "this is her meadow. I shall know where she lives now."
모모It was absurd, but irresistible.
모모And every day he returned to that meadow of the Lark.


BOOK SECOND.--EPONINE
CHAPTER II 
모모EMBRYONIC FORMATION OF CRIMES IN THE INCUBATION OF PRISONS
모모 Javert's triumph in the Gorbeau hovel seemed complete, but had not been so.
모모In the first place, and this constituted the principal anxiety, Javert had not taken the prisoner prisoner.
모모The assassinated man who flees is more suspicious than the assassin, and it is probable that this personage, who had been so precious a capture for the ruffians, would be no less fine a prize for the authorities.
모모And then, Montparnasse had escaped Javert.
모모Another opportunity of laying hands on that "devil's dandy" must be waited for.
모모Montparnasse had, in fact, encountered Eponine as she stood on the watch under the trees of the boulevard, and had led her off, preferring to play Nemorin with the daughter rather than Schinderhannes with the father.
모모It was well that he did so. He was free.
모모As for Eponine, Javert had caused her to be seized; a mediocre consolation.
모모Eponine had joined Azelma at Les Madelonettes.
모모And finally, on the way from the Gorbeau house to La Force, one of the principal prisoners, Claquesous, had been lost.
모모It was not known how this had been effected, the police agents and the sergeants "could not understand it at all."
모모He had converted himself into vapor, he had slipped through the handcuffs, he had trickled through the crevices of the carriage, the fiacre was cracked, and he had fled; all that they were able to say was, that on arriving at the prison, there was no Claquesous.
모모Either the fairies or the police had had a hand in it.
모모Had Claquesous melted into the shadows like a snow-flake in water?
모모Had there been unavowed connivance of the police agents? Did this man belong to the double enigma of order and disorder? Was he concentric with infraction and repression?
모모Had this sphinx his fore paws in crime and his hind paws in authority? Javert did not accept such comminations, and would have bristled up against such compromises; but his squad included other inspectors besides himself, who were more initiated than he, perhaps, although they were his subordinates in the secrets of the Prefecture, and Claquesous had been such a villain that he might make a very good agent. It is an excellent thing for ruffianism and an admirable thing for the police to be on such intimate juggling terms with the night. These double-edged rascals do exist.
모모However that may be, Claquesous had gone astray and was not found again.
모모Javert appeared to be more irritated than amazed at this.
모모As for Marius, "that booby of a lawyer," who had probably become frightened, and whose name Javert had forgotten, Javert attached very little importance to him.
모모Moreover, a lawyer can be hunted up at any time.
모모But was he a lawyer after all?
모모The investigation had begun.
모모The magistrate had thought it advisable not to put one of these men of the band of Patron Minette in close confinement, in the hope that he would chatter.
모모This man was Brujon, the long-haired man of the Rue du Petit-Banquier. He had been let loose in the Charlemagne courtyard, and the eyes of the watchers were fixed on him.
모모This name of Brujon is one of the souvenirs of La Force. In that hideous courtyard, called the court of the Batiment-Neuf (New Building), which the administration called the court Saint-Bernard, and which the robbers called the Fosseaux-Lions (The Lion's Ditch), on that wall covered with scales and leprosy, which rose on the left to a level with the roofs, near an old door of rusty iron which led to the ancient chapel of the ducal residence of La Force, then turned in a dormitory for ruffians, there could still be seen, twelve years ago, a sort of fortress roughly carved in the stone with a nail, and beneath it this signature:--
모모 BRUJON, 1811.
모모 The Brujon of 1811 was the father of the Brujon of 1832.
모모The latter, of whom the reader caught but a glimpse at the Gorbeau house, was a very cunning and very adroit young spark, with a bewildered and plaintive air.
모모It was in consequence of this plaintive air that the magistrate had released him, thinking him more useful in the Charlemagne yard than in close confinement.
모모Robbers do not interrupt their profession because they are in the hands of justice.
모모They do not let themselves be put out by such a trifle as that.
모모To be in prison for one crime is no reason for not beginning on another crime.
모모They are artists, who have one picture in the salon, and who toil, none the less, on a new work in their studios.
모모Brujon seemed to be stupefied by prison.
모모He could sometimes be seen standing by the hour together in front of the sutler's window in the Charlemagne yard, staring like an idiot at the sordid list of prices which began with:
모모garlic, 62 centimes, and ended with:
모모cigar, 5 centimes.
모모Or he passed his time in trembling, chattering his teeth, saying that he had a fever, and inquiring whether one of the eight and twenty beds in the fever ward was vacant.
모모All at once, towards the end of February, 1832, it was discovered that Brujon, that somnolent fellow, had had three different commissions executed by the errand-men of the establishment, not under his own name, but in the name of three of his comrades; and they had cost him in all fifty sous, an exorbitant outlay which attracted the attention of the prison corporal.
모모Inquiries were instituted, and on consulting the tariff of commissions posted in the convict's parlor, it was learned that the fifty sous could be analyzed as follows:
모모three commissions; one to the Pantheon, ten sous; one to Val-de-Grace, fifteen sous; and one to the Barriere de Grenelle, twenty-five sous.
모모This last was the dearest of the whole tariff.
모모Now, at the Pantheon, at the Val-de-Grace, and at the Barriere de Grenelle were situated the domiciles of the three very redoubtable prowlers of the barriers, Kruideniers, alias Bizarre, Glorieux, an ex-convict, and Barre-Carosse, upon whom the attention of the police was directed by this incident. It was thought that these men were members of Patron Minette; two of those leaders, Babet and Gueulemer, had been captured. It was supposed that the messages, which had been addressed, not to houses, but to people who were waiting for them in the street, must have contained information with regard to some crime that had been plotted.
모모They were in possession of other indications; they laid hand on the three prowlers, and supposed that they had circumvented some one or other of Brujon's machinations.
모모About a week after these measures had been taken, one night, as the superintendent of the watch, who had been inspecting the lower dormitory in the Batiment-Neuf, was about to drop his chestnut in the box--this was the means adopted to make sure that the watchmen performed their duties punctually; every hour a chestnut must be dropped into all the boxes nailed to the doors of the dormitories-- a watchman looked through the peep-hole of the dormitory and beheld Brujon sitting on his bed and writing something by the light of the hall-lamp. The guardian entered, Brujon was put in a solitary cell for a month, but they were not able to seize what he had written. The police learned nothing further about it.
모모What is certain is, that on the following morning, a "postilion" was flung from the Charlemagne yard into the Lions' Ditch, over the five-story building which separated the two court-yards.
모모What prisoners call a "postilion" is a pallet of bread artistically moulded, which is sent into Ireland, that is to say, over the roofs of a prison, from one courtyard to another. Etymology:
모모over England; from one land to another; into Ireland. This little pellet falls in the yard.
모모The man who picks it up opens it and finds in it a note addressed to some prisoner in that yard. If it is a prisoner who finds the treasure, he forwards the note to its destination; if it is a keeper, or one of the prisoners secretly sold who are called sheep in prisons and foxes in the galleys, the note is taken to the office and handed over to the police.
모모On this occasion, the postilion reached its address, although the person to whom it was addressed was, at that moment, in solitary confinement.
모모This person was no other than Babet, one of the four heads of Patron Minette.
모모The postilion contained a roll of paper on which only these two lines were written:--
모모"Babet.
모모There is an affair in the Rue Plumet.
모모A gate on a garden."
모모This is what Brujon had written the night before.
모모In spite of male and female searchers, Babet managed to pass the note on from La Force to the Salpetriere, to a "good friend" whom he had and who was shut up there.
모모This woman in turn transmitted the note to another woman of her acquaintance, a certain Magnon, who was strongly suspected by the police, though not yet arrested. This Magnon, whose name the reader has already seen, had relations with the Thenardier, which will be described in detail later on, and she could, by going to see Eponine, serve as a bridge between the Salpetriere and Les Madelonettes.
모모It happened, that at precisely that moment, as proofs were wanting in the investigation directed against Thenardier in the matter of his daughters, Eponine and Azelma were released.
모모When Eponine came out, Magnon, who was watching the gate of the Madelonettes, handed her Brujon's note to Babet, charging her to look into the matter.
모모Eponine went to the Rue Plumet, recognized the gate and the garden, observed the house, spied, lurked, and, a few days later, brought to Magnon, who delivers in the Rue Clocheperce, a biscuit, which Magnon transmitted to Babet's mistress in the Salpetriere. A biscuit, in the shady symbolism of prisons, signifies:
모모Nothing to be done.
모모So that in less than a week from that time, as Brujon and Babet met in the circle of La Force, the one on his way to the examination, the other on his way from it:--
모모"Well?" asked Brujon, "the Rue P.?"
모모"Biscuit," replied Babet.
모모Thus did the foetus of crime engendered by Brujon in La Force miscarry.
모모This miscarriage had its consequences, however, which were perfectly distinct from Brujon's programme.
모모The reader will see what they were.
모모Often when we think we are knotting one thread, we are tying quite another.


BOOK SECOND.--EPONINE
CHAPTER III 
모모APPARITION TO FATHER MABEUF
모모 Marius no longer went to see any one, but he sometimes encountered Father Mabeuf by chance.
모모While Marius was slowly descending those melancholy steps which may be called the cellar stairs, and which lead to places without light, where the happy can be heard walking overhead, M. Mabeuf was descending on his side.
모모The Flora of Cauteretz no longer sold at all.
모모The experiments on indigo had not been successful in the little garden of Austerlitz, which had a bad exposure.
모모M. Mabeuf could cultivate there only a few plants which love shade and dampness.
모모Nevertheless, he did not become discouraged.
모모He had obtained a corner in the Jardin des Plantes, with a good exposure, to make his trials with indigo "at his own expense."
모모For this purpose he had pawned his copperplates of the Flora.
모모He had reduced his breakfast to two eggs, and he left one of these for his old servant, to whom he had paid no wages for the last fifteen months.
모모And often his breakfast was his only meal. He no longer smiled with his infantile smile, he had grown morose and no longer received visitors.
모모Marius did well not to dream of going thither.
모모Sometimes, at the hour when M. Mabeuf was on his way to the Jardin des Plantes, the old man and the young man passed each other on the Boulevard de l'Hopital. They did not speak, and only exchanged a melancholy sign of the head.
모모A heart-breaking thing it is that there comes a moment when misery looses bonds! Two men who have been friends become two chance passers-by.
모모Royal the bookseller was dead.
모모M. Mabeuf no longer knew his books, his garden, or his indigo:
모모these were the three forms which happiness, pleasure, and hope had assumed for him.
모모This sufficed him for his living.
모모He said to himself:
모모"When I shall have made my balls of blueing, I shall be rich, I will withdraw my copperplates from the pawn-shop, I will put my Flora in vogue again with trickery, plenty of money and advertisements in the newspapers and I will buy, I know well where, a copy of Pierre de Medine's Art de Naviguer, with wood-cuts, edition of 1655."
모모In the meantime, he toiled all day over his plot of indigo, and at night he returned home to water his garden, and to read his books.
모모At that epoch, M. Mabeuf was nearly eighty years of age.
모모One evening he had a singular apparition.
모모He had returned home while it was still broad daylight. Mother Plutarque, whose health was declining, was ill and in bed. He had dined on a bone, on which a little meat lingered, and a bit of bread that he had found on the kitchen table, and had seated himself on an overturned stone post, which took the place of a bench in his garden.
모모Near this bench there rose, after the fashion in orchard-gardens, a sort of large chest, of beams and planks, much dilapidated, a rabbit-hutch on the ground floor, a fruit-closet on the first. There was nothing in the hutch, but there were a few apples in the fruit-closet,--the remains of the winter's provision.
모모M. Mabeuf had set himself to turning over and reading, with the aid of his glasses, two books of which he was passionately fond and in which, a serious thing at his age, he was interested. His natural timidity rendered him accessible to the acceptance of superstitions in a certain degree.
모모The first of these books was the famous treatise of President Delancre, De l'inconstance des Demons; the other was a quarto by Mutor de la Rubaudiere, Sur les Diables de Vauvert et les Gobelins de la Bievre.
모모This last-mentioned old volume interested him all the more, because his garden had been one of the spots haunted by goblins in former times.
모모The twilight had begun to whiten what was on high and to blacken all below. As he read, over the top of the book which he held in his hand, Father Mabeuf was surveying his plants, and among others a magnificent rhododendron which was one of his consolations; four days of heat, wind, and sun without a drop of rain, had passed; the stalks were bending, the buds drooping, the leaves falling; all this needed water, the rhododendron was particularly sad. Father Mabeuf was one of those persons for whom plants have souls. The old man had toiled all day over his indigo plot, he was worn out with fatigue, but he rose, laid his books on the bench, and walked, all bent over and with tottering footsteps, to the well, but when he had grasped the chain, he could not even draw it sufficiently to unhook it.
모모Then he turned round and cast a glance of anguish toward heaven which was becoming studded with stars.
모모The evening had that serenity which overwhelms the troubles of man beneath an indescribably mournful and eternal joy.
모모The night promised to be as arid as the day had been.
모모"Stars everywhere!" thought the old man; "not the tiniest cloud! Not a drop of water!"
모모And his head, which had been upraised for a moment, fell back upon his breast.
모모He raised it again, and once more looked at the sky, murmuring:--
모모"A tear of dew!
모모A little pity!"
모모He tried again to unhook the chain of the well, and could not.
모모At that moment, he heard a voice saying:--
모모"Father Mabeuf, would you like to have me water your garden for you?"
모모At the same time, a noise as of a wild animal passing became audible in the hedge, and he beheld emerging from the shrubbery a sort of tall, slender girl, who drew herself up in front of him and stared boldly at him.
모모She had less the air of a human being than of a form which had just blossomed forth from the twilight.
모모Before Father Mabeuf, who was easily terrified, and who was, as we have said, quick to take alarm, was able to reply by a single syllable, this being, whose movements had a sort of odd abruptness in the darkness, had unhooked the chain, plunged in and withdrawn the bucket, and filled the watering-pot, and the goodman beheld this apparition, which had bare feet and a tattered petticoat, running about among the flower-beds distributing life around her.
모모The sound of the watering-pot on the leaves filled Father Mabeuf's soul with ecstasy. It seemed to him that the rhododendron was happy now.
모모The first bucketful emptied, the girl drew a second, then a third. She watered the whole garden.
모모There was something about her, as she thus ran about among paths, where her outline appeared perfectly black, waving her angular arms, and with her fichu all in rags, that resembled a bat.
모모When she had finished, Father Mabeuf approached her with tears in his eyes, and laid his hand on her brow.
모모"God will bless you," said he, "you are an angel since you take care of the flowers."
모모"No," she replied.
모모"I am the devil, but that's all the same to me."
모모The old man exclaimed, without either waiting for or hearing her response:--
모모"What a pity that I am so unhappy and so poor, and that I can 
do nothing for you!"
모모"You can do something," said she.
모모"What?"
모모"Tell me where M. Marius lives."
모모The old man did not understand.
모모"What Monsieur Marius?"
모모He raised his glassy eyes and seemed to be seeking something that had vanished.
모모"A young man who used to come here."
모모In the meantime, M. Mabeuf had searched his memory.
모모"Ah! yes--" he exclaimed.
모모"I know what you mean.
모모Wait! Monsieur Marius--the Baron Marius Pontmercy, parbleu!
모모He lives,-- or rather, he no longer lives,--ah well, I don't know."
모모As he spoke, he had bent over to train a branch of rhododendron, and he continued:--
모모"Hold, I know now.
모모He very often passes along the boulevard, and goes in the direction of the Glaciere, Rue Croulebarbe. The meadow of the Lark.
모모Go there.
모모It is not hard to meet him."
모모When M. Mabeuf straightened himself up, there was no longer any one there; the girl had disappeared.
모모He was decidedly terrified.
모모"Really," he thought, "if my garden had not been watered, I should think that she was a spirit."
모모An hour later, when he was in bed, it came back to him, and as he fell asleep, at that confused moment when thought, like that fabulous bird which changes itself into a fish in order to cross the sea, little by little assumes the form of a dream in order to traverse slumber, he said to himself in a bewildered way:--
모모"In sooth, that greatly resembles what Rubaudiere narrates of the goblins.
모모Could it have been a goblin?"
모모APPARITION TO FATHER MABEUF 
모모 Marius no longer went to see any one, but he sometimes encountered Father Mabeuf by chance.
모모While Marius was slowly descending those melancholy steps which may be called the cellar stairs, and which lead to places without light, where the happy can be heard walking overhead, M. Mabeuf was descending on his side.
모모The Flora of Cauteretz no longer sold at all.

모모For this purpose he had pawned his copperplates of the Flora.

모모And often his breakfast was his only meal. He no longer smiled with his infantile smile, he had grown morose and no longer received visitors.
모모Marius did well not to dream of going thither.
모모Sometimes, at the hour when M. Mabeuf was on his way to the Jardin des Plantes, the old man and the young man passed each other on the Boulevard de l'Hopital. They did not speak, and only exchanged a melancholy sign of the head.

모모these were the three forms which happiness, pleasure, and hope had assumed for him.
모모This sufficed him for his living.
모모He said to himself:
모모"When I shall have made my balls of blueing, I shall be rich, I will withdraw my copperplates from the pawn-shop, I will put my Flora in vogue again with trickery, plenty of money and advertisements in the newspapers and I will buy, I know well where, a copy of Pierre de Medine's Art de Naviguer, with wood-cuts, edition of 1655."

모모One evening he had a singular apparition.
모모He had returned home while it was still broad daylight. Mother Plutarque, whose health was declining, was ill and in bed. He had dined on a bone, on which a little meat lingered, and a bit of bread that he had found on the kitchen table, and had seated himself on an overturned stone post, which took the place of a bench in his garden.

모모The first of these books was the famous treatise of President Delancre, De l'inconstance des Demons; the other was a quarto by Mutor de la Rubaudiere, Sur les Diables de Vauvert et les Gobelins de la Bievre.
모모This last-mentioned old volume interested him all the more, because his garden had been one of the spots haunted by goblins in former times.
모모The twilight had begun to whiten what was on high and to blacken all below. As he read, over the top of the book which he held in his hand, Father Mabeuf was surveying his plants, and among others a magnificent rhododendron which was one of his consolations; four days of heat, wind, and sun without a drop of rain, had passed; the stalks were bending, the buds drooping, the leaves falling; all this needed water, the rhododendron was particularly sad. Father Mabeuf was one of those persons for whom plants have souls. The old man had toiled all day over his indigo plot, he was worn out with fatigue, but he rose, laid his books on the bench, and walked, all bent over and with tottering footsteps, to the well, but when he had grasped the chain, he could not even draw it sufficiently to unhook it.
모모Then he turned round and cast a glance of anguish toward heaven which was becoming studded with stars.
모모The evening had that serenity which overwhelms the troubles of man beneath an indescribably mournful and eternal joy.
모모The night promised to be as arid as the day had been.
모모"Stars everywhere!" thought the old man; "not the tiniest cloud! Not a drop of water!"
모모And his head, which had been upraised for a moment, fell back upon his breast.
모모He raised it again, and once more looked at the sky, murmuring:--
모모"A tear of dew!
모모A little pity!"
모모He tried again to unhook the chain of the well, and could not.
모모At that moment, he heard a voice saying:--
모모"Father Mabeuf, would you like to have me water your garden for you?"
모모At the same time, a noise as of a wild animal passing became audible in the hedge, and he beheld emerging from the shrubbery a sort of tall, slender girl, who drew herself up in front of him and stared boldly at him.
모모She had less the air of a human being than of a form which had just blossomed forth from the twilight.
모모Before Father Mabeuf, who was easily terrified, and who was, as we have said, quick to take alarm, was able to reply by a single syllable, this being, whose movements had a sort of odd abruptness in the darkness, had unhooked the chain, plunged in and withdrawn the bucket, and filled the watering-pot, and the goodman beheld this apparition, which had bare feet and a tattered petticoat, running about among the flower-beds distributing life around her.
모모The sound of the watering-pot on the leaves filled Father Mabeuf's soul with ecstasy. It seemed to him that the rhododendron was happy now.
모모The first bucketful emptied, the girl drew a second, then a third. She watered the whole garden.
모모There was something about her, as she thus ran about among paths, where her outline appeared perfectly black, waving her angular arms, and with her fichu all in rags, that resembled a bat.
모모When she had finished, Father Mabeuf approached her with tears in his eyes, and laid his hand on her brow.
모모"God will bless you," said he, "you are an angel since you take care of the flowers."
모모"No," she replied.
모모"I am the devil, but that's all the same to me."
모모The old man exclaimed, without either waiting for or hearing her response:--
모모"What a pity that I am so unhappy and so poor, and that I can 
do nothing for you!"
모모"You can do something," said she.
모모"What?"
모모"Tell me where M. Marius lives."
모모The old man did not understand.
모모"What Monsieur Marius?"
모모He raised his glassy eyes and seemed to be seeking something that had vanished.
모모"A young man who used to come here."
모모In the meantime, M. Mabeuf had searched his memory.
모모"Ah! yes--" he exclaimed.
모모"I know what you mean.
모모Wait! Monsieur Marius--the Baron Marius Pontmercy, parbleu!
모모He lives,-- or rather, he no longer lives,--ah well, I don't know."
모모As he spoke, he had bent over to train a branch of rhododendron, and he continued:--
모모"Hold, I know now.
모모He very often passes along the boulevard, and goes in the direction of the Glaciere, Rue Croulebarbe. The meadow of the Lark.
모모Go there.
모모It is not hard to meet him."
모모When M. Mabeuf straightened himself up, there was no longer any one there; the girl had disappeared.
모모He was decidedly terrified.
모모"Really," he thought, "if my garden had not been watered, I should think that she was a spirit."
모모An hour later, when he was in bed, it came back to him, and as he fell asleep, at that confused moment when thought, like that fabulous bird which changes itself into a fish in order to cross the sea, little by little assumes the form of a dream in order to traverse slumber, he said to himself in a bewildered way:--
모모"In sooth, that greatly resembles what Rubaudiere narrates of the goblins.
모모Could it have been a goblin?"


BOOK SECOND.--EPONINE
CHAPTER IV 
모모AN APPARITION TO MARIUS
모모 Some days after this visit of a "spirit" to Farmer Mabeuf, one morning,-- it was on a Monday, the day when Marius borrowed the hundred-sou piece from Courfeyrac for Thenardier--Marius had put this coin in his pocket, and before carrying it to the clerk's office, he had gone "to take a little stroll," in the hope that this would make him work on his return.
모모It was always thus, however.
모모As soon as he rose, he seated himself before a book and a sheet of paper in order to scribble some translation; his task at that epoch consisted in turning into French a celebrated quarrel between Germans, the Gans and Savigny controversy; he took Savigny, he took Gans, read four lines, tried to write one, could not, saw a star between him and his paper, and rose from his chair, saying:
모모"I shall go out. That will put me in spirits."
모모And off he went to the Lark's meadow.
모모There he beheld more than ever the star, and less than ever Savigny and Gans.
모모He returned home, tried to take up his work again, and did not succeed; there was no means of re-knotting a single one of the threads which were broken in his brain; then he said to himself:
모모"I will not go out to-morrow. It prevents my working."
모모And he went out every day.
모모He lived in the Lark's meadow more than in Courfeyrac's lodgings. That was his real address:
모모Boulevard de la Sante, at the seventh tree from the Rue Croulebarbe.
모모That morning he had quitted the seventh tree and had seated himself on the parapet of the River des Gobelins.
모모A cheerful sunlight penetrated the freshly unfolded and luminous leaves.
모모He was dreaming of "Her."
모모And his meditation turning to a reproach, fell back upon himself; he reflected dolefully on his idleness, his paralysis of soul, which was gaining on him, and of that night which was growing more dense every moment before him, to such a point that he no longer even saw the sun.
모모Nevertheless, athwart this painful extrication of indistinct ideas which was not even a monologue, so feeble had action become in him, and he had no longer the force to care to despair, athwart this melancholy absorption, sensations from without did reach him. He heard behind him, beneath him, on both banks of the river, the laundresses of the Gobelins beating their linen, and above his head, the birds chattering and singing in the elm-trees. On the one hand, the sound of liberty, the careless happiness of the leisure which has wings; on the other, the sound of toil. What caused him to meditate deeply, and almost reflect, were two cheerful sounds.
모모All at once, in the midst of his dejected ecstasy, he heard a familiar voice saying:--
모모"Come!
모모Here he is!"
모모He raised his eyes, and recognized that wretched child who had come to him one morning, the elder of the Thenardier daughters, Eponine; he knew her name now.
모모Strange to say, she had grown poorer and prettier, two steps which it had not seemed within her power to take. She had accomplished a double progress, towards the light and towards distress.
모모She was barefooted and in rags, as on the day when she had so resolutely entered his chamber, only her rags were two months older now, the holes were larger, the tatters more sordid. It was the same harsh voice, the same brow dimmed and wrinkled with tan, the same free, wild, and vacillating glance.
모모She had besides, more than formerly, in her face that indescribably terrified and lamentable something which sojourn in a prison adds to wretchedness.
모모She had bits of straw and hay in her hair, not like Ophelia through having gone mad from the contagion of Hamlet's madness, but because she had slept in the loft of some stable.
모모And in spite of it all, she was beautiful.
모모What a star art thou, O youth!
모모In the meantime, she had halted in front of Marius with a trace of joy in her livid countenance, and something which resembled a smile.
모모She stood for several moments as though incapable of speech.
모모"So I have met you at last!" she said at length.
모모"Father Mabeuf was right, it was on this boulevard!
모모How I have hunted for you! If you only knew!
모모Do you know?
모모I have been in the jug.
모모A fortnight! They let me out! seeing that there was nothing against me, and that, moreover, I had not reached years of discretion.
모모I lack two months of it.
모모Oh! how I have hunted for you!
모모These six weeks! So you don't live down there any more?"
모모"No," said Marius.
모모"Ah!
모모I understand.
모모Because of that affair.
모모Those take-downs are disagreeable.
모모You cleared out.
모모Come now!
모모Why do you wear old hats like this!
모모A young man like you ought to have fine clothes. Do you know, Monsieur Marius, Father Mabeuf calls you Baron Marius, I don't know what.
모모It isn't true that you are a baron?
모모Barons are old fellows, they go to the Luxembourg, in front of the chateau, where there is the most sun, and they read the Quotidienne for a sou. I once carried a letter to a baron of that sort.
모모He was over a hundred years old.
모모Say, where do you live now?"
모모Marius made no reply.
모모"Ah!" she went on, "you have a hole in your shirt.
모모I must sew it up for you."
모모She resumed with an expression which gradually clouded over:--
모모"You don't seem glad to see me."
모모Marius held his peace; she remained silent for a moment, then exclaimed:--
모모"But if I choose, nevertheless, I could force you to look glad!"
모모"What?" demanded Marius.
모모"What do you mean?"
모모"Ah! you used to call me thou," she retorted.
모모"Well, then, what dost thou mean?"
모모She bit her lips; she seemed to hesitate, as though a prey to some sort of inward conflict.
모모At last she appeared to come to a decision.
모모"So much the worse, I don't care.
모모You have a melancholy air, I want you to be pleased.
모모Only promise me that you will smile. I want to see you smile and hear you say:
모모`Ah, well, that's good.' Poor Mr. Marius! you know?
모모You promised me that you would give me anything I like--"
모모"Yes!
모모Only speak!"
모모She looked Marius full in the eye, and said:--
모모"I have the address."
모모Marius turned pale.
모모All the blood flowed back to his heart.
모모"What address?"
모모"The address that you asked me to get!"
모모She added, as though with an effort:--
모모"The address--you know very well!"
모모"Yes!" stammered Marius.
모모"Of that young lady."
모모This word uttered, she sighed deeply.
모모Marius sprang from the parapet on which he had been sitting and seized her hand distractedly.
모모"Oh!
모모Well! lead me thither!
모모Tell me!
모모Ask of me anything you wish! Where is it?"
모모"Come with me," she responded.
모모"I don't know the street or number very well; it is in quite the other direction from here, but I know the house well, I will take you to it."
모모She withdrew her hand and went on, in a tone which could have rent the heart of an observer, but which did not even graze Marius in his intoxicated and ecstatic state:--
모모"Oh! how glad you are!"
모모A cloud swept across Marius' brow.
모모He seized Eponine by the arm:--
모모"Swear one thing to me!"
모모"Swear!" said she, "what does that mean?
모모Come!
모모You want me to swear?"
모모And she laughed.
모모"Your father! promise me, Eponine!
모모Swear to me that you will not give this address to your father!"
모모She turned to him with a stupefied air.
모모"Eponine!
모모How do you know that my name is Eponine?"
모모"Promise what I tell you!"
모모But she did not seem to hear him.
모모"That's nice!
모모You have called me Eponine!"
모모Marius grasped both her arms at once.
모모"But answer me, in the name of Heaven! pay attention to what I am saying to you, swear to me that you will not tell your father this address that you know!"
모모"My father!" said she.
모모"Ah yes, my father!
모모Be at ease. He's in close confinement.
모모Besides, what do I care for my father!"
모모"But you do not promise me!" exclaimed Marius.
모모"Let go of me!" she said, bursting into a laugh, "how you do shake me! Yes!
모모Yes!
모모I promise that!
모모I swear that to you!
모모What is that to me? I will not tell my father the address.
모모There!
모모Is that right? Is that it?"
모모"Nor to any one?" said Marius.
모모"Nor to any one."
모모"Now," resumed Marius, "take me there."
모모"Immediately?"
모모"Immediately."
모모"Come along.
모모Ah! how pleased he is!" said she.
모모After a few steps she halted.
모모"You are following me too closely, Monsieur Marius.
모모Let me go on ahead, and follow me so, without seeming to do it.
모모A nice young man like you must not be seen with a woman like me."
모모No tongue can express all that lay in that word, woman, thus pronounced by that child.
모모She proceeded a dozen paces and then halted once more; Marius joined her. She addressed him sideways, and without turning towards him:--
모모"By the way, you know that you promised me something?"
모모Marius fumbled in his pocket.
모모All that he owned in the world was the five francs intended for Thenardier the father.
모모He took them and laid them in Eponine's hand.
모모She opened her fingers and let the coin fall to the ground, and gazed at him with a gloomy air.
모모"I don't want your money," said she.

모모Marius fumbled in his pocket.
모모All that he owned in the world was the five francs intended for Thenardier the father.
모모He took them and laid them in Eponine's hand.
모모She opened her fingers and let the coin fall to the ground, and gazed at him with a gloomy air.
모모"I don't want your money," said she.


BOOK THIRD.--THE HOUSE IN THE RUE PLUMET
CHAPTER I 
모모THE HOUSE WITH A SECRET 
모모About the middle of the last century, a chief justice in the Parliament of Paris having a mistress and concealing the fact, for at that period the grand seignors displayed their mistresses, and the bourgeois concealed them, had "a little house" built in the Faubourg Saint-Germain, in the deserted Rue Blomet, which is now called Rue Plumet, not far from the spot which was then designated as Combat des Animaux.
모모This house was composed of a single-storied pavilion; two rooms on the ground floor, two chambers on the first floor, a kitchen down stairs, a boudoir up stairs, an attic under the roof, the whole preceded by a garden with a large gate opening on the street. This garden was about an acre and a half in extent.
모모This was all that could be seen by passers-by; but behind the pavilion there was a narrow courtyard, and at the end of the courtyard a low building consisting of two rooms and a cellar, a sort of preparation destined to conceal a child and nurse in case of need.
모모This building communicated in the rear by a masked door which opened by a secret spring, with a long, narrow, paved winding corridor, open to the sky, hemmed in with two lofty walls, which, hidden with wonderful art, and lost as it were between garden enclosures and cultivated land, all of whose angles and detours it followed, ended in another door, also with a secret lock which opened a quarter of a league away, almost in another quarter, at the solitary extremity of the Rue du Babylone.
모모Through this the chief justice entered, so that even those who were spying on him and following him would merely have observed that the justice betook himself every day in a mysterious way somewhere, and would never have suspected that to go to the Rue de Babylone was to go to the Rue Blomet.
모모Thanks to clever purchasers of land, the magistrate had been able to make a secret, sewer-like passage on his own property, and consequently, without interference.
모모Later on, he had sold in little parcels, for gardens and market gardens, the lots of ground adjoining the corridor, and the proprietors of these lots on both sides thought they had a party wall before their eyes, and did not even suspect the long, paved ribbon winding between two walls amid their flower-beds and their orchards. Only the birds beheld this curiosity.
모모It is probable that the linnets and tomtits of the last century gossiped a great deal about the chief justice.
모모The pavilion, built of stone in the taste of Mansard, wainscoted and furnished in the Watteau style, rocaille on the inside, old-fashioned on the outside, walled in with a triple hedge of flowers, had something discreet, coquettish, and solemn about it, as befits a caprice of love and magistracy.
모모This house and corridor, which have now disappeared, were in existence fifteen years ago.
모모In '93 a coppersmith had purchased the house with the idea of demolishing it, but had not been able to pay the price; the nation made him bankrupt.
모모So that it was the house which demolished the coppersmith.
모모After that, the house remained uninhabited, and fell slowly to ruin, as does every dwelling to which the presence of man does not communicate life. It had remained fitted with its old furniture, was always for sale or to let, and the ten or a dozen people who passed through the Rue Plumet were warned of the fact by a yellow and illegible bit of writing which had hung on the garden wall since 1819.
모모Towards the end of the Restoration, these same passers-by might have noticed that the bill had disappeared, and even that the shutters on the first floor were open.
모모The house was occupied, in fact. The windows had short curtains, a sign that there was a woman about.
모모In the month of October, 1829, a man of a certain age had presented himself and had hired the house just as it stood, including, of course, the back building and the lane which ended in the Rue de Babylone. He had had the secret openings of the two doors to this passage repaired. The house, as we have just mentioned, was still very nearly furnished with the justice's old fitting; the new tenant had ordered some repairs, had added what was lacking here and there, had replaced the paving-stones in the yard, bricks in the floors, steps in the stairs, missing bits in the inlaid floors and the glass in the lattice windows, and had finally installed himself there with a young girl and an elderly maid-servant, without commotion, rather like a person who is slipping in than like a man who is entering his own house.
모모The neighbors did not gossip about him, for the reason that there were no neighbors.
모모This unobtrusive tenant was Jean Valjean, the young girl was Cosette. The servant was a woman named Toussaint, whom Jean Valjean had saved from the hospital and from wretchedness, and who was elderly, a stammerer, and from the provinces, three qualities which had decided Jean Valjean to take her with him.
모모He had hired the house under the name of M. Fauchelevent, independent gentleman. In all that has been related heretofore, the reader has, doubtless, been no less prompt than Thenardier to recognize Jean Valjean.
모모Why had Jean Valjean quitted the convent of the Petit-Picpus? What had happened?
모모Nothing had happened.
모모It will be remembered that Jean Valjean was happy in the convent, so happy that his conscience finally took the alarm.
모모He saw Cosette every day, he felt paternity spring up and develop within him more and more, he brooded over the soul of that child, he said to himself that she was his, that nothing could take her from him, that this would last indefinitely, that she would certainly become a nun, being thereto gently incited every day, that thus the convent was henceforth the universe for her as it was for him, that he should grow old there, and that she would grow up there, that she would grow old there, and that he should die there; that, in short, delightful hope, no separation was possible.
모모On reflecting upon this, he fell into perplexity.
모모He interrogated himself.
모모He asked himself if all that happiness were really his, if it were not composed of the happiness of another, of the happiness of that child which he, an old man, was confiscating and stealing; if that were not theft? He said to himself, that this child had a right to know life before renouncing it, that to deprive her in advance, and in some sort without consulting her, of all joys, under the pretext of saving her from all trials, to take advantage of her ignorance of her isolation, in order to make an artificial vocation germinate in her, was to rob a human creature of its nature and to lie to God. And who knows if, when she came to be aware of all this some day, and found herself a nun to her sorrow, Cosette would not come to hate him?
모모A last, almost selfish thought, and less heroic than the rest, but which was intolerable to him.
모모He resolved to quit the convent.
모모He resolved on this; he recognized with anguish, the fact that it was necessary.
모모As for objections, there were none. Five years' sojourn between these four walls and of disappearance had necessarily destroyed or dispersed the elements of fear. He could return tranquilly among men.
모모He had grown old, and all had undergone a change.
모모Who would recognize him now? And then, to face the worst, there was danger only for himself, and he had no right to condemn Cosette to the cloister for the reason that he had been condemned to the galleys.
모모Besides, what is danger in comparison with the right?
모모Finally, nothing prevented his being prudent and taking his precautions.
모모As for Cosette's education, it was almost finished and complete.
모모His determination once taken, he awaited an opportunity. It was not long in presenting itself.
모모Old Fauchelevent died.
모모Jean Valjean demanded an audience with the revered prioress and told her that, having come into a little inheritance at the death of his brother, which permitted him henceforth to live without working, he should leave the service of the convent and take his daughter with him; but that, as it was not just that Cosette, since she had not taken the vows, should have received her education gratuitously, he humbly begged the Reverend Prioress to see fit that he should offer to the community, as indemnity, for the five years which Cosette had spent there, the sum of five thousand francs.
모모It was thus that Jean Valjean quitted the convent of the Perpetual Adoration.
모모On leaving the convent, he took in his own arms the little valise the key to which he still wore on his person, and would permit no porter to touch it.
모모This puzzled Cosette, because of the odor of embalming which proceeded from it.
모모Let us state at once, that this trunk never quitted him more. He always had it in his chamber.
모모It was the first and only thing sometimes, that he carried off in his moving when he moved about. Cosette laughed at it, and called this valise his inseparable, saying: "I am jealous of it."
모모Nevertheless, Jean Valjean did not reappear in the open air without profound anxiety.
모모He discovered the house in the Rue Plumet, and hid himself from sight there.
모모Henceforth he was in the possession of the name:-- Ultime Fauchelevent.
모모At the same time he hired two other apartments in Paris, in order that he might attract less attention than if he were to remain always in the same quarter, and so that he could, at need, take himself off at the slightest disquietude which should assail him, and in short, so that he might not again be caught unprovided as on the night when he had so miraculously escaped from Javert. These two apartments were very pitiable, poor in appearance, and in two quarters which were far remote from each other, the one in the Rue de l'Ouest, the other in the Rue de l'Homme Arme.
모모He went from time to time, now to the Rue de l'Homme Arme, now to the Rue de l'Ouest, to pass a month or six weeks, without taking Toussaint.
모모He had himself served by the porters, and gave himself out as a gentleman from the suburbs, living on his funds, and having a little temporary resting-place in town. This lofty virtue had three domiciles in Paris for the sake of escaping from the police.
모모THE HOUSE WITH A SECRET

BOOK THIRD.--THE HOUSE IN THE RUE PLUMET
CHAPTER II 
모모JEAN VALJEAN AS A NATIONAL GUARD
모모 However, properly speaking, he lived in the Rue Plumet, and he had arranged his existence there in the following fashion:--
모모Cosette and the servant occupied the pavilion; she had the big sleeping-room with the painted pier-glasses, the boudoir with the gilded fillets, the justice's drawing-room furnished with tapestries and vast arm-chairs; she had the garden.
모모Jean Valjean had a canopied bed of antique damask in three colors and a beautiful Persian rug purchased in the Rue du Figuier-Saint-Paul at Mother Gaucher's, put into Cosette's chamber, and, in order to redeem the severity of these magnificent old things, he had amalgamated with this bric-a-brac all the gay and graceful little pieces of furniture suitable to young girls, an etagere, a bookcase filled with gilt-edged books, an inkstand, a blotting-book, paper, a work-table incrusted with mother of pearl, a silver-gilt dressing-case, a toilet service in Japanese porcelain. Long damask curtains with a red foundation and three colors, like those on the bed, hung at the windows of the first floor. On the ground floor, the curtains were of tapestry.
모모All winter long, Cosette's little house was heated from top to bottom.
모모Jean Valjean inhabited the sort of porter's lodge which was situated at the end of the back courtyard, with a mattress on a folding-bed, a white wood table, two straw chairs, an earthenware water-jug, a few old volumes on a shelf, his beloved valise in one corner, and never any fire.
모모He dined with Cosette, and he had a loaf of black bread on the table for his own use.
모모When Toussaint came, he had said to her:
모모"It is the young lady who is the mistress of this house."--"And you, monsieur?"
모모Toussaint replied in amazement.--"I am a much better thing than the master, I am the father."
모모Cosette had been taught housekeeping in the convent, and she regulated their expenditure, which was very modest.
모모Every day, Jean Valjean put his arm through Cosette's and took her for a walk. He led her to the Luxembourg, to the least frequented walk, and every Sunday he took her to mass at Saint-Jacques-du-Haut-Pas, because that was a long way off.
모모As it was a very poor quarter, he bestowed alms largely there, and the poor people surrounded him in church, which had drawn down upon him Thenardier's epistle: "To the benevolent gentleman of the church of Saint-Jacques-du-Haut-Pas." He was fond of taking Cosette to visit the poor and the sick. No stranger ever entered the house in the Rue Plumet.
모모Toussaint brought their provisions, and Jean Valjean went himself for water to a fountain near by on the boulevard.
모모Their wood and wine were put into a half-subterranean hollow lined with rock-work which lay near the Rue de Babylone and which had formerly served the chief-justice as a grotto; for at the epoch of follies and "Little Houses" no love was without a grotto.
모모In the door opening on the Rue de Babylone, there was a box destined for the reception of letters and papers; only, as the three inhabitants of the pavilion in the Rue Plumet received neither papers nor letters, the entire usefulness of that box, formerly the go-between of a love affair, and the confidant of a love-lorn lawyer, was now limited to the tax-collector's notices, and the summons of the guard. For M. Fauchelevent, independent gentleman, belonged to the national guard; he had not been able to escape through the fine meshes of the census of 1831.
모모The municipal information collected at that time had even reached the convent of the Petit-Picpus, a sort of impenetrable and holy cloud, whence Jean Valjean had emerged in venerable guise, and, consequently, worthy of mounting guard in the eyes of the townhall.
모모Three or four times a year, Jean Valjean donned his uniform and mounted guard; he did this willingly, however; it was a correct disguise which mixed him with every one, and yet left him solitary. Jean Valjean had just attained his sixtieth birthday, the age of legal exemption; but he did not appear to be over fifty; moreover, he had no desire to escape his sergeant-major nor to quibble with Comte de Lobau; he possessed no civil status, he was concealing his name, he was concealing his identity, so he concealed his age, he concealed everything; and, as we have just said, he willingly did his duty as a national guard; the sum of his ambition lay in resembling any other man who paid his taxes. This man had for his ideal, within, the angel, without, the bourgeois.
모모Let us note one detail, however; when Jean Valjean went out with Cosette, he dressed as the reader has already seen, and had the air of a retired officer.
모모When he went out alone, which was generally at night, he was always dressed in a workingman's trousers and blouse, and wore a cap which concealed his face.
모모Was this precaution or humility? Both.
모모Cosette was accustomed to the enigmatical side of her destiny, and hardly noticed her father's peculiarities.
모모As for Toussaint, she venerated Jean Valjean, and thought everything he did right.
모모One day, her butcher, who had caught a glimpse of Jean Valjean, said to her:
모모"That's a queer fish."
모모She replied:
모모"He's a saint."
모모Neither Jean Valjean nor Cosette nor Toussaint ever entered or emerged except by the door on the Rue de Babylone.
모모Unless seen through the garden gate it would have been difficult to guess that they lived in the Rue Plumet.
모모That gate was always closed.
모모Jean Valjean had left the garden uncultivated, in order not to attract attention.
모모In this, possibly, he made a mistake.


BOOK THIRD.--THE HOUSE IN THE RUE PLUMET
CHAPTER III 
모모FOLIIS AC FRONDIBUS
모모 The garden thus left to itself for more than half a century had become extraordinary and charming.
모모The passers-by of forty years ago halted to gaze at it, without a suspicion of the secrets which it hid in its fresh and verdant depths.
모모More than one dreamer of that epoch often allowed his thoughts and his eyes to penetrate indiscreetly between the bars of that ancient, padlocked gate, twisted, tottering, fastened to two green and moss-covered pillars, and oddly crowned with a pediment of undecipherable arabesque.
모모There was a stone bench in one corner, one or two mouldy statues, several lattices which had lost their nails with time, were rotting on the wall, and there were no walks nor turf; but there was enough grass everywhere.
모모Gardening had taken its departure, and nature had returned.
모모Weeds abounded, which was a great piece of luck for a poor corner of land.
모모The festival of gilliflowers was something splendid.
모모Nothing in this garden obstructed the sacred effort of things towards life; venerable growth reigned there among them.
모모The trees had bent over towards the nettles, the plant had sprung upward, the branch had inclined, that which crawls on the earth had gone in search of that which expands in the air, that which floats on the wind had bent over towards that which trails in the moss; trunks, boughs, leaves, fibres, clusters, tendrils, shoots, spines, thorns, had mingled, crossed, married, confounded themselves in each other; vegetation in a deep and close embrace, had celebrated and accomplished there, under the well-pleased eye of the Creator, in that enclosure three hundred feet square, the holy mystery of fraternity, symbol of the human fraternity. This garden was no longer a garden, it was a colossal thicket, that is to say, something as impenetrable as a forest, as peopled as a city, quivering like a nest, sombre like a cathedral, fragrant like a bouquet, solitary as a tomb, living as a throng.
모모In Floreal[34] this enormous thicket, free behind its gate and within its four walls, entered upon the secret labor of germination, quivered in the rising sun, almost like an animal which drinks in the breaths of cosmic love, and which feels the sap of April rising and boiling in its veins, and shakes to the wind its enormous wonderful green locks, sprinkled on the damp earth, on the defaced statues, on the crumbling steps of the pavilion, and even on the pavement of the deserted street, flowers like stars, dew like pearls, fecundity, beauty, life, joy, perfumes.
모모At midday, a thousand white butterflies took refuge there, and it was a divine spectacle to see that living summer snow whirling about there in flakes amid the shade.
모모There, in those gay shadows of verdure, a throng of innocent voices spoke sweetly to the soul, and what the twittering forgot to say the humming completed.
모모In the evening, a dreamy vapor exhaled from the garden and enveloped it; a shroud of mist, a calm and celestial sadness covered it; the intoxicating perfume of the honeysuckles and convolvulus poured out from every part of it, like an exquisite and subtle poison; the last appeals of the woodpeckers and the wagtails were audible as they dozed among the branches; one felt the sacred intimacy of the birds and the trees; by day the wings rejoice the leaves, by night the leaves protect the wings.
모모 [34] From April 19 to May 20.
모모 In winter the thicket was black, dripping, bristling, shivering, and allowed some glimpse of the house.
모모Instead of flowers on the branches 
and dew in the flowers, the long silvery tracks of the snails were visible on the cold, thick carpet of yellow leaves; but in any fashion, under any aspect, at all seasons, spring, winter, summer, autumn, this tiny enclosure breathed forth melancholy, contemplation, solitude, liberty, the absence of man, the presence of God; and the rusty old gate had the air of saying:
모모"This garden belongs to me."
모모It was of no avail that the pavements of Paris were there on every side, the classic and splendid hotels of the Rue de Varennes a couple of paces away, the dome of the Invalides close at hand, the Chamber of Deputies not far off; the carriages of the Rue de Bourgogne and of the Rue Saint-Dominique rumbled luxuriously, in vain, in the vicinity, in vain did the yellow, brown, white, and red omnibuses cross each other's course at the neighboring cross-roads; the Rue Plumet was the desert; and the death of the former proprietors, the revolution which had passed over it, the crumbling away of ancient fortunes, absence, forgetfulness, forty years of abandonment and widowhood, had sufficed to restore to this privileged spot ferns, mulleins, hemlock, yarrow, tall weeds, great crimped plants, with large leaves of pale green cloth, lizards, beetles, uneasy and rapid insects; to cause to spring forth from the depths of the earth and to reappear between those four walls a certain indescribable and savage grandeur; and for nature, which disconcerts the petty arrangements of man, and which sheds herself always thoroughly where she diffuses herself at all, in the ant as well as in the eagle, to blossom out in a petty little Parisian garden with as much rude force and majesty as in a virgin forest of the New World.
모모Nothing is small, in fact; any one who is subject to the profound and penetrating influence of nature knows this.
모모Although no absolute satisfaction is given to philosophy, either to circumscribe the cause or to limit the effect, the contemplator falls into those unfathomable ecstasies caused by these decompositions of force terminating in unity.
모모Everything toils at everything.
모모Algebra is applied to the clouds; the radiation of the star profits the rose; no thinker would venture to affirm that the perfume of the hawthorn is useless to the constellations.
모모Who, then, can calculate the course of a molecule?
모모How do we know that the creation of worlds is not determined by the fall of grains of sand?
모모Who knows the reciprocal ebb and flow of the infinitely great and the infinitely little, the reverberations of causes in the precipices of being, and the avalanches of creation?
모모The tiniest worm is of importance; the great is little, the little is great; everything is balanced in necessity; alarming vision for the mind.
모모There are marvellous relations between beings and things; in that inexhaustible whole, from the sun to the grub, nothing despises the other; all have need of each other.
