모모The light does not bear away terrestrial perfumes into the azure depths, without knowing what it is doing; the night distributes stellar essences to the sleeping flowers. All birds that fly have round their leg the thread of the infinite. Germination is complicated with the bursting forth of a meteor and with the peck of a swallow cracking its egg, and it places on one level the birth of an earthworm and the advent of Socrates. Where the telescope ends, the microscope begins.
모모Which of the two possesses the larger field of vision?
모모Choose.
모모A bit of mould is a pleiad of flowers; a nebula is an ant-hill of stars. The same promiscuousness, and yet more unprecedented, exists between the things of the intelligence and the facts of substance. Elements and principles mingle, combine, wed, multiply with each other, to such a point that the material and the moral world are brought eventually to the same clearness.
모모The phenomenon is perpetually returning upon itself.
모모In the vast cosmic exchanges the universal life goes and comes in unknown quantities, rolling entirely in the invisible mystery of effluvia, employing everything, not losing a single dream, not a single slumber, sowing an animalcule here, crumbling to bits a planet there, oscillating and winding, making of light a force and of thought an element, disseminated and invisible, dissolving all, except that geometrical point, the I; bringing everything back to the soul-atom; expanding everything in God, entangling all activity, from summit to base, in the obscurity of a dizzy mechanism, attaching the flight of an insect to the movement of the earth, subordinating, who knows?
모모Were it only by the identity of the law, the evolution of the comet in the firmament to the whirling of the infusoria in the drop of water.
모모A machine made of mind. Enormous gearing, the prime motor of which is the gnat, and whose final wheel is the zodiac.


BOOK THIRD.--THE HOUSE IN THE RUE PLUMET
CHAPTER IV 
모모CHANGE OF GATE
모모 It seemed that this garden, created in olden days to conceal wanton mysteries, had been transformed and become fitted to shelter chaste mysteries.
모모There were no longer either arbors, or bowling greens, or tunnels, or grottos; there was a magnificent, dishevelled obscurity falling like a veil over all.
모모Paphos had been made over into Eden. It is impossible to say what element of repentance had rendered this retreat wholesome.
모모This flower-girl now offered her blossom to the soul.
모모This coquettish garden, formerly decidedly compromised, had returned to virginity and modesty.
모모A justice assisted by a gardener, a goodman who thought that he was a continuation of Lamoignon, and another goodman who thought that he was a continuation of Lenotre, had turned it about, cut, ruffled, decked, moulded it to gallantry; nature had taken possession of it once more, had filled it with shade, and had arranged it for love.
모모There was, also, in this solitude, a heart which was quite ready. Love had only to show himself; he had here a temple composed of verdure, grass, moss, the sight of birds, tender shadows, agitated branches, and a soul made of sweetness, of faith, of candor, of hope, of aspiration, and of illusion.
모모Cosette had left the convent when she was still almost a child; she was a little more than fourteen, and she was at the "ungrateful age"; we have already said, that with the exception of her eyes, she was homely rather than pretty; she had no ungraceful feature, but she was awkward, thin, timid and bold at once, a grown-up little girl, in short.
모모Her education was finished, that is to say, she has been taught religion, and even and above all, devotion; then "history," that is to say the thing that bears that name in convents, geography, grammar, the participles, the kings of France, a little music, a little drawing, etc.; but in all other respects she was utterly ignorant, which is a great charm and a great peril.
모모The soul of a young girl should not be left in the dark; later on, mirages that are too abrupt and too lively are formed there, as in a dark chamber. She should be gently and discreetly enlightened, rather with the reflection of realities than with their harsh and direct light. A useful and graciously austere half-light which dissipates puerile fears and obviates falls.
모모There is nothing but the maternal instinct, that admirable intuition composed of the memories of the virgin and the experience of the woman, which knows how this half-light is to be created and of what it should consist.
모모Nothing supplies the place of this instinct.
모모All the nuns in the world are not worth as much as one mother in the formation of a young girl's soul.
모모Cosette had had no mother.
모모She had only had many mothers, in the plural.
모모As for Jean Valjean, he was, indeed, all tenderness, all solicitude; but he was only an old man and he knew nothing at all.
모모
Now, in this work of education, in this grave matter of preparing a woman for life, what science is required to combat that vast ignorance which is called innocence!
모모Nothing prepares a young girl for passions like the convent. The convent turns the thoughts in the direction of the unknown. The heart, thus thrown back upon itself, works downward within itself, since it cannot overflow, and grows deep, since it cannot expand. Hence visions, suppositions, conjectures, outlines of romances, a desire for adventures, fantastic constructions, edifices built wholly in the inner obscurity of the mind, sombre and secret abodes where the passions immediately find a lodgement as soon as the open gate permits them to enter.
모모The convent is a compression which, in order to triumph over the human heart, should last during the whole life.
모모On quitting the convent, Cosette could have found nothing more sweet and more dangerous than the house in the Rue Plumet. It was the continuation of solitude with the beginning of liberty; a garden that was closed, but a nature that was acrid, rich, voluptuous, and fragrant; the same dreams as in the convent, but with glimpses of young men; a grating, but one that opened on the street.
모모Still, when she arrived there, we repeat, she was only a child. Jean Valjean gave this neglected garden over to her.
모모"Do what you like with it," he said to her.
모모This amused Cosette; she turned over all the clumps and all the stones, she hunted for "beasts"; she played in it, while awaiting the time when she would dream in it; she loved this garden for the insects that she found beneath her feet amid the grass, while awaiting the day when she would love it for the stars that she would see through the boughs above her head.
모모And then, she loved her father, that is to say, Jean Valjean, with all her soul, with an innocent filial passion which made the goodman a beloved and charming companion to her.
모모It will be remembered that M. Madeleine had been in the habit of reading a great deal.
모모Jean Valjean had continued this practice; he had come to converse well; he possessed the secret riches and the eloquence of a true and humble mind which has spontaneously cultivated itself. He retained just enough sharpness to season his kindness; his mind was rough and his heart was soft.
모모During their conversations in the Luxembourg, he gave her explanations of everything, drawing on what he had read, and also on what he had suffered. As she listened to him, Cosette's eyes wandered vaguely about.
모모This simple man sufficed for Cosette's thought, the same as the wild garden sufficed for her eyes.
모모When she had had a good chase after the butterflies, she came panting up to him and said:
모모"Ah!
모모How I have run!"
모모He kissed her brow.
모모Cosette adored the goodman.
모모She was always at his heels. Where Jean Valjean was, there happiness was.
모모Jean Valjean lived neither in the pavilion nor the garden; she took greater pleasure in the paved back courtyard, than in the enclosure filled with flowers, and in his little lodge furnished with straw-seated chairs than in the great drawing-room hung with tapestry, against which stood tufted easy-chairs. Jean Valjean sometimes said to her, smiling at his happiness in being importuned:
모모"Do go to your own quarters! Leave me alone a little!"
모모She gave him those charming and tender scoldings which are so graceful when they come from a daughter to her father.
모모"Father, I am very cold in your rooms; why don't you have a carpet here and a stove?"
모모"Dear child, there are so many people who are better than I and who have not even a roof over their heads."
모모"Then why is there a fire in my rooms, and everything that is needed?"
모모"Because you are a woman and a child."
모모"Bah! must men be cold and feel uncomfortable?"
모모"Certain men."
모모"That is good, I shall come here so often that you will be obliged to have a fire."
모모And again she said to him:--
모모"Father, why do you eat horrible bread like that?"
모모"Because, my daughter."
모모"Well, if you eat it, I will eat it too."
모모Then, in order to prevent Cosette eating black bread, Jean Valjean ate white bread.
모모Cosette had but a confused recollection of her childhood.
모모She prayed morning and evening for her mother whom she had never known. The Thenardiers had remained with her as two hideous figures in a dream.
모모She remembered that she had gone "one day, at night," to fetch water in a forest.
모모She thought that it had been very far from Paris.
모모It seemed to her that she had begun to live in an abyss, and that it was Jean Valjean who had rescued her from it. Her childhood produced upon her the effect of a time when there had been nothing around her but millepeds, spiders, and serpents. When she meditated in the evening, before falling asleep, as she had not a very clear idea that she was Jean Valjean's daughter, and that he was her father, she fancied that the soul of her mother had passed into that good man and had come to dwell near her.
모모When he was seated, she leaned her cheek against his white hair, and dropped a silent tear, saying to herself:
모모"Perhaps this man is my mother."
모모Cosette, although this is a strange statement to make, in the profound ignorance of a girl brought up in a convent,-- maternity being also absolutely unintelligible to virginity,-- had ended by fancying that she had had as little mother as possible. She did not even know her mother's name.
모모Whenever she asked Jean Valjean, Jean Valjean remained silent.
모모If she repeated her question, he responded with a smile.
모모Once she insisted; the smile ended in a tear.
모모This silence on the part of Jean Valjean covered Fantine with darkness.
모모Was it prudence?
모모Was it respect?
모모Was it a fear that he should deliver this name to the hazards of another memory than his own?
모모So long as Cosette had been small, Jean Valjean had been willing to talk to her of her mother; when she became a young girl, it was impossible for him to do so.
모모It seemed to him that he no longer dared.
모모Was it because of Cosette?
모모Was it because of Fantine?
모모He felt a certain religious horror at letting that shadow enter Cosette's thought; and of placing a third in their destiny.
모모The more sacred this shade was to him, the more did it seem that it was to be feared. He thought of Fantine, and felt himself overwhelmed with silence.
모모Through the darkness, he vaguely perceived something which appeared to have its finger on its lips.
모모Had all the modesty which had been in Fantine, and which had violently quitted her during her lifetime, returned to rest upon her after her death, to watch in indignation over the peace of that dead woman, and in its shyness, to keep her in her grave?
모모Was Jean Valjean unconsciously submitting to the pressure? We who believe in death, are not among the number who will reject this mysterious explanation.
모모Hence the impossibility of uttering, even for Cosette, that name of Fantine.
모모One day Cosette said to him:--
모모"Father, I saw my mother in a dream last night.
모모She had two big wings. My mother must have been almost a saint during her life."
모모"Through martyrdom," replied Jean Valjean.
모모However, Jean Valjean was happy.
모모When Cosette went out with him, she leaned on his arm, proud and happy, in the plenitude of her heart.
모모Jean Valjean felt his heart melt within him with delight, at all these sparks of a tenderness so exclusive, so wholly satisfied with himself alone.
모모The poor man trembled, inundated with angelic joy; he declared to himself ecstatically that this would last all their lives; he told himself that he really had not suffered sufficiently to merit so radiant a bliss, and he thanked God, in the depths of his soul, for having permitted him to be loved thus, he, a wretch, by that innocent being.


BOOK THIRD.--THE HOUSE IN THE RUE PLUMET
CHAPTER V 
모모THE ROSE PERCEIVES THAT IT IS AN ENGINE OF WAR
모모 One day, Cosette chanced to look at herself in her mirror, and she said to herself:
모모"Really!"
모모It seemed to her almost that she was pretty.
모모This threw her in a singularly troubled state of mind.
모모Up to that moment she had never thought of her face. She saw herself in her mirror, but she did not look at herself. And then, she had so often been told that she was homely; Jean Valjean alone said gently:
모모"No indeed! no indeed!" At all events, Cosette had always thought herself homely, and had grown up in that belief with the easy resignation of childhood. And here, all at once, was her mirror saying to her, as Jean Valjean had said:
모모"No indeed!"
모모That night, she did not sleep.
모모"What if I were pretty!" she thought.
모모"How odd it would be if I were pretty!" And she recalled those of her companions whose beauty had produced a sensation in the convent, and she said to herself:
모모"What!
모모Am I to be like Mademoiselle So-and-So?"
모모The next morning she looked at herself again, not by accident this time, and she was assailed with doubts:
모모"Where did I get such an idea?" said she; "no, I am ugly."
모모She had not slept well, that was all, her eyes were sunken and she was pale.
모모She had not felt very joyous on the preceding evening in the belief that she was beautiful, but it made her very sad not to be able to believe in it any longer. She did not look at herself again, and for more than a fortnight she tried to dress her hair with her back turned to the mirror.
모모In the evening, after dinner, she generally embroidered in wool or did some convent needlework in the drawing-room, and Jean Valjean read beside her.
모모Once she raised her eyes from her work, and was rendered quite uneasy by the manner in which her father was gazing at her.
모모On another occasion, she was passing along the street, and it seemed to her that some one behind her, whom she did not see, said:
모모"A pretty woman! but badly dressed." "Bah!" she thought, "he does not mean me.
모모I am well dressed and ugly."
모모She was then wearing a plush hat and her merino gown.
모모At last, one day when she was in the garden, she heard poor old Toussaint saying:
모모"Do you notice how pretty Cosette is growing, sir?" Cosette did not hear her father's reply, but Toussaint's words caused a sort of commotion within her.
모모She fled from the garden, ran up to her room, flew to the looking-glass,--it was three months since she had looked at herself,--and gave vent to a cry. She had just dazzled herself.
모모She was beautiful and lovely; she could not help agreeing with Toussaint and her mirror.
모모Her figure was formed, her skin had grown white, her hair was lustrous, an unaccustomed splendor had been lighted in her blue eyes.
모모The consciousness of her beauty burst upon her in an instant, like the sudden advent of daylight; other people noticed it also, Toussaint had said so, it was evidently she of whom the passer-by had spoken, there could no longer be any doubt of that; she descended to the garden again, thinking herself a queen, imagining that she heard the birds singing, though it was winter, seeing the sky gilded, the sun among the trees, flowers in the thickets, distracted, wild, in inexpressible delight.
모모Jean Valjean, on his side, experienced a deep and undefinable oppression at heart.
모모In fact, he had, for some time past, been contemplating with terror that beauty which seemed to grow more radiant every day on Cosette's sweet face.
모모The dawn that was smiling for all was gloomy for him.
모모Cosette had been beautiful for a tolerably long time before she became aware of it herself.
모모But, from the very first day, that unexpected light which was rising slowly and enveloping the whole of the young girl's person, wounded Jean Valjean's sombre eye. He felt that it was a change in a happy life, a life so happy that he did not dare to move for fear of disarranging something. This man, who had passed through all manner of distresses, who was still all bleeding from the bruises of fate, who had been almost wicked and who had become almost a saint, who, after having dragged the chain of the galleys, was now dragging the invisible but heavy chain of indefinite misery, this man whom the law had not released from its grasp and who could be seized at any moment and brought back from the obscurity of his virtue to the broad daylight of public opprobrium, this man accepted all, excused all, pardoned all, and merely asked of Providence, of man, of the law, of society, of nature, of the world, one thing, that Cosette might love him!
모모That Cosette might continue to love him!
모모That God would not prevent the heart of the child from coming to him, and from remaining with him! Beloved by Cosette, he felt that he was healed, rested, appeased, loaded with benefits, recompensed, crowned.
모모Beloved by Cosette, it was well with him!
모모He asked nothing more!
모모Had any one said to him:
모모"Do you want anything better?" he would have answered: "No." God might have said to him:
모모"Do you desire heaven?" and he would have replied:
모모"I should lose by it."
모모Everything which could affect this situation, if only on the surface, made him shudder like the beginning of something new.
모모He had never known very distinctly himself what the beauty of a woman means; but he understood instinctively, that it was something terrible.
모모He gazed with terror on this beauty, which was blossoming out ever more triumphant and superb beside him, beneath his very eyes, on the innocent and formidable brow of that child, from the depths of her homeliness, of his old age, of his misery, of his reprobation.
모모He said to himself:
모모"How beautiful she is!
모모What is to become of me?"
모모There, moreover, lay the difference between his tenderness and the tenderness of a mother.
모모What he beheld with anguish, a mother would have gazed upon with joy.
모모The first symptoms were not long in making their appearance.
모모On the very morrow of the day on which she had said to herself: "Decidedly I am beautiful!"
모모Cosette began to pay attention to her toilet.
모모She recalled the remark of that passer-by: "Pretty, but badly dressed," the breath of an oracle which had passed beside her and had vanished, after depositing in her heart one of the two germs which are destined, later on, to fill the whole life of woman, coquetry.
모모Love is the other.
모모With faith in her beauty, the whole feminine soul expanded within her. She conceived a horror for her merinos, and shame for her plush hat. Her father had never refused her anything.
모모She at once acquired the whole science of the bonnet, the gown, the mantle, the boot, the cuff, the stuff which is in fashion, the color which is becoming, that science which makes of the Parisian woman something so charming, so deep, and so dangerous.
모모The words heady woman were invented for the Parisienne.
모모In less than a month, little Cosette, in that Thebaid of the Rue de Babylone, was not only one of the prettiest, but one of the "best dressed" women in Paris, which means a great deal more.
모모She would have liked to encounter her "passer-by," to see what he would say, and to "teach him a lesson!"
모모The truth is, that she was ravishing in every respect, and that she distinguished the difference between a bonnet from Gerard and one from Herbaut in the most marvellous way.
모모Jean Valjean watched these ravages with anxiety.
모모He who felt that he could never do anything but crawl, walk at the most, beheld wings sprouting on Cosette.
모모Moreover, from the mere inspection of Cosette's toilet, a woman would have recognized the fact that she had no mother. Certain little proprieties, certain special conventionalities, were not observed by Cosette.
모모A mother, for instance, would have told her that a young girl does not dress in damask.
모모The first day that Cosette went out in her black damask gown and mantle, and her white crape bonnet, she took Jean Valjean's arm, gay, radiant, rosy, proud, dazzling.
모모"Father," she said, "how do you like me in this guise?"
모모Jean Valjean replied in a voice which resembled the bitter voice of an envious man:
모모"Charming!"
모모He was the same as usual during their walk.
모모On their return home, he asked Cosette:--
모모"Won't you put on that other gown and bonnet again,--you know the ones I mean?"
모모This took place in Cosette's chamber.
모모Cosette turned towards the wardrobe where her cast-off schoolgirl's clothes were hanging.
모모"That disguise!" said she.
모모"Father, what do you want me to do with it? Oh no, the idea!
모모I shall never put on those horrors again. With that machine on my head, I have the air of Madame Mad-dog."
모모Jean Valjean heaved a deep sigh.
모모From that moment forth, he noticed that Cosette, who had always heretofore asked to remain at home, saying:
모모"Father, I enjoy myself more here with you," now was always asking to go out.
모모In fact, what is the use of having a handsome face and a delicious costume if one does not display them?
모모He also noticed that Cosette had no longer the same taste for the back garden.
모모Now she preferred the garden, and did not dislike to promenade back and forth in front of the railed fence. Jean Valjean, who was shy, never set foot in the garden. He kept to his back yard, like a dog.
모모Cosette, in gaining the knowledge that she was beautiful, lost the grace of ignoring it.
모모An exquisite grace, for beauty enhanced by ingenuousness is ineffable, and nothing is so adorable as a dazzling and innocent creature who walks along, holding in her hand the key to paradise without being conscious of it.
모모But what she had lost in ingenuous grace, she gained in pensive and serious charm. Her whole person, permeated with the joy of youth, of innocence, and of beauty, breathed forth a splendid melancholy.
모모It was at this epoch that Marius, after the lapse of six months, saw her once more at the Luxembourg.


BOOK THIRD.--THE HOUSE IN THE RUE PLUMET
CHAPTER VI 
모모THE BATTLE BEGUN
모모 Cosette in her shadow, like Marius in his, was all ready to take fire. Destiny, with its mysterious and fatal patience, slowly drew together these two beings, all charged and all languishing with the stormy electricity of passion, these two souls which were laden with love as two clouds are laden with lightning, and which were bound to overflow and mingle in a look like the clouds in a flash of fire.
모모The glance has been so much abused in love romances that it has finally fallen into disrepute.
모모One hardly dares to say, nowadays, that two beings fell in love because they looked at each other. That is the way people do fall in love, nevertheless, and the only way.
모모The rest is nothing, but the rest comes afterwards. Nothing is more real than these great shocks which two souls convey to each other by the exchange of that spark.
모모At that particular hour when Cosette unconsciously darted that glance which troubled Marius, Marius had no suspicion that he had also launched a look which disturbed Cosette.
모모He caused her the same good and the same evil.
모모She had been in the habit of seeing him for a long time, and she had scrutinized him as girls scrutinize and see, while looking elsewhere. Marius still considered Cosette ugly, when she had already begun to think Marius handsome.
모모But as he paid no attention to her, the young man was nothing to her.
모모Still, she could not refrain from saying to herself that he had beautiful hair, beautiful eyes, handsome teeth, a charming tone of voice when she heard him conversing with his comrades, that he held himself badly when he walked, if you like, but with a grace that was all his own, that he did not appear to be at all stupid, that his whole person was noble, gentle, simple, proud, and that, in short, though he seemed to be poor, yet his air was fine.
모모On the day when their eyes met at last, and said to each other those first, obscure, and ineffable things which the glance lisps, Cosette did not immediately understand.
모모She returned thoughtfully to the house in the Rue de l'Ouest, where Jean Valjean, according to his custom, had come to spend six weeks.
모모The next morning, on waking, she thought of that strange young man, so long indifferent and icy, who now seemed to pay attention to her, and it did not appear to her that this attention was the least in the world agreeable to her. She was, on the contrary, somewhat incensed at this handsome and disdainful individual.
모모A substratum of war stirred within her. It struck her, and the idea caused her a wholly childish joy, that she was going to take her revenge at last.
모모Knowing that she was beautiful, she was thoroughly conscious, though in an indistinct fashion, that she possessed a weapon. Women play with their beauty as children do with a knife. They wound themselves.
모모The reader will recall Marius' hesitations, his palpitations, his terrors.
모모He remained on his bench and did not approach. This vexed Cosette.
모모One day, she said to Jean Valjean: "Father, let us stroll about a little in that direction." Seeing that Marius did not come to her, she went to him.
모모In such cases, all women resemble Mahomet.
모모And then, strange to say, the first symptom of true love in a young man is timidity; in a young girl it is boldness.
모모This is surprising, and yet nothing is more simple. It is the two sexes tending to approach each other and assuming, each the other's qualities.
모모That day, Cosette's glance drove Marius beside himself, and Marius' glance set Cosette to trembling.
모모Marius went away confident, and Cosette uneasy.
모모From that day forth, they adored each other.
모모The first thing that Cosette felt was a confused and profound melancholy. It seemed to her that her soul had become black since the day before. She no longer recognized it.
모모The whiteness of soul in young girls, which is composed of coldness and gayety, resembles snow.
모모It melts in love, which is its sun.
모모Cosette did not know what love was.
모모She had never heard the word uttered in its terrestrial sense.
모모On the books of profane music which entered the convent, amour (love) was replaced by tambour (drum) or pandour.
모모This created enigmas which exercised the imaginations of the big girls, such as:
모모Ah, how delightful is the drum! or, Pity is not a pandour.
모모But Cosette had left the convent too early to have occupied herself much with the "drum."
모모Therefore, she did not know what name to give to what she now felt.
모모Is any one the less ill because one does not know the name of one's malady?
모모She loved with all the more passion because she loved ignorantly. She did not know whether it was a good thing or a bad thing, useful or dangerous, eternal or temporary, allowable or prohibited; she loved.
모모She would have been greatly astonished, had any one said to her:
모모"You do not sleep?
모모But that is forbidden! You do not eat?
모모Why, that is very bad!
모모You have oppressions and palpitations of the heart?
모모That must not be!
모모You blush and turn pale, when a certain being clad in black appears at the end of a certain green walk?
모모But that is abominable!" She would not have understood, and she would have replied: "What fault is there of mine in a matter in which I have no power and of which I know nothing?"
모모It turned out that the love which presented itself was exactly suited to the state of her soul.
모모It was a sort of admiration at a distance, a mute contemplation, the deification of a stranger. It was the apparition of youth to youth, the dream of nights become a reality yet remaining a dream, the longed-for phantom realized and made flesh at last, but having as yet, neither name, nor fault, nor spot, nor exigence, nor defect; in a word, the distant lover who lingered in the ideal, a chimaera with a form. Any nearer and more palpable meeting would have alarmed Cosette at this first stage, when she was still half immersed in the exaggerated mists of the cloister.
모모She had all the fears of children and all the fears of nuns combined.
모모The spirit of the convent, with which she had been permeated for the space of five years, was still in the process of slow evaporation from her person, and made everything tremble around her.
모모In this situation he was not a lover, he was not even an admirer, he was a vision. She set herself to adoring Marius as something charming, luminous, and impossible.
모모As extreme innocence borders on extreme coquetry, she smiled at him with all frankness.
모모Every day, she looked forward to the hour for their walk with impatience, she found Marius there, she felt herself unspeakably happy, and thought in all sincerity that she was expressing her whole thought when she said to Jean Valjean:--
모모"What a delicious garden that Luxembourg is!"
모모Marius and Cosette were in the dark as to one another.
모모They did not address each other, they did not salute each other, they did not know each other; they saw each other; and like stars of heaven which are separated by millions of leagues, they lived by gazing at each other.
모모It was thus that Cosette gradually became a woman and developed, beautiful and loving, with a consciousness of her beauty, and in ignorance of her love.
모모She was a coquette to boot through her ignorance.


BOOK THIRD.--THE HOUSE IN THE RUE PLUMET
CHAPTER VII 
모모TO ONE SADNESS OPPOSE A SADNESS AND A HALF
모모 All situations have their instincts.
모모Old and eternal Mother Nature warned Jean Valjean in a dim way of the presence of Marius. Jean Valjean shuddered to the very bottom of his soul.
모모Jean Valjean saw nothing, knew nothing, and yet he scanned with obstinate attention, the darkness in which he walked, as though he felt on one side of him something in process of construction, and on the other, something which was crumbling away.
모모Marius, also warned, and, in accordance with the deep law of God, by that same Mother Nature, did all he could to keep out of sight of "the father."
모모Nevertheless, it came to pass that Jean Valjean sometimes espied him.
모모Marius' manners were no longer in the least natural.
모모He exhibited ambiguous prudence and awkward daring.
모모He no longer came quite close to them as formerly. He seated himself at a distance and pretended to be reading; why did he pretend that?
모모Formerly he had come in his old coat, now he wore his new one every day; Jean Valjean was not sure that he did not have his hair curled, his eyes were very queer, he wore gloves; in short, Jean Valjean cordially detested this young man.
모모Cosette allowed nothing to be divined.
모모Without knowing just what was the matter with her she was convinced that there was something in it, and that it must be concealed.
모모There was a coincidence between the taste for the toilet which had recently come to Cosette, and the habit of new clothes developed by that stranger which was very repugnant to Jean Valjean.
모모It might be accidental, no doubt, certainly, but it was a menacing accident.
모모He never opened his mouth to Cosette about this stranger.
모모One day, however, he could not refrain from so doing, and, with that vague despair which suddenly casts the lead into the depths of its despair, he said to her:
모모"What a very pedantic air that young man has!"
모모Cosette, but a year before only an indifferent little girl, would have replied:
모모"Why, no, he is charming."
모모Ten years later, with the love of Marius in her heart, she would have answered: "A pedant, and insufferable to the sight!
모모You are right!"-- At the moment in life and the heart which she had then attained, she contented herself with replying, with supreme calmness: "That young man!"
모모As though she now beheld him for the first time in her life.
모모"How stupid I am!" thought Jean Valjean.
모모"She had not noticed him. It is I who have pointed him out to her."
모모Oh, simplicity of the old! oh, the depth of children!
모모It is one of the laws of those fresh years of suffering and trouble, of those vivacious conflicts between a first love and the first obstacles, that the young girl does not allow herself to be caught in any trap whatever, and that the young man falls into every one. Jean Valjean had instituted an undeclared war against Marius, which Marius, with the sublime stupidity of his passion and his age, did not divine.
모모Jean Valjean laid a host of ambushes for him; he changed his hour, he changed his bench, he forgot his handkerchief, he came alone to the Luxembourg; Marius dashed headlong into all these snares; and to all the interrogation marks planted by Jean Valjean in his pathway, he ingenuously answered "yes." But Cosette remained immured in her apparent unconcern and in her imperturbable tranquillity, so that Jean Valjean arrived at the following conclusion:
모모"That ninny is madly in love with Cosette, but Cosette does not even know that he exists."
모모None the less did he bear in his heart a mournful tremor. The minute when Cosette would love might strike at any moment. Does not everything begin with indifference?
모모Only once did Cosette make a mistake and alarm him.
모모He rose from his seat to depart, after a stay of three hours, and she said: "What, already?"
모모Jean Valjean had not discontinued his trips to the Luxembourg, as he did not wish to do anything out of the way, and as, above all things, he feared to arouse Cosette; but during the hours which were so sweet to the lovers, while Cosette was sending her smile to the intoxicated Marius, who perceived nothing else now, and who now saw nothing in all the world but an adored and radiant face, Jean Valjean was fixing on Marius flashing and terrible eyes.
모모He, who had finally come to believe himself incapable of a malevolent feeling, experienced moments when Marius was present, in which he thought he was becoming savage and ferocious once more, and he felt the old depths of his soul, which had formerly contained so much wrath, opening once more and rising up against that young man.
모모It almost seemed to him that unknown craters were forming in his bosom.
모모What! he was there, that creature!
모모What was he there for? He came creeping about, smelling out, examining, trying! He came, saying:
모모"Hey!
모모Why not?"
모모He came to prowl about his, Jean Valjean's, life! to prowl about his happiness, with the purpose of seizing it and bearing it away!
모모Jean Valjean added:
모모"Yes, that's it!
모모What is he in search of? An adventure!
모모What does he want?
모모A love affair!
모모A love affair! And I?
모모What!
모모I have been first, the most wretched of men, and then the most unhappy, and I have traversed sixty years of life on my knees, I have suffered everything that man can suffer, I have grown old without having been young, I have lived without a family, without relatives, without friends, without life, without children, I have left my blood on every stone, on every bramble, on every mile-post, along every wall, I have been gentle, though others have been hard to me, and kind, although others have been malicious, I have become an honest man once more, in spite of everything, I have repented of the evil that I have done and have forgiven the evil that has been done to me, and at the moment when I receive my recompense, at the moment when it is all over, at the moment when I am just touching the goal, at the moment when I have what I desire, it is well, it is good, I have paid, I have earned it, all this is to take flight, all this will vanish, and I shall lose Cosette, and I shall lose my life, my joy, my soul, because it has pleased a great booby to come and lounge at the Luxembourg."
모모Then his eyes were filled with a sad and extraordinary gleam.
모모It was no longer a man gazing at a man; it was no longer an enemy surveying an enemy.
모모It was a dog scanning a thief.
모모The reader knows the rest.
모모Marius pursued his senseless course. One day he followed Cosette to the Rue de l'Ouest. Another day he spoke to the porter.
모모The porter, on his side, spoke, and said to Jean Valjean:
모모"Monsieur, who is that curious young man who is asking for you?"
모모On the morrow Jean Valjean bestowed on Marius that glance which Marius at last perceived.
모모A week later, Jean Valjean had taken his departure.
모모He swore to himself that he would never again set foot either in the Luxembourg or in the Rue de l'Ouest. He returned to the Rue Plumet.
모모Cosette did not complain, she said nothing, she asked no questions, she did not seek to learn his reasons; she had already reached the point where she was afraid of being divined, and of betraying herself. Jean Valjean had no experience of these miseries, the only miseries which are charming and the only ones with which he was not acquainted; the consequence was that he did not understand the grave significance of Cosette's silence.
모모He merely noticed that she had grown sad, and he grew gloomy. On his side and on hers, inexperience had joined issue.
모모Once he made a trial.
모모He asked Cosette:--
모모"Would you like to come to the Luxembourg?"
모모A ray illuminated Cosette's pale face.
모모"Yes," said she.
모모They went thither.
모모Three months had elapsed.
모모Marius no longer went there.
모모Marius was not there.
모모On the following day, Jean Valjean asked Cosette again:--
모모"Would you like to come to the Luxembourg?"
모모She replied, sadly and gently:--
모모"No."
모모Jean Valjean was hurt by this sadness, and heart-broken at this gentleness.
모모What was going on in that mind which was so young and yet already so impenetrable?
모모What was on its way there within?
모모What was taking place in Cosette's soul?
모모Sometimes, instead of going to bed, Jean Valjean remained seated on his pallet, with his head in his hands, and he passed whole nights asking himself:
모모"What has Cosette in her mind?" and in thinking of the things that she might be thinking about.
모모Oh! at such moments, what mournful glances did he cast towards that cloister, that chaste peak, that abode of angels, that inaccessible glacier of virtue!
모모How he contemplated, with despairing ecstasy, that convent garden, full of ignored flowers and cloistered virgins, where all perfumes and all souls mount straight to heaven! How he adored that Eden forever closed against him, whence he had voluntarily and madly emerged!
모모How he regretted his abnegation and his folly in having brought Cosette back into the world, poor hero of sacrifice, seized and hurled to the earth by his very self-devotion! How he said to himself, "What have I done?"
모모However, nothing of all this was perceptible to Cosette. No ill-temper, no harshness.
모모His face was always serene and kind. Jean Valjean's manners were more tender and more paternal than ever. If anything could have betrayed his lack of joy, it was his increased suavity.
모모On her side, Cosette languished.
모모She suffered from the absence of Marius as she had rejoiced in his presence, peculiarly, without exactly being conscious of it.
모모When Jean Valjean ceased to take her on their customary strolls, a feminine instinct murmured confusedly, at the bottom of her heart, that she must not seem to set store on the Luxembourg garden, and that if this proved to be a matter of indifference to her, her father would take her thither once more. But days, weeks, months, elapsed.
모모Jean Valjean had tacitly accepted Cosette's tacit consent.
모모She regretted it.
모모It was too late. So Marius had disappeared; all was over.
모모The day on which she returned to the Luxembourg, Marius was no longer there.
모모What was to be done? Should she ever find him again?
모모She felt an anguish at her heart, which nothing relieved, and which augmented every day; she no longer knew whether it was winter or summer, whether it was raining or shining, whether the birds were singing, whether it was the season for dahlias or daisies, whether the Luxembourg was more charming than the Tuileries, whether the linen which the laundress brought home was starched too much or not enough, whether Toussaint had
모모done "her marketing" well or ill; and she remained dejected, absorbed, attentive to but a single thought, her eyes vague and staring as when one gazes by night at a black and fathomless spot where an apparition has vanished.
모모However, she did not allow Jean Valjean to perceive anything of this, except her pallor.
모모She still wore her sweet face for him.
모모This pallor sufficed but too thoroughly to trouble Jean Valjean. Sometimes he asked her:--
모모"What is the matter with you?"
모모She replied:
모모"There is nothing the matter with me."
모모And after a silence, when she divined that he was sad also, she would add:--
모모"And you, father--is there anything wrong with you?"
모모"With me?
모모Nothing," said he.
모모These two beings who had loved each other so exclusively, and with so touching an affection, and who had lived so long for each other now suffered side by side, each on the other's account; without acknowledging it to each other, without anger towards each other, and with a smile.


BOOK THIRD.--THE HOUSE IN THE RUE PLUMET
CHAPTER VIII 
모모THE CHAIN-GANG
모모 Jean Valjean was the more unhappy of the two.
모모Youth, even in its sorrows, always possesses its own peculiar radiance.
모모At times, Jean Valjean suffered so greatly that he became puerile. It is the property of grief to cause the childish side of man to reappear.
모모He had an unconquerable conviction that Cosette was escaping from him.
모모He would have liked to resist, to retain her, to arouse her enthusiasm by some external and brilliant matter. These ideas, puerile, as we have just said, and at the same time senile, conveyed to him, by their very childishness, a tolerably just notion of the influence of gold lace on the imaginations of young girls. He once chanced to see a general on horseback, in full uniform, pass along the street, Comte Coutard, the commandant of Paris. He envied that gilded man; what happiness it would be, he said to himself, if he could put on that suit which was an incontestable thing; and if Cosette could behold him thus, she would be dazzled, and when he had Cosette on his arm and passed the gates of the Tuileries, the guard would present arms to him, and that would suffice for Cosette, and would dispel her idea of looking at young men.
모모An unforeseen shock was added to these sad reflections.
모모In the isolated life which they led, and since they had come to dwell in the Rue Plumet, they had contracted one habit. They sometimes took a pleasure trip to see the sun rise, a mild species of enjoyment which befits those who are entering life and those who are quitting it.
모모For those who love solitude, a walk in the early morning is equivalent to a stroll by night, with the cheerfulness of nature added. The streets are deserted and the birds are singing.
모모Cosette, a bird herself, liked to rise early.
모모These matutinal excursions were planned on the preceding evening.
모모He proposed, and she agreed. It was arranged like a plot, they set out before daybreak, and these trips were so many small delights for Cosette. These innocent eccentricities please young people.
모모Jean Valjean's inclination led him, as we have seen, to the least frequented spots, to solitary nooks, to forgotten places. There then existed, in the vicinity of the barriers of Paris, a sort of poor meadows, which were almost confounded with the city, where grew in summer sickly grain, and which, in autumn, after the harvest had been gathered, presented the appearance, not of having been reaped, but peeled.
모모Jean Valjean loved to haunt these fields.
모모Cosette was not bored there.
모모It meant solitude to him and liberty to her.
모모There, she became a little girl once more, she could run and almost play; she took off her hat, laid it on Jean Valjean's knees, and gathered bunches of flowers. She gazed at the butterflies on the flowers, but did not catch them; gentleness and tenderness are born with love, and the young girl who cherishes within her breast a trembling and fragile ideal has mercy on the wing of a butterfly.
모모She wove garlands of poppies, which she placed on her head, and which, crossed and penetrated with sunlight, glowing until they flamed, formed for her rosy face a crown of burning embers.
모모Even after their life had grown sad, they kept up their custom of early strolls.
모모One morning in October, therefore, tempted by the serene perfection of the autumn of 1831, they set out, and found themselves at break of day near the Barriere du Maine.
모모It was not dawn, it was daybreak; a delightful and stern moment.
모모A few constellations here and there in the deep, pale azure, the earth all black, the heavens all white, a quiver amid the blades of grass, everywhere the mysterious chill of twilight.
모모A lark, which seemed mingled with the stars, was carolling at a prodigious height, and one would have declared that that hymn of pettiness calmed immensity.
모모In the East, the Valde-Grace projected its dark mass on the clear horizon with the sharpness of steel; Venus dazzlingly brilliant was rising behind that dome and had the air of a soul making its escape from a gloomy edifice.
모모All was peace and silence; there was no one on the road; a few stray laborers, of whom they caught barely a glimpse, were on their way to their work along the side-paths.
모모Jean Valjean was sitting in a cross-walk on some planks deposited at the gate of a timber-yard. His face was turned towards the highway, his back towards the light; he had forgotten the sun which was on the point of rising; he had sunk into one of those profound absorptions in which the mind becomes concentrated, which imprison even the eye, and which are equivalent to four walls.
모모There are meditations which may be called vertical; when one is at the bottom of them, time is required to return to earth.
모모Jean Valjean had plunged into one of these reveries.
모모He was thinking of Cosette, of the happiness that was possible if nothing came between him and her, of the light with which she filled his life, a light which was but the emanation of her soul.
모모He was almost happy in his revery.
모모Cosette, who was standing beside him, was gazing at the clouds as they turned rosy.
모모All at once Cosette exclaimed:
모모"Father, I should think some one was coming yonder."
모모Jean Valjean raised his eyes.
모모Cosette was right.
모모The causeway which leads to the ancient Barriere du Maine is a prolongation, as the reader knows, of the Rue de Sevres, and is cut at right angles by the inner boulevard. At the elbow of the causeway and the boulevard, at the spot where it branches, they heard a noise which it was difficult to account for at that hour, and a sort of confused pile made its appearance. Some shapeless thing which was coming from the boulevard was turning into the road.
모모It grew larger, it seemed to move in an orderly manner, though it was bristling and quivering; it seemed to be a vehicle, but its load could not be distinctly made out.
모모There were horses, wheels, shouts; whips were cracking.
모모By degrees the outlines became fixed, although bathed in shadows.
모모It was a vehicle, in fact, which had just turned from the boulevard into the highway, and which was directing its course towards the barrier near which sat Jean Valjean; a second, of the same aspect, followed, then a third, then a fourth; seven chariots made their appearance in succession, the heads of the horses touching the rear of the wagon in front. Figures were moving on these vehicles, flashes were visible through the dusk as though there were naked swords there, a clanking became audible which resembled the rattling of chains, and as this something advanced, the sound of voices waxed louder, and it turned into a terrible thing such as emerges from the cave of dreams.
모모As it drew nearer, it assumed a form, and was outlined behind the trees with the pallid hue of an apparition; the mass grew white; the day, which was slowly dawning, cast a wan light on this swarming heap which was at once both sepulchral and living, the heads of the figures turned into the faces of corpses, and this is what it proved to be:--
모모Seven wagons were driving in a file along the road.
모모The first six were singularly constructed.
모모They resembled coopers' drays; they consisted of long ladders placed on two wheels and forming barrows at their rear extremities.
모모Each dray, or rather let us say, each ladder, was attached to four horses harnessed tandem. On these ladders strange clusters of men were being drawn. In the faint light, these men were to be divined rather than seen. Twenty-four on each vehicle, twelve on a side, back to back, facing the passers-by, their legs dangling in the air,--this was the manner in which these men were travelling, and behind their backs they had something which clanked, and which was a chain, and on their necks something which shone, and which was an iron collar. Each man had his collar, but the chain was for all; so that if these four and twenty men had occasion to alight from the dray and walk, they were seized with a sort of inexorable unity, and were obliged to wind over the ground with the chain for a backbone, somewhat after the fashion of millepeds.
모모In the back and front of each vehicle, two men armed with muskets stood erect, each holding one end of the chain under his foot.
모모The iron necklets were square. The seventh vehicle, a huge rack-sided baggage wagon, without a hood, had four wheels and six horses, and carried a sonorous pile of iron boilers, cast-iron pots, braziers, and chains, among which were mingled several men who were pinioned and stretched at full length, and who seemed to be ill.
모모This wagon, all lattice-work, was garnished with dilapidated hurdles which appeared to have served for former punishments.
모모These vehicles kept to the middle of the road. On each side marched a double hedge of guards of infamous aspect, wearing three-cornered hats, like the soldiers under the Directory, shabby, covered with spots and holes, muffled in uniforms of veterans and the trousers of undertakers' men, half gray, half blue, which were almost hanging in rags, with red epaulets, yellow shoulder belts, short sabres, muskets, and cudgels; they were a species of soldier-blackguards. These myrmidons seemed composed of the abjectness of the beggar and the authority of the executioner. The one who appeared to be their chief held a postilion's whip in his hand.
모모All these details, blurred by the dimness of dawn, became more and more clearly outlined as the light increased. At the head and in the rear of the convoy rode mounted gendarmes, serious and with sword in fist.
모모This procession was so long that when the first vehicle reached the barrier, the last was barely debauching from the boulevard. A throng, sprung, it is impossible to say whence, and formed in a twinkling, as is frequently the case in Paris, pressed forward from both sides of the road and looked on.
모모In the neighboring lanes the shouts of people calling to each other and the wooden shoes of market-gardeners hastening up to gaze were audible.
모모The men massed upon the drays allowed themselves to be jolted along in silence.
모모They were livid with the chill of morning. They all wore linen trousers, and their bare feet were thrust into wooden shoes.
모모The rest of their costume was a fantasy of wretchedness. Their accoutrements were horribly incongruous; nothing is more funereal than the harlequin in rags.
모모Battered felt hats, tarpaulin caps, hideous woollen nightcaps, and, side by side with a short blouse, a black coat broken at the elbow; many wore women's headgear, others had baskets on their heads; hairy breasts were visible, and through the rent in their garments tattooed designs could be descried; temples of Love, flaming hearts, Cupids; eruptions and unhealthy red blotches could also be seen.
모모Two or three had a straw rope attached to the cross-bar of the dray, and suspended under them like a stirrup, which supported their feet.
모모One of them held in his hand and raised to his mouth something which had the appearance of a black stone and which he seemed to be gnawing; it was bread which he was eating. There were no eyes there which were not either dry, dulled, or flaming with an evil light.
모모The escort troop cursed, the men in chains did not utter a syllable; from time to time the sound of a blow became audible as the cudgels descended on shoulder-blades or skulls; some of these men were yawning; their rags were terrible; their feet hung down, their shoulders oscillated, their heads clashed together, their fetters clanked, their eyes glared ferociously, their fists clenched or fell open inertly like the hands of corpses; in the rear of the convoy ran a band of children screaming with laughter.
모모This file of vehicles, whatever its nature was, was mournful. It was evident that to-morrow, that an hour hence, a pouring rain might descend, that it might be followed by another and another, and that their dilapidated garments would be drenched, that once soaked, these men would not get dry again, that once chilled, they would not again get warm, that their linen trousers would be glued to their bones by the downpour, that the water would fill their shoes, that no lashes from the whips would be able to prevent their jaws from chattering, that the chain would continue to bind them by the neck, that their legs would continue to dangle, and it was impossible not to shudder at the sight of these human beings thus bound and passive beneath the cold clouds of autumn, and delivered over to the rain, to the blast, to all the furies of the air, like trees and stones.
모모Blows from the cudgel were not omitted even in the case of the sick men, who lay there knotted with ropes and motionless on the seventh wagon, and who appeared to have been tossed there like sacks filled with misery.
모모Suddenly, the sun made its appearance; the immense light of the Orient burst forth, and one would have said that it had set fire to all those ferocious heads.
모모Their tongues were unloosed; a conflagration of grins, oaths, and songs exploded.
모모The broad horizontal sheet of light severed the file in two parts, illuminating heads and bodies, leaving feet and wheels in the obscurity.
모모Thoughts made their appearance on these faces; it was a terrible moment; visible demons with their masks removed, fierce souls laid bare.
모모Though lighted up, this wild throng remained in gloom.
모모Some, who were gay, had in their mouths quills through which they blew vermin over the crowd, picking out the women; the dawn accentuated these lamentable profiles with the blackness of its shadows; there was not one of these creatures who was not deformed by reason of wretchedness; and the whole was so monstrous that one would have said that the sun's brilliancy had been changed into the glare of the lightning. The wagon-load which headed the line had struck up a song, and were shouting at the top of their voices with a haggard joviality, a potpourri by Desaugiers, then famous, called The Vestal; the trees shivered mournfully; in the cross-lanes, countenances of bourgeois listened in an idiotic delight to these coarse strains droned by spectres.
모모All sorts of distress met in this procession as in chaos; here were to be found the facial angles of every sort of beast, old men, youths, bald heads, gray beards, cynical monstrosities, sour resignation, savage grins, senseless attitudes, snouts surmounted by caps, heads like those of young girls with corkscrew curls on the temples, infantile visages, and by reason of that, horrible thin skeleton faces, to which death alone was lacking.
모모On the first cart was a negro, who had been a slave, in all probability, and who could make a comparison of his chains.
모모The frightful leveller from below, shame, had passed over these brows; at that degree of abasement, the last transformations were suffered by all in their extremest depths, and ignorance, converted into dulness, was the equal of intelligence converted into despair.
모모There was no choice possible between these men who appeared to the eye as the flower of the mud. It was evident that the person who had had the ordering of that unclean procession had not classified them.
모모These beings had been fettered and coupled pell-mell, in alphabetical disorder, probably, and loaded hap-hazard on those carts.
모모Nevertheless, horrors, when grouped together, always end by evolving a result; all additions of wretched men give a sum total, each chain exhaled a common soul, and each dray-load had its own physiognomy.
모모By the side of the one where they were singing, there was one where they were howling; a third where they were begging; one could be seen in which they were gnashing their teeth; another load menaced the spectators, another blasphemed God; the last was as silent as the tomb. Dante would have thought that he beheld his seven circles of hell on the march.
모모The march of the damned to their tortures, performed in sinister wise, not on the formidable and flaming chariot of the Apocalypse, but, what was more mournful than that, on the gibbet cart.
모모One of the guards, who had a hook on the end of his cudgel, made a pretence from time to time, of stirring up this mass of human filth. An old woman in the crowd pointed them out to her little boy five years old, and said to him:
모모"Rascal, let that be a warning to you!"
모모As the songs and blasphemies increased, the man who appeared to be the captain of the escort cracked his whip, and at that signal a fearful dull and blind flogging, which produced the sound of hail, fell upon the seven dray-loads; many roared and foamed at the mouth; which redoubled the delight of the street urchins who had hastened up, a swarm of flies on these wounds.
모모Jean Valjean's eyes had assumed a frightful expression. They were no longer eyes; they were those deep and glassy objects which replace the glance in the case of certain wretched men, which seem unconscious of reality, and in which flames the reflection of terrors and of catastrophes.
모모He was not looking at a spectacle, he was seeing a vision.
모모He tried to rise, to flee, to make his escape; he could not move his feet.
모모Sometimes, the things that you see seize upon you and hold you fast.
모모He remained nailed to the spot, petrified, stupid, asking himself, athwart confused and inexpressible anguish, what this sepulchral persecution signified, and whence had come that pandemonium which was pursuing him. All at once, he raised his hand to his brow, a gesture habitual to those whose memory suddenly returns; he remembered that this was, in fact, the usual itinerary, that it was customary to make this detour in order to avoid all possibility of encountering royalty on the road to Fontainebleau, and that, five and thirty years before, he had himself passed through that barrier.
모모Cosette was no less terrified, but in a different way.
모모She did not understand; what she beheld did not seem to her to be possible; at length she cried:--
모모"Father!
모모What are those men in those carts?"
모모Jean Valjean replied:
모모"Convicts."
모모"Whither are they going?"
모모"To the galleys."
모모At that moment, the cudgelling, multiplied by a hundred hands, became zealous, blows with the flat of the sword were mingled with it, it was a perfect storm of whips and clubs; the convicts bent before it, a hideous obedience was evoked by the torture, and all held their peace, darting glances like chained wolves.
모모Cosette trembled in every limb; she resumed:--
모모"Father, are they still men?"
모모"Sometimes," answered the unhappy man.
모모It was the chain-gang, in fact, which had set out before daybreak from Bicetre, and had taken the road to Mans in order to avoid Fontainebleau, where the King then was.
모모This caused the horrible journey to last three or four days longer; but torture may surely be prolonged with the object of sparing the royal personage a sight of it.
모모Jean Valjean returned home utterly overwhelmed.
모모Such encounters are shocks, and the memory that they leave behind them resembles a thorough shaking up.
모모Nevertheless, Jean Valjean did not observe that, on his way back to the Rue de Babylone with Cosette, the latter was plying him with other questions on the subject of what they had just seen; perhaps he was too much absorbed in his own dejection to notice her words and reply to them.
모모But when Cosette was leaving him in the evening, to betake herself to bed, he heard her say in a low voice, and as though talking to herself:
모모"It seems to me, that if I were to find one of those men in my pathway, oh, my God, I should die merely from the sight of him close at hand."
모모Fortunately, chance ordained that on the morrow of that tragic day, there was some official solemnity apropos of I know not what,-- fetes in Paris, a review in the Champ de Mars, jousts on the Seine, theatrical performances in the Champs-Elysees, fireworks at the Arc de l'Etoile, illuminations everywhere.
모모Jean Valjean did violence to his habits, and took Cosette to see these rejoicings, for the purpose of diverting her from the memory of the day before, and of effacing, beneath the smiling tumult of all Paris, the abominable thing which had passed before her.
모모The review with which the festival was spiced made the presence of uniforms perfectly natural; Jean Valjean donned his uniform of a national guard with the vague inward feeling of a man who is betaking himself to shelter.
모모However, this trip seemed to attain its object. Cosette, who made it her law to please her father, and to whom, moreover, all spectacles were a novelty, accepted this diversion with the light and easy good grace of youth, and did not pout too disdainfully at that flutter of enjoyment called a public fete; so that Jean Valjean was able to believe that he had succeeded, and that no trace of that hideous vision remained.
모모Some days later, one morning, when the sun was shining brightly, and they were both on the steps leading to the garden, another infraction of the rules which Jean Valjean seemed to have imposed upon himself, and to the custom of remaining in her chamber which melancholy had caused Cosette to adopt, Cosette, in a wrapper, was standing erect in that negligent attire of early morning which envelops young girls in an adorable way and which produces the effect of a cloud drawn over a star; and, with her head bathed in light, rosy after a good sleep, submitting to the gentle glances of the tender old man, she was picking a daisy to pieces.
모모Cosette did not know the delightful legend, I love a little, passionately, etc.--who was there who could have taught her?
모모She was handling the flower instinctively, innocently, without a suspicion that to pluck a daisy apart is to do the same by a heart.
모모If there were a fourth, and smiling Grace called Melancholy, she would have worn the air of that Grace. Jean Valjean was fascinated by the contemplation of those tiny fingers on that flower, and forgetful of everything in the radiance emitted by that child.
모모A red-breast was warbling in the thicket, on one side.
모모White cloudlets floated across the sky, so gayly, that one would have said that they had just been set at liberty. Cosette went on attentively tearing the leaves from her flower; she seemed to be thinking about something; but whatever it was, it must be something charming; all at once she turned her head over her shoulder with the delicate languor of a swan, and said to Jean Valjean:
모모"Father, what are the galleys like?"


BOOK FOURTH.--SUCCOR FROM BELOW MAY TURN OUT TO BE SUCCOR FROM ON HIGH
CHAPTER I 
모모A WOUND WITHOUT, HEALING WITHIN
모모Thus their life clouded over by degrees.
모모But one diversion, which had formerly been a happiness, remained to them, which was to carry bread to those who were hungry, and clothing to those who were cold.
모모Cosette often accompanied Jean Valjean on these visits to the poor, on which they recovered some remnants of their former free intercourse; and sometimes, when the day had been a good one, and they had assisted many in distress, and cheered and warmed many little children, Cosette was rather merry in the evening. It was at this epoch that they paid their visit to the Jondrette den.
모모On the day following that visit, Jean Valjean made his appearance in the pavilion in the morning, calm as was his wont, but with a large wound on his left arm which was much inflamed, and very angry, which resembled a burn, and which he explained in some way or other. This wound resulted in his being detained in the house for a month with fever.
모모He would not call in a doctor.
모모When Cosette urged him, "Call the dog-doctor," said he.
모모Cosette dressed the wound morning and evening with so divine an air and such angelic happiness at being of use to him, that Jean Valjean felt all his former joy returning, his fears and anxieties dissipating, and he gazed at Cosette, saying:
모모"Oh! what a kindly wound! Oh! what a good misfortune!"
모모Cosette on perceiving that her father was ill, had deserted the pavilion and again taken a fancy to the little lodging and the back courtyard. She passed nearly all her days beside Jean Valjean and read to him the books which he desired.
모모Generally they were books of travel. Jean Valjean was undergoing a new birth; his happiness was reviving in these ineffable rays; the Luxembourg, the prowling young stranger, Cosette's coldness,--all these clouds upon his soul were growing dim. He had reached the point where he said to himself:
모모"I imagined all that. I am an old fool."
모모His happiness was so great that the horrible discovery of the Thenardiers made in the Jondrette hovel, unexpected as it was, had, after a fashion, glided over him unnoticed.
모모He had succeeded in making his escape; all trace of him was lost--what more did he care for! he only thought of those wretched beings to pity them.
모모"Here they are in prison, and henceforth they will be incapacitated for doing any harm," he thought, "but what a lamentable family in distress!"
모모As for the hideous vision of the Barriere du Maine, Cosette had not referred to it again.
모모Sister Sainte-Mechtilde had taught Cosette music in the convent; Cosette had the voice of a linnet with a soul, and sometimes, in the evening, in the wounded man's humble abode, she warbled melancholy songs which delighted Jean Valjean.
모모Spring came; the garden was so delightful at that season of the year, that Jean Valjean said to Cosette:--
모모"You never go there; I want you to stroll in it."
모모"As you like, father," said Cosette.
모모And for the sake of obeying her father, she resumed her walks in the garden, generally alone, for, as we have mentioned, Jean Valjean, who was probably afraid of being seen through the fence, hardly ever went there.
모모Jean Valjean's wound had created a diversion.
모모When Cosette saw that her father was suffering less, that he was convalescing, and that he appeared to be happy, she experienced a contentment which she did not even perceive, so gently and naturally had it come.
모모Then, it was in the month of March, the days were growing longer, the winter was departing, the winter always bears away with it a portion of our sadness; then came April, that daybreak of summer, fresh as dawn always is, gay like every childhood; a little inclined to weep at times like the new-born being that it is. In that month, nature has charming gleams which pass from the sky, from the trees, from the meadows and the flowers into the heart of man.
모모Cosette was still too young to escape the penetrating influence of that April joy which bore so strong a resemblance to herself. Insensibly, and without her suspecting the fact, the blackness departed from her spirit.
모모In spring, sad souls grow light, as light falls into cellars at midday.
모모Cosette was no longer sad. However, though this was so, she did not account for it to herself. In the morning, about ten o'clock, after breakfast, when she had succeeded in enticing her father into the garden for a quarter of an hour, and when she was pacing up and down in the sunlight in front of the steps, supporting his left arm for him, she did not perceive that she laughed every moment and that she was happy.
모모Jean Valjean, intoxicated, beheld her growing fresh and rosy once more.
모모"Oh!
모모What a good wound!" he repeated in a whisper.
모모And he felt grateful to the Thenardiers.
모모His wound once healed, he resumed his solitary twilight strolls.
모모It is a mistake to suppose that a person can stroll alone in that fashion in the uninhabited regions of Paris without meeting with some adventure.


BOOK FOURTH.--SUCCOR FROM BELOW MAY TURN OUT TO BE SUCCOR FROM ON HIGH
CHAPTER II 
모모MOTHER PLUTARQUE FINDS NO DIFFICULTY IN EXPLAINING A PHENOMENON
모모 One evening, little Gavroche had had nothing to eat; he remembered that he had not dined on the preceding day either; this was becoming tiresome.
모모He resolved to make an effort to secure some supper. He strolled out beyond the Salpetriere into deserted regions; that is where windfalls are to be found; where there is no one, one always finds something.
모모He reached a settlement which appeared to him to be the village of Austerlitz.
모모In one of his preceding lounges he had noticed there an old garden haunted by an old man and an old woman, and in that garden, a passable apple-tree. Beside the apple-tree stood a sort of fruit-house, which was not securely fastened, and where one might contrive to get an apple.
모모One apple is a supper; one apple is life.
모모That which was Adam's ruin might prove Gavroche's salvation.
모모The garden abutted on a solitary, unpaved lane, bordered with brushwood while awaiting the arrival of houses; the garden was separated from it by a hedge.
모모Gavroche directed his steps towards this garden; he found the lane, he recognized the apple-tree, he verified the fruit-house, he examined the hedge; a hedge means merely one stride.
모모The day was declining, there was not even a cat in the lane, the hour was propitious. Gavroche began the operation of scaling the hedge, then suddenly paused. Some one was talking in the garden.
모모Gavroche peeped through one of the breaks in the hedge.
모모A couple of paces distant, at the foot of the hedge on the other side, exactly at the point where the gap which he was meditating would have been made, there was a sort of recumbent stone which formed a bench, and on this bench was seated the old man of the garden, while the old woman was standing in front of him.
모모The old woman was grumbling.
모모Gavroche, who was not very discreet, listened.
모모"Monsieur Mabeuf!" said the old woman.
모모"Mabeuf!" thought Gavroche, "that name is a perfect farce."
모모The old man who was thus addressed, did not stir.
모모The old woman repeated:--
모모"Monsieur Mabeuf!"
모모The old man, without raising his eyes from the ground, made up his mind to answer:--
모모"What is it, Mother Plutarque?"
모모"Mother Plutarque!" thought Gavroche, "another farcical name."
모모Mother Plutarque began again, and the old man was forced to accept the conversation:--
모모"The landlord is not pleased."
모모"Why?"
모모"We owe three quarters rent."
모모"In three months, we shall owe him for four quarters."
모모"He says that he will turn you out to sleep."
모모"I will go."
모모"The green-grocer insists on being paid.
모모She will no longer leave her fagots.
모모What will you warm yourself with this winter? We shall have no wood."
모모"There is the sun."
모모"The butcher refuses to give credit; he will not let us have any more meat."
모모"That is quite right.
모모I do not digest meat well.
모모It is too heavy."
모모"What shall we have for dinner?"
모모"Bread."
모모"The baker demands a settlement, and says, `no money, no bread.'"
모모"That is well."
모모"What will you eat?"
모모"We have apples in the apple-room."
모모"But, Monsieur, we can't live like that without money."
모모"I have none."
모모The old woman went away, the old man remained alone.
모모He fell into thought.
모모Gavroche became thoughtful also.
모모It was almost dark.
모모The first result of Gavroche's meditation was, that instead of scaling the hedge, he crouched down under it.
모모The branches stood apart a little at the foot of the thicket.
모모"Come," exclaimed Gavroche mentally, "here's a nook!" and he curled up in it.
모모His back was almost in contact with Father Mabeuf's bench. He could hear the octogenarian breathe.
모모Then, by way of dinner, he tried to sleep.
모모It was a cat-nap, with one eye open.
모모While he dozed, Gavroche kept on the watch.
모모The twilight pallor of the sky blanched the earth, and the lane formed a livid line between two rows of dark bushes.
모모All at once, in this whitish band, two figures made their appearance. One was in front, the other some distance in the rear.
모모"There come two creatures," muttered Gavroche.
모모The first form seemed to be some elderly bourgeois, who was bent and thoughtful, dressed more than plainly, and who was walking slowly because of his age, and strolling about in the open evening air.
모모The second was straight, firm, slender.
모모It regulated its pace by that of the first; but in the voluntary slowness of its gait, suppleness and agility were discernible.
모모This figure had also something fierce and disquieting about it, the whole shape was that of what was then called an elegant; the hat was of good shape, the coat black, well cut, probably of fine cloth, and well fitted in at the waist.
모모The head was held erect with a sort of robust grace, and beneath the hat the pale profile of a young man could be made out in the dim light.
모모The profile had a rose in its mouth. This second form was well known to Gavroche; it was Montparnasse.
모모He could have told nothing about the other, except that he was a respectable old man.
모모Gavroche immediately began to take observations.
모모One of these two pedestrians evidently had a project connected with the other.
모모Gavroche was well placed to watch the course of events. The bedroom had turned into a hiding-place at a very opportune moment.
모모Montparnasse on the hunt at such an hour, in such a place, betokened something threatening.
모모Gavroche felt his gamin's heart moved with compassion for the old man.
모모What was he to do?
모모Interfere?
모모One weakness coming to the aid of another!
모모It would be merely a laughing matter for Montparnasse. Gavroche did not shut his eyes to the fact that the old man, in the first place, and the child in the second, would make but two mouthfuls for that redoubtable ruffian eighteen years of age.
모모While Gavroche was deliberating, the attack took place, abruptly and hideously.
모모The attack of the tiger on the wild ass, the attack of the spider on the fly.
모모Montparnasse suddenly tossed away his rose, bounded upon the old man, seized him by the collar, grasped and clung to him, and Gavroche with difficulty restrained a scream.
모모A moment later one of these men was underneath the other, groaning, struggling, with a knee of marble upon his breast.
모모Only, it was not just what Gavroche had expected. The one who lay on the earth was Montparnasse; the one who was on top was the old man.
모모All this took place a few paces distant from Gavroche.
모모The old man had received the shock, had returned it, and that in such a terrible fashion, that in a twinkling, the assailant and the assailed had exchanged roles.
모모"Here's a hearty veteran!" thought Gavroche.
모모He could not refrain from clapping his hands.
모모But it was applause wasted.
모모It did not reach the combatants, absorbed and deafened as they were, each by the other, as their breath mingled in the struggle.
모모Silence ensued.
모모Montparnasse ceased his struggles.
모모Gavroche indulged in this aside:
모모"Can he be dead!"
모모The goodman had not uttered a word, nor given vent to a cry. He rose to his feet, and Gavroche heard him say to Montparnasse:--
모모"Get up."
모모Montparnasse rose, but the goodman held him fast. Montparnasse's attitude was the humiliated and furious attitude of the wolf who has been caught by a sheep.
모모Gavroche looked on and listened, making an effort to reinforce his eyes with his ears.
모모He was enjoying himself immensely.
모모He was repaid for his conscientious anxiety in the character of a spectator.
모모He was able to catch on the wing a dialogue which borrowed from the darkness an indescribably tragic accent. The goodman questioned, Montparnasse replied.
모모"How old are you?"
모모"Nineteen."
모모"You are strong and healthy.
모모Why do you not work?"
모모"It bores me."
모모"What is your trade?"
모모"An idler."
모모"Speak seriously.
모모Can anything be done for you?
모모What would you like to be?"
모모"A thief."
모모A pause ensued.
모모The old man seemed absorbed in profound thought. He stood motionless, and did not relax his hold on Montparnasse.
모모Every moment the vigorous and agile young ruffian indulged in the twitchings of a wild beast caught in a snare.
모모He gave a jerk, tried a crook of the knee, twisted his limbs desperately, and made efforts to escape.
모모The old man did not appear to notice it, and held both his arms with one hand, with the sovereign indifference of absolute force.
모모The old man's revery lasted for some time, then, looking steadily at Montparnasse, he addressed to him in a gentle voice, in the midst of the darkness where they stood, a solemn harangue, of which Gavroche did not lose a single syllable:--
모모"My child, you are entering, through indolence, on one of the most laborious of lives.
모모Ah!
모모You declare yourself to be an idler! prepare to toil.
모모There is a certain formidable machine, have you seen it? It is the rolling-mill. You must be on your guard against it, it is crafty and ferocious; if it catches hold of the skirt of your coat, you will be drawn in bodily.
모모That machine is laziness. Stop while there is yet time, and save yourself!
모모Otherwise, it is all over with you; in a short time you will be among the gearing. Once entangled, hope for nothing more.
모모Toil, lazybones! there is no more repose for you!
모모The iron hand of implacable toil has seized you. You do not wish to earn your living, to have a task, to fulfil a duty! It bores you to be like other men?
모모Well!
모모You will be different. Labor is the law; he who rejects it will find ennui his torment. You do not wish to be a workingman, you will be a slave. Toil lets go of you on one side only to grasp you again on the other.
모모You do not desire to be its friend, you shall be its negro slave.
모모Ah!
모모You would have none of the honest weariness of men, you shall have the sweat of the damned.
모모Where others sing, you will rattle in your throat.
모모You will see afar off, from below, other men at work; it will seem to you that they are resting. The laborer, the harvester, the sailor, the blacksmith, will appear to you in glory like the blessed spirits in paradise.
모모What radiance surrounds the forge!
모모To guide the plough, to bind the sheaves, is joy.
모모The bark at liberty in the wind, what delight!
모모Do you, lazy idler, delve, drag on, roll, march!
모모Drag your halter. You are a beast of burden in the team of hell!
모모Ah!
모모To do nothing is your object.
모모Well, not a week, not a day, not an hour shall you have free from oppression.
모모You will be able to lift nothing without anguish.
모모Every minute that passes will make your muscles crack. What is a feather to others will be a rock to you.
모모The simplest things will become steep acclivities.
모모Life will become monstrous all about you.
